name: Brain Modulosignalin Homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in increased frequency of gross chromosomal rearrangements, lengthened chronological lifespan, decreased sensitivity to desiccation and increased innate thermotolerance; null mutant is sensitive to hyperosmotic stress and resistant to oxidative stress; overexpression leads to slow growth
function: Phosphoserine- and DNA replication origin-binding protein involved in many signaling pathways and processes including the DNA damage and spindle position checkpoints, signal transduction during filamentous growth, cell wall chitin biosynthesis, and aggresome assembly; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, and cytoplasmic stress granule

name: Brain Modulosignalin Homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in increased frequency of gross chromosomal rearrangements and lengthened chronological lifespan; null mutant is sensitive to selenite and resistant to selenomethionine; overexpression leads to slow growth and actin cytoskeleton abnormalities
function: Phosphoserine- and DNA replication origin-binding protein involved in Ras protein signal transduction and signal transduction during filamentous growth; involved in many processes including DNA replication initiation, DNA damage checkpoint, negative regulation of apoptosis, and cell wall chitin biosynthesis; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: S. pombe DIm1+ in Budding yeast
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional or reduction-of-function mutants show elevated chromosome instability, abnormal mitochondrial morphology and increased benomyl sensitivity
function: Subunit of the U4/U6 x U5 tri-small nuclear RNP (snRNP) complex involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing via spliceosome; localizes to U5 snRNP

name: COenzyme Q
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to respire and exhibits reduced chronological lifespan and sensitivity to linoleic acid; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, sensitivity to desiccation and heat, reduced biofilm formation, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: 2-hexaprenyl-6-methoxy-1,4-benzoquinone methyltransferase, converts 2-hexaprenyl-6-methoxy-1,4-benzoquinone to 2-hexaprenyl-3-methyl-6-methoxy-1,4-benzoquinone, the fifth step in ubiquinone (Coenzyme Q) biosynthesis; localized to mitochondrial matrix

name: D-Lactate Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased levels of lactate, fumarate and malate, but increased levels of 2-hydroxyglutarate, 2-oxoglutarate and succinate; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to hydrogen peroxide and show reduced growth rate
function: 2-hydroxyglutarate transhydrogenase that converts D-2-hydroxyglutarate to alpha-ketoglutarate with concomitant reduction of pyruvate to D-lactate; minor D-lactate dehydrogenase activity; overall contributes to lactate biosynthesis; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Transfer RNA Methyltransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to H2O2; trm7-A26P disease-analogous mutation causes reduced 2'-O-methylation of the anticodon loop of tRNA-Phe; in large-scale studies, the null mutant displays shorter chronological lifespan, decreased competitive fitness, poor growth on galactose, increased transposition of transposable elements, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: tRNA methyltransferase that catalyzes the posttranscriptional addition of methyl groups to specific residues in tRNA molecules; activity required for cytoplasmic translation

name: AROmatic amino acid requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutant is sensitive to ethanol and shows decreased competitive fitness

name: AROmatic amino acid requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness and decreased ability to utilize galactose as carbon source

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause ergosterol auxotrophy at permissive temperatures; depletion leads to abnormal mitochondrial morphology; reduction-of-function mutations result in increased sensitivity to benomyl, hydroxyurea and rapamycin; overexpression causes slow growth and increased resistance to doxorubicin

name: Biosynthesis of Nicotinic Acid
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for nicotinic acid and grows slowly; in systematic studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to His3p inhibitor amitrole and to calcium chelator BAPTA
function: 3-hydroxyanthranilic acid dioxygenase involved in de novo NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan; localizes to the cytoplasm
Component of the small subunit of the mitochondrial ribosome, which mediates translation in the mitochondrion; catalyzes the hydrolysis of 3-hydroxyisobutyryl-CoA

name: Temperature-sensitive Suppressors of Csg2 mutants
phenotype: Essential gene; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to dihydromotuporamine C; in large-scale studies, repression confers lower competitive fitness, sensitivity to HU and MMS, and resistance to myriocin; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to a human cationic antimicrobial peptide
function: 3-ketosphinganine reductase of the chemical reactions and pathways involving 3-keto-dihydrosphingosine; also involved in the formation of sphingolipids; localizes to lipid particles, endoplasmic reticulum, and outer membranes of mitochondria

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene under standard conditions; null mutant can grow when supplied with ergosterol; repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology and sensitivity to hydroxyurea; conditional mutation confers resistance to K28 killer toxin
function: 3-keto sterol reductase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum membrane and lipid bodies and to mitochondrial outer membrane in high-throughput studies

name: Genes de Respuesta a Estres (stress responsive genes)
SERine requiring
function: 3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase that catalyzes the first step in serine and glycine biosynthesis; 3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase that converts alpha-ketoglutarate to D-2-hydroxyglutarate; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: SERine requiring
function: 3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase that catalyzes the first step in serine and glycine biosynthesis; 3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase that converts alpha-ketoglutarate to D-2-hydroxyglutarate; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: 3-PhosphoGlycerate Kinase
phenotype: Essential gene under standard conditions; null mutant is unable to utilize glucose, galactose, or glycerol carbon sources but can grow on ethanol; overexpression confers increased growth rate; in large-scale studies, mutants exhibit chromosome instability and reduced starvation resistance
function: Phosphoglycerate kinase involved in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis; localizes to the plasma membrane, mitochondria, and cytoplasm

name: Folinic Acid Utilization
function: Methenyltetrahydrofolate synthetase involved in folic acid-containing compound biosynthesis; predicted to localize to cytoplasm, localizes to mitochondrion in high-throughput studies

name: MethylthioRibose-1-phosphate Isomerase
function: A S-methyl-5-thioribose-1-phosphate isomerase involved in the generation of L-methionine from methylthioadenosine; cellular process unknown

name: PhosphoRibosylpyrophosphate Synthetase
function: Subunit of a PRPP synthetase complex, which synthesizes 5-phosphoribose 1-diphosphate and is important for cell wall integrity

name: PhosphoRibosylpyrophosphate Synthetase
function: Subunit of a PRPP synthetase complex, which synthesizes 5-phosphoribose 1-diphosphate and is important for cell wall integrity

name: PhosphoRibosylpyrophosphate Synthetase
function: Subunit of a PRPP synthetase complex, which synthesizes 5-phosphoribose 1-diphosphate and is important for cell wall integrity

name: PhosphoRibosylpyrophosphate Synthetase
function: Subunit of a PRPP synthetase complex, which synthesizes 5-phosphoribose 1-diphosphate and is important for cell wall integrity

name: PhosphoRibosylpyrophosphate Synthetase
function: Subunit of a PRPP synthetase complex, which synthesizes 5-phosphoribose 1-diphosphate and is important for cell wall integrity

name: RADiation sensitive
phenotype: Essential gene; point mutations result in increased mitotic recombination, elevated mutation frequence, and increased UV sensititvity
function: ATP-dependent 5'-3' DNA helicase involved in transcription by polymerase II and positive regulation of mitotic recombination; contributes to DNA incision involved in nucleotide-excision repair, phosphorylation of RNA polymerase II C-terminal domain, regulation of RNA-mediated transposition; subunit of core TFIIH complex

name: RADiation sensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays sensitivity to agents affecting DNA metabolism such as 5-fluorouracil, MMS, and UV light; null mutant has elevated mutation frequency, decreased replicative lifespan, and abnormal nuclear morphology; in large-scale studies null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness, chronological lifespan, and filamentous growth, and is sensitive to heat, oxidative stress, metals, and various chemicals
function: 5-3 exonuclease and 5-flap endonuclease involved in base-free sugar phosphate removal as a part of base-excision repair, DNA repair synthesis during gene conversion at the mating-type locus, removal of RNA primers during DNA replication, maintenance of DNA trinucleotide repeats, and non-homologous end joining; also involved in replicative cell aging; localizes to the nucleus, mitochondrion, and cytosol

name: 6-phosphoGlucoNateDehydrogenase
function: Phosphogluconate dehydrogenase (decarboxylating); involved in the oxidative branch of the pentose phosphate pathway; localizes to the cytoplasm and mitochondrion in high-throughput studies

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations cause cell cycle arrest, abnormal cell morphology, aggregation of mitochondria, elongated spindles that fail to disassemble, sensitivity to cell wall-affecting drugs and oxidative stress; overexpression leads to slow growth
function: ATPase, a component of several multiprotein ATPase complexes involved in the release of polyubiquitinated proteins; part of the ER-associated ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation system, stress-induced homeostatically regulated protein degradation (SHRED) pathway; also plays a role in mitotic spindle disassembly, autophagy, ER membrane fusion, retrograde protein transport; localized throughout the cell

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are defective in protein secretion and show abnormal ER morphology; overexpression in Sigma127b reduces filamentous/invasive growth

name: Vacuolar Protein Sorting
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays defective trafficking of MVB cargo proteins, missorting cargo to the limiting vacuolar membrane and class E compartment rather than the vacuolar lumen; null mutant has decreased endocytosis, secretion defects and abnormal vacuolar morphology; null mutant also displays decreased acid pH resistance, decreased autophagy and starvation resistance while a gain-of-function mutant induces autophagy in rich medium; overexpression results in increased invasive filamentation while a null mutant is unable to undergo invasive growth; diploid null mutants have a severe sporulation defect
function: ATPase with homodimerization activity; involved in late endosome to vacuole transport via the multivesicular body sorting pathway, intralumenal vesicle formation, macroautophagy, sterol metabolism, and protein retention in the Golgi apparatus; localizes to the endosome and membrane

name: Bile Pigment Transporter
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for myo-inositol; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium, respiratory growth medium and synthetic oak exudate but increased fitness in synthetic complete medium; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus; null mutant has decreased resistance to lead treatment; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: ER eXport of Pma1
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: IsoLeucine-plus-Valine requiring
function: Acetolactate synthase; FAD binding protein involved in the biosynthesis of branched chain amino acids (isoleucine, valine and leucine); subunit of the acetolactate synthase complex; localizes to the mitochondrion in high-throughput studies

name: GRasp65 (Golgi reassembly stacking protein of 65kD) Homolog
ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; mutants require ergosterol; in large-scale studies, repression confers G2-phase cell cycle delay, increased chromosome instability, decreased competitive fitness, and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to hydroxyurea
function: Acetyl-CoA C-acetyltransferase that contributes to ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to cytoplasm

name: Acetyl-CoA Carboxylase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants accumulate poly(A) RNA in the nucleus; overexpression leads to increased lipid accumulation; reduction of function results in chromosome instability, decreased competitive fitness, heat sensitivity
function: Acetyl-CoA carboxylase involved in long-chain fatty acid biosynthesis; plays a role in protein import into nucleus; localizes in the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Acetyl CoA Synthetase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is capable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources, but incapable of fermentative growth on glucose as a carbon source
function: Acetyl-CoA ligase with roles in acetyl-CoA synthesis, histone acetylation and replicative cell aging; localizes to the nucleus and cytosol

name: ARGinine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutation results in arginine autotrophy; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in synthetic medium and is unable to use allantoin as nitrogen source; heterozygous diploid displays decreased starvation resistance; null has an endocytosis defect; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Acetylglutamate kinase and N-acetyl-gamma-glutamyl-phosphate reductase involved in arginine, ornithine biosynthesis and regulation of transcription; localized to the mitochondrial matrix

name: ARGinine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for arginine and is unable to use allantoin as nitrogen source; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in synthetic media but increased fitness in media containing glycerol or ethanol; null has decreased resistance to alpha-synuclein expression, and accumulates increased reactive oxygen species (ROS), while overexpression decreases the accumulation of ROS associated associated with alpha-synuclein expression; systematic null mutant has decreased telomere length and increased metal reductase activity
function: N-acetylglutamate synthase involved in arginine and ornithine biosynthesis; localized to the mitochondrial matrix

name: ARGinine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased biofilm formation, decreased resistance to flucytosine and smaller and smoother colonies when cells were grown on sucrose containing media
function: N-acetylornithine aminotransferase involved in arginine and ornithine biosynthesis; localized to the mitochondrial matrix

name: Decreased Ergosterol Transport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation changes temperature sensitivity and decreased accumulation of sterols; mutants in competitive growth experiments show decreased fitness and increased chronological lifespan

name: Acireductone DIoxygenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants show increased competitive fitness, have abnormal vacuolar morphology, are sensitive to UV and to desiccation; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Nickel-requiring acireductone dioxygenase involved in the regeneration of methionine from methylthioadenosine; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: ACOnitase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows glutamate auxotrophy, sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress, increased accumulation of iron in the mitochondria, loss of mitochondrial genome and deficiency in respiratory growth
function: Aconitate hydratase with role in tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle and mitochondrial genome maintenance; also shows DNA binding activity; localized to mitochondria and cytosol

name: ACTin
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants show pleiotropic defects including abnormal actin cytoskeleton, chromosome instability, altered subcellular morphology, increased sensitivity to heat, multiple chemicals and osmotic stress; overexpression leads to growth arrest
function: Structural constituent of the cytoskeleton; involved in cell polarity and actomyosin contractile ring assembly during cell division

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly and displays abnormal actin cytoskeleton morphology, decreased cytokinesis, defective endocytosis, sensitivity to osmotic stress, and random budding pattern
function: Actin-binding protein involved in actin filament organization and polymerization, actin nucleation, and actin cortical patch localization; also involved in positive regulation of actin filament bundle assembly and Arp2/3 complex-mediated actin nucleation; localized to actin cortical patches

name: Actin Binding Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormalities in actin cytoskeleton morphology, decreased endocytosis and blocked filamentous growth; in diploids, homozygous null mutant shows reduced sporulation efficiency; overexpression causes reduced growth rate; in systematc studies, null mutant is sensitive to caffeine, camptothecin, bleomycin and cycloheximide, but resistant to hygromycin B, spermine and tetramethylammonium
function: Actin-binding protein that activates actin nucleation mediated by the Arp2/Arp3 complex; required for the localization of protein kinases Ark1p and Prk1p and polyphosphatidylinositol phosphatase Inp52p to actin cortical patches; inhibits actin filament elongation at the barbed-end; localizes to actin cortical patches and in high-throughput studies to shmoo tips

name: Actin Interacting Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows defects in actin cytoskeleton and cytokinesis, and increased sensitivity to ethanol; in systematic studies null mutant is auxotrophic for inositol and displays defective endocytosis and sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress; overexpression in Sigma1278b leads to increased filamentous growth
function: Protein that binds actin filaments; positively regulates actin filament depolymerization and negatively regulates cytokinesis; localizes to actin filaments and cortical patches

name: Actin-Related Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has slightly disorganized actin filaments, and abnormal vacuolar morphology with a large vacuolar lobe surrounded by many smaller lobes; null mutant has an increased frequency of spontaneous interchromosomal heteroallelic recombination and an increased frequency of spontaneous and MMS-induced unequal sister chromatid recombination; null mutant has increased chronological lifespan under both nitrogen starvation and nitrogen-rich conditions; null mutant is desiccation sensitive; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient

name: Acyl-CoA-Binding
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows extended replicative lifespan under caloric restrictions; in large-scale surveys, null mutation causes increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss and decreased competitive fitness; null mutant shows greatly decreased filamentous growth and absent invasive growth in Sigma1278b

name: Acyl-coenzyme A: cholesterol acyl transferase-Related Enzyme
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced amounts of sterol esters; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness, increased resistance to selenomethionine and decreased endocytosis

name: Acyl-coenzyme A: cholesterol acyl transferase-Related Enzyme
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows abnormalities in cell wall, sensitivity to caffeine, and reduced sporulation efficiency in diploid; overexpression causes slow growth

name: Ethyl Ester Biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant contains reduced levels of medium-chain fatty acid ethyl esters; in large-scale studies null mutant has lower rate of anaerobic growth and is sensitive to oxidative stress, amitrole and cicloheximide; null mutant in Sigma1278b is incapable of invasive growth and shows decreased filamentous growth

name: acyl-protein Thioesterase with Multiple Localizations, protein of 25 kDa
Chromosome STability
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has lower phospholipid content and elevated contents of triglycerides and sterol esters; overexpression causes increased frequency of chromosome loss and altered chromosome stability; in systematic studies mutation reduces competitive fitness
function: Acyltransferase involved in remodeling of fatty acid acyl chains in one of the main phospholipids, phosphatidylinositol; localized to membranes and lipid droplets

name: Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase Related Open reading frame
STErile
function: Cytoplasmic SAM-domain-binding protein kinase regulator involved in osmosensory signalling, pheromone-dependent signal transduction, and mating

name: Adenine AminoHydrolase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a decreased growth rate, decreased competitive fitness in minimal media, decreased starvation resistance and increased cold sensitivity; null mutant has increased sensitivity to mutagenic purine base analogs, and displays decreased accumulation of hypoxanthine, inosine and IMP; overexpression results in an increase in the proportion of cells with a 1N DNA content, indicative of a G1 arrest or delay; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: An adenine deaminase involved in catabolism of adenine and salvage of hypoxanthine and purine-containing compounds

name: Adenine PhosphoribosylTransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to adenine analog 8-azaadenine; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness and sensitivity to hydroxyurea, MMS, DTT, flucytosine

name: Histidine triad NucleoTide-binding
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to cicloheximide and streptomycin, and shows decreased competitive fitness
function: Adenosine monophosphoramidase involved in nucleotide metabolism; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: ADenOsine kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased accumulation of glycogen and resistance to adenosine analog cordycepin; in systematic studies, null mutant shows reduced growth rate and lower competitive fitness, smaller peroxisomes, sensitivity to tunicamycin, caspofungin and myriocin, and increased resistance to hydroxyurea

name: ADenylate Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays slow growth and inability to utilize non-fermentable carbon sources (glycerol, lactate); also shows depleted pool of ADP and ATP, increased accumulation of ethanol and glycerol, inositol auxotrophy and delayed progression through G1 phase of the cell cycle
function: Adenylate kinase that transfers phosphate from ATP to AMP; involved in the initiation of DNA-dependent DNA replication; localizes to both the cytoplasm and mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: ADEnine requiring
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C; reduction-of-function mutations result in adenine auxotrophy
function: Adenylosuccinase involved in purine nucleotide and de novo inosine monophosphate (IMP) biosynthetic processes; cellular location is unknown

name: ADEnine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays adenine auxotrophy, forms red colonies, accumulates hypoxanthine and inosine, and is sensitive to purine analogs
function: Adenylosuccinate synthase involved in purine nucleotide biosynthesis; localized to the cytoplasm, also binds to the DNA replication origin

name: METhionine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays methionine auxotrophy, decreased endocytosis and reduced competitive fitness
function: ATP sulfurylase involved in sulfur amino acid metabolism and sulfate assimilation; localizes to cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: a-AGglutinin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced mating efficiency, elevated sensitivity to copper, and increased resistance to Calcofluor White
function: Cell adhesion protein involved in agglutination during mating; localizes to cell wall

name: Actin Binding Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant lacks 3-methylcytidine modification on tRNA-Thr and tRNA-Ser; overexpression decreases growth rate and competitive fitness in S288C but increases pseudohyphal growth in Sigma1278b

name: ADP-Ribosylation Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, decreased competitive fitness, are impaired in the use of arginine as a nitrogen source, sensitive to antimalarial mefloquine and the histone deacetylase inhibitor CG-1521, resistant to acetic acid; conditional mutants are sensitive to cold; overexpression slows vegetative growth in strain S288C, increases filamentous growth in strain Sigma1278b, arrests cell cycle progression at G2 or M phase in strain W303
function: GTPase that acts as ADP ribosylation factor (ARF); involved regulation of vesicle formation in ER to Golgi and Golgi to plasma membrane vesicular transport, and in macroautophagy; localizes in Golgi

name: ADP-Ribosylation Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is temperature sensitive for growth, is a myo-inositol auxotroph, and displays decreased competitive fitness and growth rate; null mutant has protein processing/trafficking defects, and displays decreased replicative and chronological lifespans, survival rate in stationary phase, mitophagy, desiccation resistance and shortened telomeres; overexpression results in a G2 or M phase delay
function: GTPase that acts as ADP ribosylation factor (ARF); involved regulation of vesicle formation in ER to Golgi and Golgi to plasma membrane vesicular transport, and in macroautophagy; localizes in Golgi

name: Arf Gap with Effector function(s)
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows sensitivity to cycloheximide, streptomycin and glyoxal; heterozygous null mutation in diploid causes chromosome instability
function: A GTPase activator that binds phospholipids; involved in ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport; localized to the endosome and trans-Golgi network

name: ArfGAP Effector
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, homozygous null mutant diploid shows inositol auxotrophy and sensitivity to bafilomycin and phleomycin; null mutants also show sensitivity to bleomycin, caffeine, cycloheximide, azoles, mycophenolic acid; null mutant has opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)
function: A GTPase activator that binds phospholipids; involved in ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants shows slow exponential growth, increased entry and survival in stationary phase, higher innate thermotolerance and longer replicative lifespan; null mutation decreases respiratory growth and increases resistance to cisplatin, myriocin and hydroxyurea, but lowers resistance to MMS and quinine; mutations affect sensitivity to hyperosmotic and oxidative stresses
function: Protein serine/threonine kinase involved in regulation of transcription by RNA polymerases I, II, and III; involved in regulation of sphingolipid biosynthesis, cell aging and responses to both oxidative and osmotic stresses; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm and vacuole membranes

name: ALanine Transaminase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates alanine and shows decreased growth rate in exponential phase; null mutant is defective in utilization of alanine as nitrogen source and accumulates reactive oxigen species; in systematic studies null mutants grow poorly under anaerobic growth conditions and are sensitive to amitrole, cycloheximide, neomycin, caspofungin, cordycepin, but resistant to myriocin

name: AcetylTransFerase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced production of acetate esters and sensitivity to plant-derived allylbenzene eugenol; in systematic studies null mutant shows reduced calcium accumulation, sensitivity to cycloheximide and increased competitive fitness

name: Alcohol DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant cells are large and show decreased fermentative growth rate, sensitivity to oxidative stress, antifungal drugs, and other chemicals
function: Alcohol dehydrogenase required for the reduction of acetaldehyde to ethanol during fermentation; also has methylglyoxal reductase activity, and is involved in NADH oxidation and the production of alcohol from amino acid breakdown via the Ehrlich pathway

name: Alcohol DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive and shows shortened chronological lifespan
function: NAD-dependent alcohol dehydrogenase that converts ethanol to acetylaldehyde; localizes to mitochodria

name: Alcohol DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to cycloheximide and streptomycin but resistant to nickel
function: NAD-dependent alcohol dehydrogenase that converts ethanol to acetylaldehyde
Aldehyde reductase with a role in detoxifying furfural

name: Genes de Respuesta a Estres (stress responsive genes)
function: Aldose reductase involved in the catabolism of galactose, arabinose, and D-xylose; involved in the cellular response to oxidative stress; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Stable Maintenance of pSRI
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression confers decreased competitive fitness and sensitivity to human TDP-43 protein; conditional mutant displays chromosome instability at semi-permissive temperature and accumulates less Rnr3p at the permissive temperature in the presence of MMS; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to hydrogen peroxide
function: Dolichyl-phosphate-mannose-glycolipid alpha-mannosyltransferase; involved in GPI anchor biosynthesis and plasmid maintenance; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum, integral to membrane in high-throughput studies

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to elevated temperatures and to cell wall-affecting drugs caffeine and Calcofluor White; null mutant also grows slowly

name: MaNnosidase-Like protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates glycogen; overexpression causes increased levels of Man7GlcNAc2 and decreased levels of Man8GlcNAc2
function: Mannosidase I with role in glycoprotein mannose trimming involved in glycoprotein ER-associated glycoprotein degradation pathway in the endoplasmic reticulum lumen

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has more than twice the wild-type levels of chitin, shows heat-sensitive respiratory growth, has elevated frequency of mitotic chromosome loss, and is sensitive to HU and nocodazole; in large-scale studies, the null mutant requires myo-inositol, displays rounded cell shape and decreased competitive fitness, and has altered sensitivity to a variety of chemicals
function: Alpha-1,3-glucosyltransferase that transfers glucose from dolichyl phosphate glucose (Dol-P-Glc) to lipid-linked oligosaccharide Man(9)GlcNAc(2)-PP-Dol; involved in synthesis of oligosaccharide precursor for N-linked protein glycosylation; localizes in endoplasmic reticulum

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers increased resistance to oxidative stress, Calcofluor White, Congo Red, and MMS; null mutant is sensitive to papulacandin B and tunicamycin; null mutant displays increased replicative lifespan, but the impact of caloric restriction is less than for wild type; in large-scale studies the null mutant shows altered sensitivity to a variety of chemicals and has enhanced competitive fitness
function: Alpha-1,6-mannosyltransferase that transfers a mannose residue to an oligosaccharide; involved in protein glycosylation and the assembly of dolichol-linked oligosaccharides; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Suppressor of Crl3 ts Lethality
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutation causes chromosome instability and sensitivity to bleomycin and HU; in large-scale studies, repression causes decreased competitive fitness; mutations cause sensitivity to K28 killer toxin and resistance to cycloheximide; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to calmidazolium and is haploinsufficient
function: Protein involved in proteasomal ubiquitin-dependent and independent protein degradation; subunit of proteasome core complex, alpha-subunit complex; localizes to mitochondrion in high-throughput studies

name: PUtative Proteasome subunit
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants are sensitive to bleomycin and hydroxyurea, and show chromosome instability
function: Subunit of 20S proteasome essential to pre-messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing; contributes to formation of catalytic spliceosome for second transesterification step

name: PRoteinase yscE
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants display chromosome instability, sensitivity to bleomycin and hydroxyurea; reduction of function leads to shortening of telomeres, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, and sensitivity to benomyl and MMS
function: Protein involved in proteasomal ubiquitin-independent and ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; localizes to alpha-subunit of proteasome core complex and proteasome storage granules

name: PRoteinase yscE
phenotype: Essential gene; in a large-scale study conditional mutant shows increased chromosomal instability; heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to elevated temperatures
function: Messenger RNA (mRNA) binding subunit of proteasome core complex, alpha-subunit complex involved in proteasomal ubiquitin-independent and ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; localizes to nuclear outer membrane-endoplasmic reticulum membrane network, proteasome storage granules, nucleus, cytoplasm

name: LYSine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires lysine for growth and is sensitive to acetic acid; lys2-402 mutant is able to utilize alpha-aminoadipate as nitrogen source; in large-scale studies null mutant displays altered resistance to various chemicals
function: L-aminoadipate-semialdehyde dehydrogenase involved in lysine biosynthesis; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Casein Kinase Alpha subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to cold and ionic stress, and shows lower transposition of Ty3 element; in systematic studies mutants display reduced competitive fitness and sensitivity to a variety of chemicals, including myriocin, geldanamycin, caffeine, cycloheximide, camptothecin, MMS, bleomycin, DMSO, tunicamycin

name: Casein Kinase Alpha' subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes ionic stress sensitivity, increases resistance to benomyl and extends replicative lifespan; in systematic studies mutants show increased sensitivity to a variety of chemicals, including Calcofluor White, Congo Red, wortmannin, geldanamycin, nigericin, rapamycin, caspofungin, fluconazole, tunicamycin
function: Protein serine/threonine kinase subunit of the protein kinase CK2 complex, also a subunit of the UTP-C subcomplex of 90S preribosome; involved in regulation of transcription by RNA polymerases I and III, chronological cell aging, and cellular responses to osmotic stress and DNA damage; found in nearly every subcellular compartment

name: LEUcine biosynthesis
function: Alpha-isopropylmalate synthase involved in leucine biosynthesis; catalyzes the conversion of 2-keto-isovalerate to 2-isopropylmalate; localizes to both the cytoplasm and mitochondria

name: LEUcine biosynthesis
function: Alpha-isopropylmalate synthase involved in leucine biosynthesis; catalyzes the conversion of 2-keto-isovalerate to 2-isopropylmalate; localizes to the mitochondria

name: COat Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to mislocalization of multiple protein reporters; overexpression causes slow growth

name: Fatty Acid Synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant is rescuable by fatty acid supplement; conditional mutations cause increased heat sensitivity; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Subunit of cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase, contributes acyl-carrier, beta-ketoacyl reductase, beta-ketoacyl synthase and self-pantetheinylation activities; involved in long-chain fatty acid biosynthesis

name: PhosphoFructoKinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction of function prevents growth under anaerobic conditions; null mutant is blocked in glycolysis and shows decreased rate of both respiratory and fermentative growth, increased resistance to caffeine and oxidative stress, lower survival in stationary phase and competitive fitness
function: Subunit of the 6-phosphofructokinase complex; contributes to the ATP-dependent phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate to form fructose 1,6-bisphosphate; involved in glycolysis, proton transport and regulation of intracellular pH; localizes to the cytosol, the mitochondrion and the vacuolar membrane by colocalizing with the V-ATPase

name: CAPping
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive, and displays decreased competitive fitness on both fermentative and respiratory growth media; null mutant has abnormally large and round cells; null mutant displays a random budding pattern and an inability to properly localize bud-site selection proteins Bud8p and Rax2p to the growing bud tip; null mutant has an endocytosis defect; null mutant displays decreased nitrogen starvation-induced autophagy; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased growth rate on rich medium, a severe respiratory growth defect, a decreased ability to utilize various nitrogen sources, decreased competitive fitness on a variety of media and decreased starvation resistance; null mutant has a reduced cell size; null mutant displays a reduced survival rate in stationary phase and decreased glycogen accumulation; null mutant has a reduced chronological lifespan (CLS), while gain-of-function mutants have increased CLS; null mutant has an elevated dietary restriction-induced replicative lifespan extension; null mutant has decreased resistance to acid and alkaline pH, desiccation and innate thermotolerance
function: Subunit of the catalytic core of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane; Atp1p is also found in association with mitochondrial nucleoids

name: OligoSaccharylTransferase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause defects in protein glycosylation and secretion, slow growth, increased flocculation; overexpression leads to slow growth
function: Oligosaccharide transferase involved in protein N-linked glycosylation via asparagine; localizes to oligosaccharyltransferase complex and to endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies

name: General Control Nonderepressible
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased sensitivity to numerous drugs, decreased thermotolerance and reduced competitive fitness; homozygous diploid is auxotrophic for inositol; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Translation initiation factor that contributes to the exchange of guanyl nucleotides associated with GTPases; localizes to translation initiation factor 2B complex

name: Blocked Early in Transport
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression causes abnormalities in cell cycle progression and cell morphology; conditional (ts) mutants show increased chromosome instability

name: TUBulin
phenotype: Essential gene; heterozygous diploid null mutants are haploinsufficient and sensitive to heat, TOR inhibitor rapamycin, and actin polymerization inhibitor latrunculin A; conditional mutants have abnormal spindles at cold temperatures; overexpression interferes with the cell cycle and slows growth
function: Tubulin complex subunit; involved in homologous chromosome segregation, mitotic sister chromatid segregation, and microtubule-mediated transport of the nucleus

name: ALpha tubulin Folding
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to microtubule-binding drugs benomyl and nocodazole and displays slow growth and sensitivity to freezing and thawing; in systematic studies null mutants are also sensitive to caffeine, paromomycin, DTT, DMSO, tunicamycin, rapamycin, but resistant to wortmannin, and show decreased competitive fitness; null mutant forms large cells and abnormally elongated buds
function: A microtubule and alpha-tubulin binding protein involved in post-chaperonin tubulin folding
Protein phosphatase that localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Branched-chain Amino acid Permease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness in minimal media; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate

name: Tyrosine and tryptophan Amino acid Transporter
para-AminoBenZoic acid (PABA) biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutant shows auxotrophies for para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and folic acid, and sensitivity to sulfanilamide; also shows reduced endocytosis and extended hibernating lifespan

name: HEMe biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene on standard rich medium due to heme auxotrophy; mutants lack ergosterol; in large-scale studies, repressing expression confers increased competitive fitness; heterozygous null diploid shows haploinsufficiency
function: Porphobilinogen synthase involved in the biosynthesis of heme; catalyzes the asymmetric condensation and cyclization of two 5-aminolevulinate molecules into porphobilinogen; localizes to both the nucleus and the cytoplasm

name: AminoPEptidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a small defect in vacuolar morphology in the presence of salt; null mutant has decreased resistance to the expression of alpha-synuclein, and to rapamycin treatment; overexpression results in decreased vegetative growth

name: Drs2 Neo1 Family
function: Subunit of the Lem3p-Dnf1p aminophospholipid translocase (flippase); involved in phospholipid translocation, contributing to endocytosis, protein transport, and cellular polarization; localizes primarily to the plasma membrane; localizes to the shmoo tip in pheromone-treated cells where where it has a redundant role in the cellular response to mating pheromone

name: Drs2 Neo1 Family
function: Aminophospholipid translocase (flippase); involved in phospholipid translocation, contributing to endocytosis, protein transport, and cellular polarization; localizes primarily to the plasma membrane; localizes to the shmoo tip in pheromone-treated cells where it has a redundant role in the cellular response to mating pheromone

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes increased biofilm formation and polyphosphate accumulation; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Ammonium transmembrane transporter involved in ammonium transport and nitrogen utilization; putatively localized to plasma membrane and to endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies

Transmembrane ammonium transporter; involved in the directed transport of ammonium across cell membranes facilitating nitrogen utilization; integral membrane protein that localizes to the plasma membrane and to the endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies

name: Sucrose NonFermenting
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutants are defective in glucose-dependent regulation of transcription, with pleiotropic effects on carbon source utilization, respiratory growth, cell wall structure, thermotolerance, hyperosmotic stress and starvation sensitivity, autophagy, peroxisome biogenesis, filamentous growth, sporulation in diploids
function: AMP-activated serine/threonine kinase subunit of the AMP-activated protein kinase complex; also serves as guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) specific for Arf3p in response to glucose depletion; regulates both pseudohyphal and filamentous growth in response to starvation and carbohydrate metabolic process; inhibits translation of GCN4; involved in mitotic spindle alignment along the mother-bud axis

name: AMP Deaminase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive and has a decreased growth rate on rich media and decreased competitive fitness on both rich and synthetic complete media; null mutant displays a delay in acceleration of budding after a glucose pulse; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus and increased resistance to zinc deficiency; null mutant has increased ability to form biofilms and a semi-smooth colony morphology; null mutant displays decreased resistance to compounds that alter DNA precursor pools

name: Reduced Viability on Starvation
function: Cytoskeletal protein; forms a complex with Rvs167p and is involved in actin cytoskeleton reorganization and endocytosis; localizes to the actin cortical patch

name: AnKyrin Repeat-containing protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; overexpression leads to increased resistance to phytosphingosine; null mutant shows increased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to cycloheximide and mycophenolic acid, and increased resistance to fenpropimorph; in a large-scale survey overexpression causes slow growth

name: TRyPtophan
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes tryptophan auxotrophy and increased resistance to toxic analog 5-fluoroanthranilic acid; in systematic studies null mutant shows reduced growth rate and competitive fitness, and sensitivity to alkaline pH, oxidative stress and multiple chemicals, including azole drugs and MMS
function: Anthranilate synthase involved in tryptophan biosynthesis; catalyzes the the conversion of chorismate to anthranilate; subunit of the anthranilate synthase complex

name: AP4A phosphorylase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has shorter chronological lifespan and decreased anaerobic growth; also shows fragmented vacuoles and increased resistance to myriocin; in large-scale studies null mutants show sensitivity to MMS, amitrole and cycloheximide, and reduced thermotolerance

name: fdp1 Suppressor
function: Glycerol channel involved in transport of glycerol, arsenite, acetate, and polyols; also involved in mating and the response to arsenic; localizes to the plasma membrane

name: ADP-Ribosylation factor-Like
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant mislocalizes Golgi protein Arl1p to cytoplasm; null mutant has fragmented vacuoles and shows increased sensitivity to protein glycosylation inhibitor, tunicamycin, and cell wall-affecting dye, Congo Red

name: Catabolism of ARginine
function: Manganese- and zinc binding arginase involved in ornithine biosynthesis; inhibits ornithine carbamoyltranserase; localizes to cytosol, nucleus and shmoo tip

name: Arginine/alanine AminoPeptidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness in minimal medium and in conditions like those in Phase I of batch fermentation; null mutant has increased resistance to the antifungal agent miconazole; null mutant displays decreased resistance to Benzo[a]pyrene, a carcinogen
function: Aminopeptidase involved in gylcogen metabolism and proteolysis; localizes to both cytoplasm and nucleus

name: ARGinine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for arginine and displays decreased accumulation of arginine; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in synthetic medium and is unable to use allantoin as nitrogen source; homozygous diploid null displays decreased resistance to zinc deficiency; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient
function: Ornithine carbamoyltransferase involved in arginine biosynthesis; localized to the cytosol

name: ARGinine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for arginine and displays decreased accumulation of arginine and increased ornithine accumulation; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in synthetic medium and is unable to use allantoin as nitrogen source; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus; null mutant has decreased resistance to copper sulfate; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Argininosuccinate synthase involved in arginine biosynthesis; localized to the cytosol
Mitochondrial arginyl-tRNA synthetase that performs arginyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling arginine to arginyl-tRNA

name: AROmatic amino acid requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to utilize aromatic amino acids as nitrogen source and shows decreased competitive fitness

name: AROmatic amino acid requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth, sensitivity to paromomycin and decreased ability to utilize glutamine as nitrogen source

name: ASparagiNe requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; simultaneous mutations in ASN1 and its paralog ASN2 confer asparagine auxotropy; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased cadmium accumulation

name: ASparagiNe requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; simultaneous mutations in ASN2 and its paralog ASN1 confer asparagine auxotropy; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased sensitivity to starvation

name: HOMoserine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes auxotrophy for methionine, threonine and homoserine; activation leads to excretion of threonine
function: Aspartate kinase involved in the biosynthesis of methionine, threonine, and homoserine

name: YaPSin
function: Aspartic protease; involved in nutrient limitation-induced cleavage of the signaling mucin Msb2p, resulting in filamentous growth MAPK pathway activation; involved with Kex2p in processing of the alpha factor precursor; role in the cell wall integrity response; GPI-anchored component of the plasma membrane

name: BARrier to the alpha factor response
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a decreased rate of growth on rich media but increased competitive fitness on non-fermentable carbon sources; null mutant has increased pheromone sensitivity, abnormally elongated buds, and has decreased resistance to hyperosmotic stress; overexpression results in a decreased rate of growth and increased pseudohyphal growth
function: Aspartyl protease; involved in the catabolism of the alpha factor peptide during adaptation to pheromone during conjugation with cellular fusion; localizes to the extracellular region, the cell wall and to the cell periphery in high-throughput studies
Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase that performs aspartyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling aspartate to aspartyl-tRNA; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a severe respiratory growth defect, decreased rate of vegetative growth, decreased utilization of various carbon and nitrogen sources; null mutant has a reduced cell size, displays decreased resistance to heat, manganese, freeze-thaw and oxidative stress; null mutant is petite-negative, displays decreased mitophagy, decreased chronological lifespan, decreased glycogen accumulation, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, and elevated rates of mini-chromosome loss
function: Protein with a role in assembly of the mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase complex; binds to the Atp1p subunit during assembly; localized to mitochondria

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; base-substitution mutants have a G2 delay at permissive temperature, a G1 block at elevated temperatures, and are resistant to cycloheximide; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness; overexpression confers resistance to rapamycin
function: Cytoplasmic protein required for the assembly of translation initiation factor complex, eIF2; regulates translational initiation; proposed to bind ATP-Mg2+ base on structural similarity with the fission yeast ortholog

name: INOsitol requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows inositol auxotrophy, defects in chromosome segregation, decreased growth rate, and inability to utilize ethanol as a carbon source
function: Subunit of Ino80 complex, ATPase that contributes to ATP-dependent 3'-5' DNA helicase involved in chromatin remodeling and silencing at telomeres, has a role in transcription from polymerase II promoters

name: Stress Seventy subfamily E
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation leads to increased loss of [PSI+], [URE3] and [SWI+] prions, reduced growth rate, and elevated sensitivity to hydroxyurea, cycloheximide and hygromycin B; in systematic studies null mutants show abnormally elongated buds, increased frequency of mitotic chromosome loss and elevated sensitivity to azoles, DMSO, myriocin, spermine; overexpression increases resistance to rapamycin
function: Peptide and ATP-binding adenyl-nucleotide exchange factor involved in protein folding and refolding; associates with polysomes

name: Stress-Seventy subfamily A
phenotype: Non-essential gene; both null and dominant negative mutants have an increased accumulation of prions; overexpression results in larger aggregates in fewer numbers; heterozygous diploid mutant had decreased fitness
function: ATPase subunit of the chaperonin-containing T-complex (CCT, TriC); involved in protein folding, nuclear import, stress granule disassembly, and clathrin coat disassembly; localizes to many places in the cell, including the cell wall, vacuolar and plasma membranes, and the nucleus

name: KARyogamy
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to defects in nuclear fusion during mating; overexpression causes slow growth; in systematic studies reduction-of-function mutations increase sensitivity to hydroxyurea and MMS, and increase resistance to myriocin
function: ATPase subunit of the lumial surveillance complex that is involved in a number of processes, including translocation of proteins to membranes, the ubiquitin-dependent ERAD pathway, and beta-glucan biosynthesis; localized to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Regulatory Particle Triple-A protein, or Regulatory Particle Triphosphatase
phenotype: Essential gene; point mutation confers enhanced vegetative growth; rpt3-K219R mutation causes shorter replicative lifespan; in large-scale studies, repression causes sensitivity to HU and shorter telomere length; diploid heterozygous null mutant exhibits reduced competitive fitness and is sensitive to trapoxin A and 3-nitroso-2-phenylimidazo[1,2-a]pyridine
function: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly; role in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation, positive regulation of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of proteasome regulatory particle, base subcomplex

name: Regulatory Particle Triple-A protein, or Regulatory Particle Triphosphatase
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations cause resistance to tunicamycin, sensitivity to heat, cycloheximide, and cadmium ions, slow growth, and accumulation of proteasome substrates; in large-scale studies, repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology and an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient and displays enlarged cell size and sensitivity to trapoxin A and 3-nitroso-2-phenylimidazo[1,2-a]pyridine
function: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly; role in ubiquitin-dependent ERAD pathway, nucleotide-excision repair, positive regulation of RNA polymerase II elongation and transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of proteasome regulatory particle, base subcomplex; localizes to nucleus

name: Regulatory Particle Triple-A protein, or Regulatory Particle Triphosphatase
phenotype: Essential gene; cim3-1 ts allele causes arrest with large buds and accumulation of proteasomal substrates at the restrictive temperature; rpt6-K195R mutation in ATPase active site causes decreased replicative lifespan; in large-scale studies, repression confers reduced competitive fitness and chromosome instability, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly; contributes to proteasome-mediated ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation, nonfunctional ribosomal RNA (rRNA) decay; role in nucleotide-excision repair, chromatin repair; also involved in positive regulation of transcription elongation from RNA polymerase II promoter and negative regulation of DNA binding transcription factor activity; subunit of proteasome regulatory particle, base subcomplex; localizes to proteasome storage granule and nucleus

name: Regulatory Particle Triple-A protein, or Regulatory Particle Triphosphatase
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations in the ATPase active site cause sensitivity to heat and canavanine, shorter replicative lifespan, slow growth, and increased budding index; in large-scale studies, repression causes reduced competitive fitness, sensitivity to MMS, resistance to myriocin, and shorter telomere length; diploid heterozygous null mutant exhibits enlarged cell size and haploinsufficiency
function: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly, ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation and positive regulation of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of base complex of proteasome regulatory particle

name: Regulatory Particle Triple-A protein, or Regulatory Particle Triphosphatase
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations cause slow growth, shorter replicative lifespan, increased budding index, and sensitivity to canavanine and cadmium dichloride; in large-scale studies, repression causes decreased competitive fitness, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, and an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient and sensitive to dequalinium, and has enlarged cells
function: Proteasome-activating ATPase involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; has role in nonfunctional ribosomal RNA (rRNA) decay, proteasome regulatory particle assembly, protein complex localization; subunit of proteasome regulatory particle base subcomplex and localizes to nucleus

name: Regulatory Particle Triple-A protein, or Regulatory Particle Triphosphatase
phenotype: Essential gene; cim5-1 ts allele causes arrest with large buds at restrictive temperature, accumulation of degradation intermediates, and increased resistance to 4-NQO; rpt1-K256S mutation causes shorter replicative lifespan, sensitivity to canavanine, and decreased budding index; in large-scale studies, repression causes decreased competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly, ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation and positive regulation of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of 19S regulatory particle

name: ATP-binding cassette protein involved in Ribosome Biogenesis
phenotype: Null mutants are inviable under standard aerobic conditions, viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness
function: ATPase involved in export of small ribosomal subunits from the nucleus and ribosome biogenesis; localizes in nucleus

name: ATPase Family Gene
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to defects in nuclear export and accumulation of large ribosomal subunits in the nucleus; repression also results in opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)

name: Dead Box Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to depletion of mature 18S rRNA and accumulation of 35S pre-rRNA and aberrant rRNA processing intermediates; both dominant negative mutation and overexpression lead to slow vegetative growth

name: COenzyme Q
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null and point mutants are unable to respire, fail to accumulate ubiquinones, and exhibit sensitivity to linoleic acid; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits decreased biofilm formation, increased sulfur accumulation, increased innate thermotolerance, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: ATPase and lipid binding protein, capable of autophosphorylation but not phosphorylation in trans; involved in ubiquinone biosynthesis; localizes to the matrix face of the inner mitochondrial membrane

name: Imitation SWitch subfamily
function: Subunit of the Isw1a and Isw1b complexes; contributes to the ATPase activity, DNA-binding activity, and nucleosome-binding activity of the complexes; also binds to rDNA and transcription regulatory regions; involved in chromatin remodeling and regulation of chromatin organization, nucleosome density, and histone exchange; involved in transcription elongation, regulation of transcriptional start site selection at RNA pol II promoters, positive regulation of transcription from RNA pol II promoters, and termination of RNA pol I and II transcription

name: tRNA CCA-pyrophosphorylase
phenotype: Essential gene; base-substitution mutants grow slowly and are sensitive to heat
function: Nucleotidyltransferase that adds 3'-CCA termini to tRNA molecules; localized in nucleus, cytoplasm and mitochondrial matrix

name: Mrna TRansport
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion leads to accumulation of unprocessed RNA precursors in the nucleus; reduction-of-function mutations cause increased sensitivity to benomyl and nocodazole
function: ATP-dependent 3'-5' RNA helicase involved in exonucleolytic trimming of tricistronic pre-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA) to generate mature 3'-ends of 5.8S transcripts; role in non-coding RNA (ncRNA) polyadenylation, nuclear poly(A)-dependent RNA degradation; contributes to poly(A)-dependent small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA), U4 small nuclear RNA (snRNA), U5 snRNA 3'-end processing; subunit of TRAMP complex

name: Defines Essential Domain
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional alleles confer cold sensitivity and slow growth even at permissive temperature; in a large-scale study, mutant exhibits MMS sensitivity
function: Bifunctional enzyme with both RNA strand-annealing and ATP-dependent RNA helicase activities; involved in translation initiation and spliceosomal complex disassembly; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, and cytoplasmic stress granule

name: RuVB-like
function: ATP dependent DNA helicase subunit of the nuclear Ino80 complex involved in chromatin remodeling, snoRNP assembly and regulation of transcription from RNA Pol II

name: RuVB-like
function: ATP dependent DNA helicase subunit of the nuclear Ino80 complex involved in chromatin remodeling, snoRNP assembly and regulation of transcription from RNA Pol II

name: Helicase Associated with Set1
function: An ATP-dependent RNA helicase involved in the maturation of SSU- and LSU-rRNA; subunit of box C/D and box H/ACA snoRNP complexes

name: Dead Box Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers slow vegetative growth; in a systematic study, null mutant scored as inviable in strain S288C, possibly due to slow growth
function: ATP-dependent RNA helicase involved in messenger ribonucleoprotein (mRNP) complex assembly, rRNA processing, and mRNA decay; localizes to the nucleus

name: Nuclear Accommodation of Mitochondria
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays abnormal localization of proteins and RNAs to P-bodies, increased resistance to copper, and decreased Ty element transposition; in large-scale studies null mutant shows increased resistance to a variety of chemicals, as well as increased sensitivity to some chemicals
function: ATP-dependent RNA helicase and ATPase that is involved in non-sense mediated mRNA decay, translation termination, protein ubiquitination; localizes to the polyribosomes

name: AuTophaGy related
function: Protein involved in autophagic degradation of the endoplasmic reticulum in response to nitrogen starvation; binds to Atg8p during autophagy; localized to the cortical ER

name: Centromere Binding Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly, has abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired fitness, cannot utilize allantoin as a nitrogen source, shows decreased Ty1 mobility, is sensitive to various antibiotics, auxotrophic for methionine, heat-resistant, and accumulates glycogen; overexpression causes abnormal nuclear morphology, accumulation of cells with 2C DNA content, increased percentage of large-budded cells, and increases resistance to TOR inhibitor rapamycin
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription activator and repressor; subunit of the Cbf1-Met4-Met28 complex; activates transcription of genes involved in inositol biosynthetic process and sulfate assimilation and represses transcription of genes involved in ceramide biosynthetic process; localized to the mitochondrion in high-throughput studies

name: Yeast AP-1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant show increased mutation frequency, decreased lifespan, decreased ethanol tolerance, decreased resistance to dessication, alkaline pH, resveratrol, oxidizing and reducing agents, carcinogens, antifungals, alkylating agents, metals, DNA metabolism inhibitors, protein and sterol synthesis inhibitors, and TOR inhibitor rapamycin; overexpression increases filamentous growth in Sigma1278b, interferes with cell cycle progression in S288C, and confers resistance to many of the aforementioned chemicals
function: Sequence-specific DNA-binding transcription factor involved in the regulation of transcription in response to various stresses and cellular insults; shuttles between nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Homologous to Atf/Creb1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have decreased ethanol tolerance, are extremely sensitive to glycosylation inhibitor tunicamycin, show increased [PSI+] prion formation, are sensitive to Huntingtin, heat, zinc deficiency, and are auxotrophic for inositols; overexpression interferes with cell cycle progression and cytoskeleton morphology; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in regulation of the unfolded protein response; also negatively regulates transcription during meiosis

name: Chromosome STability
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is slow-growing and cold-sensitive, also displays increased sensitivity to oxidative stress and ethanol, but increased resistance to benomyl; overexpression results in elevated mitotic recombination; in systematic studies mutants exhibit reduced competitive fitness
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in the cellular responses to carbon dioxide and oleic acid

name: Glycophospholipid-Anchored Surface protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers cell wall defects, decreased growth rate, abnormal vacuolar morphology and pheromone sensitivity; null mutatnt is incapable of filamentous growth
function: 1,3-beta-glucanosyltransferase, catalyzes splitting and linking of (1->3)-beta-D-glucan molecules that leads to elongation of (1->3)-beta-D-glucan chains; involved in cell wall organization, also has a role in chromatin silencing; localized to cell wall, nuclear periphery and throughout secretory pathway

name: clathrin Adaptor Protein complex Large chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows defects in vacuolar protein transport, increased accumulation of polyphospahates and increased excretion of inositol; null mutant also shows increased sensitivity to caffeine and caspofungin, but increased resistance to fenpropimorph, mycophenolic acid, rapamycin and tunicamycin
function: Subunit of the AP-3 adaptor complex that functions in golgi to vacuole transport

name: PUtative Proteasome subunit
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression has negative impact on chromosome stability; in Sigma1278b overexpression enhances pseudohyphal invasive growth
function: Endopeptidase activator involved in ubiquitin-independent and ubiquitin-dependent proteasome-mediated protein degradation; beta-type subunit of 20S proteasome

name: PRoteinase yscE
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause accumulation of ubiquitin conjugates and lead to elevated sensitivity to bleomycin and hydroxyurea, increased resistance to cicloheximide, and inability to sporulate in diploids; in large-scale studies repressible or conditional mutations result in cell cycle arrest at the G2 phase, increased chromosomal instability and defects in cytokinesis
function: Endopeptidase activator involved in proteasomal ubiquitin-independent and ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum membrane, nucleus, proteasome storage granules

name: clathrin Adaptor Protein complex Large chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness; in diploid homozygous null mutation increases frequency of mitotic chromosome loss
function: Subunit of the AP-2 adaptor complex that functions in vesicle mediated transport

name: clathrin Adaptor Protein complex Large chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in vacuolar protein transport and shows strong vacuolar fragmentation; null mutant is also sensitive to Congo Red, arsenite, mefloquine, monensin A and rapamycin
function: Subunit of the AP-1 adaptor complex that binds clathrin and functions in vesicle  mediated transport

name: LEUcine biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires leucine for growth and is sensitive to acetic acid; overexpression confers increased acetic acid resistance
function: Beta-isopropylmalate dehydrogenase involved in leucine biosynthesis and the glyoxylate cycle; catalyzes the conversion of beta-isopropylmalate to alpha-ketoisocaproate; localizes to the cytosol

name: Increased Recombination Centers
function: Cysteine-S-conjugate beta-lyase involved in sulfur metabolism and L-cysteine catabolism

name: Casein Kinase Beta subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to ionic stress, also shows increased sensitivity to rapamycin and nicotinamide, and accumulates triglycerides; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to multiple chemicals, including caffeine, MMS, DMSO, doxorubicin, dieldrin, chlorpromazine, fenpropimorph, paromomycin

name: Casein Kinase Beta' subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers decreased resistance to ionic stress and rapamycin; in systematic studies mutants show decreased competitive fitness and increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including doxorubicin, dieldrin, chlorpromazine, fenpropimorph, and others; mutants also show opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline) and accumulate altered levels of free amino acids; overproduction in diploid Sigma1278b cells increases invasive growth

name: Carboxy-Terminal domain Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays elevated frequency of chromosome loss and abnormally elongated buds; in systematic studies null mutation confers increased sensitivity to oxidative stress and several drugs, including hygromycin B and caspofungin; null mutants also have slow growth rate and increased cell size
function: Subunit of the C-terminal Domain Kinase I (CTDK-I) complex that acts as a positive transcription elongation regulator; localized to the nucleus

name: Fatty Acid Synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant is rescuable by fatty acid supplement; heterozygous diploid accumulates very long-chain fatty acids
function: Subunit of cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase, contributes acetyltransacylase, dehydratase, enoyl reductase, malonyl transacylase, and palmitoyl transacylase activities; required for long-chain fatty acid biosynthesis

name: PhosphoFructoKinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction of function prevents growth under anaerobic conditions; null mutant is blocked in glycolysis and shows decreased rate of both respiratory and fermentative growth, increased heat sensitivity, lower survival in stationary phase and decreased competitive fitness
function: Subunit of 6-phosphofructokinase complex involved in glycolysis; localizes in mitochondria

name: CAPping
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive, has a large cell size, and decreased competitive fitness in both rich and minimal media; null mutant has an increased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss; null mutant has severe short-chain alcohol and hydroxyurea-induced filamentous growth defects and an inability to undergo pseudohypal growth upon nitrogen starvation; null mutant has an endocytosis defect and decreased hyperosmotic stress resistance; null mutant has a nuclear migration defect; null mutant displays abnormal localization of both actin and chitin

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene, but heterozygous diploid shows haploinsufficiency; null mutant is temperature sensitive, petite-negative, has a decreased rate of survival in stationary phase, a glycogen accumulation defect, decreased starvation resistance, a respiratory growth defect and decreased resistance to desiccation and oxidative stress; null mutant has a competitive fitness defect in various media and abnormal mitochondrial and vacuolar morphologies
function: Subunit of the catalytic core of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Wheat germ agglutinin-Binding Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutant displays under-glycosylation of carboxypeptidase Y at the permissive temperature and increased apoptosis at restrictive temperature; mutant is sensitive to hygromycin B; in large-scale studies, repression confers decreased competitive fitness, increased frequency of chromosomal rearrangements and loss, and sensitivity to MMS
function: Protein subunit of oligosaccharyltransferase complex that transfers lipid-linked oligosaccharide precursor to asparagine residues on nascent proteins; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum membrane and nuclear envelope

name: General Control Derepressed
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are defective in autophagy and in Golgi localization of reporter proteins; haploproficient but sensitive to starvation and oxidative stress
function: Enzyme regulator subunit of eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2B complex and guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor complex; involved in regulation of translational initiation; localizes to mitochondrion and cytosol in high-throughput studies

name: Blocked Early in Transport
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are impaired in protein transport; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, are sensitive to DNA-damaging agent hydroxyurea (HU); heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Subunit of Rab-protein geranylgeranyltransferase complex which attaches geranylgeranyl moiety to proteins; required for vesicle-mediated transport between ER and Golgi; the complex localizes in cytoplasm

name: TUBulin
phenotype: Essential gene; heterozygous diploid null mutants have unstable chromosomes and are sensitive to cancer drugs; some conditional mutants are resistant to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl but senstive to heat, and undergo cell-cycle arrest as large-budded cells; overexpression interferes with mitotis and slows growth in some strain backgrouds, is lethal in others; cells heterozygous for a reduced function allele analogous to human mutation associated with congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles (CFEOM) are sensitive to benomyl
function: Tubulin complex subunit; involved in homologous chromosome segregation, mitotic sister chromatid segregation, and microtubule-mediated transport of the nucleus

name: AROmatic amino acid requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to 2-phenylethanol, shows auxotrophy for phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan and sensitivity to cadmium; null mutant shows no mitophagy; in large-scale studies null mutants show decreased fermentative growth, increased sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress and to multiple chemicals, including MMS, acetic acid, cycloheximide, hydroxyurea, ethanol, bleomycin, azoles, colistin, cordycepin, streptomycin, tunicamycin

name: 1-AcyldihYdroxyacetone-phosphate Reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decrease in both vegetative and respiratory growth rate; null mutant fails to germinate after sporulation; null mutant contains elongated buds; null mutant displays a defect in delivery of the cell surface marker, Fus-Mid-GFP, with late Golgi accumulation; null mutant has decreased resistance to hyperosmotic stress; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression results in growth arrest

function: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and short chain ester hydrolase; localizes to the cytoplasm and lipid particles in different large-scale studies

name: Biotin:apoProtein Ligase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat, and are subject to chromosome instability; base-substitution mutants are potentially viable and may be isolated as long-chain-fatty-acid-requiring auxotrophs; overexpression slows growth
function: Biotin ligase involved in protein biotinylation, covalent attachment of biotin moiety to target proteins; localized to cytoplasm and nucleus

name: BIOtin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for biotin, and has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium; null mutant accumulates alpha-amino acids; null mutant has elevated metal reductase activity

name: METhionine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays methionine auxotrophy and sensitivity to ionic stress; null mutation in homozygous diploid decreases sporulation and increases sensitivity to hygromycin B and Calcofluor White but increases resistance to caffeine, benomyl and oxidative stress
function: DPNDase involved in sulfate assimilation; contributes to methionine biosynthesis and salt tolerance; cellular location is unknown

name: BORon transporter
