phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased resistance to boric acid, and increased accumulation of boron, while overexpression results in increased boric acid resistance and decreased accumulation of boron; null mutant displays increased vacuolar fragmentation; null mutant displays altered free amino acid profiles including altered levels of alpha amino acids, decreased levels of asparagine and histidine, and increased levels of glutamate; null mutant displays a decreased ability to utilize galactose as carbon source and both arginine and glutamate as nitrogen sources; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus
function: Transmembrane, plasma membrane localized boron efflux transporter; involved in vacuolar protein trafficking

name: Acyltransferase for Lyso-phosphatidylEthanolamine
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant lacks membrane-bound O-acyltransferase activity and shows decreased competitive fitness
function: An 1-acylglycerol-3-phosphate O-acyltransferase involved in glyerophospholipid biosythesis; localized to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: CycLin B
phenotype: Non-essential gene; overexpression leads to slow growth and increased percentage of cells arrested at G2 phase of the cell cycle; in systematic studies mutants show increased sensitivity to Calcofluor White, MMS, cycloheximide, fenpropimorph, fluconazole, tunicamycin
function: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of the G2/M phase transition of the mitotic cell cycle; regulates mitotic spindle assembly and spindle pole body separation; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: CycLin B
phenotype: Non-essential gene; cells overexpressing an N-terminally truncated allele arrest in M phase of the cell cycle; in systematic studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to cycloheximide, fenpropimorph, fluconazole, caffeine; homozygous diploids reveal inositol auxotrophy and elevated mitotic chromosome loss
function: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of the G2/M phase transition of both the mitotic cell cycle and first meiotic division; involved in mitotic spindle assembly and spindle pole body separation; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: CycLin B
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth, abnormal budding pattern, delayed progression through the M phase of the cell cycle and increased cell size; overexpression leads to delayed G2/M transition and abnormal nuclear morphology
function: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of the G2/M phase transition of the mitotic cell cycle; regulates mitotic spindle elongation and spindle pole body separation; localizes to various cellular compartments including the nucleus, the spindle pole bodies, the mitotic spindle, and the bud neck

name: Rox Three Suppressor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to elevated temperatures and accumulates glycogen and glutathione; in systematic studies null mutants show slow growth, lower competitive fitness, decreased chronological lifespan and increased sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress, bleomycin, cycloheximide, MMS, hygromycin B, ethanol, fluconazole, but increased resistance to tunicamycin, mycophenolic acid, acetic acid
function: Protein phosphatase regulator involved in protein dephosphorylation, mitotic spindle orientation checkpoint, and septin ring organization and disassembly; also involved in sister chromatid biorientation, meiotic sister chromatid cohesion at centromeres, and establishment of protein localization to chromosome; localizes to the nucleus, kinetochore, spindle pole body, bud neck, and centromeric regions of chromosomes

name: General Control Nonderepressible
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have decreased ethanol tolerance, abnormal vacuolar morphology, and cannot utilize galactose; null also has increased lifespan, decreased competitive fitness and biofilm formation, G1 checkpoint deficiency, and is sensitive to a wide variety of different chemicals; overexpression stunts growth
function: Transcription factor with a role in positive regulation of the assembly of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex and the negative regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter; localizes to the nucleus

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene under aerobic condition, non-essential gene under anaerobic conditions; mutants are sensitive to multiple chemicals, including 6-azauracil, mycophenolic acid, fenpropimorph, Calcofluor White, hygromycin B, cisplatin, cycloheximide, doxorubicin, rapamycin, miconazole, ethanol, and show decreased respiratory growth

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal lipid particles and displays decreased replicative lifespan, increased resistance to nystatin and cycloheximide; in systematic studies null mutant is sensitive to multiple chemicals, including benomyl, nocodazole, hydroxyurea, echinocandin, rapamycin, fluconazole, Congo Red

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal lipid particles, decreased shmoo formation and mating efficiency, and shows sensitivity to brefeldin A, Calcofluor White, cycloheximide, echinocandin B, mycophenolic acid and papulacandin B; in systematic studies null mutants display decreased biofilm formation, reduced endocytosis, defective sporulation in diploids, increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals and reduced competitive fitness

name: BUD site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates ribosomal protein reporters in the nucleus; in large-scale surveys, null mutant diploids display aberrant random budding pattern, delayed G1 phase progression, abnormal cell shape and size; also display inositol auxotrophy, increased innate thermotolerance and decreased growth rate

name: PEroXin
function: Ubiquitin-protein ligase subunit of the peroxisomal importomer complex involved in the import of proteins into the peroxisomal matrix

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression confers S phase cell cycle delay, increased spontaneous DNA damage, and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to ascomycin
function: C-3 sterol dehydrogenase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene under standard conditions; null mutant can grow when supplied with ergosterol, and accumulates C-4,4-dimethylsterol; repression causes vacuolar fragmentation; in large-scale studies, repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology; mutant displays decreased competitive fitness; heterozygous null mutant diploid displays chromosome instability and sensitivity to azalomycin B
function: C-4 methylsterol oxidase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to plasma membrane and endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to synthesize ergosterol and cannot grow on nonfermentable carbon sources; null mutant exhibits increased resistance to azole antifungal drugs and decreased resistance to various other drugs; null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in a large-scale study
function: C-5 sterol desaturase, catalyzes formation of C-5(6) double bond in episterol that yields 5,7,24(28)-ergostatrienol in third to last step of ergosterol biosynthesis pathway; integral to endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays shortened replicative lifespan and sensitivity to metals, benomyl, and tacrolimus; conditional mutant shows reduced endocytosis; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays slower fermentative and respiratory growth, shorter telomeres, auxotrophy for myo-inositol, decreased resistance to osmotic stress, lower competitive fitness, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: C-8 sterol isomerase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies

name: MetaCAspase
function: Calcium-dependent cysteine-type endopeptidase; involved in apoptosis and the degradation of misfolded or incompletely synthesized proteins; localizes to the nucleus and cytosol

name: CalciNeurin A
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates increased amounts of calcium and shows increased resistance to cyclosporin A

name: CalModulin binding Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation has negative effect on recovery from pheromone-induced cell cycle arrest; overexpression shortens replicative lifespan; in systematic studies null mutants show elevated sensitivity to caffeine, azoles, tunicamycin, hydroxyurea, cycloheximide, camptothecin, bleomycin and rapamycin

name: CalciNeurin subunit B
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates increased amounts of calcium but shows increased sensitivity to higher concentrations of lithium and calcium; in systematic studies mutants show inositol auxotrophy, increased sensitivity to a variety of chemicals, including DTT, tunicamycin, caffeine, cycloheximide, increased resistance to MMS and mycophenolic acid; null mutant is also sensitive to osmotic and oxidative stress and shows reduced competitive fitness

name: Gcr1 Dependent Translation factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased sensitivity to calcium and decreased competitive fitness; haploinsufficient; homozygous diploid shows decreased rate of respiratory growth
function: Calcium and manganese ion transmembrane transporter involved in calcium and manganese ion transmembrane transport; contributes to cellular calcium and manganese ion homeostasis and Golgi calcium homeostasis; localizes to vacuoles, the cis-Golgi network and Golgi medial cisternae

name: CalMoDulin
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations affect processes that depend on actin cytoskeleton, including budding, nuclear position and spindle pole body position; in diploids, conditional (ts) mutations lead to increased chromosome loss under permissive temperature and cell cycle arrest at G2/M phase transition under restrictive temperature; in systematic studies reduction-of-function mutations confer sensitivity to benomyl, myriocin and MMS

name: Reduced Viability on Starvation
function: Cytoskeletal protein; forms a complex with Rvs161p and is involved in actin cytoskeleton reorganization and endocytosis; localizes to the actin cortical patch

name: CalModulin dependent protein Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in competitive growth studies null mutant shows decreased fitness and reduced starvation resistance

name: CalModulin dependent protein Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates increased amounts of free amino acids in a systematic study and shows slightly increased competitive fitness

name: CalNExin and calreticulin homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness, is auxotrophic for myo-inositol, displays increased chitin deposition and increased activation of the cell wall integrity (CWI) pathway

name: Takashi's Protein Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation lowers competitive fitness and increases senitivity to desiccation; overexpression leads to abnormalities in actin cytoskeleton and blocks autophagy
function: cAMP-dependent protein kinase involved in signaling; localizes to both nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Takashi's Protein Kinase
function: cAMP-dependent protein kinase involved in signaling and organization of mitochondria; localizes to both nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Takashi's Protein Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation decreases filamentous growth and prevents invasive growth in Sigma1278b; overexpression causes slow growth and abnormalities in actin cytoskeleton and nuclear morphology; in systematic studies null mutation results in vacuolar fragmentation
function: cAMP-dependent protein kinase involved in signaling and invasive growth in response to glucose limitation; localizes to both nucleus and cytosol

name: Suppressor of RasVal19
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits slow growth, an abnormal actin cytoskeleton, and reduced localization of proteins to the bud tip; in large-scale studies, null mutant fails to respire or to mate, has abnormally large cells with elongated buds and abnormal lipid particle morphology, is sensitive to hyperosmotic and oxidative stress, and is resistant to K28 killer toxin and to manganese; conditional mutant exhibits chromosome instability at semi-permissive temperature; overexpression in the Sigma1278b genetic background causes greatly increased filamentous growth; null mutant exhibits filamentous growth in response to HU treatment; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to starvation and heat; null mutant is sensitive to a variety of chemicals
function: Adenylate cyclase-binding protein involved in Ras protein signal transduction and actin filament organization; localizes to actin cortical patches

name: NonClassical Export
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly under aerobic conditions but shows normal growth rate under elevated CO2 concentration; overexpression in Sigma1278b causes increased filamentous growth
function: Carbonate dehydratase involved in responses to oxidative stress and carbon dioxide; localizes to mitochondrial envelope lumen and to nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: CaRDiolipin synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays fragmented mitochondria, increased sensitivity to heat and antifungal drugs (caspofungin, azoles), and shows reduced respiratory growth rate
function: Cardiolipin synthase; responsible for biosynthesis of cardiolipin, which is required for normal mitochondrial function

name: clathrin Adaptor Protein complex Medium chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays abnormal, random budding pattern and decreased sensitivity to mating pheromone; null mutants are also sensitive to cell wall perturbing drugs, such as Congo Red or caffeine, and to fluconazole, cycloheximide, tunicamycin
function: Subunit of the AP-2 adaptor complex that functions in vesicle mediated transport

name: ALanine Transaminase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness, shortened chronological lifespan and abnormal accumulation of polyphosphates

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Essential gene; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to rapamycin and to DNA-damaging agents methyl methanesulfonate (MMS) and hydroxyurea (HU); heterozygous diploid nulls have small cells
function: An N-acetylglucosaminyldiphosphodolichol N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase that is a component of the UDP-N-acetylglucosamine transferase complex; involved in the dolichol-linked oligosaccharide biosynthetic process; localizes to the extrinsic component of endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: Anaphase Promoting Complex
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show cell cycle arrest at G2/M phase transition, abnormal spindle morphology, chromosome instability and sensitivity to hydroxyurea
function: Ubiquitin transferase that is a component of the anaphase-promoting complex involved in degradation of mitotic cyclins and transition from metaphase to anaphase during mitotic cell cycle

name: FK506 Sensitivity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes abnormal cell wall morphology and confers sensitivity to cell-wall affecting drugs and FK506
function: Catalytic subunit of the 1,3-beta-D-glucan synthase complex; involved in beta-glucan biosynthesis, regulation of cell size, and positive regulation of endocytosis; localizes to the plasma membrane, cellular bud tip and neck, and actin cortical patch

name: Glucan Synthase of Cerevisiae
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, defects in sporulation, and decreased fitness, ethanol tolerance, and thermotolerance; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient; overexpression slows growth
function: Catalytic subunit of 1,3-beta-D-glucan synthase complex involved in beta-glucan biosynthesis and spore wall assembly; localizes to prospore membranes

name: General Control Nonderepressible
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have increased lifespan, flocculate more readily, cannot utilize glutamine or maltose, have abnormal spindles and buds, decreased ethanol tolerance, are defective in endocytosis, are sensitive to heat, metals, nucleotide analogs, TOR inhibitor rapamycin and various antibiotics, and are auxotrophic for myo-inositol; overexpression slows vegetative growth, increases lifespan, enhances invasive growth
function: Subunit of SAGA, ADA, and SLIK histone acetyltransferase complexes involved ih chromatin modification and transcription regulation

name: mRNA DeCaPping
phenotype: Gene reported to be essential in some strain backgrounds and non-essential in others; null mutant displays increased apoptosis; point mutation confers stabilization of mRNAs encoding ribosomal proteins; in large-scale studies, conditional mutant shows chromosome instability at the semi-permissive temperature; heterozygous null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and starvation resistance
function: m7G(5')pppN diphosphatase that binds chromatin and mRNA; involved in deadenylation-dependent and deadenylation-independent decapping of nuclear-transcribed mRNA; also involved in stress granule assembly and positive regulation of transcription initiation from RNA polymerase II promoters; colocalizes with cytoplasmic mRNA processing bodies during the response to stress and localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, and cytoplasmic side of membranes

name: Yeast Mitochondrial Escape
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to respire and has abnormal globular mitochondria; null mutant becomes inviable upon loss of the mitochondrial genome; null mutant displays slow growth at reduced temperatures, decreased chronological lifespan, and resistance to bortezomib; in large-scale studies, the null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness in a variety of media, sensitivity to desiccation and heat, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: ATP-dependent peptidase of the inner mitochondrial membrane; subunit of the i-AAA complex involved in mitochondrial protein turnover; also involved in protein import, folding and maturation

name: Histone AcetylTransferase
function: A H4 histone acetyltransferase; silences chromatin at telomeres with Hht1p and Hht2p; subunit of histone acetyltransferase complex

name: STErile
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant confers sterility, and an inability to undergo cell cycle arrest, and form shmoos in the presence of pheromone; null mutant has a reduced growth rate, and temperature sensitivity; homozygous diploid null mutant buds in a unipolar rather than bipolar pattern and are rounder than wild-type, indicative of bud site selection and apical growth defects; null mutant is sensitive to hyperosmotic stress, metal and desiccation stress
function: MAP kinase kinase kinase kinase involved in vacuole inheritance, pheromone signaling, osmosensory signaling, filamentous and psudohyphal growth, bud site selection, stress granule assembly, regulation of mitotic exit, and regulation of apoptosis; localizes to the nucleus, incipient bud sites, and shmoo tip

name: Factor ARrest
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to arrest the cell cycle upon mating pheromone exposure; reduced expression causes smaller cell size while overexpression causes increased cell size; null mutant is defective for shmoo formation and mating; in large-scale studies the null mutant has altered resistance to a variety of chemicals, and overexpression is lethal
function: Serine/threonine cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor; required for G1 arrest in response to treatment with pheromone and for pheromone dependent signal transduction during conjugation; sequesters the guanine-nucleotide exchange factor Cdc24p in the nucleus; localizes to the nucleus, the cytosol, and the mating projection or shmoo tip

name: DNA-damage UNinducible
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays elevated chromosomal instability, gross chromosomal rearrangements, increased loss of heterozygosity and decreased telomere length; null mutant is also sensitive to agents that damage DNA and/or invoke replication stress such as: hydroxyurea, MMS, UV, idarubicin and aminopterin; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness during growth in various media; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Protein serine/threonine kinase involved in replication fork protection and the DNA damage checkpoint; localized to the nucleus in high-throughput studies

name: Topoisomerase I Damage Affected
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the vacuole

name: TIp1-Related
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall

name: Covalently linked Cell Wall protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes abnormalities in bud and mating projection (shmoo) morphology, increased chitin deposition in cell wall, higher sensitivity to hypoosmotic stress and to cell wall-affecting chemicals (Congo Red, Calcofluor White); both null mutation and overexpression result in slow growth
function: Structural constituent of cell wall; involved in agglutination during conjugation and fungal cell wall organization; localizes to the bud tip and mating projection tip

name: Cell Wall Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has thinner cell wall and shows increased sensitivity to acidic conditions; in systematic studies mutants exhibit elevated sensitivity to copper ions and quinine, and increased ability to form biofilms
function: A structural constituent of the cell wall involved in both fungal-type cell wall organization and ascospore-type prospore membrane assembly; localized in the cell wall, cellular birth scar, and prospore membrane

name: PEroXisome related
function: Subunit of the peroxisomal import machinery involved in the docking of proteins in the peroxisomal matrix

name: Chromosome SEgregation
phenotype: Essential gene; downregulation of expression causes abnormal chromosome segregation; conditional mutants display reduced levels of centromere-localized proteins at the restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, overexpression causes decreased growth rate; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding protein that interacts with centromeres and the centromere-like sequence of the 2 micron circle; involved in kinetochore assembly, sister chromatid segregation, and 2-micron circle partitioning; localizes to the centromere-specific nucleosome, the centromeric region, the kinetochore and the circular 2 micron plasmid DNA

name: Suppressor of Initiation of Transcription
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has fermentative and respiratory growth defects, increased heat sensitivity, abnormally elongated buds, extended chronological lifespan, decreased telomere length, and increased multidrug and toxin sensitivity; null mutants have semi-smooth colony morphology, altered mitochondrial morphology, a vacuolar fragmentation defect, decreased lipid droplet size, content and quantity and are sensitive to hyperosmotic stress; conditional mutant has an actin depolarization defect, is resistant to oxidants, and contains elevated levels of glutathione
function: Protein serine/threonine phosphatase involved in signal transduction, TOR signaling, and G1/S transition of the mitotic cell cycle; involved in DNA repair, replicative cell aging, tRNA wobble uridine modification, and organization of the actin cytoskeleton and cell wall; subunit of the protein phosphatase type 2A complex; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Longevity Assurance Gene
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates free sphingoid long-chain bases and has abnormally aggregated mitochondria; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Sphingosine N-acyltransferase subunit of the acyl-CoA ceramide synthase complex, involved in ceramide biosynthesis and replicative cell aging

name: Longevity-Assurance gene Cognate (LAG1 Cognate)
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates free sphingoid long-chain bases and shows sensitivity to myriocin
function: Sphingosine N-acyltransferase subunit of acyl-CoA ceramide synthase complex involved in replicative cell aging and ceramide biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum and in high-throughput studies localizes with nuclear periphery, is putatively integral to membrane

name: Small nucleolar RNAs of the box H/ACA family Quantitative accumulation
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes accumulation of 35 S pre-rRNA and an aberrant 23S rRNA processing intermediate, with reduced levels of 18S rRA and box H/ACA snoRNAs; in large-scale studies, repression confers reduced competitive fitness; mutation causes resistance to cycloheximide; overexpression in a diploid strain of the Sigma1278b background causes enhanced pseudohyphal growth
function: Protein that binds unfolded proteins and is involved in box H/ACA small nucleolar RNP (snoRNP) assembly; localizes to nucleus, nucleoplasm, cytoplasm

name: PETite colonies
function: Protein involved in assembly of cytochrome c oxidase; integral component of mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Anti-Prion DnaJ
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to drugs that exacerbate cell wall defects, such as caffeine and Calcofluor White, also sensitive to cyclohexomide and rapamycin; overexpression results in increased loss of [SWI+] prion

name: CHitin Synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant cells produce buds that frequently undergo lysis; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to gentamycin C1, valinomycin, arsenite, cycloheximide, quinine, and show decreased competitive fitness
function: Chitin synthase found in chitosomes and plasma membrane; involved in cell separation after cytokinesis;

name: CHitin Synthase
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutations lead to defects in septum formation and abnormal cytokinesis; overexpression also results in disrupted cytokinesis that leads to extensive formation of cell chains and clumps
function: Chitin synthase involved in chitin biosynthetic process and actomyosin contractile ring contraction; localizes to the cellular bud neck

name: CHitin Synthase-related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays phenotypes associated with cell wall defects, including resistance to Calcofluor White and killer toxin, sensitivity to caffeine, and abnormal wall morphology; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows sensitivity to various chemicals and an enhanced ability to form biofilms
function: Chitin synthase involved in cell wall chitin biosynthesis; also required for spore wall assembly; localizes to bud necks, incipient bud sites, and prospore membranes

name: Congo Red Hypersensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; overexpression increases resistance to azole drugs and to benomyl; in systematic studies null mutation confers sensitivity to cell wall-affecting compound Congo Red
function: Glucosyltransferase that cross-links chitin to beta(1-6) and beta(1-3) glucans in the cell wall; involved in cell wall organization; localized to sites of cell wall growth, such as incipient buds

name: Choline KInase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to utilize exogenous choline, shows decreased competitive fitness and increased sensitivity to hygromycin B; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to ethanol, MMS, rapamycin, and resistant to hydroxyurea, caffeine, cycloheximide, fluconazole, tunicamycin

name: CholinePhosphoTransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies mutants show increased biofilm formation and elevated competitive fitness
function: Diacylglycerol cholinephosphotransferase, in the final step of CDP-choline (Kennedy) pathway transfers choline from CDP-choline to 1,2-diacylglycerol to form phosphatidylcholine; involved in phospholipid biosynthesis; localized to membranes of mitochondrion, ER, and Golgi

name: AROmatic amino acid requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for phenylalanine and sensitive to 2-phenylethanol; in systematic studies null murants show decreased fermentative growth rate and increased sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress and to multiple chemicals, including Congo Red, ethanol, eugenol, flucytosine, hygromycin B, MMS, myriocin, selenomethionine and spermine; null mutant also shows reduced competitive fitness

name: High MObility group (HMG) family
function: Chromatin-associated DNA binding protein that compacts, bends, bridges and loops dsDNA; involved in regulating transcription from RNA polymerase I promoters and start site selection from RNA pol II promoters; localizes to the nucleus and relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia

name: Binder of USO1 and GRH1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has defects in sorting of protein reporters through Golgi; in systematic studies null mutants are incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermenrable carbon sources, show elevated starvation-induced mitophagy and increased resistance to several chemicals, including tunicamycin, camptothecin, fenpropimorph, cycloheximide, hydroxyurea, mycophenolic acid

name: Suppressor of Erd2 Deletion
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutant fails to sort Atg9p from mitochondria to preautophagosomes at the restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology and sensitivity to myriocin; overexpression causes a G2 or M cell cycle arrest or delay; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: SNARE receptor subunit of SNARE complex that is involved in endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi and intra-Golgi vesicle transport; contributes to vesicle fusion with Golgi apparatus; localizes to cis-Golgi network and is integral to membrane

name: CITrate synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased ability to utilize lactate and acetate carbon sources and is sensitive to rapamycin; in large-scale studies the null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness and chronological lifespan, and sensitivity to various chemicals
function: Citrate synthase involved in citrate metabolism, the tricarboxylic acid cycle, and acetyl-CoA catabolism; localizes to the mitochondrion

name: CITrate synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased ability to utilize nonfermentable carbon sources such as glycerol, ethanol, and lactate; in large-scale studies the null mutant shows decreased thermotolerance, and sensitivity to a fragment of human Huntingtin; overexpression in a diploid confers increased pseudohyphal growth
function: Citrate synthase involved in the glyoxylate cycle; catalyzes the formation of citrate from acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate; localizes to both the cytoplasm and peroxisomes

name: Doa4-Independent Degradation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to elevated temperatures and has an increased replicative lifespan; reduction of function mutation causes mislocalization of vacuolar transport reporters; mutants in systematic studies show increased sensitivity to factors that cause ER stress, such as mercaptoethanol, DTT, tunicamycin, or cell wall stress, such as Calcofluor White, Congo Red

name: Doa4-Independent Degradation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits heat sensitivity, sensitivity to caffeine, Congo Red, and other chemicals, and defects in vacuolar protein targeting; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in several different media, sensitivity to heat shock, desiccation, and osmotic stress, poor utilization of various nitrogen sources, and altered resistance to many chemicals

name: Increased Recombination Centers
function: Protein that functions in vesicle-mediated transport by linking the AP-1 clathrin adaptor complex with the Rab GTPase Ypt31p

name: UBiquitin regulatory X
function: Clathrin-binding protein with a role in endocytosis; localizes to clathrin-coated vesicles; copurifies with the Dsc ubiquitin ligase complex; mutation affects histone ubiquitination

name: Clathrin Heavy Chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has multiple defects in endocytosis, protein secretion and distribution, and shows increased sensitivity to ionic stress, rapamycin, monesin and caffeine; null mutation causes abnormal vacuole morphology and large increase in random budding pattern in diploid
function: Structural heavy chain protein component of clathrin vesicle coats; required for  endocytosis and golgi-to-endosome transport

name: Clathrin Light Chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to cadmium and nickel ions; in systematic studies null mutans show decreased competitive fitness, decreased growth rate, inability to grow under respiratory growth conditions and increased sensitivity to both acidic and alkaline pH; also show increased sensitivity to a variety of chemicals, including azoles, cyclosporin A, caffeine, hydroxyurea, tunicamycin, DTT
function: Structural light chain protein component of clathrin vesicle coats; required for proper trimerization of clathrin heavy chains; positively regulates endocytosis; localizes to trans-Golgi network

name: Interacts with Fork Head
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression slows growth, interferes with silencing, and increases production of ribosomal protein mRNAs; reduced function alleles increase lifespan, hamper growth and rRNA processing, reduce resistance to DNA damaging agents and TOR inhibitor rapamycin; heterozygous diploids are haploinsufficient
function: Transcription regulator involved in the positive regulation of ribosomal protein gene transcription and also telomeric silencing; subunit of CURI complex

name: METhionine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is a methionine auxotroph that exhibits reduced competitive fitness in synthetic media, and is unable to grow using allantoin as a nitrogen source; overexpression results in a decreased rate of vegetative growth
function: Methionine synthase; catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to L-methionine during methionine biosynthesis; localizes to the cytoplasm and plasma membrane in high-throughput studies

name: HomoLogous to E. coli dnaJ protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to some drugs (fluconazole, bleomycin, camptothecin, tunicamycin) and resistant to others (fenpropimorph, cicloheximide)
function: ATPase activator involved in ER-associated ubiquitin-dependent pathway; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum

name: Suppressor of G2 (Two) allele of skp1
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutations cause G1 arrest and chromosome missegregation at the restrictive temperature; mutations cause sensitivity to benomyl and stabilization of Sic1p; in large-scale studies, repression causes decreased competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to geldanamycin and radicicol
function: Co-chaperone involved in cAMP-mediated signaling; contributes to kinetochore assembly; localizes with ubiquitin ligase complex

name: increased Sensitivity to Benzoquinone Ansamycins
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits shorter telomeres and chromosome loss; in large-scale studies, null mutation causes sensitivity to radicicol, decreased filamentous growth, and increased competitive fitness in minimal medium but decreased fitness in synthetic oak exudate medium; overexpression causes chromosome instability; diploid heterozygous nuill mutant is haploinsufficient and sensitive to starvation
function: Chaperone-binding protein involved in protein folding, positive regulation of telomere maintenance via telomerase, negative regulation of DNA binding, and regulation of telomerase activity; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Activator of Heat shock protein 90 ATPase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has increased temperature sensitivity, and has a strong respiratory growth defect; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness on minimal medium; null mutant has a strong vacuolar fragmentation defect; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient

name: COenzyme Q
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is deficient in respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and has high frequency of nonfunctional mitochondrial genome (rho- mutations); in systematic studies mutants have lower competitive fitness and higher sensitivity to arsenite and high concentrations of ethanol, also show decreased rate of utilization of galactose and urea or proline as carbon and nitrogen sources, respectively

name: COFilin
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations lead to accumulation of actin filament aggregates after shift to restrictive temperature, accompanied by defects in protein secretion, endocytosis, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, and increased sensitivity to benomyl, myriocin, MMS; overexpression slows down vegetative growth due to a delay in G2 or M phase of the cell cycle
function: Actin filament-binding protein that localizes to actin cortical patches; involved in  the organization, depolymerization and severing of actin filaments; also involved in endocytosis and transport of proteins from the Golgi to the plasma membrane

name: Complexed With Cef1p
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased innate thermotolerance and increased sensitivity to calcium chelator BAPTA and His3p inhibitor amitrole
function: Protein whose biological function is unknown; localized to U2-type spliceosomal complex

name: Switch INdependent
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have abnormal vacuolar morphology, decreased ethanol tolerance, short telomeres, short lifespan, large cell size, are impaired in respiratory growth and endocytosis, and are sensitive to caffeine, heat, various antibiotics; homozygous diploid nulls are defective in sporulation
function: Transcription cofactor subunit of the Rpd3L, Rpd3S, and Sin3-type histone deacetylase complexes (HDACs); regulates chromatin silencing, transcription by RNA polymerases I and II, DNA replication, meiosis, heat response, and the G2/M transition of the mitotic cell cycle; also involved in DNA repair

name: Actin-Related Protein
phenotype: Essential/non-essential gene in S288C; null mutant has been reported to be either viable, and slow growing or inviable in S288C; null mutant is viable and extremely slow growing in W303; S288C-derived viable null is unable to grow on media containing glycerol, sucrose, or galactose as the sole carbon source; conditional mutant displays elevated chromosomal instability, including increased gross chromosomal rearrangements; heterozygous null mutant is heat sensitive
function: Subunit of both the RSC and SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation

name: Actin-Related Protein
phenotype: Essential/non-essential gene in S288C; null mutant has been reported to be either viable, and slow growing or inviable in S288C; null mutant is viable and extremely slow growing in W303; S288C-derived viable null is unable to grow on media containing glycerol or sucrose as the sole carbon source and exhibits slow growth on galactose; repressible mutant displays abnormal mitochondrial morphology and increased chromosomal rearrangements and chromosome loss; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Subunit of both the RSC and SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation

name: Regulator of Ty1 Transposition
function: Subunit of both the RSC and SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation; also involved in maintaining chromosome transmission fidelity

name: METhionine requiring
function: A protein involved in the transfer of iron-sulfur clusters to other proteins; involved in DNA metabolic processes and localizes to the cytosol

name: Cytosolic Iron-sulfur protein Assembly
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutant displays signs of chromosome instability and has longer telomeres; overexpression increases mutation frequencies

name: Cytosolic Iron-sulfur protein Assembly
phenotype: Essential gene; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness, grow slowly, are sensitive to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl; conditional mutants grow very slowly at elevated temperatures; heterozygous diploid nulls show increased growth rate
function: Protein whose molecular function is unknown; acts as a component of cytosolic iron-sulfur protein assembly (CIA) machinery; localized to cytosol and nucleus

name: Pab1p-Binding Protein
function: mRNA binding protein; functions as a negative regulator of mRNA polyadenylation, and as a positive regulator of HO translation; involved in stress granule assembly and the maintenance of rDNA; localizes to the polysome, and the cytoplasmic stress granule

name: Kex2-cleavable protein Essential for Inositol phosphorylceramide synthesis
BreFeldin A Resistance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows delayed progression through anaphase and increased frequency of polyploids; in systematic studies null mutants show decreased competitive fitness and shortened chronological lifespan; null mutants accumulate increased amounts of free amino acids

name: Cytoplasmic EXport protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to ethanol, DMSO, (S)-lactic acid; in competitive growth studies null mutants show reduced fitness

name: Ribosome Quality control Complex
function: tRNA-binding component of the RQC ribosome quality control complex involved in ubiquitin-mediated degradation of stalled nascent peptides; also binds the ribosomal large subunit; binds tRNAs and directs addition of amino acids to stalled nascent peptides

name: Long-Chain Base
function: Serine palmitoyltransferase subunit involved in biosynthesis of sphingolipids; localized to the SPOTS complex in the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Long-Chain Base
phenotype: Essential gene; repression results in depletion of sphingoid long-chain bases, defects in endocytosis and shmoo formation, increased sensitivity to heat and oxidative stress
function: Serine palmitoyltransferase subunit involved in biosynthesis of sphingolipids; localized to the SPOTS complex in the endoplasmic reticulum

name: BUD site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene; repression leads to accumulation of aberrant rRNA processing intermediates; null mutant shows reduced transposition of Ty1 element; in systematic studies null mutant diploids show abnormal random budding pattern

name: Ada Histone acetyltransferase complex Component
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in both fermentative and respiratory growth media, and increased fitness in minimal medium; null mutant has a decreased rate of urea utilization; null mutant has increased chronological lifespan, and increased telomere length; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient in some growth conditions and haploproficient in others; overexpression blocks silencing at HMR, indicative of barrier function

name: Carbon Catabolite Repression
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has slow growth rate and is hypersensitive to a variety of chemicals, including caffeine, hygromycin B,  benomyl, azauracil, hydroxyurea, cycloheximide, nystatin, rapamycin
function: 3'-5'-exoribonuclease subunit of the core CCR4-NOT complex; involved in deadenylation-dependent mRNA decay, nuclear-transcribed mRNA poly(A) tail shortening, replication fork protection, DNA replication, and regulation of transcription and transcription elongation; also involved in the DNA replication checkpoint and traversing the start control point of the mitotic cell cycle; colocalizes with the Cdc73/Paf1 complex and localizes to the cytoplasm and cytoplasmic mRNA processing body

name: CCR4 Associated Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium and during hyperosmotic growth; null mutant has increased replicative lifespan and stress resistance due to zinc deficiency; null mutant is heat shock sensitive; null mutant displays decreased resistance to numerous chemicals including: caffeine, caspofungin, rapamycin, hydroxyurea and 8% ethanol; homozygous diploid null mutant has a strong sporulation defect with incomplete meiotic divisions and lack of cell wall dityrosine; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression results in elevated invasive growth

name: CLeavage/Polyadenylation factor Ia subunit
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutant under semi-permissive temperature shows increased chromosome loss; haploinsufficient, heterozygous diploid has slow growth and increased innate thermotolerance

name: Conserved Oligomeric Golgi complex
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to nicotinamide; in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness; homozygous null mutant diploid shows decreased respiratory growth unless supplied with excess copper
function: Protein involved in vesicle-mediated transport within the Golgi and CVT pathway; part of the Golgi transport complex

name: Conserved Oligomeric Golgi complex
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction of function slows down processing and delivery of vauolar proteins; null mutation lowers competitive fitness; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to multiple chemicals, including caffeine, tunicamycin, hygromycin B, rapamycin, and resistant to others, such as camptothecin, fenpropimorph, fluconazole
function: Protein transporter involved in vesicle-mediated transport within the Golgi and CVT pathway; part of the Golgi transport complex

name: Derepressed for Ribosomal protein S14 Expression
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion disrupts distribution and activity of several iron-sulfur proteins and increases chromosome instability; reduction of function or overexpression both result in slow growth
function: Electron transfer protein capable of binding 2 iron, 2 sulfur (2Fe-2S) cluster involved in iron-sulfur cluster assembly; contributes to negative regulation of both nitric oxide biosynthesis and hydrogen-peroxide mediated programmed cell death; localizes to cytosol and mitochondrial intermembrane space
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the eisosome and colocalizes with membrane raft; localizes to cytoplasm in different large-scale studies

name: homolog of human CGI-121
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation increases replicative lifespan; in systematic studies null mutants show slow growth, elevated accumulation of histidine and arginine, increased sensitivity to several drugs, and abnormalities in utilization of carbon and nitorgen sources

name: CHitin Synthase-related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has strong defect in delivering chitin synthase to plasma membrane that leads to decreased chitin content in cell wall;  null mutant displays reduced mating, increased heat sensitivity and resistance to Calcofluor White; in systematic studies null mutants show elevated sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including rapamycin, wortmannin, caffeine, bleomycin, but increased resistance to tunicamycin and fenpropimorph
function: Component of the cytoplasmic exomer complex involved in golgi to plasma membrane transport, cell wall chitin catabolic process, conjugation with cellular fusion and bud site selection; interacts selectively with the small GTPase, Arf1p

name: Mph1-associated Histone-Fold protein
function: Protein with a role in the DNA damage response

name: NUclear Filament-containing protein
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion leads to increased frequency of chromosomal rearrangements and chromosome loss; overexpression also causes chromosome instability
function: Subunit of Ndc80 complex; structural constituent of cytoskeleton involved in microtubule nucleation and chromosome segregation; localizes to spindle pole body, spindle microtubule, condensed nuclear chromosome kinetochore and centromeric region

name: MiniChromosome Maintenance
function: ATP-dependent DNA helicase component of the MCM mini-chromosome maintenance complex involved in initiation and regulation of DNA replication; binds chromatin, DNA replication origins and single-stranded DNA

name: MiniChromosome Maintenance
function: Chromatin- and DNA replication origin-binding component of the MCM mini-chromosome maintenance complex involved in initiation and regulation of DNA replication; also involved in pre-replicative complex assembly, double-strand break repair, and silencing

name: MItochondrial contact site and Cristae organizing system
MItochondrial contact site and Cristae organizing system
function: Subunit of the mitochondrial MICOS complex, which is required for cristae formation; localizes to mitochondrial crista junction; required for coupling of MICOS subcomplexes

name: MItochondrial contact site and Cristae organizing system
MItochondrial contact site and Cristae organizing system
function: Subunit of the mitochondrial MICOS complex; involved in cristae formation.

name: MItochondrial contact site and Cristae organizing system
function: Subunit of MICOS, a mitochondrial inner membrane complex; involved in mitochondrial cristae formation and the import of proteins into the mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
LEft Open reading frame
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows descreased growth and competitive fitness, abnormal vacuolar morphology, abnormally elongated buds, short telomeres, decreased resistance to DNA-damaging agents, ethanol, heat, dessication, and is auxotrophic for myo-inositol; overexpression interferes with growth, confers resistance to TOR inhibitor rapamycin
function: Non-DNA binding transcription factor; subunit of the Cdc73/Paf1 transcription elongation complex; regulates  transcription from RNA Pol I and II promoters; also involved in histone H3-K4 trimethylation

name: Cell Division Cycle
function: Non-DNA binding transcription factor; subunit of the Cdc73/Paf1 transcription elongation complex; involved in transcription activation from Pol I and II promoters, regulation of transcription coupled nucleotide excision repair (NER), mRNA 3'-end processing and histone H3 methylation

name: RNA Polymerase II Associated Factor
function: Non-DNA binding transcription factor; subunit of the Cdc73/Paf1 transcription elongation complex; regulates transcription from Pol I and II promoters; also involved in snoRNA 3'-end processing

name: Cln Three (CLN3) Requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows inositol auxotrophy, decreased anaerobic growth rate, and sensitivity to both reduced and elevated temperatures; null mutation also confers increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including hygromycin B, formamide, SDS caffeine, benomyl, cycloheximide, hydroxyurea, rapamycin
function: Non-DNA binding transcription factor; subunit of the Cdc73/Paf1 transcription elongation complex; regulates transcription from Pol I and II promoters; also involved in snoRNA 3'-end processing

name: Spindle Pole Antigen
function: MAP-kinase scaffold protein and polarisome subunit involved in regulation of protein localization, establishment of cell polarity, bipolar bud site selection, apical bud growth, pseudohyphal growth, and regulation of mating projection growth initiation and termination; positively regulates actin cytoskeleton reorganization as part of the cellular response to hypertonicity and acidic pH; localizes to incipient bud sites and sites of polarized growth

name: Ribosome Quality Control
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants show decreased competitive fitness, are defective in vacuolar fragmentation and ribosome production, and sensitive to antimicrobial paromomycin; homozygous diploid null mutants show enhanced respiratory growth, increased resistance to cell wall perturbing agent Calcofluor White and antifungal mitochondrial respiratory-chain inhibitor antimycin A, increased sensitivity to heat and protein synthesis inhibitor anisomycin; homozygous diploid overexpression enhances pseudohyphal growth; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploproficient
function: Subunit of the ribosome quality control (RQC) complex, which is a ribosome bound complex involved in the ubiquitin-dependent degradation of aberrant translation products

name: PHOsphate metabolism
function: Histone-binding component of the Rpd3L histone deacetylase complex involved in chromatin organization, modification, and silencing at telomeres, the rDNA, and the mating-type cassette; regulates transcription in response to stressors such as heat and glucose limitation

name: Cyc8-Tup1 Interacting protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation increases sensitivity to ethanol, nickel and cadmium, but increases resistance to rapamycin; in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness and increased sensitivity to some chemicals, including camptothecin, tunicamycin, Congo Red, mycophenolic acid, and increased resistance to others, including hydroxyurea and bleomycin
function: Subunit the Rpd3L complex that is acts as histone deacetylase involved in chromatin silencing and transcription initiation; localized to the nucleus

name: Asymmetric Synthesis of HO
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased filamentous growth and increased mating type switching; overexpression leads to decreased mating type switching
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding RNA Pol II transcription factor that up and down regulates transcription; its role as transcription repressor negatively regulates mating type switching, G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle; its role as transcription activator positively regulates pseudohyphal growth; subunit of the Rpd3L histone deacetylase complex; also localizes to the cellular bud

name: Remodel the Structure of Chromatin
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation

name: Remodel the Structure of Chromatin
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning, transcription regulation, and DNA double-strand break repair via nonhomologous end joining

name: Snf Five Homolog
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation; also involved in double-strand break repair and ploidy maintenance

name: Remodel the Structure of Chromatin
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation; also involved in ploidy maintenance

name: Remodel the Structure of Chromatin
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation; binds lysine-acetylated histones

name: Nuclear Protein Localization
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation

name: Low Dye Binding
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation

name: Remodel the Structure of Chromatin
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning, transcription regulation, and DNA double-strand break repair via nonhomologous end joining

name: Remodel the Structure of Chromatin
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation

name: High-Temperature Lethal
function: Subunit of RSC chromatin remodeling complex, slides along DNA affecting nucleosome positioning and transcription regulation

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Non-essential gene; conditional mutant displays a cell cycle arrest with severe cytokinesis defect, arresting with large, multibudded, multinucleate cells at elevated temperature; conditional mutant displays an altered budding pattern at semi-permissive temperature; null mutant has abnormally elongated buds, decreased rate of growth, decreased metal and starvation resistance and increased cell size; diploid nulls have a sporulation defect
function: Subunit of the septin complex with GTPase activity; localizes to the bud neck septin ring, and establishes a scaffold to support the assembly of a multiprotein complex which facilitates cytokinesis; localizes to the prospore membrane and meiotic spindle and is required for sporulation; binds to both PI(4)P and PI(5)P

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant displays cell cycle arrest with severe cytokinesis defect, arresting with large, multibudded, multinucleate cells at elevated temperature; conditional mutant displays both altered budding pattern and highly elongated bud morphology at semi-permissive temperature; overexpression results in a decreased rate of vegetative growth, large, elongated, multibudded, cells with hyperpolarized buds; repressible mutant has increased inositol excretion phenotype; heterozygous null mutant displays increased thermotolerance in stationary phase
function: GTP binding protein and subunit of the septin complex; localizes to the bud neck septin ring, and has a structural role required for cytokinesis; localizes to the prospore membrane and meiotic spindle and is required for sporulation; binds to both PI(4)P and PI(5)P

name: Seventh Homolog of Septin
function: Septin, localized to the septin ring at the bud neck; recruits Bni5p and, via Bni5p, Myo1p to the bud neck to promote cytokinesis after budding

name: Cell Division Cycle
function: Subunit of the septin complex with GTPase activity; localizes to the bud neck septin ring, and establishes a scaffold to support the assembly of a multiprotein complex which facilitates cytokinesis; localizes to the prospore membrane and meiotic spindle and is required for sporulation; binds to both PI(4)P and PI(5)P

name: Cell Division Cycle
function: GTP binding protein and subunit of the septin complex; localizes to the bud neck septin ring, and has a structural role required for cytokinesis; localizes to the prospore membrane and meiotic spindle and is required for sporulation; binds to both PI(4)P and PI(5)P

name: U Three Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes retention of tRNAs in the nucleus; in large-scale studies, heterozygous null mutant diploid displays chromosome instability and is haploinsufficient; repression confers resistance to myriocin and decreased competitive fitness
function: Nucleolar protein component of the small subunit processome involved in rRNA processing and nuclear tRNA export; also a component of the UTP-C complex which forms a subcomplex of the 90S preribosome, and the CURI complex which is involved in the transcription of ribosomal genes

name: Mitotic Arrest-Deficient
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has chromosome instability defect and shows sensitivity to benomyl, and reduced spore germination; homozygous null mutant diploid has abnormal meiosis and sporulation; in large scale studies null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and decreased growth rate
function: A subunit of the mitotic checkpoint complex; involved in  mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint and chromosome decondensation; localizes to the condensed nuclear kinetochore and nuclear pore

name: BreFeldin A Resistance
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes defects in biogenesis of small ribosomal subunits, decreased nuclear export of 40S ribosomal subunits, increased accumulation of 35S pre-rRNA, and decreased levels of 18S and 20S rRNA species

name: Translocase of the Outer Mitochondrial membrane
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is petite-negative (loss of the mitochondrial genome is lethal), has a respiratory growth defect that is exacerbated at high temperature, and exhibits slow growth on fermentable carbon sources; null mutant shows increased replicative lifespan extension in response to caloric restriction, compared to wild type; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in various media, decreased invasive growth, biofilm formation, and resistance to starvation and desiccation, and shows altered resistance to various chemicals

name: Translocase of the Outer Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Outer Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Outer Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Outer Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Outer Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Outer Mitochondrial membrane
SUppressor of Brr1-1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows extremely slowly and may be inviable in certain genetic backgrounds; null mutant in the W303 genetic background shows increased mitotic recombination and reduced mRNA levels; repression causes accumulation of unspliced U3 snoRNA precursor; in large-scale studies, diploid heterozygous null mutant and haploid conditional mutant display chromosome instability; overexpression causes arrest or delay in G1 phase
function: Putative ATP-dependent RNA helicase; involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing, export from nucleus, 3'-end processing; contributes to transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair and chromatin silencing at telomere; localizes to transcription export complex, spliceosomal complex and telomeric region of chromosome

name: TRAPP Complex Associated protein
function: Subunit of the TRAPPII complex, a multisubunit guanine nucleotide-exchange factor; involved in assembly of the TRAPPII complex and in early endosome to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport; localizes to the Golgi apparatus, and in high-throughput studies to the cytosol and clathrin-coated vesicles

name: Asparagine Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to DNA-damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS) and to heat; repression increases chromosome rearrangements and chromosome loss
function: An N-acetylglucosaminyldiphosphodolichol N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase that is a component of the UDP-N-acetylglucosamine transferase complex that is involved in the dolichol-linked oligosaccharide biosynthetic process; localizes to the intrinsic component of endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: HO and Radiation Repair
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C, non-essential in W303 and some other strain backgrounds; reduction-of-function mutations cause slow growth, abnormal cellular morphology, sensitivity to heat, X rays, killer toxins, caffeine, Calcofluor White and MMS, and increased production and excretion of inositol (Opi-); diploids are unable to sporulate
function: Dual-specificity serine/threonine and tyrosine protein kinase that regulates various cellular processes including clathrin-mediated endocytosis, ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport, pexophagy, ribosome maturation, and the attachment of microtubules to kinetochores; subunit of monopolin complex; also localizes to different sites within the cell, including bud necks and tips, plasma membrane, Golgi, and spindle pole bodies

name: MItochondrial contact site and Cristae organizing system
function: Subunit of the mitochondrial MICOS complex, which is required for cristae formation; localizes to mitochondrial crista junction

name: AuTophaGy related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows no autophagy, mitophagy or pexophagy, increased sensitivity to nitrogen starvation and is unable to sporulate
function: Atg12p transferase (transfers Atg12 from Atg12p-Atg7p conjugate to Atg10p); involved in macroautophagy and cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathways

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutations confer slow growth and defects in intracellular protein traffic
function: Subunit of the Sec61 translocon complex involved in the co-translational import of proteins into the endoplasmic reticulum (ER); also involved in retrograde protein transport and ER-associated protein degradation

name: Cu2+ suppressing and Bleomycin sensitive
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Old Yellow Enzyme
function: Mitochondrial NADPH dehydrogenase with a role in apoptosis

name: Top1T722A mutant Hypersensitive
phenotype: Essential gene; ts alleles confer resistance to hydrogen peroxide, while overexpression confers sensitivity; in large-scale studies, repression confers increased competitive fitness and reduced incorporation of Fe-S clusters into enzymes
function: Mitochondrial oxidoreductase involved in the formation of nitrogen monoxide and the incorporation of iron and exogenous sulfur into metallo-sulfur clusters

name: Multicopy suppressor Of ts Gsp1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays slow growth, sensitivity to nickel, cadmium, caffeine, hygromycin B, SDS and caspofungin; overexpression results in reduced telomeric silencing
function: Protein that selectively binds Ran GTPase and is involved in protein import into the nucleus; localizes to nucleus

name: suppressor of the Transcriptional defect of Hpr1 by Overexpression
Peptide N-Glycanase
function: Peptide N-glycanase involved in protein deglycosylation during ER-associated ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism; localizes to the nucleus and cytosol

name: AuTophaGy related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction of function mutant is defective for autophagy and the CVT pathway; null mutant is unable to undergo both late nucleophagy and pexophagy, and displays reduced mitophagy and micronucleophagy; null mutant displays decreased viability during nitrogen starvation and abnormal nuclear morphology; null mutant displays a reduction in in the C-terminal modification of Atg8p and its localization to the pre-autophagosomal structure; null mutant has a reduction in chronological lifespan, and decreased resistance to desiccation and zinc treatment; homozygous diploid null mutant has a severe respiratory growth defect and is unable to sporulate; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Contributes to Atg8 ligase activity (conjugates Atg8p to phosphatidylethanolamine, PE); subunit of the Atg12-Atg5-Atg16 complex; involved in macroautophagy, cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway, late nucleophagy, piecemeal microautophagy of nucleus, protein lipidation and mitochondrion degradation; localizes to the pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS)

name: Apl2 Vps1 Lethal
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a small cell size, is heat sensitive, displays decreased vegetative growth rate and decreased competitive fitness; null mutant has a defect in the late secretory pathway; null mutant has a decrease in chronological lifespan, decreased desiccation resistance and decreased ability to form biofilms; overexpression results in a decreased rate of vegetative growth

name: IScU homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays sensitivity to H2O2 and FeSO4, decreased respiratory growth, increased mitochondrial iron accumulation, and decreased aconitase activity; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits increased competitive fitness in a variety of media and increased resistance to acetic acid; heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to fluconazole
function: Iron-binding protein of the mitochondrial matrix in iron-sulfur cluster assembly and post-transcriptional modification of wobble uridines in tRNAs

name: Ribosomal Protein P0
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C; repression causes slow growth and accumulation of free 60S ribosomal subunits; in Sigma1278b null mutation causes decreased filamentous growth and absence of invasive growth
function: Large ribosomal subunit rRNA-binding constituent of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in assembly of the large ribosomal subunit and translation

name: Eukaryotic Ribosome Biogenesis
function: Subunit of the PeBoW complex and the preribosomal complex; binds to the large ribosomal subunit rRNA and is involved in the processing of the rRNA and the biogenesis of the large ribosomal subunit

name: Translation Initiation Factor
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes cell cycle arrest in G1; in large-scale studies, mutation decreases filamentous and invasive growth; repression reduces competitive fitness and confers resistance to cycloheximide; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to heat and verrucarin A, displays smaller cell size, and is haploinsufficient
function: Protein that binds ribosomal large subunit and is involved in biogenesis and maturation of LSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and 5.8S rRNA from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); contributes to ribosomal subunit export from nucleus

name: NucleOlar Protein
function: Subunit of the preribosmal complex (large subunit precursor) that binds rRNA; is involved in the maturation of the large subunit rRNA (LSU-rRNA) and biogenesis of the ribosomal large subunit

name: MAintenance of Killer
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C; repression causes reduced levels of mature rRNAs and overexpression causes slow growth; non-essential gene in Sigma1278b, null mutant shows increased filamentous growth but no invasive growth
function: Noc1p-Noc2p complex subunit involved in ribosomal large subunit assembly; localizes to 66S preribosome

name: Glycerol-3-Phosphate Phosphatase
function: Glycerol-1-phosphatase involved in the biosynthesis of glycerol and the response to osmotic stress; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Suppressor of Cytochrome Oxidase deficiency
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant and sco1-C148A mutant with defective copper binding site are unable to utilize nonfermentable carbon sources; null mutant is sensitive to oxidative stress but sco1-C148A mutant is not; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows lower competitive fitness in several different media, smaller cell size, shorter chronological lifespan, and sensitivity to desiccation and hyperosmotic stress; diploid homozygous null mutant accumulates reduced levels of glycogen and excretes higher levels of glutathione; null mutant has altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Putative thioredoxin peroxidase involved in protein complex assembly and copper ion transport; likely involved in response to redox state; localizes to mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Cx9C Mitochondrial protein necessary for full assembly of Cytochrome c oxidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation decreases cytochrome c oxidase activity and respiratory growth rate; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness, abnormal levels of polyphosphate and increased sensitivity to sphingolipid-depleting drug myriocin
Non-essential gene; null mutation confers sensitivity to copper ions; in systematic studies, overexpression is lethal, whereas null mutation lowers competitive fitness
function: Transcription factor that binds in a sequence-specific manner to DNA proximal to the RNA polymerase II core promoter; activates transcription of target genes in response to copper; localizes to the nucleus

name: Copper Chaperone for SOD1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires methionine, displays a respiratory growth defect and increased mutation frequency, is sensitive to alkaline pH, and is sensitive to paraquat and tunicamycin under aerobic but not anaerobic conditions; in large-scale studies the null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness, sensitivity to oxidative stress, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Copper chaperone that delivers copper to superoxide dismutase; involved in intracellular copper transport; localized to nucleus, cytosol, mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to respire and is sensitive to tin and to alkaline pH; overexpression confers increased resistance to clozapine; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and sensitivity to desiccation, heat, oxidative stress, and various chemicals; overexpression confers increased filamentous growth
function: Copper chaperone that delivers copper to respiratory chain complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase); required for the assembly of cytochrome c oxidase complex and for aerobic respiration; localized to cytosol and mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: HEMe biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene on standard rich medium due to heme auxotrophy; mutant fails to respire; in large-scale study, repressing expression confers increased competitive fitness
function: Coproporphyrinogen oxidase involved in the biosynthesis of heme; catalyzes oxidation of coproporphyrinogen III to protoporphyrinogen IX; localizes to the cytosol

name: TRapp Subunit
function: Subunit of multiple TRAPP complexes (TRAPPI, TRAPPII, and TRAPPIII); contributes to Rab family guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor activity; involved in ER-Golgi vesicle-mediated transport; localizes to the cytosol in high-throughput studies

name: TRapp Subunit
function: Subunit of multiple TRAPP complexes; contributes to Rab family guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor activity; involved in ER-Golgi vesicle-mediated transport; subunit of the TRAPPI, TRAPPII and TRAPPIII complexes

name: Blocked Early in Transport
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are subject to chromosome instability, have dilated ER, accumulate vesicles, and are impaired in protein transport and secretion at elevated temperatures; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient, sensitive to starvation, and to the dopaminergic antagonist chlorpromazine
function: Subunit of multiple TRAPP complexes (TRAPPI, TRAPPII, and TRAPPIII); contributes to Rab family guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor activity; involved in ER-Golgi vesicle-mediated transport

name: Blocked Early in Transport
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations lead to defects in protein transport and abnormalities in morphology of ER membranes and secretory vesicles
function: Subunit of multiple TRAPP complexes (TRAPPI, TRAPPII, and TRAPPIII); contributes to Rab family guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor activity; involved in ER-Golgi, and intra-Golgi vesicle-mediated transport; localizes to the cis-Golgi network

name: TRapp Subunit
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutants show abnormal endocytosis and sensitivity to Calcofluor White; diploid homozygous trs20-1 and trs20-6 mutants fail to sporulate; in large-scale studies, repression causes lower competitive fitness, longer telomeres, and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to chlorpromazine and nigericin
function: Subunit of the TRAPPI, TRAPPII, and TRAPPIII complexes that function in ER to Golgi vesicular transport, endosome-to-Golgi traffic, and trafficking of autophagy proteins from the Golgi to pre-autophagosomal structures

name: TRapp Subunit
function: Subunit of multiple TRAPP complexes that function as Rab family guanine nucleotide-exchange factors; subunit of TRAPPI, involved in ER-Golgi vesicle-mediated transport, TRAPPII, involved in intra-Golgi and endosome-Golgi traffic and TRAPPIII, involved in endosome-Golgi traffic and autophagy; positive regulator of macroautophagy; involved in the assembly and localization of TRAPP complexes; localizes to the cis- and trans-Golgi networks and the pre-autophagosomal structure

name: snRNA Sm binding site protein D1
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant displays heat- and cold-sensitivity; in large-scale studies, repression confers decreased competitive fitness, and the diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient
function: A subunit of the commitment complex that binds mRNA and is involved in mRNA splicing, via the splicesome

phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, the diploid heterozygous null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness and haploinsufficiency
function: A subunit of a U2-type presliceosome complex; involved in mRNA splicing
A subunit of the commitment and U2-type presliceosome complexes that binds mRNA; involved in mRNA splicing, via the splicesome

name: Sm protein E
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression confers decreased competitive fitness and sensitivity to benomyl
function: Protein involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing that associates with U1 small nuclear RNP (snRNP), U5 snRNP, and U4/U6 x U5 tri-snRNP complex

phenotype: Essential gene; in a large-scale study, diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient
function: Protein subunit of the spliceosome Sm core complex that binds messenger RNA (mRNA) and other splicing factors; involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing

name: Nucleolar silencing Establishing factor and Telophase regulator
CORe protein of QH2 cytochrome c reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources; in systematic studies mutants show decreased competitive fitness under various conditions and decreased ability to utilize alternative carbon and nitrogen sources
function: Component of the mitochondrial inner membrane ubiquinol-cytochrome c reductase complex (Complex III) that is essential for activity of the complex during cellular respiration.

name: CoRoNin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in abnormal spindle morphology, decreased endocytosis and increased sensitivity to benomyl; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to tunicamycin, fenpropimorph and nickel ions, but resistant to hydroxyurea and bleomycin
function: Component of cortical actin cytoskeleton that regulates actin nucleation mediated by the Arp2/3 complex; colocalizes with the Arp2/3 complex within the actin cytoskeleton

name: ARE2 Required for Viability
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows abnormal ER and vacuolar morphology, defects in endocytosis and abnormal distribution of sterols and ceramides; in large-scale studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness
function: Protein whose molecular function is unknown; implicated in GPI anchor biosynthesis and transport; also involved in intracellular sterol and sphingolipid transport; localized to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Three Calcium and lipid Binding domains (TriCalBins)
Target Of Sbf
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall; localized to the vacuole in a large-scale study

name: Covalently linked Cell Wall protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; both null mutation and overexpression confer increased sensitivity to cell wall-affecting chemicals (Congo Red, Calcofluor White); in systematic studies null mutants show decreased biofilm formation and shortened telomeres

name: Cell Division Cycle
