phenotype: Essential gene; reduced function increases competitive fitness; conditional mutants are sensitive to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl at permissive temperature, arrest in G1 with a single nucleus, multiple elongated buds, and spindle pole bodies that fail to separate at elevated temperatures; overexpression slows growth, disrupts cellular morphology; repression disrupts mitochondrial morphology
function: Subunit of Skp1/Cul1/F-box (SCF) complexes; acts as a bridging factor which contributes to proteasomal-dependent ubiquitin protein ligase activity involved in protein catabolism; required for both the G1/S and G2/M phase transitions of the mitotic cell cycle; binds to replications origins

name: DNA Damage Inducible
function: Cyanamide hydratase involved in detoxification of cyanamide

name: Cyclic nucleotide PhosphoDiesterase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation decreases resistance to cytotoxic drug cordycepin under competitive growth conditions; in systematic studies null mutants display abnormal amino acid accumulation and decreased formation of biofilms in strain Sigma1278b
function: Cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterase that hydrolyzes nucleoside 2',3' cyclic phosphodiester bond to yield nucleoside 2'-phosphate; localizes to the Golgi apparatus

name: Pho85 CycLin
function: Component of the cyclin-dependent protein kinase holoenzyme complex; regulator of the Pho85p kinase; involved in regulation of transcription during G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle and establishment or maintenance of cell polarity; localizes to the bud neck and incipient bud site

phenotype: Essential gene; base-substitution mutants are resistant to cycloheximide; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient and sensitive to lactoferricin, which is an amphipathic, cationic peptide with antimicrobial and anticancer properties
function: Cyclin that acts as regulator of a protein kinase component of the transcription factor holo TFIIH complex; stimulates phosphorylation of RNA polymerase II C-terminal domain and positively regulates transcription by Polymerase II; localized to the nucleus

name: PHOsphate metabolism
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal morphology, increased rate of mitotic chromosome loss, increased chronological lifespan, and sensitivity to a variety of chemicals; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in a variety of different media, slow growth rate, shortened telomeres, reduced endocytosis, and sensitivity to many different chemicals
function: Cyclin-dependent protein serine/threonine kinase involved in regulation of phosphate and glycogen metabolism, cell cycle progression, establishment of cell polarity, autophagy, response to DNA damage, and calcium-mediated signaling; localized to the nucleus

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants display allele specific cell cycle arrest as either large, unbudded, conjugation-competent cells with a single, undivided nucleus and pear-shaped morphology at START in the G1 phase or as abnormally large, elongated cells with undivided nuclei at the G2/M phase transition; reduction-of-function mutant has a decreased rate of growth and buds in a bipolar or unipolar manner; conditional mutants are benomyl sensitive, have an elevated rate of plasmid and chromosome loss, and accumulate trigylcerides; homozygous diploid mutants have a sporulation defect
function: Protein serine/threonine kinase subunit of multiple cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) complexes, which regulate the mitotic and meiotic cell cycles as well as many other cellular processes; CDK complexes function at various locations throughout the cell

name: Substrate/Subunit Inhibitor of Cyclin-dependent protein kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a decreased growth rate, a reduced duration of the G1 phase of the cell cycle, is thermosensitive, and has impaired anaerobic growth during anoxia; null mutant has elevated levels of chromosome loss, and overall chromosomal instability; null mutant also displays a shorter chronological lifespan, accumulates superoxide, and is defective for entry into stationary phase; homozygous diploid null mutant has a sporulation defect, and reduced innate thermotolerance; overexpression enhances invasive growth
function: An inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK), specifically serine/threonine CDKs; active during the G1/S transition of the mitotic cell cycle; negative regulator of macroautophagy; localizes to both the nucleus and the cytoplasm

name: Cdc28 Kinase Subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; originally thought to be essential because the null mutant is extremely slow-growing; null mutant is sensitive to heat, cold, hydroxyurea, and ionic stress, and requires myo-inositol for growth; in large-scale studies repressible or conditional mutants display chromosome instability and increased DNA damage
function: Regulatory subunit of cyclin-dependent protein kinase holoenzyme complex; acts as activator kinase activity in regulation of mitotic cell cycle; positively regulates transcription by RNA Polymerase II; localized to nucleus and cytoplasm in high throughput studies

name: Bypass UAS Requirement
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows elevated frequency of gross chromosomal rearrangements, decreased levels and reduced phosphorylation of RNA Polymerase II, and inositol auxotrophy; overexpression causes increased frequency of chromosome loss and sensitivity to benomyl; in systematic studies null mutants display reduced growth rate, enlarged cells, decreased competitive fitness, and sensitivity to multiple factors, such as heat, killer toxins, caffeine, hygromycin B, DTT, MMS

name: Cyclin-Like Gene
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant under competitive growth conditions shows decreased fitness, shortened chronological lifespan and increased sensitivity to antileukemic drug cordycepin; homozygous diploids have lower sporulation efficiency and higher innate thermotolerance

name: Regulator of IME2
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, are impaired in respiration, endocytosis, sporulation, filamentous growth, and biofilm formation; nulls are also sensitive to various toxins, antibiotics, and acid pH, and are resistant to metals; conditional mutants are sensitive to cold; overexpression increases resistance to TOR inhibitor rapamycin
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor that regulates transcription by RNA polymerase II involved in meiosis, spore formation, cell wall biosynthesis, and the cellular responses to anoxia and alkaline pH

name: Deficient in Utilization of Glutathione
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to utilize glutathione as a source of sulfur; overexpression increases resistance to rapamycin (sirolimus); in large-scale studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness and increased chronological lifespan
function: Omega peptidase and metallodipeptidase; involved in glutathione degradation; localizes to cytoplasm and to mitochondrion and ribosome in high-throughput studies

name: CYStathionine beta-synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for cysteine, grows slowly, shows decreased accumulation of glutathione and sensitivity to oxidative stress and metals (zinc, cobalt, manganese, cadmium); null mutant also shows decreased rate of respiratory growth; overexpression leads to decreased cell size and increased growth rate
function: Cystathionine beta-synthase involved in transsulfuration, cysteine biosynthesis, and generation of hydrogen sulfide; also implicated in traversing start control point of mitotic cell cycle; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: CYStathionine gamma-lyase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is cysteine auxotroph and shows slow growth in exponential phase; in Sigma1278b strain background, null mutant is incapable of invasive growth; in systematic studies, mutants are sensitive to arsenite, selenide, DMSO, and resistant to selenomethionine and myriocin
function: Cystathionine gamma-lyase involved in transsulfuration and cysteine biosynthesis; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant displays increased desiccation resistance; in large-scale studies, heterozygous null diploid is haploproficient but shows reduced starvation resistance; repression causes decreased competitive fitness and sensitivity to MMS
function: Cysteinyl-tRNA synthetase that performs cysteinyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling cysteine to cysteinyl-tRNA; localizes to the cytoplasm and colocalizes with ribosomes

name: CytochrOme B
phenotype: Non-essential gene; loss of function blocks electron transport chain in mitochondria, eliminates aerobic growth (on respiratory, nonfermentable carbon sources) and causes slow growth on fermentable carbon sources (petite phenotype)
function: A ubiquinol-cytochrome-c reductase that transfers electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c during aerobic respiration; a subunit of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex III

name: CYtochrome B
phenotype: Non-essential gene; under competitive growth conditions, mutants show decreased competitive fitness, increased chronological lifespan and elevated sensitivity to cordycepin; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to rapamycin and wortmannin, and resistant to myriocin and ethanol

name: Cytochrome b Reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness; in homozygous diploids, null mutation leads to elevated glycogen accumulation and increased resistance to MMS

name: CYTochrome c1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and grows slowly on fermentable carbon sources (petite phenotype); in systematic studies, mutants show decreased competitive fitness, abnormal lipid particle and mitochondria morphology, and increased sensitivity to lipids and amitrole

name: CYTochrome-c1-heme-lyase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased growth rate, a respiratory growth defect, and a decreased rate of proline utilization; null mutant displays increased biofilm formation, increased starvation-induced mitophagy and increased dietary restriction-induced replicative lifespan extension; homozygous diploid null mutant displays decreased sporulation efficiency, decreased accumulation of storage carbohydrate glycogen, decreased chronological lifespan and decreased desiccation resistance
function: Holocytochrome c synthase involved in cytochrome c-heme linkage; localizes to mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: CYtochrome C
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows greatly decreased rate of respiratory growth and decreased apoptosis; in large-scale studies null mutant shows sensitivity to ethanol, flucytosine, MMS, inability to utilize proline or glutamine as a nitrogen source, and displays decreased competitive fitness
function: Holocytochrome c synthase involved in cytochrome c-heme linkage; localizes to mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: CYtochrome C
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources and displays resistance to 3-chlorolactic acid; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, shorter chronological lifespan, decreased desiccation resistance, and poor utilization of proline, ammonium, glutamine, and glutamate as nitrogen sources
function: Electron carrier of the mitochondrial inter membrane space, involved in ubiquinol-to-cytochrome c and cytochrome c-to-oxygen electron transport

name: CYtochrome C
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced anaerobic growth rate; mutants also show increased competitive fitness and resistance to miconazole and toxaphene

name: Cytochrome Oxidase Assembly
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory metabolism and unable to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources, and has petite phenotype, i.e. forms small colonies on fermentable carbon sources due to respiratory defect

name: ALAnyl-tRNA synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are impaired in cell cycle progression at elevated temperatures; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness and have shortened telomeres; heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to zinc chloride and to oxidative stress; overexpression slows vegetative growth in S288C, increases invasive growth in Sigma1278b
function: Alanyl-tRNA synthetase that performs alanyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling alanine to alanyl-tRNA; localizes to the both the cytoplasm and mitochondria

name: Glycyl-tRNA Synthase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations cause decreased growth rate and chromosome instability; reduction of function blocks respiratory growth; null mutation in heterozygous diploid causes starvation sensitivity
function: Glycine-transfer RNA (tRNA) ligase involved in termination of DNA-templated transcription; contributes to mitochondrial glycyl-tRNA aminoacylation; localizes to cytoplasm and mitochondrion

name: Histidine-Trna Synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to ethanol; reduction of funcion increases competitive fitness
function: Histidine tRNA synthetase that catalyzes histidyl-tRNA aminoacylation through the coupling of histidine to histidyl-tRNA; localizes to both the mitochondria and cytoplasm

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased resistance to cycloheximide and neomycin; heterozygous diploid null has decreased resistance to starvation; null mutant displays a small defect in vacuolar morphology in the presence of salt

name: Stress-Seventy subfamily B
function: ATPase involved in protein folding, export of ribosomal subunit from nucleus, regulation of translation fidelity, rRNA processing; associated with polysomes and localized in the cytoplasm

name: Stress-Seventy subfamily B
function: ATPase involved in protein folding, export of ribosomal subunit from nucleus, regulation of translation fidelity, rRNA processing; associated with polysomes and localized in the cytoplasm

name: Dead Box Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function causes slow vegetative growth, heat sensitivity and elevated sensitivity to paromomycin and hygromycin B; overexpression of dominant negative allele blocks poly(A)+ mRNA export from nucleus

Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to freeze-thaw; in large-scale experiments null mutants are sensitive to cycloheximide, streptomycin, fluconazole, show decreased telomere lengths and decreased competitive fitness, and increased production and excretion of inositol (Opi-)
function: Chaperone protein and ATPase involved in de novo protein folding and protein refolding; involved in proteasome assembly, telomere maintenance, box C/D snoRNP assembly, and the cellular response to heat; localizes to the cytoplasm, mitochondrion, and plasma membrane in high-throughput studies

name: BCK1-like Resistance to Osmotic shock
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a growth defect, is heat sensitive, and displays decreased competitive fitness on both fermentative and respiratory growth media; null mutant has a decreased ability to use raffinose as carbon source; null mutant has a reduced ability to target Doa4p to the endosome, an inability to sort MVB cargo protein to the vacuole and a strong vacuolar fragmentation defect; null mutant has decreased resistance to ionic stress, cadmium and manganese treatment, oxidative stress, and desiccation; null mutant is defective in regulating intracellular pH and displays decreased resistance to acid pH; null mutant has decreased telomere length, reduced innate thermotolerance, and a decreased ability to form biofilms; null mutant displays increased accumulation of cadmium, calcium and alanine and decreased accumulation of glycogen; homozygous diploid null mutant has a sporulation defect; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient

name: DEAD box Helicase Homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits slow growth, shortened chronological and replicative lifespan, heat sensitivity, increased apoptosis, inability to sporulate, and increased resistance to 2-deoxyglucose; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows slow growth, reduced competitive fitness in several different media, poor utilization of various nitrogen sources, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: ATP-dependent RNA helicase; involved in deadenylation-dependent mRNA decapping, unwinding of RNA secondary structure, and assembly of cytoplasmic mRNA processing body (P-body); plays a role in translation regulation; localizes in cytoplasm, cytoplasmic stress granules and cytoplasmic P-bodies

name: Mac1-Dependent Regulator
function: A GTPase activator involved in intrascellular protein transport; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: IsoLeucine-tRNA Synthetase
function: Cytosolic isoleucyl-tRNA synthetase that catalyzes isoleucyl-tRNA aminoacylation through the coupling of isoleucine to isoleucyl-tRNA

name: Cyclosporin A-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers increased sensitivity to oxidative stress-inducing agents, such as hydrogen peroxide and menadione, and to sulfuric acid and ethanol; null mutant exhibits increased resistance to cyclosporin and rapamycin; homozygous null mutant diploid shows delays sporulation; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to streptomycin, fenpropimorph, tunicamycin and bleomysin, but resistant to mycophenolic acid
function: Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase (cyclophilin) that catalyzes the cis-trans isomerization of peptide bonds preceding proline residues in oligopeptides; involved in histone deacetylation, regulation of meiosis and ascospore formation; localizes to Set3 histone deacetylase complex in the nucleus
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in different large-scale studies

name: Altered Inheritance rate of Mitochondria
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a decreased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss; null mutant is ethanol sensitive; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus; overexpression results in decreased filamentous group and an inability to undergo invasive growth
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localized to the cytoplasm

name: REgulation of Enolase
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: KELch
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Vacuolar Import and Degradation
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Oxidant-induced Cell-cycle Arrest
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Oxidant-induced Cell-cycle Arrest
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large scale study

name: Oxidant-induced Cell-cycle Arrest
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Required for Meiotic nuclear Division
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Slower Growth on Non-fermentable carbon sources
Suppressor of rho3
function: RNA-binding protein involved in cytoplasmic translation; localizes to polysomes and cytoplasmic stress granules

name: ADEnine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays adenine and histidine auxotrophy; in large-scale studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness
function: Formate-tetrahydrofolate ligase, methenyltetrahydrofolate cyclohydrolase and methylenetetrahydrofolate dehydrogenase (NADP+) involved in folic acid-containing compound and puring nucleobase biosynthetic processes; localized to the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: W (tryptophan) RS (tRNA synthetase)
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression causes reduced competitive fitness while overexpression confers slow growth and resistance to rapamycin
function: Cytoplasmic tryptophanyl-tRNA synthetase that performs tryptophanyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling tryptophan to tryptophanyl-tRNA

name: TYrosyl-tRNA Synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; tys1-1 ts mutant accumulates tRNA-Tyr in the nucleus at restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, repression causes lower competitive fitness; diploid homozygous tys1-1 ts mutant displays reduced sporulation efficiency; diploid heterozygous null mutant has altered resistance to human cationic antimicrobial peptides
function: Tyrosine-tRNA ligase that couples tyrosine to tyrosyl-tRNA; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Synthetic Lethal with ABP1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is temperature sensitive, has a decreased growth rate, decreased competitive fitness in various growth media and a respiratory growth defect; homozygous diploid null mutant has abnormally round cells, a random budding pattern, cell size heterogeneity, actin cytoskeleton defects that are more pronounced at elevated temperature and defects in HU-induced filamentous growth; null mutant has an endocytotic defect, resulting in a reduction in the localization of Bud8p, and Rax2p to growing bud tips; null mutant displays decreased resistance to hyperosmotic and oxidative stress, metals, acid pH, and has decreased thermotolerance; chitin deposition is increased at least two fold in the null mutant
function: Endocytic adaptor protein that interacts with ubiquitin; involved in endocytosis and actin cortical patch assembly; inhibits Arp2/3-complex mediated actin nucleation; shuttles between the nucleus and actin cortical patches

name: ALdehyde Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased growth rate, competitive fitness and an inability to utilize ethanol as a carbon source; null mutant is defective for acetate formation during anaerobic growth, and for glycogen accumulation; null mutant is sensitive to oxidative stress, but displays increased resistance to methylmercury, hyperosmotic stress, nitrogen starvation and zinc limitation
function: An aldehyde dehydrogenase involved in acetate biosynthesis, NADPH regeneration and response to salt stress; localized to the mitochondrion and cytosol

name: Defines Essential Domain
phenotype: Essential gene in a systematic study; in a large-scale survey, repression leads to increased chromosomal rearrangements and chromosome loss
function: Asparagine-tRNA ligase that couples the amino acid asparagine to asparaginyl-tRNA

name: Aspartate AminoTransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene in S288C, but essential in the Sigma1278b background; S288C null mutant displays a decreased growth rate and decreased competitive fitness in rich medium, temperature sensitivity, and a decreased respiratory growth rate; null mutant is sensitive to DNA synthesis inhibitors, DNA damaging agents and topoisomerase inhibitors; null mutant has decreased resistance to hyperosmotic stress, metals, and zymolyase; null mutant displays decreased chronological lifespan; homozygous null mutant has decreased sporulation efficiency
function: L-aspartate:2-oxoglutarate aminotransferase that binds pyridoxal phosphate; involved in amino acid metabolism ; localizes to mitochondria, peroxisome and cytsol

name: Branched-chain Amino acid Transaminase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness in rich media containing 6% ethanol, and decreased fitness in minimal medium; null mutant has increased resistance to stress caused by zinc deficiency, and increased resistance to the antifungal agent miconazole; null mutant displays decreased levels of isobutanol, amyl alcohol and isoamyl alcohol
function: Branched-chain amino acid aminotransferase involved in both the biosynthesis and degradation of branched chain amino acids, such as leucine, isoleucine and valine; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: AnTioXidant
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants show decreased competitive fitness, poor anoxic growth, are impaired in respiration, sensitive to cycloheximide, curcumin, antifungal ciclopirox olamine, and cardiovascular drug amiodarone; heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to starvation
function: Copper chaperone involved in cellular response to oxidative stress and iron ion homeostasis; localizes to the cytosol

name: SuperOxide Dismutase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires lysine and methionine, displays a respiratory growth defect and decreased chronological and replicative lifespan, and is sensitive to a variety of environmental stresses including oxidative stress, desiccation, alkaline pH, and the presence of various chemicals; in large-scale studies the null mutant displays altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Superoxide dismutase involved in copper and zinc homeostasis, superoxide metabolism, cell aging, cell wall organization, regulation of cellular respiration, and regulation of transcription in response to oxidative stress; localized to the nucleus, cytosol, and mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: DnaJ Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction-of-function mutant has fewer and smaller peroxisomes, and mislocalizes peroxisomal reporter proteins in the cytoplasm; in systematic studies null mutant becomes sensitive to fatty acids, whereas overexpression severely hinders vegetative growth
function: Cytosolic protein that facilitates protein import into both peroxisomes and the mitochondrial outer membrane

name: ASParaginase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in competitive-growth studies null mutant shows reduced fitness; in systematic studies null mutant has lower rate of utilization of ammonium as nitrogen source
function: L-asparaginase; catalyzes the hydrolysis of L-asparagine to aspartic acid and ammonia during asparagine catabolism; localizes to the cytosol

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function increases sensitivity to rapamycin; conditional mutants are subject to chromosome instability at semi-permissive temperature, arrest in G1 as unbudded cells with a single nucleus at elevated temperatures; overexpression slows vegetative growth, enhances pseudohyphal growth; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient, sensitive to protein synthesis inhibitor tavaborole
function: Leucine-tRNA ligase required for synthesis of leucyl-tRNA; also involved in regulation of cell growth through control of the TOR signaling pathway; localized to the cytoplasm

name: SEryl-tRNA Synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, overexpression causes slow growth
function: Seryl-tRNA synthetase that performs seryl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling serine to seryl-tRNA; localizes to cytoplasm

name: D-Lactate Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits abnormal actin cytoskeleton morphology, defects in cytokinesis and increased extracellular levels of lactate; overexpression results in decreased F-actin levels and multibudded cells with elongated bud necks; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to copper, amidarone, MMS
function: D-2-hydroxyglutarate (D-2HG) dehydrogenase that oxidizes D-2HG to alpha-ketoglutarate; minor D-lactate dehydrogenase activity involved in lactate catabolism; localizes to the mitochondrial matrix

name: D-Arabinono-1,4-Lactone Oxidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is hypersensitive to oxidative stress and shows increased genome instability; overexpression increases resistance to oxidative stress and decreases growth rate

name: Daughter Specific Expression
function: Protein involved in cell separation after cytokinesis, invasive growth under limited glucose conditions, and regulation of signal transduction during mating; associates with the Ste4p (Gbeta)/Ste18p (Ggamma) complex, and with the MAPKKK, Ste11p

name: Daughter Specific Expression
function: Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

name: Daughter Specific Expression
function: Glucan endo-1,3-beta-D-glucosidase involved in cell separation after cytokinesis; localizated to the cell wall, cell septum and extracellular region

name: Daughter Specific Expression
function: Glucosidase involved in cell separation and pseudohyphal growth; localized to the cell wall and extracellular region

name: Dead Box Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutation confers slow growth at permissive temperature; reduction-of-function mutations in systematic studies confer increased resistance to cycloheximide and increased sensitivity to MMS and hydroxyurea

name: Protein Associated with Topoisomerase II
function: Protein that binds RNA, mRNA, and chromatin; subunit of the Lsm1-7-Pat1 complex; involved in deadenylation-dependent decapping of nuclear-transcribed mRNA, cytoplasmic mRNA processing body assembly, translation preinitiation complex formation, and regulation of translational initiation; localizes to the cytoplasm, cytoplasmic stress granule, cytoplasmic mRNA processing body, nucleus, and kinetochore

name: Homolog of Fatty aldehyde Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to extracellular sphingosine and dihydrosphingosine
function: 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde dehydrogenase; contributes to ubiquinone biosynthesis from tyrosine and to sphingolipid metabolism; localized to lipid droplets and integral to mitochondrial outer membrane

name: Proline UTilization
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to utilize proline as a nitrogen source and becomes growth-inhibited by proline; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness, shortened chronological lifespan, and sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress
function: 1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate dehydrogenase involved in proline degradation to glutamate; localizes to mitochondrial matrix

name: PROline requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for proline and fails to grow in standard rich medium (YPD) without proline supplementation; conditional (ts) mutant shows chromosome instability
function: Pyrroline-5-carboxylate reductase involved in proline biosynthesis; localizes to cytoplasm

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant cannot synthesize ergosterol but accumulates zymosterol; null mutant fails to exhibit lifespan extension under caloric restriction and is sensitive to metals and alkaline pH; overproduction leads to abnormal nuclear and actin cytoskeletal morphology; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits reduced competitive fitness and sensitivity to various drugs, but increased resistance to azole antifungal drugs and amphotericin B
function: Sterol 24-C-methyltransferase; catalyzes the conversion of zymosterol to fecosterol in the presence of S-adenosyl-L-methionine, a reaction in the biosynthesis of ergosterol; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum, lipid droplets and the mitochondrial outer membrane in high-throughput studies

name: tRNA MODification
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits reduced respiratory growth and shows sensitivity to 5-FU at high temperatures; in large-scale studies, the null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness in a variety of media, decreased endocytosis, lower resistance to starvation or hyperosmotic stress, and decreased tRNA gene-mediated silencing
function: tRNA dimethylallyltransferase; involved in tRNA modification and tRNA gene-mediated silencing; localizes to the cytosol, nucleus, nucleolus, and mitochondrion

name: OLEic acid requiring
phenotype: Essential gene under standard conditions; null mutant is viable with oleic acid supplementation; heat-sensitive mutant requires oleic acid at restrictive temperature but displays abnormal distribution of mitochondria even at permissive temperature; overexpression confers increased resistance to ethanol; in large-scale studies, overexpression causes increased invasive growth
function: Stearoyl-CoA 9-desaturase involved in unsaturated fatty acid biosynthesis; catalyzes conversion of stearoyl-CoA to oleoyl-CoA in the presence of ferrocytochrome b5; involved in mitochondrial inheritance; integral endoplasmic reticulum membrane protein

name: clathrin Adaptor Protein complex Large chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in vacuolar protein transport and shows some vacuolar fragmentation; also shows abnormal accumulation of polyphosphates and excretion of inositol; null mutant is also sensitive to Congo Red, caffeine, camptothecin, caspofungin, fluconazole, rapamycin
function: Subunit of the AP-3 adaptor complex that functions in golgi to vacuole transport

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations)
function: Subunit of the central stalk of the F1 catalytic core of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: dCMP Deaminase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutants exhibit dUMP and dTMP auxotrophy and resistance to 5-fluoro-2-deoxycytidylate

name: DeoxyhYpusine Synthase
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion leads to cell cycle arrest at G1 in a large-scale study
function: Deoxyhypusine synthase involved in modification of peptidyl-lysine to peptidyl-hypusine; localizes to cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: DUTp pyrophosphatase
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant can be rescued by exogenous thymidylate (dTMP); reduction-of-function mutants show cell cycle arrest at G2/M transition, decreased exponential growth rate and increased mutation frequency
function: dUTP diphosphatase and dITP diphosphatase; involved in dUTP and dITP degradation; localizes to cytoplasm and nucleus in high-throughput studies

name: BIOtin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has increase competitive fitness in minimal medium; null mutant displays a reduced ability to utilize glutamine as nitrogen source; null mutant displays increased sensitivity to the biotin vitamers 7,8-diaminopelargonic acid and 7-keto-8-aminopelargonic; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: DiacylGlycerol Acyltransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in reduced level of triglycerides and abnormal morphology of lipid particles; overexpression causes elevated lipid accumulation; mutants in systematic studies show decreased anaerobic growth, elevated polyphosphates, increased sensitivity to flucytosine, and reduced competitive fitness

name: DiacylGlycerol Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased replicative lifespan; overexpression causes heat sensitivity and abnormal nuclear morphology; in systematic studies mutants show increased sensitivity to hydroxyurea, caffeine, cycloheximide, camptothecin, bleomycin and DMSO

name: AP4A phosphorylase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows sensitivity to myriocin and small vacuolar fragmentation; in large-scale studies homozygous null mutant diploid is sensitive to soraphen A and cerulenin

name: DIcarboxylic amino acid Permease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness, and decreased budding index, slow respiratory growth and sensitivity to Calcofluor White, benomyl, hygromycin B in diploids

name: DihydroFolate Reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant in some strain backgrounds shows adenine, histidine, methionine and dTMP auxotrophy, and inability to grow under respiratory growth conditions; overexpression confers resistance to methotrexate; mutants in S288C strain is inviable in a systematic study and repression leads to cell cycle defects and increased frequency of chromosome loss

name: LiPoamide Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in respiratory growth and sensitive to canavanine and dipyridyl disulfide
function: Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase, subunit of mitochondrial alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and pyruvate dehydrogenase complexes; involved in metabolism of 2-oxoglutarate, pyruvate, and several amino acids

name: alpha-KetoGlutarate Dehydrogenase
function: Subunit of mitochondrial alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, involved in tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle

name: URAcil requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires uracil, is sensitive to 5-fluorouracil, and is resistant to N-carbamoyl-L-aspartic acid; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows increased competitive fitness in minimal media and reduced competitive fitness in several other media; null mutant displays sensitivity to anoxia and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals; diploid homozygous null mutant displays increased innate thermotolerance and resistance to oxidative stress
function: Dihydroorotate dehydrogenase involved in 'de novo' pyrimidine biosynthesis; localizes to cytoplasm and membranes

name: DihydroxyAcetone Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to dihydroacetone (glycerone); in systematic studies, mutants show poor growth under anaerobic conditions; overexpression in strain Sigma1278b leads to greatly increased filamentous growth
function: Glycerone kinase involved in glycerol catabolism and cellular response to toxins; unknown localization

name: Dipeptidyl AminoPeptidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutation causes slightly reduced competitive fitness and decreased growth under anaerobic conditions

name: Heat Shock Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased thermotolerance, shortened replicative lifespan, and increased loss of [PSI+] prion; overexpression slow growth and increased resistance to rapamycin
function: Adenosine-binding protein chaperone involved protein folding, unfolding and refolding, cellular heat acclimation, and the inheritance of oxidatively modified proteins during replicative cell aging; localized to the nucleus and cytoplasm; subunit of the TRC endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane insertion complex

name: DATin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutation causes reduced competitive fitness and decreased biofilm formation

name: ARS-Binding Factor 1
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression variously reported to cause sensitivity to nocodazol, decreased growth rate, or lethality; conditional mutants show delayed progression through G2 phase
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor; involved in chromatin silencing and remodeling; binds replication origins and is involved in DNA replication; subunit of nucleotide-excision repair factor 4 complex

name: DNA Damage Inducible
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased protein secretion; in systematic studies null mutation increases chronological lifespan and competitive fitness, and slows down vegetative growth rate

name: DNA Damage Responsive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased survival in the presence of gold nanoparticles; in systematic studies mutants show sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress and to myriocin

name: DnaJ-like protein of the ER Membrane
Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations cause cell cycle arrest in S phase, increased mutation frequency and decreased resistance to MMS and X rays
function: DNA ligase, catalyzes formation of phosphodiester bonds between polydeoxyribonucleotides; required for joining DNA ends in DNA repair, recombination and in Okazaki fragment processing during DNA replication, localized to the nuclear replication forks and to mitochondria

name: eNdonuclease Three-like Glycosylase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased mutation rate and fails to increase mitochondrial genome copy number after oxidative stress;

name: O-6-MethylGuanine-DNA methylTransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows cell cycle arrest at G1/S transition at elevated temperature and is sensitive to DNA-affecting drugs (MMS, MMNG)
function: Methylated-DNA-[protein]-cysteine S-methyltransferase that contributes to DNA dealkylation involved in DNA repair; localizes to nucleus

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional class B sec mutant displays reduced N-linked glycosylation and secretion of carboxypeptidase Y, invertase, and alpha-factor; incorporation of myo-inositol and palmitic acid into GPI-membrane anchored proteins is decreased at restrictive temperatures; conditional mutant has reduced membrane levels of dolichyl phosphate, elevated cell wall chitin levels, and decreased resistance to calcofluor white and caspofungin; overexpression results in elevated colony sectoring due to increased mini-chromosome loss; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Dolichol kinase involved in dolichyl monophosphate biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum, putatively integral to membrane in high-throughput studies

name: Dolichol Phosphate Mannose synthase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants display impaired N- and O-linked glycosylation, and decreased incorporation of myo-inositol into GPI-membrane anchored proteins; conditional mutant has an aberrant cell wall structure, increased chitin deposition and increased sensitivity to calcofluor white and to cell wall, and plasma membrane-directed antifungal agents; conditional mutant displays elevated phosphorylation of Slt2p, a measure of activation of the cell wall integrity pathway; repressible allele has an abnormal mitochondrial morphology
function: Dolichyl-phosphate mannose synthase that catalyses the formation of the mannosyl donor required for the production of dolichol-linked oligosaccharides used in glycosylation, as well as the glycolipid core required for GPI anchor biosynthesis; localizes to the nuclear envelope-endoplasmic reticulum network

name: Asparagine Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to reducing agents such as mercaptoethanol and DTT; null mutant has increased replicative and chronological lifespans and is resistant to killer toxin HM-1; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reductions in competitive fitness, desiccation resistance, vegetative growth, and respiratory growth
function: Alpha-1,3-mannosyltransferase that transfers a mannose residue to an oligosaccharide; involved in protein glycosylation and the assembly of oligosaccharide-lipid intermediates; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Derepression of ITR1 Expression
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in large-scale studies null mutant displays inositol auxotrophy, decreased competitive fitness and increased chronological lifespan; null mutant diploid shows abnormal unipolar budding pattern
function: Dolichyl-phosphate-glucose-glycolipid alpha-glucosyltransferase; involved in dolichyl-linked oligosaccharide biosynthesis and protein N-linked glycosylation; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: CAlmodulin-dependent in cmd one two twenty-siX
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation inteferes with protein N-linked glycosylation that leads to cell wall defects and sensitivity to cell-wall affecting chemical Calcofluor White; null mutant also displays sensitivity to hygromycin B, thymol, tacrolimus, and resistance to vanadate

name: Yeast vaccinia virus VH1 Homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have small cell size, decreased competitive fitness, increased replicative lifespan, and exhibit defects in rRNA processing, glycogen accumulation, endocytosis, and protein localization; null mutatns are also sensitive to cold, acetolactate synthase inhibitor sulfometuron methyl, antioxidant spermine, antimicrobial hygromycin B, and radical scavenger dimethyl sulfoxide; homozygous diploid null mutants are resistant to zymocin and to zinc deficiency, but sensitive to TOR inhibitor rapamycin, reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol, antimicrobial doxorubicin, and carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene; homozygous diploid nulls are also impaired in cell cycle progression, meiosis, sporulation, and fermentative growth, but have increased lifespan; overexpression slows growth
function: Protein tyrosine/serine/threonine phosphatase involved in cAMP-mediated signaling, ribosomal large subunit assembly, spore wall assembly, and meiotic nuclear division; positively regulates pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS) formation upon nitrogen starvation and rapamycin treatment

name: Meiosis and Centromere regulatory Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased growth rate, is thermosensitive and has reduced innate thermotolerance; null displays elevated rates of mitotic chromosome loss at semi-permissive temperatures and in the presence of benomyl; homozygous null mutant has delayed and reduced sporulation, with defects in ascus maturation; null mutant has a reduced critical cell size at START, delayed mitotic exit and elevated Clb2p-Cdc28p activity; null mutant is sensitive to DNA damaging agents, ionic, oxidative, and hyperosmotic stress; heterozygous null is haploinsufficient; overexpression increases filamentous growth and results in bud elongation
function: Protein serine/threonine/tyrosine kinase involved in protein phosphorylation and breakdown; cyclin-binding protein; implicated in double-strand break repair via nonhomologous end joining, meiotic nuclear division, and mitotic chromosome segregation; involved in in ascospore formation and the cellular response to heat and salt stress

phenotype: Non-essential gene; in large-scale studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness, decreased growth rate, increased sensitivity to heat, Congo Red, 5-fluorouracil; homozygous null mutant diploid shows sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including sorbate, benomyl, caffeine, rapamycin, DTT

name: BUD site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene, largely overlaps another gene, RPL39; in systematic studies null mutant diploid shows abnormal random budding pattern, reduced competitive fitness, and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin and DTT, which are phenotypes shared with rpl39 null mutants; in another large-scale study null mutant shows decreased cell size

name: BUD site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene, largely overlaps an essential gene, RPC53; in systematic studies null mutant diploid shows abnormal random budding pattern, reduced competitive fitness, and increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals

name: BUD site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene, largely overlaps another gene, RPL22A; in systematic studies null mutant diploid shows abnormal random budding pattern, reduced competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, Congo Red, and multiple other chemicals, which are phenotypes shared with rpl22a null mutants

name: Vacuolar Protein Sorting
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in vacuolar protein sorting, resulting in decreased processing, missorting, and secretion of hydrolases; null mutant displays decreased endocytosis, a fragmented vacuolar morphology, fewer but enlarged peroxisomes and an altered endocytic vesicle distribution; null mutant is temperature sensitive and exhibits decreased ionic, oxidative and hyperosmotic stress resistance; null mutant has a respiratory growth defect, a reduced rate of nitrogen utilization and increased starvation induced mitophagy
function: GTPase involved in vacuolar protein sorting, protein retention in Golgi apparatus, peroxisome organization and fission, endocytosis, and actin cytoskeleton organization; localizes to the vacuole membrane, late endosome, peroxisome, and actin cortical patch

name: DyNaMin-related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits reduced autophagy and apoptosis, and increased chronological lifespan; null mutant has aberrant mitochondrial and peroxisomal morphology; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness in several media, reduced desiccation resistance and innate thermotolerance, lower spore viability, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: GTPase with homodimerization activity; involved in the localization, organization, fission, and inheritance of the mitochondrion; also involved in chronological cell aging, macroautophagy, and peroxisome organization and fission; localizes to the cytosol, peroxisome, and mitochondrial outer membrane

name: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Alpha
function: Pyruvate dehydrogenase (acetyl-transferring) subunit of the mitochondrial pyruvate dehydrogenase complex; involved in acetyl-CoA biosynthesis from pyruvate and pseudohyphal growth; also associates with the mitochondrial nucleoid

name: UBiquitin-Activating
function: Multifunctional, Urm1p-activating enzyme, sulfurtransferase and adenylyltransferase; catalyzes the formation of a high energy thioester bond with ubiquitin-like protein, Urm1p, the first step in protein urmylation; catalyzes the adenylation followed by thiolation of Urm1p leading to tRNA thiolation of uridine in the wobble position; involved in invasive growth and the response to oxidative stress; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: BREfeldin A sensitivity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows accelerated progression through the S phase and G1/S phase transition, increased chromosome instability, and abnormal pattern of histone acetylation; null mutation confers increased sensitivity to brefeldin A, echinocandin B, phleomycin and hydroxyurea
function: Ubiquitin protein ligase (E2,E3); involved in double strand break repair via homologous recombination, histone ubiquitination, DNA damage checkpoint, chromatin silencing and transcription from RNA Pol II promoter; localizes to the the nuclear chromatin

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates short-lived substrates of N-end rule based degradation, mis- and unfolded cytosolic quality control pathway substrates, as well as substrates of stress-induced ER-associated protein degradation; null mutant displays chromosomal instability, impaired filamentous and invasive growth, a strong vacuolar fragmentation defect, decreased competitive fitness in various media, and both decreased uptake and increased resistance to specific dipeptides; homozygous diploid null mutant has decreased resistance to gamma rays, and sporulation defects
function: E3 ubiquitin ligase; N-recognin of the UBR1-RAD6 ubiquitin ligase complex involved in the polyubiquitination step of N-end rule mediated substrate catabolism; involved in ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD) and the stress-induced homeostatically regulated protein degradation (SHRED) pathway; involved in ubiquitin-dependent degradation of misfolded cytoplasmic proteins and ribosome associated degradation (RAD) of aberrant nascent polypeptides; localizes to the cytoplasm and interacts with subunits of the 19S proteasome regulatory particle

name: Temperature dependent Organization in Mitotic nucleus or Trigger Of Mitosis
Translation Initiation Factor
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression causes an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline), sensitivity to MMS, and reduced competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant displays elevated innate thermotolerance and lower starvation resistance, and is haploinsufficient
function: Translation initiation factor involved in translational initiation, reinitiation, termination; subunit of multi-eIF and translation initiation factor 3 complexes; localizes to cytoplasmic stress granules

name: High-Copy suppressor of Rpg1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows delays in rRNA processing and reduction in Ty1 transposition, increased resistance to azoles and arsenite but sensitivity to caffeine, MMS, weak acids, tunicamycin; also shows decreased biofilm formation and reduced competitive fitness
function: Subunit of translation initiation factor eIF3 involved in cytoplasmic translation initiation and small subunit rRNA processing

name: Phosphorylation Inhibited by Long chain bases
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has an abnormal plasma membrane, with defective eisosome organization and aberrant localization of eisosome proteins; null mutant is sensitive to rapamycin and H2O2, has reduced endocytosis, and has increased innate thermotolerance; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in a variety of different media, is sensitive to osmotic stress, and has altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Lipid-binding protein involved in protein localization, endocytosis and eisosome assembly; also involved in negative regulation of protein kinase activity and the response to heat; localizes to the eisosome

name: fatty acid ELOngation
function: Fatty acid elongase involved in very long-chain fatty acid biosynthesis, sphingolipid biosynthesis and late endosome to vacuole transport via the multivesicular body sorting pathway; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Beta-GLucanase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays elevated cell wall chitin accumulation and increased sensitivity to cell wall-affecting drugs, Calcofluor White and Congo Red; overexpression causes slow growth; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness and increased accumulation of free amino acids

name: ChiTinaSe
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation blocks cell separation after mitosis; in systematic studies mutants show reduced anaerobic growth and decreased competitive fitness
function: Endochitinase that cleaves internal 1-4-beta bonds between N-acetyl-D-glucosamine moieties within chitin chains; involved in cell separation after cytotokinesis; localized to the cell wall at bud necks and to extracellular region

name: Lethal in the Absence of SSD1-v
Rna 3'-terminal phosphate Cyclase Like
function: An endoribonuclease involved in endonucleolytic cleavage during rRNA processing, localized to the nucleuolus

name: Der1-like Family Member
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates misfolded substrates for ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD); in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness and increased levels of intracellular copper and sulfur

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays slow growth and abnormal sterol distribution; in systematic studies null mutants display random budding pattern, small cell size and sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including miconazole, hydroxyurea, camptothecin, caffeine, ethanol, tetracycline, streptomycin, paromomycin

name: Calcium Sensitive Growth
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates unmannosylated sphingolipids (ceramide and inositol phosphoceramide, IPC) instead of mannosylated forms, MIPC and M(IP)2C; mutants accumulate calcium and show increased sensitivity to extracellular calcium; in systematic studies mutants show decreased competitive fitness and sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including ethanol, acetaldehyde, hydrogen peroxide, hydroxyurea, caffeine, tunicamycin, azoles
function: Regulatory subunit for mannosylinositol phosphorylceramide (MIPC) synthase; required for biosynthesis of mature sphingolipids; integral to the ER membranes

name: Yeast Endoplasmic reticulum Transmembrane protein
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum and colocalizes with the ribosome, in large-scale studies

name: COnserved Sequence
function: Protein predicted to have a role in the multivesicular body sorting pathway and to localize to the endosome

name: COnserved Sequence
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies mutants exhibit increased resistance to organochloride insecticides dieldrin and toxaphene, but increased sensitivity to pentachlorophenol and flucytosine
function: Protein predicted to have a role in the multivesicular body sorting pathway; localizes to the endosome; detected in the vacuole and vacuole membrane in different large-scale studies

name: COnserved Sequence
function: Protein predicted to have a role in the multivesicular body sorting pathway; localizes to the endosome; localizes to the cytoplasm, the nucleus and the vacuole membrane in large-scale studies

name: COnserved Sequence
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutation increases competitive fitness; in strain Sigma1278b null mutation decreases filamentous growth and prevents invasive growth
function: Protein predicted to have a role in the multivesicular body sorting pathway; localizes to the endosome; localizes to the vacuole in a large-scale study

name: COnserved Sequence
function: Protein predicted to have a role in the multivesicular body sorting pathway; localizes to the nuclear envelope; predicted to localize to the endosome

name: COnserved Sequence
function: Protein with a role in the multivesicular body sorting pathway; localizes to the endosome; detected in the vacuole in a large-scale study

name: Cell Division Cycle
function: Subunit of the Cdc50p-Drs2p phospolipid flippase complex that is involved in phospholipid translocation, endocytosis and other cellular processes; localizes to the late-golgi and late endosome membrane

name: SYNtaxin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; vacuolar protein import is defective in the null mutant; null mutant has higher resistance to low pH

name: Vacuolar Protein Sorting
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays chromosome instability, reduced respiratory growth and autophagy, sensitivity to Cd2+, and resistance to Ni2+; mutant accumulates abnormal membrane stacks; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness in several different media, shorter chronological lifespan, abnormal lipid particle morphology, sensitivity to heat and desiccation, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Endosomal retromer complex subunit involved in retrograde transport of membrane-bounded vesicles from endosomes back to the trans-Golgi network where they are recycled for further rounds of transport

name: ENOlase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays fragmented vacuoles; in large-scale studies the null mutant exhibits decreased endocytosis and increased competitive fitness; heterozygous null mutant exhibits haploinsufficiency
function: Phosphopyruvate hydratase; catalyzes the hydrolysis of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate during glycolysis and the reverse reaction during gluconeogenesis; localized to mitochondria and vacuoles

name: ENOlase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays fragmented vacuoles; in a large-scale study, overexpression causes a G1 phase delay or arrest
function: Phosphopyruvate hydratase; catalyzes the hydrolysis of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate during glycolysis and the reverse reaction during gluconeogenesis; localized to mitochondria and vacuoles

name: Temperature-sensitive Suppressors of Csg2 mutants
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutant has smaller piecemeal microautophagy of the nucleus blebs and vesicles; in large-scale studies, repression confers increased competitive fitness, resistance to myriocin, and sensitivity to HU and MMS; overexpression confers slow growth
function: Oxidoreductase involved in metabolism of very long chain fatty acids, which have a chain length greater than C22; localizes to mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum membranes

name: ADEnine
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to cisplatin and shows increased competitive fitness
function: Inosine monophosphate (IMP) cyclohydrolase and phosphoribosylaminoimidazolecarboxamide (AICAR) formyltransferase involved in purine nucleotide and 'de novo' IMP biosynthetic processes; also involved in aerobic respiration and ascospore formation; localized to the cytosol

name: ADEnine
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to cisplatin, shows increased chromosome instability and decreased competitive fitness
function: Inosine monophosphate (IMP) cyclohydrolase and phosphoribosylaminoimidazolecarboxamide (AICAR) formyltransferase involved in purine nucleotide and 'de novo' IMP biosynthetic processes; localized to the cytosol and the plasma membrane

name: ADEnine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays adenine auxotrophy; in large-scale studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness, shortened chronological lifespan and lower innate thermotolerance
function: Putative phosphoribosylamine-glycine ligase and phosphoribosylformylglycinamidine cyclo-ligase likely to be involved in purine nucleobase metabolic process; localized to the cytoplasm

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to grow on non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory growth defect; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to Congo Red, MMS, rapamycin, but resistant to miconazole, and show reduced competitive fitness
function: Subunit of the central stalk of the F1 catalytic core of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Epsin N-Terminal homology
function: Clathrin and ubiquitin binding protein; localizes to the early endosome; involved in actin filament organization and actin patch assembly, and endocytosis

name: Epsin N-Terminal homology
function: Clathrin binding protein, that localizes to the mating projection tip; involved in actin filament organization and actin patch assembly, and endocytosis
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum in a large-scale study

name: GlycosylPhosphatidylInositol anchor biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; repression of expression causes actin cytoskeletal abnormalities; in large-scale studies, mutants show slow growth rate and increased telomere length and K28 killer toxin resistance
function: GPI-anchor transamidase subunit of GPI-anchor transamidase complex; involved in attachment of GPI anchor to protein

name: GlycosylPhosphatidylInositol anchor biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression of expression causes decreased competitive fitness; heterozygous null mutant has lower starvation resistance and is haploinsufficient
function: Mannose-ethanolamine phosphotransferase involved in GPI anchor biosynthesis in the endoplasmic reticulum

name: GlycosylPhosphatidylInositol anchor biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression of expression causes increased competitive fitness, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, sensitivity to HU, and cytokinesis defects; heterozygous null mutant has lower starvation resistance and is haploinsufficient
function: Mannose-ethanolamine phosphotransferase involved in GPI anchor biosynthesis in the endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: GlycosylPhosphatidylInositol anchor biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression of expression causes decreased competitive fitness and confers Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); overexpression enhances filamentous growth; conditional mutant exhibits increased resistance to K28 killer toxin
function: N-acetylglucosaminylphosphatidylinositol deacetylase involved in GPI anchor biosynthesis; localizes to cytoplasm, endoplasmic reticulum, and putatively integral to membrane in high-throughput studies

name: Degradation in the Endoplasmic Reticulum
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in increased prion formation and increased replicative lifespan; mutants in systematic studies show increased sensitivity to myriocin and quinine

name: Three Calcium and lipid Binding domains (TriCalBins)
PEroXisome related
function: Endoplasmic reticulum and peroxisomal membrane protein involved in the organization and ER-derived biogenesis of peroxisomes

name: MultiVesicular Body sorting factor of 12 kilodaltons
SECretory
function: Subunit of the exocyst complex which mediates the targeting and tethering of post-Golgi secretory vesicles containing exocytic cargo to sites of exocytosis at the plasma membrane

name: SECretory
function: Subunit of the exocyst complex which mediates the targeting and tethering of post-Golgi secretory vesicles containing exocytic cargo to sites of exocytosis at the plasma membrane; interacts directly with the active, GTP-bound form of Sec4 (Rab GTPase); localizes to sites of polarized growth

name: DIMethylase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants have opi- phenotype (excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); overexpression causes slow growth
function: Putative rRNA (adenine-N6,N6-)-dimethyltransferase; contributes to the maturation of SSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA) and rRNA modification; localizes to 90S preribosome in high-throughput studies

name: PTPLA Homolog involved in Sphingolipid biosynthesis 1
Mitotic Chromosome Determinant
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant has a mitotic delay, with loss of viability, chromosome segregation defects, and chromosomal instability; conditional mutant has increased sensitivity to UV radiation, gamma rays and nocodazole and abnormal spindle morphology
function: Subunit of the nuclear mitotic cohesion complex; binds chromatin; involved in establishment of mitotic sister chromatid cohesion and mitotic chromosome condensation; involved in DNA unwinding during DNA replication, DNA damage response, double-strand break repair, and apoptosis

name: Actin-Related Protein
phenotype: Essential/non-essential gene; null mutant has been reported to be either viable, poorly germinating and slow growing or inviable in S288C; conditional mutant arrests randomly and loses viability at elevated temperature; conditional mutant exhibits decreased actin-cortical patch motility, accumulates aggregates and immobile cables, and replaces cortical actin patches by bundle-like structures; conditional mutant is benomyl sensitive; reduction of function allele has decreased telomere length; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: Actin-Related Protein
phenotype: Essential/non-essential gene; null mutant has been reported to be either viable and slow growing or inviable in S288C; conditional mutant arrests non-uniformly and loses viability; conditional mutant displays abnormal actin cytoskeleton morphology, abnormal bud morphology, a random budding pattern in both haploids and diploids, abnormal chitin deposition, defective endocytosis and sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress; conditional mutant displays decreased mitochondrial movement velocity, loss of directed movement, and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; homozygous conditional diploid has a defect in spore wall formation and a severe sporulation defect; hypomorphic DAmP allele has reduced telomere length

name: Conserved Oligomeric Golgi complex
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits slow growth and heat sensitivity; in systematic studies mutants show decreased anaerobic growth, abnormally round buds and shorter chronological lifespan
function: Bridging protein involved in the Golgi organization, retrograde transport and CVT pathways; localizes to the Golgi transport complex

name: Conserved Oligomeric Golgi complex
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes delays in vacuolar transport; reduction of function confers sensitivity to MMS
function: Protein involved in vesicle transport within the Golgi and between Golgi and ER; also involved in CVT pathway, macroautophagy and pexophagy; part of the Golgi transport complex

name: Conserved Oligomeric Golgi complex
phenotype: Essential gene in a systematic study; mutants show severely decreased growth rate and defects in protein secretion and vacuolar transport; haploinsufficient, heterozygous null mutant diploids have chromosome instability and hypersensitivity to several drugs, including aureobasidin A, rapamycin and others
function: Protein transporter involved in vesicle transport within the Golgi and between Golgi and ER; also involved in CVT pathway, macroautophagy and pexophagy; part of the Golgi transport complex

name: Conserved Oligomeric Golgi complex
phenotype: Essential gene in a systematic study; null mutant has severely decreased growth rate at normal temperatures and fails to grow at reduced temperatures
function: Protein involved in vesicle transport within the Golgi and between Golgi and ER; also involved in CVT pathway, macroautophagy and pexophagy; part of the Golgi transport complex and localizes to membranes

name: Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
Essential for Maintenance of the cell Wall
Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations cause reduced accumulation of mitochondrial proteins; in large-scale studies, repression confers sensitivity to MMS and resistance to myriocin; diploid heterozygous null mutant displays chromosome instability and is sensitive to ethidium bromide
function: Protein channel that binds mitochondrial targeting peptide sequences to localize proteins within mitochondria; subunit of the Tim22 complex which is embedded in the mitochondrial inner membrane and mediates insertion of carrier proteins into the inner membrane

name: Repressor/Activator site binding Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; reduced function mutants have decreased fitness, long telomeres increased telomeric silencing, and are sensitive to DNA-damaging agent MMS; overexpression slows growth
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription activator and repressor; activates expression of genes involved in glycolysis; involved in chromatin silencing, establishment of protein localization to chromatin and telomere maintenance; localizes to the cytosol and nucleus

name: MiniChromosome Maintenance
function: Component of the MCM mini-chromosome maintenance complex involved in initiation and regulation of DNA replication; also involved in pre-replicative complex assembly and double-strand break repair; binds DNA replication origins and single-stranded DNA

name: Associated with Microtubules and Essential
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat sensitive, arresting in anaphase at the restrictive temperature, and displays reduced vegetative growth at permissive temperatures; conditional, repressible and heterozygous null mutants display chromosomal instability, including elevated chromosome loss and chromosomal rearrangements; overexpression results in the accumulation of large-budded cells with 2C DNA content, indicative of a G2 or M phase delay or arrest

name: PhosphoaCetylglucosamine Mutase
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function causes sensitivity to starvation and several chemicals, such as benomyl, hydroxyurea, MMS, rapamycin
function: Phosphoacetylglucosamine mutase that contributes to cell wall chitin synthesis; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm in high throughput studies

name: Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to abnormal mitochondrial morphology; reduction of function causes decreased competitive fitness
function: Peripheral lid subunit of proteasome regulatory particle involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation

name: Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants accumulate polyubiquitinated proteins and show abnormal cell cycle transition through G2/M phase and increased cell size
function: Structural molecule of proteasome regulatory particle involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; subunit of proteasomal peripheral lid subcomplex

name: Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function causes senstitvity to MMS and hydroxyurea, and decreased competitive fitness; repression increased resistance to myriocin
function: Peripheral lid subunit of proteasome regulatory particle involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation

name: Factor Activating Pos9
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression increases resistance to arsenite
function: NTPase that participates in maturation of SSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); involved in response to oxidative stress; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasmic stress granules

name: Bad Response to Refrigeration
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant is cold sensitive, some alleles are also heat sensitive, and slow growing at permissive temperature; conditional mutant is sensitive to sterol biosynthesis inhibitors and membrane fluidizing agents, accumulating ergosterol, sterol precursors and monounsaturated fatty acids at reduced temperatures; conditional mutant is defective in the export of poly(A)+ mRNA, and mislocalizes nuclear pore complex (NPC) cytoplasmic filament proteins; conditional mutant has a nuclear morphology defect with abnormal nuclear envelope, and an abnormal lipid droplet arrangement with a circular patter of droplets surrounding the nucleus; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate
function: Integral membrane protein of the nuclear envelope and ER; involved in lipid homeostasis; role in nuclear export of mRNA, and nuclear envelope organization

name: MAintenance of Killer
phenotype: Essential gene; heterozygous null mutant shows decreased fitness and starvation sensitivity; temperature-sensitive mutant shows decreased levels of 25S and 5.8S rRNA under non-permissive conditions

Essential gene; reduction of function mutant has a competitive fitness defect in minimal medium; repressible mutant displays a reduced accumulation of the large ribosomal subunit (60S) and a defect in the export of the 60S subunit; conditional mutant displays a defect in the nuclear export of Mss4p; heterozygous diploid null mutant has decreased resistance to oxidative stress; overexpression results in a growth defect

name: Dead Box Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; repressible and dominant-negative mutants have decreased growth rates; repressible mutant displays a deficit in 60S ribosomal subunits accumulation; repressible mutant leads to decreased accumulation of 27S and 7S rRNA precursors, and depletion of mature 25S and 5.8S rRNA species; conditional mutant has a colony sectoring defect indicative of chromosome instability; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: ATP-dependent RNA helicase; involved in the maturation of LSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) from a tricistronic rRNA transcript; localises to 66S preribosome

name: PinX1-Related gene
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C under standard aerobic conditions but not under anaerobic conditions; in some strain backgrounds null mutation has been shown to cause extremely slow growth, accumulation of incompletely processed rRNA and snoRNA precursors, and decreased telomere length
function: Telomerase inhibitor involved in negative regulation of telomere maintenance via telomerase; localizes to nucleoplasm and nucleolus

name: Ribosome Production Factor
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants are sensitive to desiccation and to myriocin; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Protein involved in maturation of LSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and 5.8S rRNA from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); contributes to LSU precursor of preribosome; localizes to nucleolus

name: Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
Copper TRansport protein
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutations confer increased sensitivity to hydroxyurea and MMS
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in large-scale studies

name: Box C/D snoRNA accumulation
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function mutant has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium; transposon insertion mutant is unable to undergo invasive growth and has a reduction in filamentous growth; repressible mutant displays decreased accumulation of Box C/D snoRNAs; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate

name: KSH (similar to the Hungarian word for "small")
function: Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

name: NineTeen complex Related protein
function: Subunit of the U2-type post-mRNA release spliceosomal complex, a post-splicing intron-containing complex; involved in disassembly of the spliceosomal complex; localizes to the nucleus, the cytoplasm and the endoplasmic reticulum in HTP studies

name: Core Interacting Component
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutation results in chromosome instability; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Protein that binds to the rRNA of the large ribosomal subunit and proteasome; involved in the maturation of the large subunit rRNA and protein catabolic process; localizes to the nucleolus and large precursor subunit of the preribosome

name: Zinc finger PRotein
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants display sensitivity to rapamycin, MMS, cycloheximide, and other chemicals; mutant cells are enlarged, form chains, and accumulate in G2/M phase; in large-scale studies, repression causes decreased competitive fitness and sensitivity to HU
function: Translation elongation factor eEF-1 binding protein involved in cell cycle regulation and starvation response; relocalizes from cytoplasm to nucleus under DNA replication stress

name: S. cerevisiae protein involved in the Control of Ploidy
function: mRNA binding protein involved in mRNA localization, chromatin silencing at silent mating type cassette and telomere, chromosome seggregation and pheromone dependent signal transduction; localizes to cytoplasm, endoplasmic reticulum membrane and polysome

name: NUclear Pore
function: Structural constituent of the inner ring of the nuclear pore that plays a role in modulating transport through the nuclear pore complex

name: B Double Prime
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional alleles confer sensitivity to heat and cold; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient and has decreased ethanol tolerance
function: RNA polymerase III recruiting transcription factor involved in preinitiation complex assembly, open complex formation, and activation of transposon integration; subunit of the TFIIIB transcription factor complex

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; sec62-1 mutant is sensitive to paromomycin; in large-scale studies, repression causes decreased competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient and is sensitive to ascomycin
function: Component of the Sec62/Sec63 complex that is involved in the posttranslational translocation of proteins to the ER

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations decrease endocytosis and mating and cause defects in protein traffick through ER
function: Component of the Sec62/Sec63 complex that is involved in the posttranslational translocation of proteins to the ER
