name: Duo1 And Dam1 interacting
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant is haploinsufficient (slow growing) in heterozygous diploid under competitive growth conditions
function: A protein that contributes to microtubule plus-end binding involved in positive regulation of microtubule polymerization and attachment of spindle microtubules to kinetochore; localized to DASH complex

name: Duo1 And Dam1 interacting
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutation leads to defective mitotic spindles and cell cycle arrest
function: A protein that contributes to microtubule plus-end binding involved in the positive regulation of attachment of spindle microtubules to kinetochore and of microtubule polymerization; localized to DASH complex

name: Duo1 And Dam1 interacting
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant is haploinsufficient in heterozygous diploid showing significant increase in chromosome instability
function: A protein that contributes to microtubule plus-end binding involved in the positive regulation of attachment of spindle microtubules to kinetochore and of microtubule polymerization; localized to DASH complex

name: Duo1 And Dam1 interacting
phenotype: Essential gene
function: A protein that contributes to microtubule plus-end binding involved in the positive regulation of attachment of spindle microtubules to kinetochore and of microtubule polymerization; localized to DASH complex

name: T-snare affecting a Late Golgi compartment
eXoRiboNuclease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly, has large cells, abnormal morphology of vacuoles, buds and lipid particles, short telomeres, shortened lifespan, decreased transposition, and is sensitive to antimalarial quinine, various antibiotics, caffeine, metals, heat, osmotic stress; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficent and sensitive to starvation; overexpression slows growth
function: Chromatin-binding 5'->3' exoribonuclease that activates transcription initiation and elongation by RNA polymerase II; involved in nuclear mRNA catabolism and decay of nonfunctional rRNAs; role in processing of both rRNA and snoRNA; negative regulator of autophagy; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasmic stress granules and mRNA P-bodies

name: Suppressor of Kinetochore Protein mutant
function: Component of the SCF ubiquitin ligase complex, the CBF3 centromeric DNA binding complex, and the RAVE complex that regulates assembly of the V-ATPase; involved in many processes such as kinetochore assembly, exit from mitosis, SCF-dependent protesaomal ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; septin ring assembly, protein neddylation, vacuolar acidification

name: Psi+ INducibility
function: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown

name: homolog of S. pombe dis3 (chromosome DISjunction)
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to buildup of aberrant mRNA, rRNA, snRNA reporters, slow growth, and increased sensitivity to nocodazole and benomyl

name: SuperKIller
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutants display delayed exit from stationary phase and sensitivity to benomyl and hygromycin B; mutant cells are enlarged, with large drooping buds that have elongated necks; repression or conditional mutations cause lowered levels of mature 5.8S rRNA and higher levels of many different RNA processing intermediates; in large-scale studies, repression causes chromosomal instability; mutations confer sensitivity to Calcofluor White and resistance to cycloheximide; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient and sensitive to starvation
function: Subunit of both nuclear and cytoplasmic exosome (RNase complex); involved in exonucleolytic trimming of tricistronic pre-ribosomal RNA (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA) to generate mature 3'-ends of 5.8S transcripts; contributes to nonsense, non-stop, and nonsense-mediated decay and U1, U4, and U5 small nuclear RNA (snRNA) 3'-end processing

name: Ribosomal RNA Processing
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes accumulation of 35S pre-rRNA and 3'-extended forms of 5.8S rRNA and U4 and U5 snRNA; in a large-scale study, repression confers Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)
function: Subunit of both nuclear and cytoplasmic exosome (RNase complex); involved in exonucleolytic trimming of tricistronic pre-ribosomal RNA (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA) to generate mature 3'-ends of 5.8S transcripts; contributes to 3'-end processing of U1,U4,U5 small nuclear RNA (snRNA)

name: Cep1 Synthetic Lethal
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutations cause increased accumulation of unprocessed mRNA and rRNA species, increased cold and heat sensitivity and decreased competitive fitness
function: Component of exosome, which is a ribonuclease complex with 3'-5' processive hydrolytic exoribonuclease activity involved in multiple RNA processing and degradation processes, including rRNA maturation, ncRNA processing, poly(A)-dependent degradation, non-stop and nonsense-mediated mRNA decay; localized to both the nucleus and the cytoplasm

name: Ribosomal RNA Processing
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutant is sensitive to benomyl and nocodazole at the permissive temperature; ts mutation and repression cause accumulation of unprocessed RNAs; in large-scale studies, ts mutant shows chromosome instability at the semi-permissive temperature; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient, sensitive to heat and oxidative stress, and has reduced competitive fitness
function: Subunit of both nuclear and cytoplasmic exosome (RNase complex); involved in exonucleolytic trimming of tricistronic pre-ribosomal RNA (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA) to generate mature 3'-ends of 5.8S transcripts and nuclear polyadenylation-dependent RNA degradation; contributes to U4 small nuclear RNA (snRNA) and small nucleolar RNA 3'-end processing

name: INner membrane Assembly 17 kDa
function: Mitochondrial inner membrane protein and subunit of the INA complex (INAC) with a role in assembly of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase

name: INner membrane Assembly 22 kDa
function: Mitochondrial inner membrane protein and subunit of the INA complex (INAC) with a role in assembly of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase

name: FAD PYrophosphatase
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: STErile
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant of ‘a’ mating type is sterile; null mutant fails to methylate a-factor, Ras1p, or Ras2p; null mutant displays defective export of a-factor; overexpression causes proliferation of the nuclear inner membrane; in large-scale studies, null mutation confers shorter chronological lifespan and sensitivity to myriocin and CG-1521; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to starvation
function: Protein C-terminal S-isoprenylcysteine carboxyl O-methyltransferase; involved in C-terminal protein methylation and peptide pheromone maturation; localizes to nuclear inner membrane and endoplasmic reticulum membrane, integral to membrane in high-throughput studies

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations lead to ergosterol auxotrophy, increased accumulation of farnesol and decreased accumulation of squalene

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations cause ergosterol auxotrophy and excretion of prenyl alcohols; reduction of function results in increased sensitivity to hydroxyurea and MMS, and increased reistance to myriocin

name: fatty acid ELOngation
function: Fatty acid elongase involved in very long-chain fatty acid biosynthesis, sphingolipid biosynthesis and late endosome to vacuole transport via the multivesicular body sorting pathway; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Ubiquitination of Citrate synthase in the glyoxylate Cycle
Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; many conditional alleles result in a cell cycle arrest at the G1/S phase transition, but cells that are first synchronized in S phase will delay at the G2/M phase transition; a few alleles will naturally arrest at both G1/S and G2/M phase transitions; conditional mutants have an elevated rate of chromosome loss at semi-permissive temperature and increased stability of certain reporter proteins; homozygous diploids are unable to sporulate at semi-permissive temperatures
function: Subunit of the Skp1/Cul1/F-box (SCF) protein complex which contributes to proteasomal-dependent ubiquitin protein ligase activity involved in protein catabolism; required for both the G1/S and G2/M phase transitions of the mitotic cell cycle; required for meiotic nuclear division; localizes to the nucleus

name: Termination and PolyAdenylation
function: Oxidative DNA demethylase, that catalyzes the repair of methyl-base lesions by oxidative demethylation; contains poly (A) binding activity, involved in deadenylation-dependent mRNA catabolism; influences translation termination efficiency; localizes to the nucleus

name: Yeast Adrenodoxin Homolog
phenotype: Essential gene; ts allele causes a decrease in the ratio of heme A to heme B at semi-permissive temperature; repression causes decreased accumulation of uniquinone-6 and increased accumulation of ferric nanoparticles; in large-scale studies, repression confers increased competitive fitness and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; conditional mutant is sensitive to benomyl and MMS
function: NAD(P)H oxidoreductase of the mitochondrial matrix involved in the assembly of iron-sulfur clusters and the biosynthesis of ubiquinone and heme a, which is a derivative of heme found in cytochrome aa3

name: HEMe biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene on standard rich medium due to heme auxotrophy; mutant fails to respire; in large-scale studies, repressing expression confers increased competitive fitness; heterozygous null diploid shows haploinsufficiency
function: Ferrochelatase involved in the biosynthesis of heme; chelates protoheme to form protoporphyrin IX; localizes to the inner membrane of mitochondria

name: FErrous Transport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth, sensitivity to metals and alkaline pH, and is unable to grow in iron-deficient conditions

name: Anti-Suppressor in Multicopy
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to microtubule-binding drug benomyl; overexpression causes delays in cell cycle progression and abnoramal budding pattern; in systematic studies null mutant is unable to utilize non-fermentable carbon sources at elevated temperatures and displays increased sensitivity to ethanol, but increased resistance to caffeine, camptothecin, cycloheximide, fluconazole, tunicamycin

name: NUclear Pore
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays defects in nuclear export and localization of mRNAs

name: Suppressor of ACtin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly, fails to localize actin patches preferentially to growing buds, and has a severe endocytosis defect; null mutant is sensitive to metal ions and latrunculin A; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in several different media, exhibits a respiratory growth defect, and is sensitive to heat, starvation, acid pH, and K. lactis zymocin; null mutant has increased chitin deposition and is resistant to K28 killer toxin; null mutant is sensitive to a variety of chemicals
function: Actin filament binding protein involved in actin filament organization and formin-nucleated actin cable assembly; localizes to bud tips and mating projection tips in high-throughput studies

name: COenzyme Q
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to respire and exhibits sensitivity to linoleic acid; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, sensitivity to desiccation, heat, and oxidative stress, and altered resistance to various chemicals; overexpression confers enhanced invasive growth
function: Flavin-dependent monooxygenase, involved in ubiquinone biosynthesis; localizes to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Essential for Respiration and Viability
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations disrupt mitochondrial protein import and prevent respiratory growth; null mutant is viable but slow growing under anaerobic growth conditions
function: Flavin-linked sulfhydryl oxidase that contributes to protein import into mitochondrial intermembrane space; has role in iron ion homeostasis and response to oxidative stress; localizes to mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: Succinate DeHydrogenase
function: FAD-binding succinate dehydrogenase subunit of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex; involved in cellular respiration, the tricarboxylic acid cycle, and mitochondrial electron transport; localizes to the mitochondrial membrane

name: ForK head Homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, reduced silencing at mating-type loci and abnormal mating-type switching; nulls are also sensitive to heat, and exhibit altered rates of cell cycle progression through the S and G2/M phases; overexpression slows growth
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor involved in chromatin remodeling, mitotic transcription regulation, transcription termination, mating-type switching, and pseudohyphal growth; binds DNA replication origins and positively regulates replication initiation; also binds centromeres

name: High-Copy suppressor of Calmodulin
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor involved in spindle pole body organization, mitochondrion organization, and the cellular response to oxidative stress

name: Nuclear Undecaprenyl pyrophosphate Synthase
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes deficiency in protein glycosylation; in large-scale studies repression leads to cell cycle arrest in G2 phase and defects in cytokinesis; heterozygous null mutation in diploids casuses decreased innate thermotolerance and oxidative stress sensitivity
function: Forms a dehydrodolichyl diphosphate synthase complex with SRT1 or RER2; involved in dolichol biosythesis

name: Retention in the Endoplasmic Reticulum
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction of function causes abnormal ER, Golgi and vacuolar morphology and mislocalization of membrane proteins; null mutation results in severe growth defect
function: Forms a dehydrodolichyl diphosphate synthase complex with NUS1; involved in dolichol biosythesis and ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport

name: ADEnine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays adenine auxotrophy and increased chromosome instability; in large-scale studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness, increased heat sensitivity and lower innate thermotolerance
function: Phosphoribosylformylglycinamidine synthase involved in purine nucleotide and 'de novo' IMP (inosine monophosphate) biosynthetic processes; localized to cytoplasm

name: Biosynthesis of NAD
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth; in systematic studies null mutants display increased competitive fitness, extended lifespan under hibernation and elevated accumulation of free tryptophan
function: Arylformamidase involved in de novo NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan

name: Fructose-1,6-Bisphosphate Aldolase
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations confer slow growth, reduced competitive fitness, failure to sporulate, and sensitivity to MMS; overexpression causes increased filamentous growth
function: Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate aldolase; catalyzes the conversion of fructose 1,6 bisphosphate to glyceraldehyde-3-P and dihydroxyacetone-P; required for gluconeogenesis and glycolysis; localizes to the mitochondria and the cytosol

name: FUMarase
function: Fumarate hydratase (fumarase); converts fumarate to malate in the TCA cycle; localizes to the mitochondrial matrix and cytosol

name: OSMotic sensitivity
function: Fumarate reductase with a role in oxidation of FAD, which is required for oxidative protein folding in the endoplasmic reticulum; localized to both the ER and mitochondria

name: GlycosylPhosphatidylInositol
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression of expression causes decreased competitive fitness; overexpression causes slow growth; heterozygous null mutant has increased heat sensitivity
function: Dolichyl-phosphate-mannose-glycolipid alpha-mannosyltransferase involved in GPI anchor biosynthesis; localizes to mannosyltransferase complex and integral to endoplasmic reticulum membrane
Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown
Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

name: Ribosomal Protein of the Small subunit
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to increased telomere length and benomyl sensitivity; heterozygous null mutant diploid shows increased innate thermotolerance
function: Fusion protein that is cleaved to yield ubiquitin and a subunit of the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit; involved in maturation of the small subunit rRNA, assembly of the small ribosomal subunit, and translation

name: CycLiN
phenotype: Non-essential gene; dominant hyperactive alleles result in decreased critical cell size at START, decreased duration of the G1 phase, increased alpha-factor resistance, transient pheromone-induced cell cycle arrest, reduced mating efficiency; null mutants have an increased critical cell size at START, increased duration of the G1 phase, elevated chromosome instability, and increased chronological lifespan; homozygous diploid nulls have an increased sporulation efficiency and enhanced pseudohyphal growth
function: Cyclin-dependent protein kinase (CDK) regulatory subunit; regulates cell cycle passage through START by regulating transcription at the G1/S phase transcription; regulates non-autophagic vacuole fusion; localizes to the nucleus

name: CycLiN
phenotype: Non-essential gene; dominant hyperactive alleles result in decreased critical cell size at START, decreased duration of the G1 phase and decreased pheromone-induced cell cycle arrest; null mutants display decreased invasive growth, starvation resistance, chronological lifespan, endocytosis and a decreased rate of nitrogen utilization; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Cyclin-dependent protein kinase (CDK) regulatory subunit involved in regulating passage through the cell cycle, as well as cell cycle re-entry after pheromone-induced arrest; localizes to both the cytoplasm and nucleus

name: clathrin Adaptor Protein complex Large chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal, fragmented vacuoles and defects in vacuolar transport; null mutant also shows reduced respiratory growth and endocytosis
function: Subunit of the AP-1 adaptor complex that binds clathrin and functions in vesicle  mediated transport

name: glutathione (GSH)
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers glutathione auxotrophy, slow growth and increased sensitivity to oxidative stress
function: Gamma-glutamylcysteine synthetase responsible for the first step of glutathione biosynthesis; catalyzes the conversion of cysteine and glutamate to gamma-glutamylcysteine, consuming ATP; also involved in the response to hydrogen peroxide and cadmium

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants accumulate extra ER membranes and show decreased protein secretion; in large-scale studies, repression causes reduced competitive fitness, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, and sensitivity to HU and MMS; overexpression causes sensitivity to rapamycin; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to a variety of chemicals
function: COPI vesicle coat protein involved in anterograde (endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi) and retrograde (Golgi to ER) vesicle-mediated transport

name: Carboxy-Terminal domain Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation in W303 confers slow growth, sensitivity to low temperatures and abnormal nuclear morphology; in S288C null mutation lowers resistance to nickel and cadmium ions; in systematic studies performed in S288C, mutants show decreased competitive fitness and increased resistance to some drugs (fluconazole, bleomycin) and increased sensitivity to others (caspofungin, valinomycin), mutations also cause slow growth and increased cell size
function: Subunit of the C-terminal Domain Kinase I (CTDK-I) complex that acts as a positive transcription elongation regulator; localized to the nucleus

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows reduced survival rate in stationary phase
function: Subunit of the central stalk of the F1 catalytic core of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: TUBulin
phenotype: Essential gene; heterozygous diploid null mutants have large cells with hyperelongated spindles and chromosome instability; phosphorylation mutants have abnormal spindles; repression mutants have abnormal mitochondria and arrest in M phase; conditional mutants grow slowly, have abnormally short anaphase spindles, and are sensitive to heat; activation mutants are resistant to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl

name: General Amino acid Permease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutant takes up reduced levels of methionine, glycine, and glutamine; activated allele confers increased citrulline transport but also confers sensitivity to all amino acids except alanine and phenylalanine; in large-scale experiments, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, poor growth in the absence of oxygen, and sensitivity to various chemicals
function: Transmembrane amino acid transporter of broad specificity, involved in uptake of extracellular amino acids; integral to plasma membrane

name: dTMP-UPtake
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly, cannot respire, has decreased fitness, shortened lifespan, and is sensitive to heat, various antibiotics, antimalarial quinine; homozygous diploid null has rounded cells, abnormal budding pattern, cannot sporulate
function: General transcription repressor that binds histones and is involved in nucleosome positioning; forms repressor complex with Cyc8p

name: Complexed With Cef1p
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to accumulation of unspliced pre-mRNAs; overexpression causes increased chromosome instability
function: Component of U2-type spliceosomal complex involved in snoRNA and mRNA splicing, as well as the generation of catalytic splicesome

name: CYtochrome C
phenotype: Non-essential gene in S288C, essential gene in Sigma1278b; null grows slowly, buds in random pattern, has large rounded cells, short telomeres, decreased lifespan, and cannot respire; null is also sensitive to heat, oxidative stress, metals, acid, and antimalarial drug mefloquine; homozygous diploid null cannot sporulate
function: Chromatin-remoding transcription factor that regulates transcription by RNA polymerase II; binds histone deacetylases and is involved in nucleosome positioning; present in transcriptional repressor complex with Tup1p

name: DNA Strand Transfer
function: Core RNA polymerase II-recruiting, regulatory region DNA-binding transcription factor involved in transcription initiation, elongation, and antitermination; involved in the maintenance of transcriptional fidelity and regulation of mRNA 3-end processing; also involved in transcription from RNA pol I and III promoters; localizes to the nucleus

name: Bet Two Suppressor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to cold and shows reduced levels of geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to multiple chemicals, including Congo Red, Calcofluor White, amitrole, cyclisporin A, and show reduced competitive fitness

name: GLucoKinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has lower survival rate in stationary phase and decreased chronological lifespan
function: Glucokinase involved in glucose import, glycolysis, and mannose metabolism

name: GlucosamiNe-6-phosphate Acetyltransferase
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutation leads to chromosome instability
function: Glucosamine 6-phosphate N-acetyltransferase involved in UDP-N-acetylglucosamine biosynthesis; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: ZWischenFerment
phenotype: Non-essential gene in S288C and W303, essential gene in Sigma1278b; null mutant is auxotrophic for methionine, displays abnormal vacuolar morphology, reduced competitive fitness, and decreased resistance to both pH and oxidative stresses; null displays increased resistance to DNA-damaging agents and antivirals; heterozygous null is haploinsufficient
function: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase involved in the pentose-phosphate shunt, NADPH regeneration and carbon catabolite repression of transcription

name: ADP-Ribosylation Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormalities in polarization of actin cortical patches and abnormal budding pattern; null mutation in in Sigma1278b reduces invasive growth

name: Alcohol DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates hydrogen peroxide and superoxide and is resistant to allyl alcohol; overexpression stimulates filamentous growth
function: NAD-dependent alcohol dehydrogenase that converts ethanol to acetylaldehyde; localizes in cytoplasm

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to reducing agents such as mercaptoethanol and DTT and displays under-glycosylation of secreted proteins; in large-scale studies, the null mutant requires myo-inositol, displays rounded cell shape and decreased competitive fitness, and has altered sensitivity to a variety of chemicals
function: Alpha-1,3-glucosyltransferase that transfers glucose from dolichyl phosphate glucose (Dol-P-Glc) to lipid-linked oligosaccharide Man(9)GlcNAc(2)-PP-Dol; involved in synthesis of oligosaccharide precursor for N-linked protein glycosylation; localizes in endoplasmic reticulum

name: GLutamiNe metabolism
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C; reduction of function leads to hypoosmotic stress sensitivity rescuable by osmotic support in growth medium; non-essential gene in Sigma1278b, where null mutation causes glutamine auxotrophy and reduced filamentous growth
function: Glutamate-ammonia ligase involved in glutamine biosynthesis; localizes to nuclear periphery

name: GLutamiNe metabolism
function: Glutaminyl-tRNA synthetase that performs glutaminyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling glutamine to glutaminyl-tRNA; localizes to both the cytosol and mitochondria

name: Glutathione
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has lower amounts of intracellular glutathione, grows slowly, displays sensitivity to methylglyoxal and resistance to diamide; also shows decreased intracellular accumulation of copper, but increased accumulation of cadmium, molybdenum, nickel
function: Glutathione synthase involved in the formation of glutathione, which acts as a coenzyme for some enzymes and as an antioxidant in the protection of sulfhydryl groups in enzymes and other proteins

name: Triose-phosphate DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants are heat-tolerant, grow slowly, show decreased biofilm formation, are defective in vacuolar fragmentation, and sensitive to desiccation, mutagens, and antipsychotic drugs
function: Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (NAD+); catalyses the conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 3-phospho-D-glyceroyl-phosphate during glycolysis and the reverse reaction during gluconeogenesis; localizes to the mitochondria, lipid particles, and during stationary phase to the cell wall and cytosol; localizes to the plasma membrane in high-throughput studies

name: Triose-phosphate DeHydrogenase
function: Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase involved in glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, apoptosis, and the metabolism of reactive oxygen species; binds to promoter-associated sections of chromatin; localizes to the cytoplasm, mitochondria, lipid particles, and the cell wall

name: Triose-phosphate DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is temperature sensitive, has a decreased growth rate and reduced competitive fitness in various growth media; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus; null mutant has decreased desiccation resistance, and acid pH resistance but increased resistance to zinc deficiency; haploinsufficiency results in chromosome instability; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate, and an extended G1 phase
function: Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase involved in glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, apoptosis, and the metabolism of reactive oxygen species; binds RNA; localizes to cytoplasm, mitochondria, lipid particles, and the cell wall

name: GlyceroPhosphoCholine acyltransferase
function: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown

name: PhosphoGlucoIsomerase
function: Phosphoglucose isomerase; catalyzes the interconversion of glucose-6-phosphate and fructose-6-phosphate; involved in gluconeogenesis and glycolysis; localizes to the mitochondrion, and additionally to the cytoplasm and plasma membrane in high-throughput studies

name: POre Membrane
function: Subunit of nuclear pore transmembrane ring involved in nuclear pore organization and nucleocytoplasmic transport; contributes to spindle pole body duplication
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall

name: AnTioXidant
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a decreased ability to utilize proline as a nitrogen source; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness in minimal medium; overexpression results in decreased growth, decreased resistance to rapamycin treatment and increased accumulation of manganese ions; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Manganese ion transmembrane transporter involved in manganese ion homeostasis; localizes to the Golgi membrane

name: CASP Of Yeast
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced fitness under competitive growth conditions; in a systematic study null mutation confers sensitivity to nickel; overexpression causes decreased growth rate
function: Protein whose molecular function is unknown; involved in vesicular transport within Golgi; localizes to the Golgi membrane

name: Multicopy suppressor of Kex2 Cold sensitivity
TOS One Homolog
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall; localizes to mitochondrion and plasma membrane in different large-scale studies

name: Bypass of Sec Thirteen
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in protein cargo sorting in the ER and shows increased sensitivity to protein glycosylation-blocking drug tunicamycin, but increased resistance to cell wall-affecting drugs, Congo Red and Calcofluor White

name: Calcofluor White Hypersensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutation confers sensitivity to cell wall-affecting drug Calcofluor White; in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness and defects in endocytosis

name: STErile
phenotype: Non-essential gene; conditional mutant is alpha-factor resistant, being unable to undergo pheromone-induced cell cycle arrest, unable to form shmoos, unable to produce mating pheromone and is sterile; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate and the accumulation of large, misshapen, unbudded cells in G1 and S phase; overexpression results in activation of Fus3p and Kss1p in the absence of pheromone; mutation of a monoubiquitination site results in cells that initiate polarized growth in response pheromone stimulation more rapidly than wt
function: Signaling protein for pheromone-dependent signal transduction involved in conjugation with cellular fusion; contributes to invasive growth in response to glucose limitation, chemotropism, regulation of RNA-mediated transposition; localizes to heterotrimeric G-protein complex, plasma membrane, mating projection

name: Absence of growth Suppressor of Cyp1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in biogenesis of the large ribosomal subunit, forms enlarged cells and shows increased heat sensitivity, decreased gamma ray sensitivity and increased sensitivity to chemicals, including Calcofluor White, hygromycin B, hydroxyurea, cycloheximide, daunorubicin; null mutant is incapable of filamentous and invasive growth
function: GDP-dissociation inhibitor; interacts with and inhibits the guanine nucleotide exchange activity of Gpa2p; inhibits the glucose-mediated G-protein coupled receptor signaling pathway, and negatively regulates both translation and translational frameshifting; involved in invasive growth in response to glucose limitation; localizes to the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit

name: SuperSensiTive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows elevated sensitivity to mating pheromone and increased mating response; in systematic studies null mutation leads to increased cell size and decreased growth rate

name: Chromosome INstability
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to microtubule-affecting drugs (benomyl, nocodazole), has abnormal spindle and shows increased frequency of chromosome loss
function: GTPase activator involved in tubulin complex assembly; cellular component is unknown

name: rapid cessation of net RNA accumulation
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations result in defective nuclear import of proteins and elevated accumulation of pre-rRNA and pre-tRNA precursors; repression leads to abnormal peroxisomal morphology, sensitivity to myriocin, and opi- phenotype (excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); overexpression causes chromosome instability
function: GTPase activator that contributes to protein, RNA import into nucleus; involved in ribosomal RNA (rRNA), transfer RNA (tRNA), and ribosomal subunit export from nucleus; localizes to nucleus and cytosol and putatively integral to membrane in high-throughput studies

name: Multicopy Suppression of a Budding defect
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has lower innate thermotolerance; overexpression causes slow growth, defects in actin cytoskeleton and abnormalities in G2 phase of the cell cycle
function: GTPase activator involved in exocytosis and formin-nucleated actin cable assembly; localizes to incipient cellular bud site, bud tip and polarisome

name: homologous to RAS proto-oncogene
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased chronological and increased replicative lifespan; null mutant has a decreased rate of growth on various nitrogen sources, decreased starvation resistance, and increased competitive fitness in minimal medium; overexpression increases invasive growth, and a dominant interfering allele results in a growth defect in the absence of cAMP
function: GTPase involved in the G-protein coupled receptor signaling pathway via activation of adenylate cyclase activity; has roles in replicative cell aging and protein localization to the bud neck; localizes to the plasma membrane

name: BMh Sensitive
phenotype: Essential gene; repressible mutant undergoes growth arrest; overexpression in a homozygous diploid background results in enhanced invasive growth

name: homologous to RAS proto-oncogene
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a respiratory growth defect, displays enhanced efficiency of G1 arrest during nutrient depletion, increased accumulation of storage carbohydrates, decreased replicative but extended chronological lifespan, decreased filamentous and invasive growth, and an ability to sporulate on rich media; dominant hyperactive allele displays a loss of viability and decreased G1 arrest during nutrient depletion, fails to accumulate storage carbohydrates, has decreased replicative and chronological lifespan, a block in nitrogen starvation induced autophagy, reduced innate thermotolerance, enhanced pseudohyphal growth, and a reduction in sporulation; overexpression increases replicative lifespan and filamentous growth
function: GTPase involved in the regulation of filamentous growth and regulation of transcription in response to nutrient changes; primarily localized in the plasma membrane but has been detected in the ER membrane and mitochondria

name: Chromosome INstability
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal spindles, shows increased frequency of chromosome loss and increased cold sensitivity; null mutant is hypersensitive to microtubule-affecting drugs benomyl and nocodazole; in systematic studies null mutants are also sensitive to ethanol, fenpropimorph, bleomycin, hydroxyurea and mycophenolic acid; in strain Sigma1278b, null mutation greatly decreases filamentous growth

name: Ras HOmolog
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional class-A alleles display reduced phosphorylation of Slt2p, a measure of defective PKC cell wall integrity pathway signal transduction, while class-B alleles are defective in activation of 1,3-beta-D-glucan synthase; class-A alleles have delocalized actin patches, enlarged cells and increased cell lysis; haploinsufficiency in a heterozygous null mutant results in chromosome instability; overexpression results in G1 arrest and increased cell size
function: GTPase involved in actin cytoskeleton remodeling, cell wall organization, bud growth, and septin ring organization; positively regulates endocytosis and protein kinase C signaling; involved in regulating cell size, secondary cell septum biogenesis, exocyst localization, and non-autophagic vacuole fusion; regulatory subunit of the 1,3-beta-D-glucan synthase complex; localizes to incipient bud sites, sites of polarized growth, the peroxisome, and the Golgi apparatus

name: FOLic acid synthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant can be rescued by exogenous formyltetrahydrofolic acid; depletion causes S phase delay and increased chromosome loss; overexpression increases filamentous growth
function: GTP cyclohydrolase I; has role in folate-containing compound biosynthesis; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants accumulate Berkeley bodies and are defective in protein secretion and autophagy

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are arrested in cell cycle as large unbudded cells with abnormal nuclear morphology; show mating defects and abnormal shmoo formation even at permissive temperatures
function: Rho guanine nucleotide exchange factor for Cdc42p; involved in cellular bud site selection, septin ring organization, and regulation of mitotic exit; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, incipient bud sites, and sites of polarized growth

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits extremely slow growth, a respiratory growth defect, and accumulation of Por1p; ts mutant displays increased desiccation resistance at the restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, null mutant scored as inviable likely due to very slow growth; ts mutant is sensitive to K28 killer toxin at elevated temperature; repression confers reduced competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant shows sensitivity to starvation and to fenpropimorph
function: Guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor that contributes to mature ribosome assembly; localizes to preribosome and polysome

name: GUanylate Kinase
function: Guanylate kinase, involved in the biosynthesis of guanosine diphosphate (GDP); localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Capping Enzyme Guanylyltransferase
phenotype: Essential gene; base-substitution mutants are resistant to cycloheximide; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl; at permissive temperature, conditional mutants are sensitive to 6-azauracil and to caffeine; at elevated temperature, conditional mutants accumulate pre-mRNA and show a decrease of spliced mRNA and 7-methyl guanosine capped RNA; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Subunit of mRNA cap methyltransferase complex responsible for mRNA 5' capping; localized to the nucleus
Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

name: Stress-Seventy subfamily A
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation elevates sensitivity to ethanol and herbicide 2,4-D; in systematic studies null mutants are defective in polyphosphate accumulation and show decreased cell size
function: Putative ATPase; involved in protein folding and response to heat shock

name: Bypass Sod1p Defects
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant cells accumulate increased amounts of metal (cadmium, cobalt) ions, and show increased metal sensitivity; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness

function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to respire; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and chronological lifespan, sensitivity to desiccation, starvation, and oxidative stress, small cell size, increased biofilm formation, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: Putative protoheme IX farnesyltransferase, catalyzes conversion of protoheme to heme A in heme A biosynthesis; localized to mitochondria in high-throughput experiments

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and grows slowly on fermentable carbon sources (petite phenotype); null mutant also shows increased frequency of nonfunctional mitochondrial genome (rho- mutations); under competitive growth conditions null mutant is sensitive to oxidative stress caused by hydrogen peroxide; in systematic studies mutants exhibit reduced biofilm formation, decreased competitive fitness and resistance to miconazole

name: DAmage resistance Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates increases amounts of ergosterol precursors lanosterol and episterol; null mutant also exhibits "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutation causes increased sensitivity to azoles and MMS

name: Regulation by OXygen
function: Transcription factor that represses expression of hypoxia-induced genes in the presence of oxygen; also represses target genes during osmotic stress

name: COenzyme Q
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and shows reduced rate of necrosis-like cell death under high concentrations of mating pheromone; in systematic studies mutants exhibit elevated sensitivity to miconazole and high concentrations of ethanol, and also show decreased rate of utilization of several carbon and nitrogen sources

name: HeXoKinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slightly increased resistance to sirolimus (rapamycin) and decreased competitive fitness; overexpression causes reduced fructose consumption; null mutant is also sensitive to copper and several drugs (bleomycin, camptothecin, fenpropimorph, fluconazole, tunicamycin, mycophenolic acid)
function: Hexokinase; phosphorylates glucose, mannose, and fructose; localized in the cytoplasm but also has minor activity associated with mitochondria

name: HeXoKinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays reduced growth rate, decreased replicative lifespan and increased apoptosis; null mutation also causes sensitivity to alkaline pH, acetic acid, fluconazole, but increased resistance to caffeine, camptothecin, bleomycin
function: Hexokinase, phosphorylates D-hexoses to D-hexose-6-phosphates; involved in cellular metabolism and homeostasis of glucose, fructose and mannose; localized to cytosol, nucleus and mitochondria

name: Function Unknown Now
function: Nicotinamide riboside transmembrane transporter; localizes to the vacuole membrane

name: Plasma Membrane ATPase Related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires inositol for growth and is sensitive to calcium and magnesium ions, alkaline pH, and reducing agents; vacuoles of null mutant have multiple lobes or are fragmented; null mutant has shorter replicative lifespan and reduced mating efficiency, and accumulates excess triglycerides, sterol esters, and calcium ions; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness, desiccation resistance, heat resistance, and freeze-thaw resistance, altered resistance to various chemicals, and poor utilization of several nitrogen sources
function: Calcium and manganese-transporting ATPase involved in calcium ion transport and homeostasis, manganese ion transport, macroautophagy, and exocytosis; localizes to the Golgi membrane

name: Copper TRansport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased rate of vegetative growth; null has a decreased respiratory growth rate that can be rescued by addition of copper sulfate; null mutant displays decreased utilization of various carbon and nitrogen sources and decreased competitive fitness on various carbon sources; null mutant has decreased resistance to various metals, oxidative stress, alkaline pH, desiccation and heat shock; haploinsufficiency results in elevated chromosome instability; homozygous null mutant has a decreased sporulation efficiency; overexpression can result in either inviability or reduced growth rate, abnormal cytoskeleton morphology, and alkaline pH resistance
function: Copper ion transmembrane transporter that has role in copper ion import; localizes to plasma membrane; localizes to nucleus, cytoplasm, and putatively integral to membrane in high-throughput studies

name: PhosphoDiEsterase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has higher levels of cAMP and shows pleiotropic defects, including increased cell size, sensitivity to osmotic and oxidative stresses, cell wall defects, and inability to survive loss of mitochonrial genome (petite-negative phenotype); in Sigma1278b null mutation prevents invasive growth; overexpression causes slow growth and abnormal budding
function: 3',5'-cyclic-AMP phosphodiesterase involved in cAMP-mediated signaling; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: HeXose Transporter
function: Hexose transmembrane transporter that transports glucose, fructose, and mannose; also has pentose transmembrane transporter activity; localizes to the plasma membrane

name: PHOsphate metabolism
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to grow in low-phosphate medium, does not take up inorganic phosphate, and fails to accumulate polyphosphate; null mutant displays metal resistance; ts mutant has elevated acid phosphatase activity at elevated temperature in the presence of inorganic phosphate; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in a variety of media and has altered resistance to various chemicals
function: Inorganic phosphate transmembrane transporter involved in phosphate ion transport and polyphosphate metabolism; also has manganese ion transmembrane transporter activity and selenite:proton symporter activity involved in the transport of selenite across the plasma membrane; integral component of the plasma membrane

name: Fe TRansporter
function: High-affinity iron transporter of the plasma membrane involved in iron assimilation; also implicated in arsenate transport

name: Branched-chain Amino acid Permease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness on various synthetic media; null mutant displays reduced uptake of isoleucine, leucine, and valine in a background lacking the general amino acid permease GAP1; homozygous diploid null mutant has increased sporulation efficiency; null mutant has decreased resistance to acid pH and methylmercury chloride; overexpression results in a reduction in vegetative growth rate, and increased cold sensitivity

name: Zinc-Regulated Transporter
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, are challenged in using urea as a nitrogen source, and have low intracellular zinc levels; null mutants are sensitive to cadmium, propolis extract, gliotoxin, chelator EDTA, herbicide amitrole, suffer increased mutation frequency, and show decreased competitive fitness as haploids and diploids; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: High-affinity zinc uptake transmembrane transporter of the plasma membrane involved in zinc ion transport

name: Genetically Interacts with Ribosomal genes
function: Cytoplasmic stress-sensing translation regulator involved in the cellular response to amino acid starvation

name: Kinase-Associated Endopeptidase
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function depletes tRNA t6A modification and leads to slow growth, shortened telomeres and severe chromosome instability
function: Subunit of EKC/KEOPS complex capable of chromatin binding; contributes to telomere maintenance via recombination, transfer RNA (tRNA) modification, and chromosome organization; involved in tRNA threonylcarbamoyladenosine metabolism and positive regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II

name: Cytosolic Fe-S cluster Deficient
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function causes decreased fitness in a competitive growth study; heterozygous null mutation confers increased sensitivity to myriocin, verrucarin A, 2-deoxy-glucose, benzo[a]pyrene

Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a decreased growth rate, decreased utilization of glutamate, ribose, and is unable to grow on glycerol at elevated temperature; null mutant accumulates tRNA relative to total RNA and shows decreased silencing at tRNA genes adjacent to strong RNA pol II promoters; null mutant displays decreased biofilm formation; overexpression results in decreased vegetative growth, decreased filamentous growth and is unable to invade agar; diploid null displays decreased sporulation efficiency
function: RNA polymerase III inhibitor, involved in silencing and repression of tRNA genes; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Mitochondrial Pyruvate Carrier
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for valine, grows slowly, accumulates pyruvate, and shows decreased competitive fitness
function: Pyruvate transporter of the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Mitochondrial Pyruvate Carrier
function: Integral membrane protein of the mitochondrial inner membrane with pyruvate transporter activity

name: STErile
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits reduced mating and pheromone, sensitivity to Ni2+, and proliferation of the nuclear inner membrane; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows increased competitive fitness, decreased mating response and anaerobic growth, and abnormal secretion of Kar2p; overexpression in the Sigma1278b genetic background confers enhanced pseudohyphal growth; null mutant displays altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Metalloendopeptidase involved in the CAAX-box dependent processing and maturation of a-factor mating pheromone; localizes to both the inner nuclear membrane, and integral to the endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: Non-Histone Protein
function: DNA and nucleosome-binding protein involved in chromatin remodeling, assembly of the RNA polymerase II and III pre-initiation complexes, and maintenance of transcriptional fidelity; localizes in the nucleus

name: Non-Histone Protein
function: DNA and nucleosome-binding protein involved in chromatin remodeling, assembly of the RNA polymerase II and III pre-initiation complexes, and maintenance of transcriptional fidelity; localizes in the nucleus
Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown

name: Nucleosome Assembly Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation decreases nuclear import of histones H2A and H2B, and causes elongated buds, increased resistance to benomyl and acetate, but increased sensitivity to rapamycin; in systematic studies null mutants show increased biofilm formation, sensitivity to Calcofluor White and DMSO, and decreased anaerobic growth
function: Histone-binding and cyclin-binding protein; involved in bud growth, nucleosome assembly and disassembly, and protein import into the nucleus; involved in positive regulation of microtubule polymerization and transcription elongation; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Chaperone for Htz1/H2A-H2B dimer
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness and mild increase in sensitivity to UV and Congo Red

name: Reduced Potassium Dependency
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have abnormal vacuolar morphology, altered silencing, are impaired in respiration, mitotic recombination, mating, and are sensitive to heat and anoxia; null mutants also show increased recombination at hotspots
function: Histone deacetylase subunit of the Rpd3S, Rpd3L  and Snt2C complexes; functions as both a transcription coactivator and corepressor; regulates transcription by RNA polymerases I and II through chromatin silencing; involved in mitosis, meiosis, macroautophagy, and aging

name: NucleOlar Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to reduced levels of pre-rRNA species, increased accumulation of snRNAs and defects in small ribosomal subunits biogenesis; overexpression causes G1 phase delay and slow growth
function: A histone-glutamine methyltransferase that regulates transcription from the RNA polymerase I promoter and is involved in box C/D snoRNA 3'-end processing; found in the nucleolus and small-subunit processome

name: Histone h Two A
phenotype: Non-essential gene due to the presence of nearly identical HTA1, deletion of both HTA1 and HTA2 is lethal; null mutation of HTA2 leads to decreased competitive fitness; overexpression causes slow growth, abnormal budding index and slower G2 progression
function: DNA-binding subunit of the nuclear nucleosome; involved in chromatin assembly/disassembly and DNA repair

name: Histone h Two A
phenotype: Non-essential gene due to the presence of nearly identical HTA2, deletion of both HTA1 and HTA2 is lethal; null mutation of HTA1 causes decreased competitive fitness and sensitivity to various stresses; overexpression leads to slow growth, abnormal budding index and slower G2 progression
function: DNA-binding subunit of the nuclear nucleosome; involved in chromatin assembly/disassembly, DNA repair, tRNA gene-mediated chromatin silencing, and negative regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter

name: Histone h Two B
phenotype: Non-essential gene due to the presence of nearly identical HTB1, deletion of both HTB1 and HTB2 is lethal; null mutation of HTB1 causes slow growth, shortened chronological lifespan, decreased competitive fitness; other mutations affect mating, sporulation, and resistance to oxidative stress
function: DNA-binding subunit of the nuclear nucleosome; involved in chromatin assembly/disassembly

name: Histone h Two B
phenotype: Non-essential gene due to the presence of nearly identical HTB2, deletion of both HTB1 and HTB2 is lethal; overexpression of HTB1 causes slow growth, abnormal budding index and slower G2 progression
function: DNA-binding subunit of the nuclear nucleosome; involved in chromatin assembly/disassembly, postreplication repair, and negative regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter

name: Histone H Three
phenotype: Non-essential gene, due to the presence of two identical genes, HHT1 and HHT2; conditional mutations in cells lacking HHT1 cause slow growth, heat and cold sensitivity and increased sensitivity to 6-azauracil, benomyl, bleomycin, caffeine, camptothecin, formamide and hydroxyurea
function: DNA binding protein; involved in chromatin assembly, transcription of ribosomal RNA, global genome nucleotide-excision repair and sporulation; localizes to the nucleosome, the centromere specific nucleosome, and the replication fork protection complex

name: Histone H Three
phenotype: Non-essential gene, due to the presence of two identical genes, HHT1 and HHT2; conditional mutations in cells lacking HHT2 confer slow growth and sensitivity to 6-azauracil, benomyl, hydroxyurea and sirolimus (rapamycin)
function: DNA binding protein; involved in chromatin assembly, transcription of ribosomal RNA, global genome nucleotide-excision repair and sporulation; localizes to the nucleosome, the centromere specific nucleosome, and the replication fork protection complex

name: Histone H Four
phenotype: Non-essential gene, due to the presence of two identical genes, HHF1 and HHF2; reduction of function increases sensitivity to hydroxyurea; overexpression causes increased chromosome instability
function: DNA-binding subunit of the nuclear nucleosome; involved in chromatin assembly/disassembly, histone H3-K79 methylation, and tRNA gene-mediated chromatin silencing; also involved in sexual sporulation resulting in formation of a cellular spore

name: Histone H Four
phenotype: Non-essential gene, due to the presence of two identical genes, HHF1 and HHF2; null mutation leads to chromosome instability and decreased telomere length; overexpression causes abnormal budding index and G2 phase progression
function: DNA-binding subunit of the nuclear nucleosome; involved in chromatin assembly/disassembly, histone H3-K79 methylation, and tRNA gene-mediated chromatin silencing; also involved in sexual sporulation resulting in formation of a cellular spore

name: SET domain-containing
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes lack of methylation at Lys4 of histone H3 and lowers silencing at telomeres and HML locus; null mutants have multiple buds, defects in cell wall and increased flocculation; also show sensitivity to gamma rays, formamide and rapamycin, and lower survival rate in stationary phase
function: Subunit of the Set1C/COMPASS complex, contributes to methyltransferase activity that methylates histone H3 on lysine at position 4 (H3-K4 specific methylation); involved in chromatin silencing at telomeres and at mating type loci; localized in nucleus

name: Histone Two A Z1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays loss of silencing at telomeres and sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including azauracil, benomyl, hydroxyurea, camptothecin, mycophenolic acid; homozygous null mutant diploid shows decreased growth rate, increased frequency of chromosome loss, increased sensitivity to heat, UV and oxidative stress, and increased sporulation efficiency; in systematic studies null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness; overexpression causes abnormalities in budding, cell cycle progression and cellular morphology
function: A chromatin binding protein that regulates transcription from RNA polymerase II and is involved in chromatin remodeling and silencing at the silent mating-type cassette

name: 3-Hydroxy-3-MethylGlutaryl-coenzyme a reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased resistance to statins including mevastatin, atorvastatin and fluvastatin, has an increased chronological lifespan and decreased starvation resistance; overexpression results in increased synthesis of squalene and decreased synthesis of ergosterol, a decreased rate of vegetative growth and results in the formation of karmellae, nuclear-associated, paired membranes
function: HMG-CoA reductase that catalyzes the conversion of (R)-mevalonate and coenzyme A into (S)-3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A; involved in the biosynthesis of ergosterol and the biosynthesis of isopentenyl disphosphate; localizes to membranes of both the nucleus and the endoplasmic reticulum

name: 3-Hydroxy-3-MethylGlutaryl-coenzyme a reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to hypoxia-inducing compounds cobalt chloride hexahydrate and ferrozine; null mutant diploid shows decreased sporulation; overexpression causes abnormal ER morphology
function: HMG-CoA reductase that catalyzes the conversion of (R)-mevalonate and coenzyme A into (S)-3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A; involved in the biosynthesis of ergosterol; localizes to membranes of both the nucleus and the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Yeast Homeo-Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; overexpression impairs growth, budding, and cytoskeletal morphology; haploid null mutants exhibit abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired fitness and anaerobic growth, increased resistance to DNA-damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS), and decreased resistance to caffeine; homozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to dessication, zinc limitation, sterol biosynthesis inhibitor fenpropimorph, and antibiotic nigericin; heterozygous diploid null shows increased fitness
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor involved in the negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II during the G1/S transition of the mitotic cell cycle

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers sensitivity to copper ions and increases replicative lifespan; in systematic studies, null mutation causes inositol auxotrophy in diploid, and increased competitive fitness and increased lifespan in haploids
function: A sequence-specific transcription factor involved in the negative regulation of dipeptide transport by negative regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter; localized to the nucleus

name: LYSine requiring
function: Putative homoaconitate hydrates involved in lysine biosynthesis; localizes to mitochondria

name: LYSine
function: Putative homocitrate synthase involved in lysine biosynthesis; localizes to the nucleus

name: LYSine requiring
function: Homocitrate synthase involved in lysine biosynthesis, DNA repair and histone eviction; locates to both the nucleus and mitochondria

name: LYSine requiring
function: Mitochondrial homoisocitrate dehydrogenase involved in lysine biosynthesis

name: Stress-Seventy subfamily A
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in protein targeting to vacuoles and in maintenance of [URE3] and [PSI+] prions; homozygous diploids are sensitive to actinomycin D and show increased innate thermotolerance; overexpression in Sigma1278b causes increased invasive growth
function: Subunit of the chaperonin-containing T-complex (CCT particle, TriC) that is predicted to be an ATPase; involved in protein folding and tRNA import into nucleus under starvation conditions

name: Heat Shock Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to freeze-thaw; some point mutations cause sensitivity to heat, hyperosmotic stress, Calcofluor White, geldanamycin and radicicol, decreased competitive fitness, slow exponential growth and decreased budding
function: Unfolded protein-binding ATPase (chaperone); involved in folding of nascent proteins, mitochondrial targeting, and assembly of multiprotein complexes, such as proteasome and box C/D snoRNP; localizes in cytoplasm

name: STress Inducible
function: Hsp70 and Hsp90-binding protein and ATPase inhibitor; also binds to mRNA; involved in protein folding, localization, and targeting to the mitochondrion; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: HIStidine
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutations confer histidine auxotrophy and increased sensitivity to amitrol (aminotriazole) and metal ions
function: Imidazoleglycerol-phosphate dehydratase involved in histidine biosynthesis

name: Mitochondrial intermembrane space Import and Assembly
Helix-Extension-Helix domain
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nuclear envelope in a large-scale study

name: Inositol Polyphosphate Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly and shows defects in glycogen accumulation and increased heat sensitivity; also shows sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including caffeine, cicloheximide, DMSO, hydroxyurea, MMS, tunicamycin
function: Nuclear inositol pentakisphosphate 2-kinase involved in biosynthesis of inositol phosphate and in non-stop mRNA decay

name: INOsitol requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows inositol auxotrophy and decreased accumulation of glycogen; overexpression lowers sensitivity to alcohols
function: Inositol-3-phosphate synthase involved in myo-inositol biosynthesis; localized in cytoplasm

name: Inositol phosphoSphingolipid phospholipase C
function: Inostitol phosphosphingolipid phospholipase involved in salt stress response and sphigolipid catabolism and ceramide biosythesis; localizes to the mitochondrial outer memembrane and endoplasmic reticulum

name: Suppressor of Choline Sensitivity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has inositol auxotrophy and cold sensitivity; null mutation also leads to highly elongated cells and reduced telomeric silencing; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Phosphatidylinositol- and FFAT-motif binding protein involved in endoplasmic reticulum (ER) inheritance, ER polarization and ER membrane organization; regulates nuclear import of transcription factors and intracellular lipid transport; also involved in phospholipid biosynthesis and telomeric chromatin silencing; localizes to the nuclear envelope, nucleus-vacuolar junctions, the ER, and bud tips and necks

name: Suppressor of lethality of Kex2 Gas1 double null mutant
function: Negative regulator of cytokinesis; integral component of the membrane that localizes to the incipient bud site, bud tip, bud neck and cell periphery

name: Ypt-Interacting Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology and cycloheximide resistance; overexpression confers rapamycin resistance and increased invasive growth; conditional mutation causes chromosome instability at semi-permissive temperature; diploid heterozygous null mutant displays haploinsufficiency
function: Membrane protein involved in vesicle-mediated transport from endoplasmic reticulum to the Golgi; integral component of Golgi membranes, and also localizes to ER membranes

name: GlycosylPhosphatidylInositol anchor biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutant is sensitive to caffeine and SDS at permissive temperature; overexpression confers increased resistance to the GPI synthesis inhibitor YW3548; in large-scale studies, repression of expression causes increased competitive fitness; conditional mutants display chromosome instability and elevated resistance to K28 killer toxin
function: Dolichol phosphomannose-oligosaccharide-lipid mannosyltransferase involved in GPI anchor biosynthesis; putatively integral to membrane

name: Bad In Glucose
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation slows down vegetative growth; null mutant cells are very large, often unbudded and multinucleate; repression causes cell cycle delay or arrest in G2 phase

name: Kre6-binding ER protein responsible for Glucan synthesis
Function Unknown Now
phenotype: Non-essential gene; heterozygous null mutant shows decreased fitness; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness on minimal media; overexpression results in a G1 phase arrest or delay
function: Integral component of the mitochondrial outer membrane involved in mitochondrial organization and phopholipid homeostasis

name: AXiaL 2 bud site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene; haploid null mutant displays increased bipolar and decreased axial budding pattern; null mutant has droopy buds, elongated necks and prominent bulges; mating projections in null mutant form at the pole distal to the previous bud scar; null impacts the localization of Axl1p to the mother bud neck and division site; null mutant has decreased oxidative stress resistance; heterozygous null mutant displays chromosomal instability; overexpression results in a decreased vegetative growth rate

name: Assembly Complementing Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutant shows slow growth, inability to utilize nonfermentable carbon sources, increased mitophagy and sensitivity to ethanol and methanol

name: Yeast Presenilin-like Family 1
function: Intramembrane peptidase that regulates abundance of plasma membrane transporters via proteolysis, in response to nutrient starvation; localized to the perinuclear endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: PEroXin
function: Subunit of the peroxisomal importomer complex involved in the import of proteins into the peroxisomal matrix

name: SUCrose
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutant is unable to utilize sucrose, raffinose or inulin as carbon sources; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased growth rate and lowered competitive fitness
function: Beta-fructofuranosidase (invertase) that hydrolyzes sucrose into glucose and fructose; involved in carbohydrate catabolism; two distinct forms are localized to cytoplasm and secreted extracellularly

name: Perish in the Absence of Cin8p
function: Microtubule plus-end binding protein involved in nuclear migration along the microtubule; localized to the cytoplasmic microtubule and the nucleus

name: Activator of Fe (iron) Transcription
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to heat, desiccation, and various chemicals; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor that regulates cellular iron homeostasis and oxidative stress response; localizes to both nucleus and mitochondria

name: Succinate DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources but respiratory defect is rescued by the addition of FAD; null mutant loses viability in stationary phase faster than wild type does, but is resistant to sugar-induced cell death; disease-analogous mutation from a mitochondrial disorder patient reduced Sdh2p activity; in large-scale studies, the null mutant displays increased competitive fitness in minimal medium but decreased competitive fitness in several other media; null mutant is sensitive to desiccation, displays poor growth in anoxic conditions, and has shorter chronological lifespan
function: Succinate dehydrogenase subunit of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex; involved in cellular respiration, the tricarboxylic acid cycle, and mitochondrial electron transport; localizes to vacuolar and mitochondrial membranes

name: LEUcine biosynthesis
function: Isopropylmalate isomerase involved in leucine biosynthesis; catalyzes the conversion of 2-isopropylmalate to 3-isopropylmalate; localizes to the cytosol

name: Regulator of PHR1
function: Histone demethylase specific for K36 tri- and dimethylated histone H3; independently functions as a transcription factor that represses the expression of genes involved in autophagy and DNA repair; involved in transcriptional elongation

name: KAryoPherin
function: Nuclear localization sequence-binding protein transporter that imports proteins to the nucleus; localizes to cytoplasmic stress granules and nuclear pores

name: KAryoPherin
function: Nuclear localization sequence-binding protein transporter that directs the movement of proteins from the cytoplasm to the nucleus

name: Killer EXpression defective
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to tacrolimus and zinc; in systematic studies null mutant shows defective endocytosis, reduced growth rate, greatly increased cell size, and increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including DTT, bleomycin, caffeine, tunicamycin, camptothecin, cyclosporin A, fluconazole hydroxyurea, MMS, rapamycin; overexpression in Sigma1278b increases invasive growth

name: Budding Uninhibited by Benzimidazole
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays eleveated chromosome instability; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced growth rate, increased cell size, and sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including benomyl, bleomycin, caffeine, caspofungin, flucytosine, myriocin, but increased resistance to camptothecin, fluconazole, MMS, rapamycin
function: Ubiquitin binding subunit of the mitotic checkpoint complex; involved in mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint and mitotic DNA integrity checkpoint; localized to condensed nuclear chromosome kinetochore

name: Biosynthesis of Nicotinic Acid
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for nicotinic acid; in systematic studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to His3p inhibitor amitrole, increased resistance to antifungal drug miconazole, and increased accumulation of free amino acids
function: Kynureninase involved in de novo NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan; localizes to both the cytoplasm and nucleus

name: Biosynthesis of Nicotinic Acid
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for nicotinic acid; systematic studies null mutant accumulates elevated amounts of free amino acids and shows reduced [GAR+] prion formation
function: Kynurenine 3-monooxygenase involved in de novo NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan; localizes to the mitochondrial outer membrane

name: Biosynthesis of Nicotinic Acid
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant releases reduced amounts of volatile thiol 4-mercapto-4-methylpentan-2-one (4MMP), during wine fermentation; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased endocytosis
function: L-kynurenine and 2-aminoadipate transaminase; involved in the biosynthesis of kynurenic acid from kynurenine; localizes to both the cytoplasm and mitochondria

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene under standard growth conditions; null mutant is viable under anaerobic conditions and requires ergosterol for growth; down-regulation causes sensitivity to azole drugs and overexpression confers resistance; in large-scale studies, heterozygous null diploid is sensitive to heat and to toxic antimicrobial peptides
function: Lanosterol 14-alpha-demethylase; catalyzes the demethylation of lanosterol during the biosynthesis of ergosterol; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; mutants require ergosterol, accumulate squalene and 2,3-epoxysqualene, and display abnormal lipid particle morphology; in large-scale studies, repressible mutant exhibits an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline) and displays abnormal mitochondrial morphology
function: Lanosterol synthase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to lipid bodies

name: Carbamyl Phosphate synthetase A
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in arginine auxotrophy and increased sensitivity to fluorouracil; overexpression increases resistance to fluorouracil and flucytosine; in systematic studies mutants show decreased competitive fitness
function: Subunit of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase that catalyzes the synthesis of carbamoyl phosphate from bicarbonate in the arginine biosynthesis pathway; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: METhionine requiring
function: Transcription coactivator and subunit of the Cbf1-Met4-Met28 complex, which activates the transcription of genes involved in sulfur amino acid metabolism; involved in the response to arsenic and cadmium

name: METhionine requiring
function: L-homoserine-O-acetyltransferase; catalyzes the conversion of L-homoserine to O-acetyl L-homoserine; involved in methionine biosynthesis and homoserine metabolism; localizes to the cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Bud Neck Involved
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness on minimal medium; null mutant displays increased accumulation of serine; homozygous diploid null mutant is sensitive to treatment with various antimicrobial peptides; heterozygous diploid null is haploproficient in conditions that mimic Phase I of a batch fermentation
function: Protein that binds to the septin ring at the bud neck; recruits myosin to the bud neck

name: Nucleus-Vacuole Junction
function: Lipid binding protein; localizes to nucleusvacuole junction and the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Three Calcium and lipid Binding domains (TriCalBins)
ATPase STabilizing
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased sensitivity to oxidative stress and reduced competitive fitness

name: Long-Chain Base
function: Dihydrosphingosine-1-phosphate phosphatase involved in sphingolipid metabolism; localized to endoplasmic reticulum

name: Fatty Acid Activation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced incorporation of myristate into phospholipids at elevated temperatures and reduced accumulation of long-chain fatty acids; null mutant is sensitive to cerulenin and displays decreased survival in stationary phase; in large-scale studies, homozygous null mutant displays increased competitive fitness; overproduction confers enhanced invasive growth
function: Fatty acid-CoA ligase involved in long-chain fatty acid metabolism and import; contributes to sphingoid transport; localizes to lipid bodies and plasma membrane and to mitochondrion and endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies

name: Fatty Acid Activation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant contains lower levels of long-chain acyl-CoA and shows decreased anaerobic growth and sensitivity to cicloheximide, neomycin and streptomycin
function: Long-chain fatty acid-CoA ligase involved in long-chain fatty acyl-CoA metabolism and long-chain fatty acid import; contributes to sphingoid transport; localizes to lipid bodies, plasma membrane, cytoplasmic stress granules and to cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Catabolism of ARginine
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes slow growth and decreased innate thermotolerance; overexpression increases filamentous growth
function: L-ornithine-oxo-acid transaminase, involved in arginine catabolism; localized to cytosol

name: high-Affinity Glutamine Permease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has increased competitive fitness in minimal medium; homozygous diploid null mutant has an elevated chronological lifespan and accumulated glycogen; null mutant displays reduced apoptosis after a ramped heat stimulus, and has increased resistance to quinine, camptothecin and hydroxyurea; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate and increased invasive growth
function: Transmembrane transporter of L-proline; localizes to plasma membrane

name: Copper TRansport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to high copper levels and accumulates excess copper in vacuoles; overexpression prevents sensitivity to copper starvation
function: Transmembrane transporter of copper ions, involved in intracellular copper homeostasis; localized to vacuolar membrane

name: PhosphoDiEsterase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates cAMP; overexpression causes decreased levels of cAMP and sensitivity to rapamycin
function: 3',5'-cyclic-AMP phosphodiesterase involved in cAMP-mediated signaling; cellular location unknown

name: HeXose Transporter
function: Glucose transporter; involved in glucose uptake; localized to plasma membrane

name: HeXose Transporter
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes decreased transport of glucose and mannose across the plasma membrane, and increased resistance to quinine; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased lifespan; overexpression results in decreased growth rate
function: Hexose and pentose transmembrane transporter of the plasma membrane

name: Zinc-Regulated Transporter
