phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have low intracellular zinc levels, have abnormal vacuolar morphology, are resistant to heat, carcinogen toxaphene, serine C-palmitoyltransferase inhibitor myriocin, tin dichloride, and show increased competitive fitness as haploids in rich medium but decreased competive fitness as haploids in minimal medium and as diploids under batch fermentation conditions; null mutants are sensitive to tellurite, cadmium; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Low-affinity zinc transmembrane transporter of the plasma membrane involved in zinc ion transport

name: Phosphorylated After Rapamycin
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Like SM
phenotype: Essential gene under aerobic condition; null mutant is viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions
function: U4/U6 x U5 tri-small nucleolar RNP (snRNP) complex and Lsm1-7-Pat1 complex subunit; involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing and nuclear-transcribed mRNA degradation; localizes to U6 small nucleolar RNP (snRNP)

name: Like SM
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to sensitivity to acetate and caffeine; haploinsufficient
function: U6 small nuclear RNA (snRNA) binding protein involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing and cytoplasmic mRNA processing body assembly; localizes to P-body, U6 small nucleolar RNP (snRNP), U4/U6 x U5 tri-snRNP complex and Lsm1-7-Pat1 complex

name: Elongation Factor Methyltransferase
function: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the dimethylation of translational elongation factor EF-1 alpha (Tef1p/Tef2p); role in vesicle-mediated transport; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Elongation Factor Methyltransferase
function: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the monomethylation of translational elongation factor EF-1 alpha (Tef1p/Tef2p); localizes to the cytoplasm

name: LYsine-specific Permease
function: Permease involved in the transport of basic amino acids; predicted to localize to the plasma membrane based on sequence similarity

name: CYtosolic Metalloprotease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal mitochondrial morphology and respiratory growth defects; in systematic studies mutants exhibit reduced competitive fitness and elevated sensitivity to neomycin, hydroxyurea, bleomycin and myriocin; overexpression causes increased frequency of chromosome loss

name: Increased Copper Tolerance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to azole drugs; overexpression increases resistance to azoles and benomyl
function: Lysophosphatidic acid acyltransferase involved in the biosynthesis of phosphatidic acid

name: PHosphate Metabolism
function: Lysophosphatidic acid phosphatase with nucleotidase activity; involved in a cell's response to phosphate or carbon starvation as well as nucleotide catabolism

name: TAfaZzin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants are subject to chromosome instability, sensitive to osmotic stress and starvation, have abnormal mitochondria and are impaired in respiration; overexpression enhances pseudohyphal growth in strain Sigma1278b
function: Lysolecithin acyltransferase involved in phospholipid biosynthesis and cardiolipin acyl-chain remodeling; role in organization of inner mitochondrial membrane, mitochondrial ATP synthesis coupled electron transport, mitochondrial respiratory chain supercomplex assembly; integral to outer mitochondrial membrane

name: Lysyl (K) tRNA Synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression causes telomere shortening, reduced competitive fitness, and MMS sensitivity; uncharacterized mutation confers cycloheximide resistance; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: Cytoplasmic lysyl-tRNA synthetase that catalyzes lysyl-tRNA aminoacylation through the coupling of lysine to lysyl-tRNA
Protein tyrosine phosphatase involved in peptidyl-tyrosine dephosphorylation

name: PETite
phenotype: Non-essential gene in W303, essential gene in other strain backgrounds; null mutants grow slowly, cannot respire, are sensitive to heat and cold; missense mutants that correspond to human disease mutations display electron transport chain damage, hypersensitivity to the chemical uncoupler CCCP, mtDNA instability, and intolerance to mtDNA loss; overexpression slows growth
function: ATP/ADP exchanger of the mitochondrial inner membrane involved in respiration and apoptosis

name: APurinic/apyrimidinic eNdonuclease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to DNA-damaging factors, including UV, gamma rays, 5-fluorouracil, MMS; also shows increased mutation frequency and loss of mitochondrial genome

name: RiboNucleotide Reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene in S288C; in some strains null mutation results in terminal cell cycle arrest at S phase after spore germination; mutations in W303 affect telomere length; in systematic studies in S288C null mutants grow slowly, have enlarged cells and abnormally elongated buds and show elevated sensitivity to heat, various metals, oxidative stress, and multiple drugs, including azoles, cyclosporin A, hygromycin B
function: Subunit of the ribonucleoside-diphosphate reductase complex; nucleotide-binding protein that contributes to the ribonucleoside-diphosphate reductase activity of the complex; involved in deoxyribonucleotide biosynthesis and localizes to the cytoplasm

name: METhionine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires methionine; homozygous null mutant diploid accumulates elevated levels of tellurium and displays resistance to tellurite; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits either increased or decreased competitive fitness in different media, increased glycogen accumulation, increased filamentous growth, and decreased sporulation with altered spore wall composition
function: Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (NAD(P)H) involved in methionine biosynthesis; localizes to mitochondrion in high-throughput studies

name: Chromosome Region Maintenance
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause defects in actin cytoskeleton and endocytosis at both permissive and restrictive temperatures, and lead to reduced nuclear export of poly(A)+ RNA and abnormal distribution of reporter proteins; overexpression results in slow growth and increased frequency of chromosome loss and rearrangements
function: Protein transporter involved in export of mRNA, proteins, and large ribosomal subunits from the nucleus; also involved in protein localization to the kinetochore; localizes to the nucleus, spindle pole body, and kinetochore

name: D-Lactate Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation accumulates lactate; in competitive growth studies null mutation increases competitive fitness
function: Major D-lactate dehydrogenase oxidizing D-lactate to pyruvate; role in lactate catabolism; localizes to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Pyruvate DeCarboxylase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth rate; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits decreased competitive fitness, heat sensitivity, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: Pyruvate decarboxylase involved in amino acid catabolism and the fermentation of glucose to ethanol; localizes to both the nucleus and the cytosol

name: Suppression of Exponential Defect
function: Structural constituent of the cell wall; involved in cell wall organization and mitochondrial genome maintenance; localizes to the cell wall, ribosome, and mitochondrion

name: CIk1 Suppressing
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes defects indicative of weakened cell walls, such as reduced resistance to low pH,  SDS, Calcofluor White and caffeine; null mutant is also sensitive to amphotericin B but resistant to cystamine; null mutant has lower survival rate in stationary phase; in systematic studies null mutant is auxotrophic for inositol and has higher competitive fitness

name: SUppressor of Rvs161 and rvs167 mutations
function: Catalytic subunit of mannosylinositol phosphorylceramide (MIPC) synthase; required for biosynthesis of mature sphingolipids; predicted to be integral to membranes

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are senstive to heat and impaired in invertase glycosylation; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to DNA-damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS); heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to starvation
function: Beta-1,4-mannosyltransferase that transfers a mannose residue to an oligosaccharide; involved in protein glycosylation and the assembly of oligosaccharide-lipid intermediates; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations cause sensitivity to gentamycin, hygromycin B, kanamycin and neomycin B; repression leads to increased sensitivity to MMS and myriocin; overexpression results in slow growth

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to reducing agents such as mercaptoethanol and DTT and displays under-glycosylation of secreted proteins; in large-scale studies, the null mutant requires myo-inositol, displays either increased or decreased competitive fitness depending on the growth medium, shows an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline), and has reduced desiccation resistance and innate thermotolerance
function: Dol-P-Man-dependent alpha-1,2 mannosyltransferase that catalyzes addition of seventh and ninth mannose to lipid-linked oligosaccharides; involved in synthesis of oligosaccharide precursor for N-linked protein glycosylation; localizes in endoplasmic reticulum

name: Yeast Unknown Reading frame
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have increased lifespan, decreased competitive fitness, are defective in vacuolar fragmentation, resistant to phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase inhibitor wortmannin and K28 killer toxin, sensitive to immunosuppressive agent tacrolimus, TOR inhibitor rapamycin, and antimicrobial paromomycin; homozygous diploid null mutants show decreased comptitive fitness, are resistant to antineoplastic topoisomerase inhibitor topotecan, experimental anticancer drug tirapazamine, and nitrogen mustard mechlorethamine, but sensitive to protein kinase C inhibitor staurosporine, antimicrobials hygromycin B and actinomycin D; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient; overexpression slows growth

name: Polymyxin B Sensitivity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays phenotypes associated with a defective cell wall, including sensitivity to killer toxin, reducing agents, SDS, and zymolyase, and resistance to Calcofluor White; null mutant accumulates elevated levels of cell wall (1->6)-beta-D-glucan and has elongated cell shape; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness, reduced resistance to hyperosmotic stress, decreased endocytosis and desiccation resistance, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: MAP kinase kinase and scaffold protein involved in the osmosensory signaling pathway and hyperosmotic response; involved in activation of MAPK activity and MAPK nuclear import during osmolarity sensing; has a role in actin filament organization; localizes to the cytoplasm, bud neck and tip, and cytoplasmic stress granule

name: Down-regulator of Invasive Growth
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has mating defects, such as reduced cell fusion during mating, and increased filamentous and invasive growth; overexpression decreases invasive growth and pheromone-induced cell cycle arrest; mutants in systematic studies exhibit decreased competitive fitness under some conditions, and increased biofilm formation, also show increased telomere length

name: Down-regulator of Invasive Growth
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal localization of MAP kinase Fus3p during mating; mutants in systematic studies show increased competitive fitness

name: A-Factor Barrier
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and some vacuolar fragmentation in systematic studies; overexpression causes slow growth

name: SPOrulation
function: Protein involved in prospore membrane assembly and spore wall formation; localizes to the cytosol and the prospore membrane

name: Iswi One Complex
function: Subunit of the Isw1b chromatin remodeling complex

name: OxySterol binding protein Homolog
function: Phosphatidylinositol- and phosphatidic acid-binding protein involved in endocytosis, exocytosis, sterol metabolism, and maintenance of cell polarity; localizes to the cortical endoplasmic reticulum

name: OxySterol binding protein Homolog
function: Sterol transporter involved in endocytosis, exocytosis, karyogamy, invasive growth, and maintenance of cell polarity; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum and plasma membrane

name: OxySterol binding protein Homolog
function: Sterol transporter involved in endocytosis, exocytosis, and maintenance of cell polarity; localizes to the nuclear envelope, endoplasmic reticulum, plasma membrane, and bud neck

name: ER Membrane protein Complex
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased biofilm formation and lower ability to utilize arginine as a nitrogen source; overexpression increases resistance to oxidative stress
function: Subunit of endoplasmic reticulum membrane protein complex; involved in oxidative protein folding
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Cysteine-Three-Histidine
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has an abnormal cell cycle and reduced Ty1 transposition; in large-scale studies, null mutant has enhanced competitive fitness in several different media and shortened chronological lifespan; overproduction is lethal

name: Bud7 and Chs6 Homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased growth rate on rich media, but increased competitive fitness on nonfermentable carbon sources; null mutant is sensitive to growth on plates containing elevated levels of ammonium sulfate; heterozygous null; heterozygous diploid null mutant displays decreased starvation resistance, has an elevated level of mini-chromosome loss indicative of chromosomal instability, and is haploinsufficient

name: Nucleolar Preribosomal Associated
function: A GTPase with ATPase activity involved in localization of RNA polymerase II complex to the nucleus and mitotic sister chromatid cohesion.

name: RiBosome interacting Gtpase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness and an extended hibernating lifespan

name: Synthetic lethal to prp NineTeen mutation
Homologous Mmf1p Factor
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm and mitochondrial intermembrane space.

name: Emp24p/Erv25p Related Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth, defects in protein processing, increased resistance to azole antifungals; increased fitness on nonfermentable carbon sources

name: Emp24p/Erv25p Related Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased endocytosis

name: Emp24p/Erv25p Related Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in Golgi-to-ER transport and protein processing
function: Component of the COP II vesicle that is involved in ER to Golgi vesicle mediated transport of Gas1p and retention of Kar2 (BIP) in the ER
Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

name: Yeast RNA Annealing protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased fitness, increased resistance to the apoptosis inducer edelfosine, and increased accumulation of cadmium

name: Multi-copy Bypass of AFG3
function: Ribosome-binding protein involved in organization of the mitochondrial inner membrane; required for assembly of mitochondrial respiratory chain complexes III and IV; localizes to mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C, conditional mutants arrest at G1 phase of cell cycle as large unbudded cells; non-essential gene in Sigma1278b, null mutant is deficient in filamentous growth
function: Ras guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor involved in Ras protein signal transduction, cell cycle regulation, traversing the start control point of the mitotic cell cycle, and replicative cell aging; localizes to the nucleus, cytosol, endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: FKBP Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to freeze-thaw treatment, also shows sensitivity to heat and 5-fluorouracil; null mutant is sensitive to human huntingtin protein
function: Peptidylproyl isomerase that binds the macrolide lactone FK506; localizes to membrane, localizes to vacuoles, nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: PEroXisome related
function: Subunit of the peroxisomal importomer complex involved in the docking of proteins in the peroxisomal matrix

name: Implicated in Zinc Homeostasis
function: A protein involved in cellular zinc ion homeostasis with an unknown cellular location

name: Ligand-Effect Modulator
function: Subunit of the Lem3p-Dnf1 aminophospholipid translocase (flippase); involved in phospholipid translocation, cell surface receptor signal transduction and vacuole organization; localizes to the plasma membrane and endoplasmic reticulum

name: Rescue of Sro7 at high Nacl
Requiring Fifty-Three
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion results in accumulation of dolichol-bound Man5GlcNAc2 on the cytoplasmic face of ER membrane, underglycosylation and defective secretion of proteins, and opi- phenotype (excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); overexpression leads to slow growth
function: Protein involved in glycolipid translocation; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum and putatively integral in high-throughput studies

name: Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show fragmented mitochondria, increased number of peroxisomes, and abnormal localization of proteasome subunits; mutants show decreased survival in stationary phase; repression leads to opi- phenotype (excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline
function: Thiol-dependent ubiquitin-specific protease and putative metallopeptidase; subunit of the proteasome regulatory particle lid subcomplex; involved in protein deubiquitination, proteasomal ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism, and proteasome storage granule assembly; also involved in peroxisome fission and mitochondrial fission; localizes to the cytosol, mitochondrion, nucleus, and proteasome storage granule

name: Methionine AminoPeptidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth and decreased replicative lifespan, competitive fitness and cell size; null mutation in homozygous diploid causes abnormal budding pattern and increased sensitivity to low pH, elevated temperatures, hyperosmotic stress, caffeine, hygromycin B, benomyl, DTT
function: Metalloaminopeptidase involved in negative regulation of gene expression; contributes to removal of initiator methionine that contributes to protein maturation; localizes to cytoplasmic stress granules and cytosolic ribosomes

name: MEthionyl-tRNA Synthetase
function: Cytoplasmic methionyl-tRNA synthetase that catalyzes methionyl-tRNA aminoacylation through the coupling of methionine to methionyl-tRNA; when present as a subunit of the methionyl glutamyl tRNA synthetase complex, binds methionyl-tRNA more efficiently than it does as a monomer

name: OverProducer of Inositol
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline), abnormal ER morphology, and reduced resistance to desiccation; in large-scale studies null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, decreased innate thermotolerance, increased glycogen accumulation, reduced filamentous growth, and sensitivity to various chemicals
function: Phosphatidyl-N-methylethanolamine N-methyltransferase involved in phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis; putative integral membrane protein

name: Regulator of rDNA Transcription
function: Dipthine methylesterase that catalyzes the penultimate demethylation step of diphthamide biosynthesis; hydrolyzes methylated diphthine to diphthine; localizes to the cytoplasm and to endosomes

phenotype: Essential gene; temperature-sensitive mutation causes decreasing protein synthesis upon temperature shift; repression leads to abnormal protein secretion
function: Messenger RNA (mRNA) guanine 7-methyltransferase involved in addition of 7-methylguanosine cap to 5' end of nascent mRNA transcript; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Essential for Mitotic Growth
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion leads to accumulation of aberrant rRNA processing intermediates
function: Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) (pseudouridine) methyltransferase that contributes to RNA base methylation; involved in rRNA processing and ribosomal SSU biogenesis including endonucleolytic cleavage at A0, A1, and A2 of tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); localizes with 90S preribosome and SSU processome

name: Base Methyltransferase of Twenty five S rRNA 5
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness on minimal medium and increased fitness on ethanol and glycerol-containing media, as well as rich media with 6% ethanol; null mutant displays increased glycogen accumulation and decreased accumulation of copper cations; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient during turbidostat growth in FPM medium, and is haploproficient in conditions that mimic Phase II of a batch fermentation

name: DiPHthamide
function: Diphthine synthase involved in the synthesis of peptidyl-diphthamide from peptidyl-histidine

name: BUD site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly, accumulates small ribosomal subunits in the nucleus and shows defects in ribosome biogenesis; null mutant diploid displays abnormal random budding pattern; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to multiple chemicals and show reduced competitive fitness

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; mutants require ergosterol; in large-scale studies, repression confers increased competitive fitness and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to zaragozic acid C
function: Mevalonate kinase involved in the mevalonate pathway including biosynthesis of farnesyl and isopentenyl diphosphate; contributes to ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to nucleus, cytoplasm and cytosol in high-throughput studies

name: MeValonate pyrophosphate Decarboxylase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations increase sensitivity to hydroxyurea and resistance to stichloroside C1 and theopalauamide
function: Diphosphomevalonate decarboxylase involved in sterol biosynthesis; localizes to cytoplasm

name: BIlateral Karyogamy defect
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has both a decreased growth rate and competitive fitness and is both heat and cold sensitive; diploid null mutant displays a reduced number and length of cytoplasmic microtubules, short and broken anaphase spindles, and abnormally positioned nuclei resulting in anucleate and multinucleate cells; null mutant has a strong bilateral karyogamy defect; null mutant has an elevated rate of chromosome loss, is benomyl sensitive and displays an increased fraction of cells with nuclear extensions at the nuclear envelope; overexpression results in chromosomal instability, and a large-budded cell cycle arrest where cells contain a single nucleus located in or near the neck and abnormal cytoplasmic microtubules; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient
function: Microtubule-binding protein involved in 2-micrometer plasmid partitioning, nuclear migration and karyogamy during mating, mitotic spindle elongation, and negative regulation of microtubule polymerization; has protein homodimerization activity; localizes to kinetochores, microtubule plus-ends, the mating projection tip, the cell cortex, and the spindle and spindle pole body

name: BInding to Microtubules
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays chromosome instability (CIN) and increased chronological lifespan; overexpression leads to slow growth and abnormal G2 phase progression and budding index
function: Microtubule plus-end binding protein involved in microtubule depolymerization, microtubule nucleation, mitotic sister chromatid cohesion and mitotic spindle orientation checkpoint; also localizes to the spindle pole body

name: Pyruvate DeCarboxylase
function: Pyruvate decarboxylase involved in amino acid catabolism and the fermentation of glucose to ethanol; localizes to the nucleus

name: ADenylate Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutant displays reduced growth rate under anaerobic conditions and increased sensitivity to amitrole and cycloheximide

name: Alcohol DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth rate and shortened chronological lifespan
function: Mitochondrial NAD-dependent alcohol dehydrogenase involved in NADH oxidation

name: ALdehyde Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to acetate and shows reduced competitive fitness
function: An aldehyde dehydrogenase involved in acetate biosythesis

name: ALdehyde Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-esseential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, decreased respiratory growth, decreased growth on galactose and ribose, increased lifespan, are sensitive to oleic acid and to oxidative stress, and are resistant to the allergen nickel sulfate
function: An aldehyde dehydrogenase involved in ethanol metabolism, pyruvate metabolism, acetate biosythesis and NADPH regeneration; localized to mitochondria

name: Aspartate-Glutamate Carrier
phenotype: Non-esseential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, decreased competitive fitness, and are impaired in respiratory growth; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient, and sensitive to salt and various antifungals; overexpression slows vegetative growth in S288C, increases invasive growth in Sigma1278b
function: A transporter protein that moves aspartate and glutamate across membranes; involved in synthesis of  nitrogen-containing compounds; localizes to mitochondrial inner membrane

name: VAlyl-tRNA Synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression causes nocodazole sensitivity; in large-scale studies, repression confers increased competitive fitness and sensitivity to HU and MMS; overexpression causes accumulation of large-budded cells in G2 or M phase arrest and increased invasive growth
function: Valyl-tRNA synthetase that performs alanyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling valine to valyl-tRNA; localizes to cytoplasm and mitochondria

name: Aspartate AminoTransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a reduced respiratory growth rate and decreased competitive fitness on non-fermentable carbon sources; null has reduced groth on minimal medium and a reduced ability to use proline as a nitrogen source; null mutant has a reduction in caloric restriction-mediated lifespan extension, while overexpression enhances both chronological and replicative lifespan; overexpression increases silencing at the rDNA locus; null mutant has enhanced biofilm formation; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: L-aspartate:2-oxoglutarate aminotransferase that binds pyridoxal phosphate; involved in amino acid metabolism and cell aging; localizes to mitochondria

name: COx Interacting
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the mitochondrial outer membrane in a large-scale study

name: Branched-chain Amino acid Transaminase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is a valine auxotroph, displays an increase in growth rate, decrease in cell size and a decrease in the duration of the G1 phase of the cell cycle; null mutant is heat sensitive; overexpressor is rapamycin resistant
function: Branched-chain amino acid aminotransferase; involved in both the biosynthesis and degradation of branched chain amino acids, such as leucine, isoleucine and valine; localizes to the mitochondrial matrix

name: Mitochondrial Distribution and Morphology
function: Protein with a role in mitochondrion organization and tethering to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER); involved in phospholipid transport with Crd1p; localizes to the mitochondrial outer membrane and the ERMES complex with Mmm1p

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and grows slowly on fermentable carbon sources (petite phenotype); in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to ethanol and chlorophenol but resistant to miconazole, and show reduced competitive fitness

name: Cytochrome c Peroxidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to oxidative stress; null mutation increases chronological lifespan and competitive fitness

name: DIcarboxylate Carrier
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies mutants exhibit higher frequency of mitochondrial genome loss and severely fragmented vacuoles

name: ARS-Binding Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth, sensitive to hyperosmotic stress, and shows defects in mitochondrial genome maintenance; overexpression causes abnormal budding and cell cycle progression through G2 phase
function: DNA binding protein involved in maintenance of mitochondrial genome; localizes to mitochondrial nucleoid

name: NADH Dehydrogenase, External
function: NADH dehydrogenase involved glycolytic fermentation to ethanol and NADH oxidation; also involved in chronological cell aging; localizes to the mitochondrion

name: FLavin eXchange
function: FAD transmembrane transporter involved in FAD transport; localizes to mitochondrion and likely integral to membrane in high-throughput studies

name: HEMe synthesis by SLC25 family member
ABC Transporter, Mitochondrial
phenotype: Null mutants are inviable under standard aerobic conditions, viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions; null mutant cells accumulate glutathione disulfide, and mitochondria contain increased levels of free iron; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient, sensitive to starvation and to the Sir2 histone deacetylase inhibitor tenovin-6; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness and chromosome instability
function: ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter with ATPase activity; involved in transport of Fe/S clusters to cytosol; localized to mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Citrate Transport Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation reduces fitness in competitive growth experiments; in systematic studies mutants exhibit increased sensitivity to ethanol
function: Mitochondrial tricarboxylic acid transporter involved in transport of citric acid through the mitochondrial inner membrane; localized to mitochondrial membrane

name: MultiDrug resistance-Like
function: An integral membrane ATPase that transports oligopeptides; involved in a cell's response to hydrogen peroxide, transmembrane transport, and export of opligopeptides from mitochondria; localizes to the mitochondrial inner membrane and vacuolar membrane

name: cytochrome OXidase Activity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction of function causes defects in fermentative and respiratory growth, sensitivity to oxidative and osmotic stresses, decreased endocytosis; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Membrane insertase involved in mitochondrial genome maintenance and protein insertion into mitochondrial membrane from inner side; role in mitochondrial proton-transporting ATP synthase complex assembly; localizes to inner bounding mitochondrial membrane and cristae

name: ATPase Family Gene
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to use nonfermentable carbon sources and has a lengthened replicative lifespan, although lifespan extension by caloric restriction is less than in wild type; null mutant displays increased resistance to oxidative and heat stress; null mutant accumulates decreased levels of cardiolipin in mitochondrial membranes; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and altered sensitivity to a variety of drugs
function: ATPase and metallopeptidase of the inner mitochondrial membrane; subunit of the m-AAA complex involved in assembly of mitochondrial membrane protein complexes, degradation of nonassembled inner membrane proteins and processing of proteins imported into mitochondria

name: Yeast Tat-binding Analog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to respire and accumulates less cardiolipin and PE in mitochondria; homozygous null mutant has shorter chronological lifespan; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in a variety of media; null mutant displays sensitivity to heat and ethanol, mitochondrial genome instability, and increased chitin deposition
function: ATPase and metallopeptidase of the inner mitochondrial membrane; subunit of the m-AAA complex involved in mitochondrial protein turnover and processing of proteins imported into mitochondria

name: Quasi-Renownless Information
function: Component of the small subunit of the mitochondrial ribosome, which mediates translation in the mitochondrion; involved in the processing of COX1 pre-mRNA

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits petite phenotype (inability to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources and slow growth on fermentable carbon sources) indicating respiratory defficiency; in systematic studies mutants show decreased competitive fitness, reduced ability to form biofilms, increased sensitivity to hygromycin B and spermine, and increased resistance to edelfosine and miconazole

name: Cytochrome Oxidase Assembly
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows greatly diminished respiratory metabolism and growth; homozygous diploid displays reduced sporulation; in systematic studies mutants have shorter chronological lifespan, decreased competitive fitness and increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss; in strain Sigma1278b null mutation prevents invasive growth

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits petite phenotype (inability to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources and slow growth on fermentable carbon sources) indicating respiratory defficiency; null mutant is also sensitive to oxidative stress caused by exposure to hydrogen peroxide; overexpression causes abnormal budding and cell morphology

name: Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays lower levels of Tim13p
function: Protein carrier of the Tim9-Tim10 complex which resides in the mitochondrial intermembrane space and guides proteins to the Tim22 complex for insertion into the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays sensitivity to MMS and accumulates reduced levels of Tim8p; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and has altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Protein carrier of the Tim9-Tim10 complex which resides in the mitochondrial intermembrane space and guides proteins to the Tim22 complex for insertion into the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Mitochondrial Distribution and Morphology
function: Protein involved in mitochondrion organization and assembly of mitochondrial respiratory chain complex; localized to mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: Mitochondrial Intermembrane space CX(n)C motif protein
function: Protein localized to the mitochondrial intermembrane space; involved in aerobic respiration

name: Mitochondrial Peculiar Membrane protein
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; associated with membranes; localizes to the mitochondrial intermembrane space; localizes to the mitochondrion in different large-scale studies

name: Mitochondrial Intermembrane space CX(n)C motif protein
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localized to mitochondrial intermembrane space

name: Mitochondrial Intermembrane space CX(n)C motif protein
Malate DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a severe respiratory growth defect; null mutant displays decreased replicative and chronological lifespans while the overexpressor has elevated lifespans; null mutant displays decreased survival rate in stationary phase and decreased desiccation resistance; null mutant has reduced mitochondrial zinc accumulation and increased acetic acid excretion; homozygous diploid null has decreased sporulation efficiency; overexpression results in increased silencing at the rDNA locus
function: Mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase and putative mRNA binding protein; catalyzes the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate, a step in the in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, integral to aerobic fermentation; localizes to the mitochondrial matrix

name: SuperOxide Dismutase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a respiratory growth defect, increased apoptosis, and decreased chronological and replicative lifespan, null mutant is sensitive to a variety of environmental stresses including oxidative stress, desiccation, heat, ionic stress, and a variety of chemicals; in large-scale studies the null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Mitochondrial manganese superoxide oxidoreductase involved in the metabolism of reactive oxygen species, cell aging, and the response of non-dividing cells oxidative stress

name: Acyl Carrier Protein
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C, but non-essential in another background; S288C-derived null mutant is viable but slow growing when cultured anaerobically; non-essential null mutant is petite and displays decreased accumulation of lipoic acid; reduction of function mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium, chromosomal instability, and decreased resistance to hydroxyurea and MMS; overexpression results in increased resistance to dihydromotuporamine C, a tumor cell invasion inhibitor; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient

name: Mitochondrial GrpE
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression is lethal; point mutants display increased oxidative stress resistance, heat sensitivity, and defective mitochondrial import

name: Yeast Frataxin Homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to respire and loses the mitochondrial genome; null mutant shows elevated mitochondrial iron accumulation and shorter replicative lifespan, and is sensitive to oxidative stress and metals; null mutant scored as inviable in original comprehensive deletion survey; in large-scale studies, repression confers reduced competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant displays haploinsufficiency; null mutant is resistant to myriocin
function: Ferroxidase and iron chaperone involved in the assembly of iron-sulfur clusters, glutathione metabolism, and iron homeostasis; localized to the mitochondrial matrix

name: BolA-like protein
function: Mitochondrial matrix protein involved in assembly and/or transfer of [4Fe-4S] clusters from the ISA complex to client proteins
Integral mitochondrial membrane protein involved in aerobic respiration that also localizes to the cytoplasmic mRNA processing body

name: Mitochondrial aminoacyl-tRNA Synthetase, Methionine
function: Mitochondrial methionyl-tRNA synthetase that catalyzes methionyl-tRNA aminoacylation through the coupling of methionine to methionyl-tRNA

name: AuTophaGy related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a pronounced defect in mitophagy; null mutant has a reduced ability to use urea as nitrogen source; null mutant has decreased resistance to zinc treatment; null mutant has increased competitive fitness on minimal medium; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Mitochondrial protein involved in mitochondrial degradation

name: ARGinine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a reduced growth rate and a leaky arginine auxotrophy; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in synthetic medium; null mutant displays decreased oxidative stress resistance and resistance to zinc deficiency; null displays increased resistance to calcofluor white
function: N-acetylglutamate synthase and glutamate N-acetyltransferase involved in arginine and ornithine biosythesis; localized to the mitochondrial matrix

name: Translocase of the Outer Mitochondrial membrane
Suppressor of Cdc4 Mutation
function: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the mitochondrion and mitochondrial outer membrane in large-scale studies

name: Outer Membrane Protein of 14 kDa
function: Mitochondrial outer membrane protein that binds to the nascent chain-associated complex to dock cytosolic ribosomes at the mitochondrion and facilitate co-translational import of mitochondrial proteins

name: Cyclosporin A-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows elevated copper-induced apoptosis; in systematic studies mutants display decreased biofilm formation and increased resistance to azoles; overexpression in strain Sigma1278b increases filamentous growth
function: Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase that converts peptide bonds located next to proline residues between cis and trans configuration; involved in protein folding, localizes in mitochondria

name: PORin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has reduced growth rate on nonfermentable carbon sources and respiratory growth is heat-sensitive; replicative lifespan of null mutant is extended more under caloric restriction than is wild-type lifespan; null mutant is sensitive to acid pH and oxidative stress, but resistant to rapamycin; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness in a variety of media, small cell size, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: Voltage-gated anion channel; involved in ion transport, cellular redox homeostasis, and mitochondrial organization; implicated in DNA transport and apoptosis; integral membrane protein of the outer mitochondrial membrane

name: Mitochondrial Distribution and Morphology
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to respire and exhibits fragmented mitochondria; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness, is sensitive to heat, acid pH, and desiccation, and has altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Ribosome binding protein that positively regulates mitochondrial translation with Mba1p; involved in cellular potassium ion homeostasis by transporting potassium ions with Rbk1p and YDL183Cp; plays a role in biogenesis of both cytochrome bc(1) and cytochrome c oxidase complexes; localized to mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Mitochondrial Translation Optimization
phenotype: Non-essential gene in S288C but essential in the Sigma1278b background; null mutant exhibits reduced oxygen consumption although respiratory growth rate is normal; null mutant accumulates unmodified mitochondrial lysine tRNA; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, increased resistance to benomyl and rapamycin, and reduced starvation resistance
function: Protein involved in the post-transcriptional modification of a uridine in position 34 of a mitochondrial transfer RNA (tRNA)

name: ATPase ExPression
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to grow under respiratory growth conditions; in systematic studies, null mutant shows slow growth under fermentative growth condtions, produces small-size cells, has abnormal mitochondrial morphology and lower resistance to ethanol; in diploids under competitive growth conditions, homozygous null mutation results in sensitivity to oxidative stress and increased resistance to cell wall-affecting chemicals, such as caffeine and Calcofluor White, and to DNA-damaging factors, such as MMS, idarubicin, melphalan

name: Mitochondrial Ribosomal Protein, Small subunit
function: Component of the small subunit of the mitochondrial ribosome, which mediates translation in the mitochondrion

name: Succinate DeHydrogenase
function: Protein involved in gluconeogenisis regulation and carbon utilization; localized to mitochondrial intermembrane space
Mitochondrial protein required for assembly of the succinate dehydrogenase complex (respiratory complex II)

name: Manganese Trafficking factor for Mitochondrial SOD2
function: Pyridoxal 5' phosphate carrier; involved in cellular iron homeostasis; localizes to mitochondria
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the mitochondrion in a large scale study

name: Mdm10 Complementing Protein
function: Protein involved in mitochondrion organization during lipid homeostatis; is an integral component of the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Mdm10 Complementing Protein
function: Integral membrane protein of the outer mitochondrial membrane; involved in the organization of the mitochondrion as well as in lipid homeostasis

name: Cytochrome B mRNA Processing
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutants are incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources, grow slowly on fermentable carbon sources and show reduced competitive fitness
function: Mitochondrial ribosome binding protein; component of the Cbp3p-Cbp6p complex involved in mitochondrial cytochrome bc(1) complex assembly and mitochondrial translation

name: Cytochrome B mRNA Processing
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutants show reduced rate of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources, grows slowly on fermentable carbon sources and shows reduced competitive fitness
function: Mitochondrial protein involved in mitochondrial cytochrome bc(1) complex assembly

name: Cytochrome Oxidase Assembly
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays petite phenotype, i.e. forms small colonies on fermentable carbon sources due to respiratory growth defect; null mutant is unable to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources

name: IscU homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased respiratory growth, reduced biofilm formation, shortened chronological lifespan and lower competitive fitness
function: Protein involved in iron-sulfur cluster assembly, iron ion homeostasis and transfer RNA (tRNA) wobble uridine modification; localizes to nucleus and cytosol

name: ATPase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations); in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to ethanol and palmitoleate, but resistant to miconazole and edelfosine; overexpression in Sigma1278b causes increased invasive growth
function: Mitochondrial inner membrane protein, required for stability of the ATP9 mRNA and for assembly of the F1F0 ATP synthase complex

name: Mitochondrial Matrix Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes isoleucine auxotrophy, respiratory defect and mitochondrial genome instability
function: Mitochondrial matrix protein involved in mitochondrial translation and isoleucine biosynthesis

name: Cytochrome B Protein synthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased replicative lifespan; in systematic studies, null mutants have lower competitive fitness and slow growth rate
function: Mitochondrial ribosome binding protein; component of the Cbp3p-Cbp6p complex involved in mitochondrial cytochrome bc(1) complex assembly and mitochondrial translation

name: Changed Intracellular Redox state
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has faster growth rate and increased sensitivity to oxidative stress during respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources; also shows proliferation of peroxisomes
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the mitochondrion in different large-scale studies

name: Mitochondrial Distribution and Morphology
function: Protein involved in mitochondrion organization and inheritance and cellular ion homeostasis; regulates cardiolipin metabolic process with Mdm10p, Mmm1p, Mdm12p, and Mdm34p; localizes to the inner mitochondrial membrane

name: Nuclear Accommodation of Mitochondria
function: Component of the small subunit of the mitochondrial ribosome, which mediates translation in the mitochondrion

function: Component of the large subunit of the mitochondrial ribosome, which mediates translation in the mitochondrion
