name: Processing of Cytochrome c Peroxidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows respiratory growth defects and abnormal mitochondrial morphology, also shows sensitivity to osmotic stress, caffeine, rapamycin; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Serine-type endopeptidase involved in regulation of mitochondrion organization and signal peptide processing; localizes to mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Mitochondrial aminoacyl-tRNA Synthetase, Threonine
function: Mitochondrial threonyl-tRNA synthetase that performs threonyl-tRNA aminoacylation in the mitochondria by coupling threonine to threonyl-tRNA

name: Cytochrome B Synthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes accumulation of unspliced COB and COX1 mRNA precursors and inability to grow on non-fermentable carbon sources; in systematic studies null mutants show slow growth rate, increased resistance to azoles and reduced competitive fitness
function: Mitochondrial translation regulator required for assembly of mitochondrial respiratory chain complex III; localizes to mitochondrial inner membrane; associates with mitochondrial ribosomes

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants show small cell size, grow slowly, are defective in vacuolar fragmentation, have abnormal mitochondria, are impaired in respiration, have shortened lifespan, and decreased biofilm formation; null mutants are resistant to phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase inhibitor wortmannin, TOR inhibitor rapamycin, apoptosis inducer edelfosine, azole drugs and some metals; null mutants are sensitive to quinine, ethanol, and herbicides; overexpression slows growth; R328Q reduction-of-function mutation that corresponds to infantile macrocystic leukodystrophy-associated mutation in human EFTu impairs respiratory growth
function: Mitochondrial translation elongation factor, catalyzes the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to ribosomes and possesses an intrinsic GTPase activity

name: Mitochondrial aminoacyl-tRNA Synthetase, tryptophan (W)
function: Mitochondrial tryptophanyl-tRNA synthetase that performs tryptophanyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling tryptophan to tryptophanyl-tRNA

name: Phosphatase Two C
function: Protein serine/threonine phosphatase involved in mitophagy and macroautophagy; localized to mitochondria

name: Mitochondrial aminoacyl-tRNA Synthetase, tyrosine (Y)
function: Mitochondrial tyrosyl-tRNA synthetase that performs mitochondrial tyrosyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling tyrosine to tyrosyl-tRNA

name: Altered Inheritance of Mitochondria
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has increased competitive fitness on minimal medium; null mutant displays an increased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss
function: Mitochondrial protein involved in then regulation of chronological lifespan, and the response to both heat shock and oxidative stress; negative regulator of mitophagy

name: High Osmolarity Glycerol response
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to hyperosmotic stress and fails to accumulate glycerol under hyperosmotic conditions; null mutation confers increased sensitivity to cold, acid and multiple chemicals including tunicamycin, DTT, SDS, Congo Red
function: Mitogen-activated protein kinase involved in osmoregulation

name: Kinase Suppressor of Sst2 mutations
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reported to be nonfunctional in S288C and related strains; in Sigma1278b null mutation decreases filamentous and invasive growth and causes sensitivity to osmotic stress; reduction-of-function mutations in Sigma1278b lead to abnormal distribution of Bcy1p and Sks1p, and sterile phenotype

name: cell FUSion
phenotype: Non-essential gene; isolated based on a bilateral cell fusion defect; null mutant has reduced mating efficiency and is unable to undergo pheromone induced G1 arrest; overexpression increases pheromone sensitivity; null mutant displays decreased autophagy and endocytosis; null mutant is hyperfilamentous and disrupts the nuclear localization of Sks1p and Ksp1p after induction of filamentous growth
function: MAP kinase involved in pheromone-dependent signal transduction during mating; has a role in invasive growth in response to glucose limitation and negative regulation of MAPK cascade; localized to both the nucleus and mating projection tip

name: Antagonist of Mitotic exit Network
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has slow growth in rich media, decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium and a reduced ability to utilize urea as nitrogen source; null mutant displays greatly decreased filamentous growth and is unable to undergo invasive growth; null mutant displays reduced flocculation; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate, misshapen, elongated cells with multiple nuclei and a shift towards 2C DNA content with eventual inviability; overexpression results in an elevated frequency of mitotic recombination, and an increased frequency of chromosome loss and non-disjunction, indicative of chromosomal instability
function: Protein involved in the mitotic cell cycle checkpoint and regulation of mitotic exit; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, and cellular bud

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon source and shows no sporulation, increased sensitivity to starvation and oxidative stress, increased resistance to benomyl and caffeine, and decreased resistance to ethanol, MMS, neomycin, streptomycin
function: Protein with a role in assembly of the mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase complex; binds to the unfolded Atp2p subunit during assembly; localized to mitochondria

name: MonoacylGlycerol Lipase
function: Monoacylglycerol and triacylglycerol lipase; involved in triacylglycerol catabolism; minor role in the biosynthesis of medium-chain fatty acid ethyl ester

name: GLyOxalase
function: Glyoxalase I; catalyzes the catabolic conversion of methylglyoxal to S-lactoyl-glutathione in a condensation reaction that consumes glutathione; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Protein 1 of Cleavage and polyadenylation Factor I
Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, are sensitive to DNA-damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS); base-substitution mutants are resistant to cycloheximide; at permissive temperatures, conditional mutants have a G1 delay, complete loss of pseudohyphal growth; at elevated temperatures, conditional mutants accumulate 80S monosomes, arrest in G1, have decreased budding index, and are completely impaired in adhesion; repression induces defects in cytokinesis; overexpression confers resistance to rapamycin; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Translation initiation factor eIF4E, mRNA cap binding protein involved in translation initiation; localized to cytoplasm and nucleus

name: clathrin Adaptor Protein complex Medium chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays defects in vacuolar protein sorting; null mutants are also sensitive to acid pH, Congo Red, quinine, rapamycin; in large-scale studies null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and sensitivity to multiple drugs
function: Subunit of the AP-1 adaptor complex that binds clathrin and functions in golgi to vacuole transport

name: clathrin Adaptor Protein complex Medium chain
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows defects in vacuolar protein sorting; null mutant also show abnormal accumulation of polyphosphates and magnesium ions, excretion of inositol, and sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including DTT, chlorophenol, caspofungin, tunicamycin
function: Subunit of the AP-3 adaptor complex that functions in golgi to vacuole transport

name: Multicopy Suppression of a Budding defect
AminoTriazole Resistance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium; null mutant is highly sensitive to boron, and accumulates boron, while overexpression results in increased boron resistance; null mutant has decreased resistance to tin; null mutant displays increased levels of spontaneous Rad52p foci

name: HIStidine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutations confer histidine auxotrophy and increased sensitivity to metal ions
function: Multifunctional enzyme with phosphoribosyl-ATP pyrophosphatase, phosphoribosyl-AMP cyclohydrolase, and histidinol dehydrogenase activities; catalyzes several steps in the biosynthesis of histidine; localizes to the cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Protease in FXNA-related Family
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the vacuole membrane

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for myo-inositol, has a pseudohyphal growth defect, small cell size in saturated culture, decreased basal and acquired ethanol tolerance, and decreased acquired therotolerance; diploid null mutant is haploinsufficient, and has a sporulation defect

name: DNA Damage Responsive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has lower survival in stationary phase; in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness and abnormal polyphosphate accumulation

name: Defective for SREBP Cleavage
function: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the Dsc E3 ubiquitin ligase complex

name: BASal
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal vacuolar morphology, decreased transposition, increased replicative lifespan, is resistant to oxidative stress, sensitive to desiccation, impaired in endocytosis, and auxotrophic for adenine; null mutant also shows increased invasive growth; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression slows growth
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding RNA polymerase II transcription activator

name: ARAbinose
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced levels of dehydro-D-arabinono-1,4-lactone and decreased competitive fitness

name: Glycerol-3-Phosphate Dehydrogenase
function: NAD-dependent glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase involved in glycerol metabolism and NADH oxidation; localized in the cytosol and mitochondrion

name: Glycerol-3-Phosphate Dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased accumulation of ethanol and decreased accumulation of glycerol, also shows sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress; overexpression causes increased accumulation of glycerol, acetate, acetoin and butane-2,3-diol
function: NAD-dependent glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase with key role in synthesis of glycerol and in intracellular glycerol accumulation in response to high-osmolarity stress; localized to the cytoplasm and peroxisomes

name: Homolog of SIR Two (SIR2)
function: Histone deacetylase subunit of the Set3 complex involved in transcription regulation; also involved in negative regulation of mitotic recombination and chromatin silencing at silent mating-type cassettes

name: Butanediol DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased accumulation of (R,R)-butane-2,3-diol and acetoin; null mutant shows filamentous growth defect; heterozygous null mutant displays decreased fitness

function: Protein that reduces aldehyde in an NADH-dependent manner; involved in cellular detoxification of aldehyde; localizes to the cytoplasm in a high-throughput study

name: NADH Dehydrogenase Internal
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in decreased apoptosis, replicative lifespan and respiratory growth; overexpression causes increased accumulation of reactive oxygen species
function: NADH:ubiquinone oxidoreductase involved in mitochondrial electron transport, chronological cell aging, NADH oxidation, and positive regulation of apoptosis; localizes to the mitochondrion

name: D-ARAbinose dehydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation decreases utilization rate of galactose and glucose as carbon sources, and allantoin, glutamate, glutamine as nitrogen sources'

name: Glutamate DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness, decreased growth in ethanol containing media and increased sensitivity to calcofluor white

name: Glutamate DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates 2-oxoglutarate when grown on glucose as a carbon source and shows respiratory growth deficiency on non-fermentable carbon sources
function: Glutamate dehydrogenase (NADP+) involved in glutamate biosynthesis and the ammonia assimilation cycle; localized to the nucleus

name: Aldehyde Reductase Intermediate, subclass of SDR
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant becomes sensitive to aluminum under disulfide stress and shows reduced growth rate

name: Yeast Putative Reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in large-scale studies, the null mutant displays increased competitive fitness, decreased endocytosis, and sensitivity to DMSO; null mutant requires myo-inositol; heterozygous null mutant diploid is haploproficient
function: NADPH-dependent carbonyl reductase involved in arabinose catabolism
An aldo-keto reductase involved in cellular response to oxidative stress and cellular ketone and amide metabolism

name: Alcohol DeHydrogenase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to veratraldehyde, amitrole, cycloheximide and streptomycin
function: Alcohol dehydrogenase involved in alcohol, aldehyde, and furaldehyde metabolism

name: Altered Inheritance rate of Mitochondria
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in minimal media and in media supporting respiratory growth; null mutant displays an increased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss; null mutant displays increased chronological lifespan, reduced ROS levels, elevated oxidative stress resistance and decreased resistance to F-actin nucleation inhibitor wiskostatin and elongation inhibitor latrunculin B, both of which are reversed by hydrogen peroxide treatment; overexpression results in decreased chronological lifespan, increased ROS accumulation, an increased budding index in stationary phase, and apoptosis
function: NADPH oxidase that generates superoxide; regulates actin cytoskeleton organization; has a role in apoptosis; localized to the perinuclear endoplasmic reticulum

name: Na+/H+ eXchanger
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to hyperosmotic stress and has abnormal vacuoles, also shows decreased growth rate and sensitivity to multiple drugs, including hygromycin B, actinomycin D, bleomycin, doxorubicin, and other chemicals (MMS, hydroxyurea, flucytosine, spermine)
function: Sodium:proton and potassium:proton antiporter involved in sodium ion and potassium ion transmembrane transport; has role in vacuolar acidification and cellular monovalent inorganic cation homeostasis; localizes to vacuolar membranes, trans-Golgi network and endosomes

name: Reverses Spt- Phenotype
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations lead to buildup of unprocessed reporter proteins normally targeted for degradation and to defects in processing of mRNA, rRNA and tRNA precursors; reduction of function causes higher sensitivity to cell wall-affecting chemicals (caffeine, Calcofluor White); repression results in opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); overexpression causes slow growth
function: E3 ubiquitin ligase that conjugates ubiquitin to proteins to target them for degradation; known to ubiquitinate Ste4p; involved in regulating a variety of processes via ubiquitin-dependent catabolism including organization of the mitochondrion, multivesilular body size, initiation of the mating tip projection and actin cytoskeletal organization; positively regulates dolichol and fatty acid biosynthesis; localized throughout the cell

name: Degradation of Allantoin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays elevated expression of several genes controlled by nitrogen catabolite repression system; both null mutation and overexpression in strain Sigma1278b cause increased filamentous growth
function: A RNA polymerase II transcription factor that binds specific DNA sequence; negatively regulates transcription and is involved in nitrogen catabolite repression of transcription; localized to the nucleus

name: WHIskey
function: Protein phosphatase activator involved in the general stress response; role in mitophagy, endocytosis and organization of the actin cytoskeleton; localizes to the cell periphery

name: BYpass of ESS1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to ethanol, hydroxyurea, tunicamycin, but resistant to MMS, caffeine; overexpression causes slow growth

name: Vacuolar Protein Sorting
function: Endosomal phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate binding retromer complex subunit involved in retrograde transport of membrane-bounded vesicles from endosomes back to the trans-Golgi network where they are recycled for further rounds of transport

name: Histone Synthetic Lethal
function: Ser/thr protein kinase involved in the G2/M transition of the mitotic cell cycle; substrates include Swe1p and Hsl7p; capable of autophosphorylation; localizes to the bud neck septin ring

name: UREidosuccinate transport
function: A glutathione peroxidase involved in regulating cellular nitrogen utilization with Gln3p; part of cytoplasmic sequestering of Gln3p; localized to cytosol

name: FReQuenin homolog
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are defective in autophagy and in Golgi localization of reporter proteins; heterozygous diploid is sensitive to starvation and oxidative stress
function: Enzyme activator involved in regulation of signal transduction; localizes to Golgi membrane and to cytosol in high-throughput studies

name: Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations increase resistance to lovastatin and sensitivity to canavanine; conditional (ts) mutation causes chromosome instability; overexpression leads to slow growth
function: Protein-protein adaptor subunit of proteasome regulatory particle, base subcomplex involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; localizes to nucleus and proteasome storage granules

name: Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to elevated temperatures, shows cell cycle arrest in metaphase, and grows slowly; in a systematic study null mutant shows normal growth under anaerobic conditions
function: Structural peripheral lid subunit of proteasome regulatory particle involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; role in proteasome assembly; localizes to proteasome storage granules, nucleus, cytosol

name: Mitochondrial Distribution and Morphology
function: A subunit of the NatB complex that contributes to peptide alpha-N-acetyltransferase activity; involved in cytoskeleton organization, mitochondrion inheritance and N-terminal peptidyl-methionine acetylation

name: Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
DeCapping Scavenger
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased stability of mRNA, decreased growth rate and reduced survival in stationary phase; in systematic studies mutants have lower competitive fitness, decreased resistance to hyperosmotic stress and are unable to grow under respiratory growth conditions

function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the mitochondrion and mitochondrial outer membrane in large scale studies

name: Complexed With Cef1p
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to Congo Red, streptomycin, amitrole
function: An RNA binding protein involved in mRNA splicing; localized to the U2-type splicesomal complex in the nucleus
Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: ExtraCellular Mutant
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localized to cytoplasm and nucleus in large scale studies
Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

name: ExtraCellular Mutant
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Early Meiotic Induction
function: Cytoplasmic protein implicated in sporulation and transcription regulation

name: HmG1/2 Homolog
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in different large-scale studies

name: SECretory
function: Component of the Sec62/Sec63 complex that is involved in the posttranslational translocation of proteins to the ER

name: SECretory
function: Component of the Sec62/Sec63 complex that is involved in the posttranslational translocation of proteins to the ER
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus, nucleolus, and cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Glycerate PhosphoMutase
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: Mitochondrial ClpX
function: ATPase that facilitates linkage of a pyridoxal phosphate cofactor to Hem1p; localized to the mitochondrial matrix

name: ADEnine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays adenine auxotrophy and forms red colonies
function: Phosphoribosylaminoimidazolesuccinocarboxamide synthase involved in the biosynthesis of purine nucleotides

name: Ribonucleic Acid Trafficking
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant accumulates poly(A)+ RNA in the nucleus, and conditional mutant accumulates unprocessed forms of pre-rRNA and snoRNAs; conditional mutant has an S phase delay, increased hydroxyurea sensitivity, and accumulates telomeric repeat-containing RNA (TERRA) and shortened telomeres; null mutant displays chromosomal instability and decreased competitive fitness in rich media; conditional mutant has increased phosphorylation of the C-terminal domain (CTD) of RNAPII, and elevated recruitment of Ctk1p to active chromatin; overexpression causes slow growth and elevated invasive growth
function: Nuclear 5' to 3' RNA exoribonuclease; functions in both exosome-dependent and poly(A)-coupled RNAPII transcriptional termination; functions in mRNA surveillance, and processing of both rRNA and snoRNA; inhibits RNAPII transcriptional elongation, and phosphorylation of the CTD of RNAPII

name: Actin-Related Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant has a G1/S phase delay, a metaphase arrest with elevated spindle elongation, breakage associated with lagging chromosomes in mother cells, and abnormal nuclear morphology; conditional mutant has non-uniform stationary phase arrest after prolonged cultivation, with abnormal nuclear morphology and decreased viability; conditional and reduction of function alleles are sensitive to hydroyurea, benomyl and rapamycin; repressible mutant displays increased spontaneous DNA damage and increased excretion of inositol
function: Subunit of the Ino80, NuA4 histone acetyltransferase and SWR1 complexes that contributes to 3' to 5' DNA helicase and histone acetylase functions in chromatin remodeling and DNA repair processes.

name: Actin-Related Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene in S288C, but essential in sigma1278b; S288C-derived null mutant has a large cell size and abnormally elongated buds; null mutant is heat sensitive, has a decreased growth rate on rich media and decreased competitive fitness on various media; null mutant is sensitive to oxidative stress, acid and alkaline pH, zinc and cadmium treatment, enzymatic treatment with zymolyase, and treatment with zymocin or killer toxin; null mutant has an altered ionome and a decreased ability to accumulate polyphosphate and glycogen; null has a decreased chronological lifespan, and decreased innate thermotolerance; overexpression results in enhanced invasive growth

name: APical growth revealed by Quantitative morphological analysis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a large cell size with abnormally elongated bud, and an anaphase delay; null mutant is heat and cold sensitive, slow growing at permissive temperature and has competitive fitness defects; null mutant is sensitive to sterol biosynthesis inhibitors and membrane fluidizing agents, accumulating sterol precursors and monounsaturated fatty acids at reduced temperatures; null mutant is defective in the nuclear export of poly(A)+ mRNA, mislocalizes nuclear pore complex (NPC) cytoplasmic filament proteins and mRNA export factor, Dbp5p; null mutant has a vacuolar fragmentation deficiency, and nuclear morphology defects with abnormal nuclear envelope and NPC distribution; null mutant displays filamentous growth defects and is unable to undergo invasive growth; null mutant has decreased chronological lifespans, decreased acquired thermotolerance and does not accumulate trehalose after heat shock; null mutant is sensitive to metal treatment and antifungals
function: Integral membrane protein of the nuclear envelope and ER; involved in lipid homeostasis; role in nuclear export of mRNA, and nuclear envelope organization

name: Nuclear Transport Factor
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause defects in nuclear import and slow growth
function: Ran GTPase binding protein involved in protein import into nucleus; localizes to nuclear envelope and putatively integral to membrane in high-throughput studies

name: Chromosome SEgregation
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutation leads to elevated rate of chromosome loss even at permissive temperature; depletion blocks nuclear import; overexpression causes poly(A)+ RNA accumulation in the nucleus and inviability
function: Nuclear export receptor involved in protein export from the nucleus, localizes in nuclear envelope

name: Ribosomal RNA Processing
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates incompletely processed mRNA, rRNA, snRNA, snoRNA species, and shows decreased exponential growth rate, increased sensitivity to elevated temperature and 5-fluorouracil; in systematic studies null mutants shows reduced competitive fitness and altered sensitivity to chemicals
function: 3'-5'-exoribonuclease that is a subunit of the nuclear exosome; involved in nuclear mRNA surveillance, nuclear polyadenylation-dependent RNA catabolism, and 3-end processing of U1, U4, and U5 snRNA; plays a role in exonucleolytic trimming to generate mature 3'-end of 5.8S rRNA from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); localizes to the nucleus and the nucleolus

name: Associated with Ribosomal eXport complex
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows modest nuclear retention of 60S ribosomal subunits; in systematic studies null mutant shows reduced growth rate, decreased competitive fitness, increased resistance to benomyl, edelfosine and oxidative stress

name: Mrna TRansport defective
function: Nuclear localization sequence-binding protein involved in protein and RNA import to the nucleus; also involved in tRNA transport; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Yeast RNA Annealing protein
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutants glow slowly and are sensitive to heat, DNA synthesis inhibitor HU, and microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl; overexpression causes cell-cycle arrest and decreased budding
function: RNA-binding protein and ATP-dependent RNA helicase inhibitor; involved in mRNA export from the nucleus and transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair; subunit of the transcription export (TREX) complex, which couples transcription elongation by RNA polymerase II to mRNA export

name: Nuclear polyAdenylated RNA-Binding
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations result in accumulation of poly(A)+ mRNAs in the nucleus; haploinsufficient; overexpression in Sigma1278b increases invasive growth; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Polyadenylated RNA-binding protein that regulates poly(A) mRNA tail length and export from the nucleus; positively regulates RNA polymerase III transcription; shuttles between the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Aip Three Complex
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants show slow growth, reduced competitive fitness and increased telomere length

function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytosol and to the nucleus in different large-scale studies

name: Suppressor of Kre Null
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have decreased ethanol tolerance, are sensitive to oxidative stress and dessication, show delayed S phase progression, increased mutation frequency, decreased filamentous growth under nitrogen starvation, and increased chitin deposition; overexpression slows growth, interferes with budding and cellular morphology
function: A sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor that regulates transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter in response to oxidative stress; also involved in DNA-templated transcription, regulation of cell size, and response to osmotic stress and singlet oxygen; localized to the nucleus

name: HnRNP MethylTransferase
function: Nuclear protein-arginine omega-N methyltransferase that adds methyl groups to unmethylated terminal nitrogen atoms; involved in transcription regulation and mRNA export

name: Disruptor Of Telomeric silencing
function: Thioredoxin peroxidase involved in oxidative stress response and maintaining cell redox environment; localized to the nucleus

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in various media and decreased ability to utilize glutamate as nitrogen source; null mutant has an altered amino acid profile and a decreased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss; overexpression results in a decreased rate of vegetative growth, abnormal cell cycle arrest or delay in G2/M phase and increased invasive growth on nitrogen sufficient medium; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: U Three Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes cell cycle arrest in G1 and decreased levels of all rRNA precursors; in large-scale studies, repression confers resistance to cycloheximide; conditional mutant displays resistance to K28 killer toxin; heterozygous null mutant diploid displays reduced competitive fitness in YPD medium and is haploinsufficient; overproduction increases filamentous growth
function: snoRNA-binding nucleolar protein involved in rDNA transcription regulation and maturation of small subunit rRNA; subunit of the small-subunit processome and the t-UTP complex which forms a subcomplex of the 90S preribosome and is required for the subsequent assembly of the rest of the preribosome

name: Xenopus laevis Brix (Biogenesis of Ribosomes in Xenopus) homolog
phenotype: Essential gene; repressible mutant is defective in the biogenesis of the 60S large ribosomal subunit and has delayed processing of ribosomal rRNA; conditional mutant is heat sensitive, has decreased resistance to killer toxin and increased desiccation resistance; transposon insertion mutant displays a large increase in filamentous growth; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient

name: NucleOlar Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function decreases starvation resistance and competitive fitness; haploinsufficient, heterozygous null mutation in diploids causes starvation sensitivity and increased sensitivity to 5-fluorouracil, flucytosine
function: RNA binding protein that contributes to the maturation of LSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); localizes to nucleus

name: DOM34 Interacting Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to accumulation of aberrant rRNA processing intermediates and depletion of mature 18S rRNA; a reduction-of-function mutation confers sensitivity to benomyl in a systematic study

name: SPOrulation
function: Protein involved in meiosis and regulation of mitotic exit; localized to the nucleolus

name: Nuclear ImPort
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion leads to abnormal mitochondrial morphology; conditional (ts) mutant is sensitive to paromomycin and accumulates abnormal polysomes (halfmers)
function: Protein involved in maturation of LSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); contributes to ribosomal LSU biogenesis and assembly of LSU precursor of preribosome; localizes to nucleus, cytoplasm

name: eukaryotic translation initiation factor Four A Like
phenotype: Essential gene; dominant negative mutant accumulates aberrant rRNA processing intermediates and grows slowly; haploinsufficient
function: RNA helicase subunit of FAL1-SGD1 complex; contributes to maturation of SSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA)

name: contains KRR-R motif
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes the accumulation of rRNA precursors; in large-scale studies, repression causes reduced competitive fitness, increased diploidization, and sensitivity to MMS; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: Nucleolar protein involved in pre-rRNA cleavage and biogenesis of the small ribosomal subunit

Nuclear localization sequence (NLS) binding protein involved in rRNA processing and ribosomal small subunit assembly; binds to RNA and single-stranded telomeric DNA; localized to the nucleus and the nuclear envelope

name: FOrk Blocking less
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits lengthened replicative lifespan, increased resistance to MMS, and reduced Hot1p-mediated mitotic recombination; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays increased rDNA recombination during meiosis but decreased rDNA recombination during mitosis; null mutant shows reduced starvation resistance and competitive fitness
function: rDNA spacer replication fork barrier-binding protein; involved in replication fork arrest at rDNA repeats, chromatin silencing at rDNA, rDNA condensation, and maintenance of rDNA; also involved in replicative cell aging, extrachromosomal circular DNA accumulation during aging, dsDNA loop formation, and regulation of DNA replication and recombination; localizes to rDNA heterochromatin and the nucleolus

name: Chromosome Segregation in Meiosis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows aberrant chromosome segregation during meiosis, defects in sporulation and spore germination, and increased sensitivity to benomyl, hydroxyurea, Calcofluor White; null mutation reduces growth rate and competitive fitness
function: Subunit of the monopolin complex that is involved in homologous chromosome segregation during meiosis; required for attachment of spindle microtubules to kinetochores; localized to the nucleolus

name: Base MethylTransferase of 25S RNA
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness on minimal medium and increased fitness on both ethanol and glycerol-containing media; null mutant is sensitive to oxidative stress; null mutant displays increased sorbate resistance; null mutant has an extended hibernating lifespan when stored at reduced temperature; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness, are sensitive to DNA-damaging agents methyl methanesulfonate (MMS) and hydroxyurea (HU); conditional mutants arrest in meiosis I after spindle pole body duplication before spindle and synaptonemal complex formation; overexpression increases filamentous growth; heterozygous diploid nulls show increased growth rate
function: Thymidylate kinase, uridylate kinase and nucleoside diphosphate kinase; involved in the de novo biosynthesis of deoxythymidine diphosphate (dTDP), deoxyuridine diphosphate (dUDP), and deoxythymidine triphosphate (dTTP); localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: 6-n-HydroxylAMinopurine sensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to nucleoside analogs and azoles; overexpression increases resistance to nucleoside analogs and methotrexate
function: Nucleoside-triphosphate diphosphatase involved in nucleotide catabolism; active against a wide variety of nucleotide substrates including ATP, CTP, GTP, ITP, TTP, UTP and XTP; localizes to both the nucleus and the cytoplasm

name: Disruptor Of Telomeric silencing
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits sensitivity to gamma rays but resistance to X rays and MMS; null mutant shows decreased silencing and has telomeres of heterogeneous length; overexpression also causes decreased silencing; in large-scale studies, null mutant has shortened chronological lifespan, increased resistance to heat, and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: Histone methyltransferase, specific to H3-K79; involved in DNA damage checkpoint, recombinational and nucleotide-excision repair and chromatin silencing at telomeres; localized to the nucleus

name: SuPpressor of Ty's
phenotype: Essential gene in strain S288C, non-essential gene in strain Sigma1278b, in which nulls cannot grow invasively; conditional mutants glow slowly, are sensitive to heat; overexpression slows growth
function: DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in nucleosome remodeling, transcription antitermination, and mRNA export from the nucleus

name: Suppressor of the Ire1/Lhs1 double mutant
METhionine requiring
function: Bifunctional enzyme with O-acetylserine and O-acetylhomoserine sulfhydrylase activities involved in methionine and cysteine metabolism; catalyses the reaction between acetylated serine or homoserine with thiol to produce the corresponding amino acids; localized to the cytoplasm and plasma membrane

name: COenzyme Q
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and is sensitive to linoleic acid; in systematic studies mutants exhibit decreased competitive fitness under several conditions, produce fewer lipid droplets per cell, and have higher sensitivity to quinine, acetaldehyde, tunicamycin, DTT and various lipids; mutants are also deficient in utilization of alternative carbon and nitrogen sources

name: Sucrose NonFermenting
function: Subunit of the ESCRT III complex; involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism via the multivesicular body sorting pathway, late endosome to vacuole transport, intralumenal vesicle formation, ATP export, and the cellular response to anoxia; also localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Calcium And Membrane-binding protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants show decreased fitness and hyperosmotic stress resistance, but increased resistance to oxidative stress and to the antibiotic paromomycin
function: Promoter-binding guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor that binds calcium and phospholipids, and affects transcription, ribosome biogenesis, and translational elongation and termination

name: ARGinine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for arginine and displays decreased accumulation of arginine and increased accumulation of ornithine; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in synthetic media newly germinated spores have a decreased growth rate; homozygous diploid null has an increased sporulation efficiency; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: ornithine carbamoyltransferase involved in arginine biosynthesis; localized to the cytosol

name: SPErmidine auxotroph
function: Ornithine decarboxylase involved in putrescine and pantothenate biosynthesis; localized to the cytoplasm in large scale studies

name: URAcil requiring
phenotype: Null mutant is auxotrophic for uracil, and display increased resistance to ureidosuccinic acid and 5-fluoroorotic acid (5-FOA), and show increased acetic acid sensitivity
function: Orotidine-5'-phosphate decarboxylase involved in the 'de novo' biosynthesis of pyrimidine nucleobases; localized to the cytosol

name: Adrenodoxin Reductase Homolog
phenotype: Essential gene under standard aerobic conditions; null mutant grows slowly under anaerobic condition; repression casues accumulation of ubiquinone-6; overexpression in Sigma1278b leads to increased invasive growth

name: OxySterol binding protein Homolog
function: Lipid-binding protein involved in endocytosis, exocytosis, sterol metabolism and transport, and maintenance of cell polarity; localizes to the cortical endoplasmic reticulum

name: Twin Of Dot6p
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding protein involved in regulation of RNA polymerase II transcription; subunit of the Rpd3L-Expanded chromatin remodeling histone deacetylase complex

name: Yeast Casein Kinase I homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; overexpression causes slow growth in haploid and enhanced pseudohyphal growth in diploid; null mutant has decreased fitness and lifespan, exhibits abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired utilizatin of different nitrogen sources, increased manganese resistance, and is sensitive to protein synthesis inbibitor cycloheximide, herbicide amitrole, and carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Protein serine/threonine kinase involved in cell morphogenesis, endocytosis, and glucose-mediated signaling; localizes to the plasma membrane

name: AnKyrin Repeat containing
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes reduced protein palmitoylation, abnormal cell morphology (enlarged cells and elongated buds), decreased sporulation and respiratory growth; in large-scale studies null mutant is haploinsufficient and shows decreased competitive fitness; overexpression results in slow growth
function: Palmitoyltransferase involved in the regulation of mating and endocytosis; localizes to the Golgi; anchors sphinganine kinase LCB4 to membrane via palmitoylation

name: Coenzyme A Biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat sensitive; heterozygous diploid null mutant is haploproficient, has a decreased cell size, and decreased resistance to compounds that inhibit fatty acid and sphingolipid biosynthesis; hypomorphic DAmP allele displays decreased competitive fitness on minimal medium
function: Pantothenate kinase involved in coenzyme A biosynthetic process; localizes to the cytoplasm and nucleus in high-throughput studies

name: para-AminoBenZoic acid (PABA) biosynthesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA); in systematic studies, null mutant displays increased competitive fitness, sensitivity to sulfanilamide and small vacuolar fragmentation

name: COenzyme Q
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to respire and exhibits mitochondrial genome instability; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, sensitivity to desiccation, heat, and oxidative stress, increased starvation-induced mitophagy, and sensitivity to various chemicals
function: 4-hydroxybenzoate octaprenyltransferase, catalyzes the prenylation of para-hydroxybenzoate with farnesylfarnesylgeranyl, which is the second step in ubiquinone (coenzyme Q) biosynthesis; localized to mitochondrial membrane

name: CCR4 Associated Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness on minimal medium, and on rich medium with 6% ethanol; null mutant has decreased resistance to oxidative stress and decreased resistance to ethanol
function: Component of the CCR4-NOT complex involved in regulation of transcription from RNA Polymerase II promoter; predicted to have ATPase activity

name: Perish in the Absence of Cin8p
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants show slow vegetative growth and fermentation, increased growth on palmitoleic and oleic acids; null mutants show increased cell size, abnormal budding, decreased competitive fitness, decreased osmotic stress resistance, abnormal vacuolar morphology, are impaired in endocytosis and actin polymerization, and sensitive to cold, ethanol, caffeine, heavy metals cadmium and arsenic, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase inhibitor wortmannin, TOR inhibitor rapamycin, actin polymerization inhibitor latrunculin B, DNA synthesis inhibitor hydroxyurea, microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl, fluorescent stain Calcofluor White, and various antimicrobials; homozygous diploid nulls are enhanced in respiration and oxidative stress resistance, and show increased mitotic recombination and chromosome loss
function: Tubulin binding subunit of prefoldin complex involved in tubulin complex assembly; localizes to polysome and cytoplasm

name: Pbp1p Binding Protein
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm and nucleus in a large-scale study and to the cytoplasmic stress granule

name: AROmatic amino acid requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to 2-phenylethanol and shows auxotrophy for phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan; in large-scale studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including MMS, mycophenolic acid, cycloheximide, ethanol, bleomycin, azoles, camptothecin, cordycepin, eugenol, rapamycin, streptomycin, tunicamycin
function: Pentafunctional enzyme that catalyzes multiple steps in the chorismate biosynthesis pathway; localizes to the cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Cyclosporin-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has slow exponential growth rate and shows increased sensitivity to cycloheximide and hygromycin B; homozygous null mutant diploid shows increased sporulation; in systematic studies mutants display increased heat sensitivity and reduced competitive fitness
function: Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase that converts peptide bonds located next to proline residues between cis and trans configuration; involved in refolding of proteins during cellular response to heat; localized to the cytosol

name: Cyclosporin-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies mutants display sensitivity to citric acid and resistance to azole drugs; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Putative peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase based on sequence similarity; may convert peptide bonds located next to proline residues between cis and trans configuration; exact biological role is unknown; predicted to be localized to membranes

name: Cyclosporin-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation reduces competitive fitness; in systematic studies mutants exhibit increased sensitivity to heat, cycloheximide, camptothecin, fenpropimorph fluconazole, MMS, but decreased sensitivity to caffeine
function: Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase that converts peptide bonds located next to proline residues between cis and trans configuration; involved in folding of several proteins including Hsp90; localized to the cytoplasm

name: Cyclosporin-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation reduces competitive fitness and extends hibernating lifespan
function: Putative peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase based on sequence similarity; may convert peptide bonds located next to proline residues between cis and trans configuration; exact biological process is unknown; localized to the vacuole in a high-throughput study

name: Cyclosporin A-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased competitive fitness; homozygous diploid is sensitive to oxidative stress under competitive growth conditions
function: Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase that catalyzes the cis-trans isomerization of peptide bonds N-terminal to proline residues; its biological role and localization remain unknown

name: Cyclosporin-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutation causes elevated sensitivity to cycloheximide and bleomycin, whereas overexpression causes decreased growth rate and chromosomal instability
function: Putative peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase based on sequence similarity; may convert peptide bonds located next to proline residues between cis and trans configuration; exact biological role is unknown; localized to the ER

name: Fk 506-sensitive Proline Rotamase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth and increased resistance to rapamycin and FK506
function: Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase (PPIase) involved in chromatin organization, protein folding, and regulation of homoserine biosynthesis; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, and mitochondrion in high throughput studies

name: FKBP Proline Rotamase (isomerase)
function: Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase (PPIase); involved in histone proline isomerization, regulation of histone methylation and nucleosome assembly; localizes to the chromatin

name: ESSential
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion leads to cell cycle arrest at M phase; conditional mutations cause reduced histone H3 methylation, sensitivity to 4-NQO, MMS, cyclosporin A and UV; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Peptidylprolyl isomerase; binds RNA polymerase II core and has a role in termination of RNA polymerase II transcription and regulating phosphorylation of RNA polymerase II C-terminal domain; contributes to histone H3-K4 trimethylation, positive regulation of chromatin silencing at ribosomal DNA (rDNA) and negative regulation of histone deacetylation

name: ZEOcin resistance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have long telomeres, are sensitive to thymol, palmitoleic acid, resistant to manganese, auxotrophic for myo-inositol; null mutants show increased competitive fitness in minimal medium but decreased competitive fitness and survival in other conditions; overexpression confers slow growth; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient, have increased chromosome stability

name: PEroXisome related
function: Subunit of the peroxisomal importomer complex involved in the organization and biogenesis of peroxisomes, and import of proteins into the peroxisomal matrix

name: Mitochondrial DiVision
function: Ubiquitin binding protein that positively regulates mitochondrial fission; involved in mitochondrial genome maintenance and peroxisome fission; localized to mitochondrial outer membrane

name: PEroXin
function: Peroxisomal protein involved in the import of proteins into the peroxisomal matrix; also regulates the binding of seryl-tRNA synthetase with its cognate tRNA(Ser)

name: Adenine Nucleotide Transporter
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation increases sensitivity to streptomycin and cycloheximide in large scale studies; overexpression causes slow growth and abnormalities in cell cycle progression through G1 phase

name: PEroXin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows mislocalization of peroxisomal proteins into the cytoplasm and is unable to utilize oleic acid as a carbon source, also shows sensitivity to oleic and palmitoleic acids, and decreased replicative lifespan; in large-scale studies null mutation lowers competitive fitness
function: Subunit of the peroxisomal importomer complex involved in the docking of proteins in the peroxisomal matrix

name: PEroXisome related
function: Peroxisomal membrane protein involved in the organization and biogenesis of peroxisomes

name: PeroXisomal Protein
function: Peroxisomal protein whose biological role is unknown; localized to mitochondria in a large-scale study

name: PEroXin
function: Peroxisomal membrane protein involved in the targeting of other proteins into the peroxisomal membrane; also involved in peroxisome organization that takes place in the endoplasmic reticulum, and peroxisome inheritance from the mother cell to the bud

name: PEroXin
function: Peroxisomal targeting signal-binding importer involved in the docking of proteins in the peroxisomal matrix

name: PEroXin
function: Peroxisomal ubiquitin-protein ligase involved in peroxisome organization and the recycling of peroxisome targeting sequence receptors from cargo proteins back to the cytosol

name: AROmatic amino acid requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased accumulation of copper, calcium and sulfur, and increased sensitivity to amitrole and neomycin
function: Phenylpyruvate decarboxylase involved in the catabolism of aromatic amino acids, branched-chain amino acids, and methionine via the Ehrlich pathway; localizes to the cytosol in high-throughput studies

name: Pheromone-Regulated Membrane protein
function: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the plasma membrane and the endoplasmic reticulum in different large-scale studeies

name: Pheromone-Regulated Membrane protein
function: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown

name: Pheromone-Regulated Membrane protein
function: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown

name: CDP-Diacylglycerol Synthase
phenotype: Variously reported as essential and as non-essential gene; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness and sensitivity to rapamycin; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat; null mutants have abnormal morphology of the ER and lipid particles; overexpression slows growth in strain S288C, enhances pseudohyphal growth in strain Sigma1278b
function: Phosphatidate cytidylyltransferase (CDP-diacylglycerol synthetase), converts phosphatidic acid to CDP-diacylglycerol that serves as a substrate for synthesis of phospholipids (phosphatidylinositol, phosphatidylserine, phosphatidylcholine, cardiolipin); localized to endoplasmic reticulum

name: Actin Patch Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness and decreased biofilm formation; null mutants are also sensitive to antifungal drug miconazole, DNA-affecting chemical MMS and palmitoleic acid; overexpression in Sigma1278b increases filamentous growth
function: Phosphatidate phosphatase; catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidate to diacylglycerol; involved in lipid metabolism; localizes to the actin cortical patch and interacts with several cortical patch proteins

name: CHOline requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant without supplementation of choline in growth medium shows severely altered phospholipid content and distribution, overproduction and excretion of inositol, abnormal morphology of endoplasmic reticulum and lipid particles
function: Phosphatidylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PEMT) involved in phosphatidylcholine biosynthetic process; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: Phosphatidyl Inositol Kinase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations disturb phosphatidylinositol phosphate pools and cause multiple abnormalities in actin cytoskeleton, Golgi and vacuole morphology, defects in cytokinesis, autophagy, mitophagy, protein trafficking
function: 1-phosphatidylinositol 4-kinase involved in phosphatidylinositol phosphorylation; localizes to trans-Golgi network and nucleus

name: AUreobasidin A Resistance
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant displays decreased accumulation of ceramide and inositol phosphoceramide; repressible mutant has disassembled intranuclear and cytoplasmic microtubules, a reduction in beta-tubulin levels and diffuse cell surface disposition of chitin; overexpression results in a decreased rate of vegetative growth and hyperosmotic stress resistance; dominant mutant and overexpressor are resistant to aureobasidin A

name: Suppressor of ACtin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation affects phosphatidylinositol phosphate pools and leads to abnormal actin cytoskeleton, defects in protein secretion, endocytosis and vacuolar transport, increased sensitivity to low temperatures, cell wall-affecting drugs (caffeine, Calcofluor White) and multiple other chemicals; mutations cause inositol auxotrophy
function: Phosphatidylinositol phosphate phosphatase; involved in the hydrolysis of PI3P, PI4P, and PI(3,5)P2; localizes as an integral membrane protein to the endoplasmic reticulum, and Golgi apparatus

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants accumulate Berkeley bodies and are defective in protein secretion and autophagy

name: Phosphatidyl Inositol Synthase
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function results in cell cycle arrest, increased levels of phosphatidylcholine and decreased levels of phosphatidylinositol; overexpression leads to slow growth
function: CDP-diacylglycerol-inositol 3-phosphatidyltransferase involved in phosphatidylinositol biosynthesis; integral to membrane and localizes to Golgi apparatus and mitochondrial outer membrane, to endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies

name: Chs5 Spa2 Rescue
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers cadmium sensitivity; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to anoxia and to rapamycin
function: Phosphatidylinositol transfer protein that mediates transport of phosphatidylinositol within the cell; involved in phospholipid metabolism; localized to the cytosol, endosome, and lipid droplets

name: PhosphatidylSerine Decarboxylase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has fragmented and aggregated mitochondria, and displays defective respiratory growth; null mutant accumulates elevated levels of phosphatidylinositol but reduced levels of other phospholipids; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness and reduced resistance to various chemicals; overexpression in strain Sigma1278b confers increased invasive growth
function: Phosphatidylserine decarboxylase involved in phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis, positive regulation of protein processing, and positive regulation of mitochondrial fusion; undergoes autoprocessing; integral component of mitochondrial inner membrane

name: CHOline requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires choline for growth, has elevated sensitivity to ionic stress, and has increased resistance to killer toxin HM-1; in large-scale experiments, null mutant shows decreased resistance to acid pH and various chemicals
function: Phosphatidylserine synthase (CDP-diacylglycerol-serine O-phosphatidyltransferase) involved in phosphatidylserine biosynthetic process; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondrial outer membrane

name: AuTophaGy related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows no autophagy, pexophagy or mitophagy, increased sensitivity to nitrogen starvation and is unable to sporulate; also shows abnormal vacuolar morphology and decreased rate of respiratory growth
function: Subunit of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase complex that binds phosphatidylinositol-3,5-bisphosphate and ubiquitin; involved in macroautophagy, cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway late nucleophagy, peroxisomal degradation, piecemeal microautophagy of nucleus, vacuolar protein processing and late endosome to vacuole transport; localizes to the  pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS)

name: NEOmycin-resistance
function: Putative aminophospholipid translocase (flippase); involved in endocytosis, vacuolar biogenesis and Golgi to ER vesicle-mediated transport; localizes to endosomes and the Golgi apparatus

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutation leads to ergosterol auxotrophy and increased heat sensitivity; repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology and sensitivity to hydroxyurea; reduction of function results in increased sensitivity to MMS

name: LYSine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires lysine for growth; lys5-101 mutant is able to utilize alpha-aminoadipate as nitrogen source; in large-scale studies null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness, altered resistance to various chemicals, and increased glycogen accumulation; overexpression in a diploid confers increased pseudohyphal growth
function: Phosphopantetheinyl transferase involved in lysine biosynthesis; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Coenzyme A Biosynthesis
phenotype: Null mutants are inviable under standard aerobic conditions, viable under anaerobic conditions, sensitive to zinc deficiency; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat
function: Phosphopantothenate-cysteine ligase subunit of the CoA-synthesizing complex that is involved in coenzyme A biosynthetic process

name: Cap Associated Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays an increased rate of growth in exponential phase, while overexpression results in a decreased growth rate; null mutant has decreased starvation resistance, decreased ability to utilize ammonium sulfate as nitrogen source, and decreased resistance to stress due to zinc deficiency; null mutant displays increased replicative and decreased chronological lifespan; homozygous diploid null mutant has a decreased sporulation efficiency

name: TRyPtophan
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes tryptophan auxotrophy and increased cold sensitivity; null mutant is also sensitive to gamma rays, acetate, cisplatin, daunorubicin, and shows decreased competitive fitness in systematic studies
function: Phosphoribosylanthranilate isomerase involved in tryptophan biosynthesis

name: ADEnine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays adenine auxotrophy and increased sensitivity to tellurite; in large-scale studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness, lower innate thermotolerance, shortened chronological lifespan
function: Phosphoribosylformylglycinamidine synthase involved in purine nucleotide and 'de novo' IMP (inosine monophosphate) biosynthetic processes; localized to the cytoplasm

name: ADEnine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays adenine auxotrophy and resistance to cisplatin; in large-scale studies null mutant is haploinsufficient and shows shortened chronological lifespan
function: Amidophosphoribosyltransferase involved in 'de novo' IMP (inosine monophosphate) biosynthetic process; localized to the cytoplasm

name: Rich in asparagine (N) and glutamine (Q)
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation leads to loss of [PIN+] prion and decreased de novo generation of [PSI+] prion; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased anaerobic growth and increased sensitivity to rapamycin; overexpression in W303 leads to delay in cell cycle progression through the M phase
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytosol

name: CANavanine resistance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutations cause arginine auxotrophy; null mutant is resistant to canavanine
function: Permease involved in transmembrane transport of basic amino acids; localizes to the plasma membrane and to lipid rafts

name: Pleiotropic Drug Resistance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null and point mutations confer resistance or sensitivity to various drugs; in large-scale studies, null mutation confers a filamentous growth defect, increased competitive fitness in minimal medium, and altered resistance to a wide variety of drugs
function: Plasma membrane ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter involved in resistance to multiple drugs; facilitates drug removal from the cell

name: STErile
function: Peptide-transporting ATPase involved in the export of a-factor pheromone; localizes to the Golgi apparatus, plasma membrane, and mating projection tip

name: Plasma Membrane ATPase
function: Proton pump localized to membrane rafts in the plasma membrane; regulates intracellular pH by pumping protons out of the cell

name: 5-FlUoRouridine sensitivity
function: Uracil:cation symporter; localizes to plasma membrane and membrane rafts

name: ALuminum Resistance
phenotype: Null mutants grow very slowly; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl; overexpression slows growth, increases sensitivity to rapamycin
function: Magnesium transmembrane transporter; localized in plasma membrane

name: Plasma Membrane ATPase
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations cause heat sensitivity, reduced innate thermotolerance, killer toxin resistance, longer replicative lifespan, and increased formation of the [GAR+] prion; in large-scale studies, heterozygous null mutant has decreased competitive fitness and shows altered resistance to various chemicals; overexpression also confers a growth disadvantage
function: Proton pump localized to membrane rafts in the plasma membrane; regulates intracellular pH by pumping protons out of the cell

name: GlycerophosphoInosiTol
function: Glycerophosphodiester and glycerol-3-phosphate transmembrane transporter; involved in transport of glycerol-3-phosphate and glyceroldiester across plasma membrane

name: Heat Shock Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes slow growth, increased flocculation, and sensitivity to cell-wall affecting drugs (Congo Red, caffeine)
function: Lipid binding protein; involved in plasma membrane organization and response to oxidative, osmotic and heat stress; localized to plasma membrane

name: Ammonia (Ammonium) Transport Outward
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is a myo-inositol auxotroph; null mutant displays decreased accumulation of the calcium and copper cations, and decreased sulfur anion accumulation; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: Plasma membrane protein Upregulated during Nitrogen stress
Implicated in Zinc Homeostasis
function: A protein that negatively regulates transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter and is involved in cellular zinc ion homeostasis and response to toxic substances; localized to the plasma membrane

name: Acids Quinidine Resistance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to short-chain monocarboxylic acids, quinidine and ketoconazole; overexpression increases excretion of amino acids and confers resistance to monocarboxylic acids and quinidine

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional and repressible mutants arrest as large-budded cells in telophase with an abnormal nuclear morphology; overexpression results in a large multibudded cell cycle arrest with an abnormal actin cytoskeleton, an increase in bipolar budding, and cells with multiple nuclei; homozygous diploid mutants have an increased frequency of chromosome loss, defective meiosis and reduced sporulation
function: Protein kinase that plays a role in exit from mitosis; regulates nuclear organization, spindle pole body separation, and protein localization to mitotic spindle pole body; involved in local activation of Rho1p at the division site by activation of GEF, Tus1p; involved in meiotic spindle assembly, synaptonemal complex disassembly, and resolution of meiotic recombination intermediates; associates with the nuclear mitotic cohesin complex and localizes to the nucleus, bud neck, and spindle pole

name: Poly(A) Binding protein
phenotype: Essential gene; heat-sensitive mutant arrests as unbudded cells and displays shorter polysomes and longer mRNA poly(A) tail length at restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, heterozygous null mutant exhibits heat sensitivity, reduced competitive fitness, and sensitivity to some chemicals; overexpression confers chromosomal instability, increased invasive growth, and reduced vegetative growth rate
function: Poly(A) binding protein involved in control of the length of poly(A) tails on nuclear mRNA transcripts; localized to the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: PolyUridylate Binding
function: Protein that binds to poly(U) RNA and mRNA; involved in nonsense-mediated mRNA decay, regulation of mRNA stability, and stress granule assembly; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm, and to both cytoplasmic stress granules and mRNA processing bodies

name: Messenger RNA EXport factor of 67 kDa
SUPpressor
phenotype: Essential gene; mutations cause aberrant cell shape and sensitivity to heat, cold, hyperosmotic stress, caffeine, HU, paromomycin, or cycloheximide; ts mutation blocks cytokinesis at the restrictive temperature; mutation blocks respiratory growth; mutations confer increased resistance to K. lactis zymocin and increased accumulation of certain tRNAs; in large-scale studies, repression confers lower competitive fitness; conditional mutant displays chromosome instability at the semi-permissive temperature; overexpression causes slow growth and G1 phase arrest or delay; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to starvation and echinocandin, and displays haploinsufficiency
function: Codon-specific translation release factor involved in translation termination and snoRNA transcription termination; subunit of heterodimeric translation release factor complex involved in release of nascent polypeptides from ribosomes; also localizes to cytoplasmic stress granules

name: Diadenosine and Diphosphoinositol Polyphosphate phosphohydrolase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates elevated amounts of inositol polyphosphates; overexpression results in increased resistance to rapamycin

name: HEMe biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene on standard rich medium due to heme auxotrophy; mutants lack ergosterol, fail to respire, and exhibit increased nystatin resistance; in large-scale studies, repressing expression confers increased competitive fitness; heterozygous null diploid shows increased heat sensitivity
function: Hydroxymethylbilane synthase involved in the biosynthesis of heme; catalyzes the conversion of four porphobilinogen molecules into hydroxymethylbilane; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Degradation of Allantoin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction of function decreases utilization of urea s nitrogen source; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness
function: A sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor involved in both allantoin breakdown and nitrogen catabolite activation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter; localized to nucleus

name: General Control Nonderepressible
function: Putative ATPase involved in translational elongation regulation; localizes to cytosolic ribosome

name: General Control Nonderepressible
function: Protein involved in the regulation of translational elogation; localizes to cytosolic ribsosome

Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; colocalizes with COPI-coated vesicles and localizes to the Golgi apparatus in multiple large-scale studies; localizes to the nuclear periphery

name: Adenine PhosphoribosylTransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, accumulates hydrogen sulfide under cysteine supplementation, and is sensitive to calcium chelator BAPTA
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum and colocalizes with ribosome in large scale studies

name: Golgi/endosome Localized Dsc protein
function: Subunit of Dsc E3 ubiquitin ligase complex with role in transporting the complex to Golgi/endosome; predicted to be integral to membrane
Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell periphery

name: DEAH-box RNA helicase
phenotype: Essential gene; a dominant negative mutation causes decreased growth rate and accumulation of aberrant 23S rRNA intermediates; overexpression in a systematic study leads to abnormal cell cycle progression

name: ExtraCellular Mutant
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness, displays defective accumulation of 60S ribosomal subunits; null mutant also has increased heat shock resistance, and decreased resistance to various stressors including acid pH, calcofluor white and tunicamycin

name: DnaJ protein Involved in ER-associated Degradation
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the mitochondrion in different large-scale studies

name: Defective for Filamentous Growth
phenotype: Non-essential gene; homozygous diploid transposon insertion mutant is unable to undergo nitrogen starvation induced pseudohyphal growth, hypoglycosylates carboxypeptidase Y and accumulates polyprenol with a corresponding reduction in dolichol; null mutant displays increased biofilm formation, an endocytosis defect and decrease in transposable element transposition
function: Steroid 5-alpha-reductase that contributes to dolichol-linked oligosaccharide biosynthesis and polyprenol degradation; involved in pseudohyphal growth; integral to membrane and localises to endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies

name: Calcofluor White Hypersensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutants are sensitive cell wall-affecting drugs, such as Calcofluor White; in systematic studies null mutation confers sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including hygromycin B, bleomycin, cycloheximide, fluconazole, tunicamycin; overexpression increases sensitivity to rapamycin
function: Mannosyl-oligosaccharide glucosidase involved in fungal-type cell wall biogenesis and protein N-linked glycosylation; localized to the endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: ProFilin of Yeast
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C, non-essential in Sigma1278b and other strain backgrounds; null mutant in a non-essential background has a growth defect, is temperature sensitive, is larger and rounder than wt, with a decreased unipolar budding pattern, altered actin cytoskeleton morphology, delocalized chitin deposition, and is often multinucleate; null mutant has a reduced mating efficiency when cells are mating type alpha; conditional mutant displays increased chromosomal instability; heterozygous diploid null mutant has reduced starvation resistance; overexpression results in a reduced growth rate
function: Peripheral plasma membrane protein capable of binding actin monomers, PIP2, and proline-rich regions of proteins; involved in sequestering of actin monomers and positive regulation of formin-nucleated actin cable assembly; also localizes to cytosol

name: POLymerase
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes chromosome instability; point mutations confer increased mutation frequency, increased mitotic recombination, aberrant meiotic recombination, and resistance to HU and MMS; in a large-scale study, point mutants have reduced competitive fitness and display chromosome instability
function: Sliding clamp for DNA polymerase delta; involved in DNA replication and DNA repair processes it exists in a trimeric complex form.
Prolyl-tRNA synthetase that catalyzes prolyl-tRNA aminoacylation through the coupling of proline to prolyl-tRNA; colocalizes with ribosomes

name: BLeoMycin resistance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive, and displays decreased competitive fitness on minimal and synthetic complete media; null mutant is sensitive to dessication stress; null mutant has an elevated frequency of respiration-deficient petite colonies; null mutant is defective in the sequestration of proteasome core particles in proteasome storage granules during stationary phase; null mutant displays increased sensitivity to DNA damaging agents, and topo II inhibitors; null mutant displays increased resistance to cycloheximide, tunicamycin, edelfosine and Mg2+ ions

name: FUnction of Boundary
function: Proteasome-binding protein whose biological role is unknown

name: Histone Synthetic Lethal
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased growth rate in rich media and displays strain specific (W303) elongated buds with an undivided nucleus in the bud neck; haploid null displays increased invasive growth, and homozygous diploid null has elevated pseudohyphal growth; null mutant has decreased chronological lifespan, desiccation resistance, and thermotolerance; Swe1p is stabilized and less hyperphosphorylated during G2/M phase in the haploid null mutant; haploinsufficiency in the heterozygous diploid null results in elevated chromosomal instability; in large-scale studies the null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness, decreased sporulation and elevated oxidative stress resistance
function: Protein-arginine N-methyltransferase involved in protein catabolism and regulation of the G2/M transition of mitosis; localizes to the septin collar of the bud neck, and the outer plaque of the spindle pole body in the G1 phase of the cell cycle

name: Essential Nuclear Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion results in accumulation of unprocessed rRNA precursors; reduction-of-function mutations cause decreased competitive fitness and sensitivity to MMS; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) binding protein that contributes ribosomal RNA (rRNA) processing and endonucleolytic cleavage at A2; involved with poly(A)+ messenger RNA (mRNA) export from nucleus; localizes with small subunit precursor of the preribosome

name: ZInc finger Motif protein of 17 kDa
phenotype: Essential gene; repression adversely affects mitochondrial morphology and G1 cell cycle progression; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat, reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploproficient

name: Bud EMergence
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly, fails to form shmoo under alpha factor treatment, shows reduced mating efficiency, decreased invasive growth and is unable to form pseudohyphae
