name: Bem1 (One) Interacting protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium; homozygous diploid null mutant has decreased oxidative stress resistance; null mutant displays increased resistance to treatment with bleomycin, camptothecin, cycloheximide and miconazole; overexpression results in a growth defect, increased cell size, a round morphology and an abnormal budding index with an increased quantity of unbudded cells; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: Bem1 (One) Interacting protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a respiratory growth defect, and decreased fitness on minimal media; null mutant has enhanced replicative lifespan; null mutant displays decreased starvation resistance; null mutant has an abnormal cellular distribution of Cdc24p; overexpression results in a growth arrest as large, round, unbudded cells; null mutant displays a reduction in filamentous growth, and an inability to undergo invasive growth, while overexpression results in enhanced invasiveness on nitrogen-sufficient medium

name: Important for cleavage and PolyAdenylation
function: Protein of unknown function implicated in pre-mRNA cleavage and polyadenylation; binds to multiple ubiquitin conjugating enzymes and alters Ub-mediated proteasome activity

name: Alpha1-proteinase inhibitor-Degradation Deficient
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows sensitivity to cadmium but increased resistance to DNA-damaging drugs 4-NQO, camptothecin and MMS; homozygous null mutant diploid shows increased resistance to oxidative stress in competitive-growth studies

name: Transfer RNA Methyltransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in large-scale studies, the null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness and slightly abnormal vacuolar morphology; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient under conditions mimicking Phase II of a batch fermentation
function: Protein that methylates tRNAs; localizes to cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: BaX Inhibitor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to apoptosis induction by weak acids or oxidative stress, but more succeptible to apoptosis induction by heat shock, ethanol or glucose; null mutant shows prolonged chronological and replicative lifespan, and increased sensitivity to ER stress-inducing drugs beta-mercaptoethanol and tunicamycin

name: Ribosome Production Factor

function: Subunit of 66S preribosome involved in maturation of LSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and 5.8S rRNA from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); contributes to LSU assembly and export from nucleus; localizes to nucleolus

name: RNA-Binding Suppressor of PAS kinase
function: Protein that is required for assembly of RNA Polymerase III complex, shuttles between nucleus and cytoplasm

name: BUD site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant diploid displays aberrant random budding pattern and abnormal movement of secretory vesicles; null mutants in systematic studies show sensitivity to caffeine, camptothecin, cycloheximide, fluconazole, rapamycin, and resistance to hydroxyurea, tunicamycin

name: BUD site selection
phenotype: Non-essential gene; homozygous null mutant diploid shows abnormal unipolar budding pattern; in systematic studies null mutant displays increased sensitivity to osmotic stress and cell wall affecting drug caffeine; overexpression causes slow growth

name: HIgh Temperature growth

name: Vps10 (Ten) Interacting

name: ERd Suppressor

name: Cytochrome Oxidase Assembly

name: MiniChromosome Maintenance

name: MiniChromosome Maintenance

function: Chromatin- and DNA replication origin-binding component of the MCM mini-chromosome maintenance complex involved in initiation and regulation of DNA replication; also involved in pre-replicative complex assembly and double-strand break repair

name: NifU-like protein

name: BolA-like protein

function: Mitochondrial matrix protein involved in transferring [4Fe-4S] clusters from the ISA complex to client proteins

phenotype: Essential gene; several point mutations cause slow growth; haploinsufficient, null mutation in heterozygous diploid results in decreased cell size, slow growth and starvation sensitivity
function: GTP binding protein involved in assembly of large subunit precursor of preribosome and ribosomal large subunit biogenesis; contributes to ribosomal subunit export from nucleus and ribosomal RNA (rRNA) processing

name: NucleOlar G-protein
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C; depletion results in slow growth; in Sigma1278b null mutation causes defects in filamentous growth
function: A putative GTPase involved in exporting the ribosomal large subunit from the nucleus; localizes to the nucleous and nucleoplasm, as well as the preribosome large subunit precursor

name: Gly-Pro-Asn (N) motif
function: GTP binding protein involved in localization of the RNA polymerase II complex to the nucleus and establishment of mitotic sister chromatid cohesion

name: Altered Inheritance rate of Mitochondria
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in various media, a decreased respiratory growth rate, and decreased rate of utilization of various carbon and nitrogen sources; null mutant has a reduced cell size, increased heat sensitivity, and decreased chronological lifespan; null mutant displays a reduced frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss and elevated levels of Rnr3p, indicative of genome instability; null mutant contains severely reduced lipoate levels and is unable to lipoylate several mitochondrial enzymes; null mutant has decreased resistance to oxidative stress and desiccation but increased resistance to zinc deficiency
function: Lipoate-protein ligase involved in protein lipoylation; localized to mitochondria

name: Defective for Filamentous Growth
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutants in systematic studies have low competitive fitness and show slow growth and increased sensitivity to various chemicals, including rapamycin, neomycin, chloroquine, Congo Red

name: Defective Cell Wall
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness and increased sensitivity to low pH and antifungal agent neothyonidioside

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant diploid shows abnormal random budding pattern

name: SPOrulation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null and conditional mutants have decreased sporulation efficiency; null mutants display abnormal nuclear and endoplasmic reticulum morpholgies; heterozygous null mutant displays decreased fitness

phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutation causes increased biofilm formation, increased chronological lifespan, but decreased competitive fitness; overexpression confers slow growth

name: Amino acid Vacuolar Transport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased proline levels in vacuole; in systematic studies null mutant is sensitive to neomycin and oxidative stress; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Protein of unknown biological role; predicted to be an amino acid transporter; localizes to the vacuole

name: Amino acid Vacuolar Transport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness, weak sensitivity to caffeine, reduced growth on galactose
function: Protein of unknown biological role; predicted to be a transporter

name: P-BodY associated protein
function: Component of the cytoplasmic mRNA processing body (P body);   but not involved in mRNA catabolic process

name: Yeast PQ-loop protein
function: A basic amino acid transmembrane transporter protein involved in basic amino acid transmembrane export from the vacuole that is an integral component of fungal-type vacuolar membrane
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: PYruvate Carboxylase
function: Pyruvate carboxylase that catalyzes the carboxylation of pyruvate to form oxaloacetate; involved in gluconeogenesis; localizes to the cytosol

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; heterozygous null mutant displays decreased fitness; conditional mutant is heat-sensitive and arrests in an unbudded state; overexpression confers chromosome instability
function: Pyruvate kinase that catalyzes the final step in glycolysis, the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, which is then utilized in anaerobic or aerobic respiration; localized to the cytoplasm

name: Biosynthesis of Nicotinic Acid
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for nicotinic acid, shows elevated sensitivity to oxidative stress and defective respiratory metabolism; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness
function: Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase involved in de novo NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan; localizes to both the cytoplasm and nucleus

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations cause defects in protein secretion, abnormal secretory vesicles and vacuolar morphology, decreased autophagy, abnormal budding and sporulation; overexpression results in slow growth
function: GTPase involved in Golgi to plasma membrane transport, vesicle fusion, and exocytosis; also involved in membrane addition at the site of cytokinesis, autophagy, and ascospore-type prospore assembly; localizes to the incipient bud site, mating projection tip, and transport vesicle

name: Yeast Protein Two
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits decreased fitness, abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired utilization of various nitrogen sources, short telomeres, decreased lifespan, and decreased resistance to ethanol, caffeine, metals, and TOR inhibitor rapamycin; null mutant also fails to undergo autophagy; homozygous diploid null is thermotolerant, defective in sporulation, and sensitive to UV irradiation and a wide variety of antibiotics
function: GTPase involved in vacuole inheritance, regulation of non-autophagic vacuole fusion, retrograde (endosome to Golgi) transport, endocytosis, and the CVT pathway; also involved in macroautophagy and piecemeal microautophagy of the nucleus; colocalizes with the cargo-selective retromer subcomplex and localizes to the vacuole, vacuole membrane, and vacuole-mitochondrion membrane contact site

name: Yeast Protein Two
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants are slow-growing, sensitive to both heat and cold, have fragmented DNA, abnormal ER morphology and aberrant microtubules, undergo cell cycle arrest, do not undergo autophagy, and are sensitive to nitrogen starvation, antibiotics and dopaminergic antagonists; reduction-of-function mutants display chromosome instability and decreased fitness; homozygous diploid conditional mutants fail to sporulate
function: SNARE-binding GTPase involved in vesicle budding and docking, vesicle-mediated transport, endocytic recycling, macroautophagy, SNARE complex disassembly, and pre-mRNA catabolism; localizes to Golgi and ER membranes, pre-autophagosomal structures, and cytoplasmic vesicles

name: Yeast Protein Two
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits decreased fitness, slow growth, increased lifespan, abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired utilization of various nitrogen sources, impaired endocytosis, and decreased resistance to heat, metals, and TOR inhibitor rapamycin; homozygous diploid null is auxotrophic for myo-inositol, and is sensitive to caffeine and a variety of antibiotics; heterozygous diploid null mutant is haploinsufficient

name: STErile
phenotype: Non-essential gene; conditional and reduction-of-function mutants display a decrease in cell cycle arrest in response to pheromone addition, are unable to form shmoos, and have MatA cell specific sterility; reduction of function mutant has a unilateral cell fusion defect and produces elevated levels of Mfa1p/Mfa2p; null mutant has a reduced mating response to alpha factor; heterozygous null mutant has decreased starvation resistance
function: Alpha-factor pheromone receptor; role in pheromone-dependent signal transduction involved in cellular conjugation, mating projection assembly, and in cell fusion; localizes to the plasma membrane

name: AuTophaGy related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows normal autophagy and pexophagy; overexpression leads to decreased filamentous growth
function: Protein involved in the cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway, ER-associated ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process, protein complex localization, protein processing and vesicle organization; localizes to the pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS)

name: Split Finger Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have abnormal vacuolar morphology, decreased ethanol tolerance, small cells and nuclei, slow G1 phase progression, abnormal budding, and are sensitive to DNA-damaging agents, caffeine, heat, and various drugs; homozygous diploid nulls tolerate zinc deficiency, cannot sporulate; overexpression slows growth, interferes with silencing, and can be lethal in S288C; overexpression enhances pseudohyphal growth in Sigma1278b
function: Predicted RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in the activation of transcription of ribosomal protein genes and in the regulation of cell size; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Fork Head-Like
function: Transcription regulator-binding protein involved in the regulation of ribosomal protein gene transcription

name: Viable in a Hal3 Sit4 background
function: Protein involved in the organization of the septin ring, and in polarized actin organization at elevated temperature; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Activator of SKn7
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to arsenite; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to hyperosmotic stress and to many chemicals, including benomyl, camptothecin, cycloheximide, fluconazole, hydroxyurea, MMS, tunicamycin
function: Regulator of the Fps1p glycerol channel; involved in oxidative stress response, protein catabolism, and regulation of glycerol transport; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: tRNA Processing Deficient
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has low proportion of S-phase cells and G1 cells in heterozygous diploid; null mutant shows secreation defect

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays abnormally elongated buds, decreased growth rate and increased sensitivity to cold, benomyl, hydroxyurea, nocodazole; homozygous diploid is unable to complete meiosis
function: Type 2A protein phosphatase regulatory subunit; positively regulates mitotic entry at the G2/M phase transition and negatively regulates mitotic exit; regulator of the mitotic spindle assembly and the morphogenesis checkpoint; stimulates transcription in response to hyperosmotic stress by regulating the nuclear localization of Msn2p and Msn4p, as well as the activation of Msn2p; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, bud neck, bud tip, vacuolar membrane and shmoo tip

name: Bypass of CYclic-AMP requirement
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is temperature sensitive, is unable to utilize various fermentable carbon sources, has respiratory growth defects, is nitrogen starvation intolerant, has decreased spore viability, an inability to accumulate glycogen and reduced thermotoleance; null mutants are also sensitive to desiccation and have a decreased replicative lifespan; heterozygous diploid null has decreased resistance to osmotic and oxidative stress
function: cAMP-dependent protein kinase inhibitor involved in the regulation of signaling; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm and plasma membrane

name: homolog of S. pombe SDS22
phenotype: Essential gene; sds22-77 frameshift mutation causes heat- and cold-sensitivity and sensitivity to CsCl, formamide, and rapamycin at the restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, repression confers reduced competitive fitness; sds22-5 mutant displays chromosome instability at the semi-permissive temperature; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient but sensitive to starvation and to human cationic antimicrobial peptide derivatives
function: Protein serine/threonine phosphatase inhibitor and protein phosphatase activator; contributes to maintenance of protein location in nucleus and chromosome segregation; localizes to nucleus and protein phosphatase type 1 complex, to cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Vacuolar Transporter Chaperone
function: Calmodulin-binding regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex; involved in vacuole fusion, vacuolar transport, microautophagy and polyphosphate metabolism; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum and vacuole membranes

name: Vacuolar Transporter Chaperone
function: Calmodulin-binding regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex; involved in vacuole fusion, vacuolar transport, microautophagy and polyphosphate metabolism; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum and vacuole membranes

name: Trehalose Phosphate Synthase
function: Subunit of alpha,alpha-trehalose phosphate synthase complex that contributes to trehalose-synthase and trehalose-phosphate activities; involved in trehalose biosynthesis

name: REsistance to Glucose repression
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased rate of fermentative growth, sensitivity to starvation and elevated glycogen accumulation; null mutation decreases utilization of galactose, maltose, sucrose as carbon sources, also increases resistance to a toxic glucose analog 2-deoxy-D-glucose and causes sensitivity to L-canavanine; null mutants have large cell size

name: Chromosome Segregation in Meiosis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays high rate of chromosome instability, increased sensitivity to benomyl, hydroxyurea, camptothecin and selenomethionine; null mutant is also sensitive to UV; in systematic studies mutants are resistant to caffeine, cycloheximide and fluconazole
function: Subunit of the replication fork protection complex that stabilizes stalled replication forks during DNA replication; required for sister chromatid cohesion and chromosome segregation during meiosis; localized to the nucleus

name: PHOsphate metabolism
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits reduced acid phosphatase activity in low-inorganic phosphate medium; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays small cell size and elongated buds, reduced or increased competitive fitness in different media, increased chitin deposition, and MMS sensitivity
function: Acid phosphatase involved in the cellular response to phosphate starvation and the metabolism of phosphate-containing compounds; also has nucleoside-triphosphatase and nucleoside-triphosphate pyrophosphatase activities; localized to the cell wall

name: PHOsphate metabolism
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates reduced levels of N-ribosylnicotinamide; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays reductions in competitive fitness and starvation resistance, and is sensitive to sodium selenide
function: Alkaline phosphatase involved in protein dephosphorylation and nicotinamide nucleotide metabolism; localizes to the vacuole membrane

name: YIP One Partner
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a reduced ability to utilize glutamine or glutamate as nitrogen source; null mutant displays increased autophagy during nitrogen starvation; overexpression results in increased filamentous growth in sigma1278b; overexpression in another strain background results in lethality, with huge swollen cells that accumulate internal membranes, and have a block in membrane traffic; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: Bud EMergence
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a competitive fitness defect, a decreased growth rate in rich media and a severe respiratory growth defect; null and conditional mutants are heat sensitive, arresting as large, multinucleate cells, with some polyploid and aploid cells; null mutant is defective in polarization of the actin cytoskeleton, with reduced endocytosis; null mutant accumulates hyperphosphorylated Cdc24p at multiple cortical sites, displays increased Cdc42p activation, a reduction in Gic2p levels and elevated Slt2p phosphoryation in the absence of stress; null mutant displays increased chitin deposition, and mitophagy; null mutant is zymolyase sensitive; null mutant is sensitive to benomyl, caffeine, cell wall agents and zymolyase as well as to some DNA replication inhibitors and damaging agents; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient

name: FMN biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; depletion causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology; overexpression causes slow growth; haploinsufficient
function: Riboflavin kinase that contributes to FMN biosynthesis; localizes to mitochondrial inner membrane and intracellular membrane-bounded organelles

name: Suppressor of Mec1 Lethality
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased resistance to DNA damaging agents, while overexpression results in increased sensitivity; null mutant has elevated pools of dNTPs; null mutant has elevated mini-chromosome loss and elevated mitochondrial genome copy number; null mutant displays elevated temperature resistance and increased resistance to fluconazole; null mutant has a pseudohyphal growth defect; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: Inhibitor of ribonucleoside-diphosphate reductase (RNR); involved in mitochondrion organization and the cellular response to DNA damage; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Ribose-5-phosphate Ketol-Isomerase
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes increased sensitivity to arsenite; reduction of function leads to lower competitive fitness
function: Ribose-5-phosphate isomerase involved in pentose-phosphate pathway and pyridoxine biosynthesis; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Ribosomal Protein of the Small subunit
function: Subunit of the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit; involved in rRNA processing and export from the nucleus, assembly of the small ribosomal subunit, and translation

name: Ribosomal Protein of the Large subunit
phenotype: Essential gene; reduced function slows growth, enhances cold tolerance; missense mutants that correspond to human lymphoblastic leukemia mutations show ribosome biogenesis defects, as well as abnormal cytoplasmic accumulation of translation initiation factor Tif6p (eIF6) and ribosomal large subunit nuclear exporter Nmd3p; heterozygous diploid nulls are heat-tolerant
function: Subunit of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in ribosomal large subunit assembly, translation, and translational termination

function: Subunit of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in ribosomal large subunit assembly and translation

function: Ribosomal S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the monomethylation of large ribsomal subunit protein L42 (Rpl42ap/Rpl42bp); localizes to the nucleus

name: Ribosomal Protein of the Small subunit
function: Subunit of the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit; involved in maturation of the small subunit rRNA

name: Ribosomal Protein of the Small subunit
function: Subunit of the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit; involved in maturation of the small subunit rRNA

name: Ribosomal Protein of the Small subunit
function: Subunit of the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit; involved in maturation of the small subunit rRNA, and regulation of translational fidelity

function: Subunit of the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit; involved in maturation of the small subunit rRNA, and regulation of translational fidelity

function: Subunit of the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit; involved in assembly of the small ribosomal subunit and translation

function: Subunit of the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit; involved in assembly of the small ribosomal subunit and translation

name: Ribosomal protein lysine (K) Methyltransferase
function: Ribosomal S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the trimethylation of large ribsomal subunit protein L12 (Rpl12Ap/Rpl12Bp)

name: Ribosomal Protein P1 Beta
function: Protein kinase activating constituent of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in translation

name: Ribosomal Protein P2 Alpha
function: Protein kinase activating constituent of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in translation

name: Ribosomal Protein P2 Beta
function: Protein kinase activating constituent of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in translation

name: Ribosomal Protein P1 Alpha
function: Protein kinase activating constituent of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in translation

name: ZUOtin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants exhibit slow growth, abnormal vacuolar morphology, and decreased resistance to cold, gamma rays, various antibiotics, mutagens, protein synthesis inbibitor cycloheximide; null mutants also show defects in rRNA processing and export of ribosomes from the nucleus to the cytoplasm; homozygous diploid null mutants have abnormal cell shapes and budding patterns, and are defective in sporulation
function: Ribosome-binding protein involved in rRNA processing and nuclear export of ribosomal subunits; also implicated in translational frameshifting and the regulation of translational fidelity

name: Late-annotated Small Open reading frame
function: Protein with a potential role in iron homeostasis; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm

name: PEroXin
function: Peroxisomal membrane ubiquitin-protein ligase subunit of the peroxisomal protein import machinery, involved in the import of proteins into the peroxisomal matrix

name: Histone E3 Ligase
function: RING finger E3 ubiquitin ligase involved in ubiquitination and degradation of excess histones; localizes to the cytoplasm and colocalizes with ribosomes

name: High level expression Reduces Ty3 transposition
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutations cause decreased telomere length and increased sensitivity to MMS, sulfanilamide and verrucarin A
function: SCF, Cul3-RING and Cul8-RING ubiquitin ligase complex subunit involved in G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle; contributes to protein ubiquitination involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation, SCF-dependent proteasomal ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Small NUclear ribonucleoprotein associated
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes mis-localization of box C/D snoRNAs to the nucleoplasm rather than the nucleolar body; in large-scale studies, conditional mutants display chromosome instability, sensitivity to K28 killer toxin, and reduced levels of Rnr3p; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to heat shock, oxidative stress, and verrucarin A; mutant is resistant to cycloheximide
function: RNA binding protein involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing; contributes to the maturation of SSU-rRNA from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA); associates with U4/U6 x U5 tri-snRNP complex

name: Nuclear Protein Localization
phenotype: Non-essential gene in S288C, reported essential in Sigma1278b; null mutant is sensitive to elevated temperatures, metals and multiple drugs, including rapamycin, paromomycin, tacrolimus; in systematic studies homozygous null mutant diploid shows slow growth, decreased fermentative growth, inositol auxotrophy, decreased innate thermotolerance, abnormal budding pattern and elevated sensitivity to multiple drugs, including doxorubicin, echinocandin, fenpropimorph, hygromycin B
function: RNA-binding protein involved in pre-mRNA splicing and mRNA export from the nucleus; regulates RNA pol II transcription elongation and termination; implicated in translation termination and repression of translational initiation; shuttles between the cytoplasm and nucleus

name: HEterogeneous nuclear rnp K-like gene
function: mRNA binding protein; involved in the localization of the ASH1 mRNA and telomere maintenance; localizes to cytoplasmic mRNA processing body and the telomeric region of nuclear chromosome

name: Nuclear Assembly Factor
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to decreased levels of mature rRNA, tRNA, snoRNA species and accumulation of aberrant RNA processing intermediates
function: RNA-binding protein involved in the assembly of box H/ACA small nucleolar ribonucleoprotein complexex

name: WHIskey
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased critical cell size at START, while overexpression results in G1 arrest as large unbudded cells with decreased viability; null mutant has an invasive growth defect, decreased mating efficiency and pheromone sensitivity; null mutant is sensitive to translation elongation inhibitors, and spontaneously diploidizes due to an increased rate of whole-genome duplication; homozygous diploid null has a pseudohyphal growth defect, decreased sporulation efficiency, decreased chronological lifespan and decreased desiccation resistance, while the heterozygous null is haploinsufficient

name: Nuclear pre-mRNA Down-regulation
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function results in accumulation of abnormally processed mRNA, rRNA, snRNA precursors; mutants show small cell size and slow growth; overexpression increases invasive growth in Sigma1278b
function: RNA-binding subunit of the Nrd1 complex; involved in exosome-dependent termination of RNA polymerase II transcription, nuclear mRNA surveillance, catabolism of CUTs and antisense RNA, and 3-end processing of mRNA, tRNA, snoRNA, and snRNA; localizes to the nucleus

name: Rescuer Of Kem1
function: ATP-dependent RNA helicase; involved in the processing and maturation of the small subunit rRNA; localizes to the nucleolus in a small scale study and to 90S preribosome in a large scale study

name: Dead Box Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes slow vegetative growth, especially at lower temperatures, and increased innate thermotolerance and oxidative stress resistance; null mutant cells have fewer 60S ribosomal subunits relative to 40S, and show increased resistance to ER stress conferred by tunicamycin

name: Pre-mRNA Processing
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to defective processing of 35S pre-mRNA, depletion of 27S and 20S pre-rRNAs, and buildup of ribosomal proteins in the nucleolus; a conditional (ts) mutant accumulates pre-mRNAs and excised intron lariats; overexpression causes slow growth
function: ATP-dependent RNA helicase that contributes to maturation of SSU-ribosomal RNA (rRNA), LSU-rRNA, and 5.8S rRNA from tricistronic rRNA transcript; involved in spliceosomal complex disassembly; localizes to post-mRNA release spliceosomal complex, to 90S preribosome and mitochondrion in high-throughput studies

name: RNAPII DEgradation Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers abnormal cytokinesis and meiosis; null mutant is sensitive to 4-aminofolic acid, HU, MMS, and X-rays; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in several different media, slow fermentative growth and defective respiratory growth, enlarged cell size, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Protein involved in protein ubiquitination, ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation, transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair, telomere maintenance, and the response to DNA damage; localizes to the nucleus
Phosphatase subunit of the transcription factor TFIIIC complex; involved in recruiting TFIIIB to chromatin for transcription of RNA genes by RNA polymerase III

name: RNA polymerase I Enhancer Binding protein
phenotype: Essential gene in strain S288C, in which conditional mutants are heat-sensitive, and reduced function mutants are sensitive to microtubule-destabilising agent benomyl; non-essential gene in strain Sigma1278b, in which null mutants are impaired in filamentous growth
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding protein in the nucleus involved in regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II, and in the termination of transcription by RNA polymerase I

name: RNA Polymerase C
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show decreasing levels of tRNA; reduction-of-function mutations cause sensitivity to rapamycin and MMS, and increased chromosome instability
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase III that contributes to RNA polymerase III activity including termination of transcription

name: RNA Polymerase C
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to decreased levels of tRNA; reduction of function causes sensitivity to MMS; repression increases resistance to myriocin; heterozygous null mutant diploid is sensitive to starvation
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase III complex that contributes to RNA polymerase III activity; involved in transcription initiation from RNA polymerase III promoter and transfer RNA (tRNA) transcription by RNA polymerase III; localizes to nucleus and cytosol

name: RNA Polymerase C
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show decreasing levels of tRNA; mutants are sensitive to hygromycin B and Calcofluor White; haploinsufficient
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase III complex that contributes to RNA polymerase III activity; involved in transfer RNA (tRNA) transcription by RNA polymerase III; localizes to mitochondrion, to nucleus and cytosol in high-throughput studies

name: RNA Polymerase C
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show decreasing levels of tRNA and arrest their cell cycle at G1 phase; haploinsufficient
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase III complex that contributes to RNA polymerase III activity; involved in transfer RNA (tRNA) transcription by RNA polymerase III

name: RNA POlymerase
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to slow growth, lower mRNA production and decreasing cell viability; depletion causes inositol auxotrophy
function: An RNA-directed RNA polymerase with a role in translesion synthesis and transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter; localized to the core complex of RNA polymerase II

name: RNA Polymerase B
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes abnormally long transcripts; null mutant shows inositol auxotrophy, increased heat and cold sensitivity, and sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including caffeine, hygromycin B, formamide, mycophenolic acid, cisplatin; null mutant is also defective in anaerobic and respiratory growth and produces abnormally elongated buds
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase II core complex; contributes to RNA-directed 5'-3' RNA polymerase activity, transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair, transcription initiation from RNA polymerase II promoter; involved in maintenance of transcriptional fidelity during DNA-dependent transcription elongation from RNA polymerase II promoter

name: RNA Polymerase B
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations result in sensitivity to cicloheximide and paromomycin; haploinsufficient, heterozygous null mutant diploid produces large cells and is sensitive to starvation, heat, oxidative stress; reduction of function causes shortened telomeres
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase II core complex that contributes to transcription initiation from RNA polymerase II promoter; involved in positive regulation of translational initiation and of nuclear-transcribed messenger RNA (mRNA) poly(A) tail shortening; localizes to P-body, nucleus

name: RNA Polymerase A
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations lead to decreasing levels of rRNA; heterozygous null mutant diploid forms very small cells; repression causes opi- phenotype (excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase I that contributes to RNA polymerase I activity; involved in nucleolar large ribosomal RNA (rRNA) transcription by RNA polymerase I

name: NTS1 SIlencing protein 1
function: Nucleolar protein involved in termination of rRNA transcription by RNA polymerase I and silencing at rDNA locus

name: RNA Polymerase C
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations lead to decreasing levels of mRNA, rRNA and tRNA; heterozygous null mutant diploid produces very large cells; repression causes chromosome instability
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase I, III and II core complexes; involved in transcription by RNA polymerase I, II, III and transfer RNA (tRNA) transcription by RNA polymerase III; contributes to RNA-directed 5'-3' RNA polymerase activity; localizes to nucleolus, nucleus, cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: RNA Polymerase B
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations lead to decreased production of mRNA and rRNA; haploinsufficient
function: Protein involved in transcription by RNA polymerase I, II, and III; contributes to transfer RNA (tRNA) transcription by RNA polymerase III, RNA-directed 5'-3' RNA polymerase activity; subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerases I, III and RNA polymerase II core complexes

name: RNA Polymerase B
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause defects in RNA accumulation; haploinsufficient
function: Protein involved in transcription by RNA polymerase I, II, and III; contributes to RNA polymerase I, II, II activity and RNA-directed 5'-3' RNA polymerase activity; subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerases I, III and II core complexes

name: RNA POlymerase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants have lower accumulation of rRNA, mRNA and tRNA and show inositol auxotrophy
function: Subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerase I, III and II core complexes; involved in transcription by RNA polymerase I, II, III and transfer RNA (tRNA) transcription by RNA polymerase III; contributes to RNA-directed 5'-3' RNA polymerase activity

name: RNA Polymerase B
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show decreased production of mRNA, rRNA and tRNA; also show elevated chromosome instability and sensitivity to azauracil and mycophenolic acid; haploinsuficient, heterozygous null mutant diploids display very small cell size and decreased competitive fitness; reduction of function results in increased telomere length
function: Protein involved in transcription by RNA polymerase I, II, and III; contributes to RNA-directed 5'-3' RNA polymerase activity; subunit of DNA-directed RNA polymerases I, III and RNA polymerase II core complexes

name: PGK promoter directed OverProduction
function: Subunit of the CCR4-NOT complex; involved in nuclear-transcribed mRNA poly(A) tail shortening, as well as transcription elongation and transcription regulation from RNA polymerase II promoters; localizes to the cytoplasm and cytoplasmic mRNA processing body
An rRNA(cytosine-C5-)-methyltransferase localized to the nucleous

name: NucleOlar Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function results in defects in pre-rRNA processing that leads to decreased production of mature rRNA and 60S ribosomal subunits
function: Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) (cytosine-C5-)-methyltransferase; contributes to the maturation of LSU-rRNA from tricistronic rRNA transcript (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA), rRNA base methylation, and 66S preribosome assembly

name: SECretory
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in maturation of cell wall-bound proteins and shows increased sensitivity to cell wall affecting chemicals (Calcofluor White, caffeine, hygromycin B) and other factors (zinc, cadmium, benomyl, MMS, UV)

name: LYSine requiring
function: Saccharopine dehydrogenase involved in lysine biosynthesis; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: LYSine requiring
function: Saccharopine dehydrogenase involved in lysine biosynthesis; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: NuCLear protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to elevated temperatures, oxidative stress, and multiple chemicals, including caffeine, benomyl, azole drugs, MMS, DMSO, and shows increased cell size and reduced transposition of Ty elements; null mutation also increases resistance to spermine and tunicamycin; overexpression causes resistance to rapamycin
function: Transfer RNA (tRNA) (cytosine-5-)-methyltransferase; involved in tRNA wobble base cytosine methylation and response to hydrogen peroxide; localizes to nucleus

name: SPErmidine auxotroph
function: Adenosylmethionine decarboxylase involved in pantothenate, spermine and spermidine biosynthesis; localized to the nucleus and cytoplasm in large scale studies

name: Elongation Factor Methyltransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium; null mutant displays decreased trimethylation of eEF1A at K79
function: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the trimethylation of translational elongation factor EF-1 alpha (Tef1p/Tef2p); localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Nicotinamide N-methylTransferase
function: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent methyltransferase that trimethylates the N-terminal glycine residue and dimethylates lysine 3 in eEF1A; role in chromatin silencing at rDNA

name: Elongation Factor Methyltransferase
function: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the dimethylation of translation elongation factor EF2 (Eft1p/Eft2p) and methylates EF3 (Yef3p); role in translational termination; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Elongation Factor Methyltransferase
function: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the trimethylation of translation elongation factor EF2 (Eft1p/Eft2p); localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Cantharidin Resistance Gene
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers sensitivity and overexpression confers resistance to terpenoid blistering agent cantharidin; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to oxidative stress
function: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent methyltransferase that transfers a methyl group from S-adenosyl-L-methionine to a substrate; implicated in lipid homeostasis; cellular location is unknown

name: EH Domains and Endocytosis
function: Involved in the organization of endocytic sites and in the regulation of cytokinesis; binds to ubiquitin; localizes to actin cortical patches, the bud neck, the bud tip, the cytoplasm and the shmoo tip

name: DNA Polymerase B subunit 2
function: Subunit of the DNA polymerase epsilon complex; involved in maintenance of fidelity during DNA replication, error prone translesion synthesis, heterochromatin organization that contributes to chromatin silencing; also localizes to the cytoplasm

name: SEIpin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormally shaped lipid droplets; null mutant diploid is sensitive to tunicamycin and DTT, shows lower rate of anaerobic growth and decreased sporulation
function: Protein of the endoplasmic reticulum involved in lipid droplet biogenesis

name: ReTroGrade regulation
function: Non-DNA binding transcription factor; subunit of the SAGE-like SLIK histone acetyltransferase complex; involved in regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter by nitrogen catabolites, mitochondria-nucleus signaling pathway and other cellular processes

name: Synthetic Lethal with Gap
function: Transmembrane signaling receptor involved in Rho protein signal transduction and the response to osmotic stress and heat; involved in actin cytoskeleton organization, establishment of cell polarity, pexophagy, and cell wall organization; localizes to the plasma membrane and the bud neck

name: cell Wall integrity and Stress response Component
RIght Open reading frame
function: Protein kinase involved in repression of rDNA transcription by RNA polymerase I; also involved in rRNA processing and maturation; autophosphorylates; localizes to nucleolar chromatin and cytoplasm

name: Multicopy suppressor of LeFlunomide sensitivity
function: Protein involved in polarized actin organization at elevated temperature; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: CHeckpoint Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows abnormal cell cycle arrest following DNA damage and greatly increased rate of gross chromosomal rearrangements; null mutation confers sensitivity to selenomethionine, selenite and bleomycin; overexpression leads to slow growth

name: Suppressor of the LyTic phenotype
function: MAP kinase involved in control of cell wall integrity, regulation of proteasome assembly, response to osmotic stress and ER unfolded proteins; component of a MAP kinase regulatory cascade; localized to the cytoplasm and sites of cell wall growth (bud tips, bud necks, mating projections)

name: Cell wall Biosynthesis Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has defects in actin cytoskeleton and shows abnormal budding pattern, round cell shape, crinkled colony appearance and increased cell aggregation in liquid cultures; null mutant is also defective in mating projection formation; null mutants in Sigma1278b are incapable of invasive growth
function: Protein serine/threonine kinase involved in apical bud growth, establishment or maintenance of cell polarity, regulation of cell wall organization, and cell separation after cytokinesis; localizes to incipient bud sites, sites of polarized growth, the nucleus, and the cytoplasm

name: Bypass of C Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for inositol, has decreased competitive fitness on various media but increased fitness on YPD with 6% ethanol; null mutant has an increased critical cell size requirement at START, and a large cell size in both log phase and saturated culture, while overexpression results in a cell size reduction; null mutant displays increased sensitivity to several cell wall stressors (e.g. congo red, caffeine, and calcofluor white); null mutant has increased sensitivity to mating pheromone treatment while the overexpressor is more resistant; null mutant has a reduced chronological lifespan, and decreased resistance to zinc deficiency; homozygous diploid null mutant has an elevated sporulation efficiency; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate

name: Ribosomal lysine (K) Methyltransferase
function: Ribosomal S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the dimethylation of large ribsomal subunit protein L23 (Rpl23Ap/Rpl23Bp), and monomethylation of L18 (Rps18Ap and Rps18Bp); localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows defective internalization of endocytosis reporters; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased competitive fitness

name: CYtoKinesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in cytokinesis and displays abnormally shaped bud necks, slow growth rate and increased chromosome instability; in a systematic study, Sigma1278b mutants have defects in filamentous and invasive growth; in other systematic studies mutants are sensitive to Calcofluor White, caffeine, rapamycin, and resistant to tunicamycin, hydroxyurea and cycloheximide

name: Arx1 Little Brother
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to cycloheximide and fenpropimorph, but resistant to bleaomycin, caffeine, camptothecin and tunicamycin; overexpression causes slow growth

name: Signal Recognition Particle
phenotype: Essential gene in the S288C genetic background, non-essential in the Sigma1278b background; ts mutant mis-localizes polarity and secretion factor mRNAs to the mother cell instead of to the bud tip at the restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, repression causes increased competitive fitness and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; conditional mutant displays chromosome instability; null mutation in Sigma1278b background blocks invasive growth and decreases biofilm formation
function: Protein that binds GTP and signal recognition particles; involved in protein targeting to endoplasmic reticulum

name: SPOrulation
function: Protein involved in sporulation; localizes to the prospore membrane

name: Heat Shock Protein
function: Putative chaperone that binds to unfolded proteins; involved in cytoskeletal organization; localizes to the cytoskeleton and colocalizes with the chaperonin-containing T-complex

name: Plasma Membrane Proteolipid
function: Protein that binds to phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate, phosphatidylinositol-3,5-bisphosphate, phosphatidic acid, and sphingolipids; involved in cation transport and regulation of membrane potential; localized to the plasma membrane

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant arrests as large, unbudded cells and repressible mutant displays a G1 phase cell cycle defect; conditional mutant affects the polarized localization of Sec3p and Sec5p to emerging bud sites, bud tips, and bud necks; mutants with a reduction-of-function allele have a bilateral cell fusion defect; conditional mutant displays increased chromosomal instability; heterozygous diploid shows haploinsufficiency
function: GTPase involved in establishment of cell polarity, bud growth, septin ring organization, and mating; involved in regulating mitotic exit, pseudohyphal growth, non-autophagic vacuole fusion, and exocytosis; localizes to the nuclear, vacuolar, and plasma membranes and also to incipient bud sites, sites of polarized growth, and the septin ring

name: Carbamyl Phosphate synthetase A
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers arginine auxotrophy, and increased sensitivity to ferrozine, cobalt and fluorouracil; overexpression causes increased resistance to flucytosine, fluorouracil, azauracil, methotrexate, and rapamycin; in systematic studies mutants display reduced anaerobic growth rate, decreased competitive fitness, and sensitivity to hygromycin B, neomycin, amitrole, and strong vacuolar fragmentation
function: Glutamine-hydrolyzing subunit of carbamoyl phosphate synthase that catalyzes the synthesis of carbamoyl phosphate from bicarbonate; involved in biosynthesis of arginine; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: clathrin Associated Protein complex Small subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutant is sensitive to ferrous ion chelator ferrozine, shows elevated accumulation of cadmium and manganese, and reduced competitive fitness

name: clathrin Associated Protein complex Small subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in vacuolar protein transport and shows severe vacuolar fragmentation and reduced competitive fitness; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to ethanol; in diploids homozygous null mutation causes increased sensitivity to multiple drugs, including actinomycin D, bleomycin, caffeine, hygromycin B

name: Cap Binding Complex
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays sensitivity to 6-azauridine and mycophenolic acid; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness, increased telomere length, decreased sporulation in homozygous diploids

name: Function Unknown Now
phenotype: Non-essential gene, null mutant shows decreased silencing at telomeres, rDNA and siilent mating loci and also chromosome segregation defects;
function: DNA-dependent ATPase that binds chromatin; involved in DNA double-strand break processing and heterochromatin maintenence by chromatin silencing at telomere, silent mating-type cassette, rDNA; localizes to centromeric regions of chromosomes

name: Bad Response to Refrigeration
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive, has a decreased fermentative growth rate, decreased competitive fitness on standard growth media, but an increased respiratory growth rate; conditional mutant is cold sensitive and has a defect in the accumulation of spliceosomal snRNAs; null mutant has a cell polarity defect with hyperpolarized cells and elongated buds; null mutant has decreased resistance to oxidative stress, zinc deficiency, killer toxin, and dessication; null mutant displays enhanced glycogen accumulation and altered accumulation of alpha-amino acids; homozygous diploid null has a sporulation defect; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient

name: ADP-Ribosylation factor-Like
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has fragmented vacuoles and shows increased sensitivity to protein glycosylation inhibitor, tunicamycin, and cell wall-affecting dye, Congo Red

name: Curing of [URe3]
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased formation of [URE3] prion; in systematic studies, overexpression increases chromosome loss and rearrangements

name: J-type Accessory Chaperone
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to slow growth, sensitivity to benomyl, tunicamycin and MMS
function: Mitochondrial protein chaperone involved in iron-sulfur cluster assembly and required for aerobic respiration

name: Mitochondrial Acidic Matrix protein
function: Specific translational activator for the mitochondrial COX1 mRNA; localizes to the mitochondrial matrix

name: Mitochondrial Splicing Suppressor
function: Mitochondrial translation regulator required for assembly of mitochondrial respiratory chain complex IV; localizes to mitochondrial inner membrane; colocalizes with vacuolar membranes under oxidative stress

name: SPErmidine auxotroph
function: Spermidine synthase involved in spermidine and pantothenate biosynthesis; localized to nucleus and cytoplasm in large-scale studies

name: SPErmidine auxotroph
function: Spermine synthase involved in spermine and pantothenate biosynthesis; localized to the cytoplasm in large scale studies

name: SUppressor of Rvs161 and rvs167 mutations
Long-Chain Base
function: Sphingosine kinase, phosphorylates dihydrosphingosine to form dihydrosphingosine-1-phosphate; involved in sphingolipid metabolism; localizes to plasma membrane, endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi membranes

name: Complexed With Cef1p
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function decreases fitness in a competitive growth study
function: Component of U2-type spliceosomal complex involved in mRNA splicing

name: Spout Family Methyltransferase 1
function: Omega-N monomethyltransferase that methylates arginine residues of proteins; biological role and cellular location are unknown

name: SuPpressor of Ty's
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits three-budded morphology, fails to asymmetrically localize ASH1 mRNA and Ash1p to daughter cells, and is sensitive to heat, oxidative stress, and chemicals that affect nucleic acid metabolism; in large-scale studies, the null mutant has enlarged cells, shows reduced competitive fitness and chromosome instability, has a longer replicative lifespan but a shorter chronological lifespan, and is sensitive to heat, desiccation, acid pH, and anoxia; diploid homozygous null mutant requires myo-inositol and shows increased respiratory growth rate; null mutant displays altered sensitivity to a variety of chemicals
function: Core RNA polymerase I and II-binding transcription factor that is a subunit of the DSIF complex; binds transcription elongation factor complexes and rDNA; involved in regulating DNA transcription, rRNA processing, transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair, and transcription elongation from RNA polymerase I and II promoters; also involved in 7-methylguanosine mRNA capping and mRNA splicing via the spliceosome, as well as chromatin organization and chromosome segregation; colocalizes with nuclear telomeric heterochromatin, mating-type region heterochromatin, rDNA heterochromatin, and the kinetochore

name: SuPpressor of Ty's
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause abnormal accumulation and mislocalization of mRNA reporters, and increased chromosome loss; reduction of function leads to slow growth and reduced competitive fitness
function: Core RNA polymerase I and II-binding transcription factor that is a subunit of the DSIF complex; binds DNA, rDNA, and transcription elongation factor complexes; involved in regulating transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair, rRNA processing, and transcription elongation from RNA polymerase I and II promoters; also involved in intracellular mRNA localization, mRNA splicing via the spliceosome, and 7-methylguanosine mRNA capping; localizes to the nucleus and colocalizes with rDNA heterochromatin

name: ERGosterol biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant requires ergosterol for growth at elevated temperature; repression causes abnormal lipid particle morphology and accumulation of elevated levels of squalene; mutants are sensitive to terbinafine; in large-scale studies, repression confers increased competitive fitness and abnormal mitochondrial morphology
function: Squalene epoxidase; catalyzes the oxidation of squalene to 2,3-oxidosqualene in the presence of NADPH and oxygen, a step in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to both the endoplasmic reticulum and lipid particles

name: SRPK1-like Kinase in Yeast
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased growth rate, small cell size, displays decreased competitive fitness on various growth media and increased hyperosmotic stress resistance; homozygous diploid null mutant has an increased duration of the G1 phase of the cell cycle, increased toxin resistance, increased oxidative stress resistance, elevated innate thermotolerance and increased resistance to several chemicals including: actinomycin D, benomyl, caffeine, MMS and calcofluor white; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Protein serine/threonine kinase involved in protein phosphorylation; contributes to mRNA splice site selection, positive regulation of protein import into nucleus, and cellular ion and cation homeostasis; localizes to cytoplasm

name: Replication In Mitochondria
function: Single-stranded DNA binding protein; stimulates use of RNA primers by mitochondrial DNA polymerase; localizes to mitochondrial nucleoids

name: Yeast Suicide Protein
function: Sterol binding protein with a role in intracellular sterol transport; localizes to mitochondria and the cortical ER

name: Niemann Pick type C homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to nystatin, but resistant to acetic acid or hydrogen chloride
function: Protein involved with the directed movement of sterols within cells; localizes to vacuolar lumen

name: Yeast Protein Kinase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays slow growth, reduced endocytosis, and sensitivity to caffeine, HU, and myriocin; overexpression confers abnormal budding, abnormal vacuolar morphology, and increased resistance to myriocin; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness in several different media, sensitivity to heat and ionic stress, increased biofilm formation and K28 killer toxin resistance, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Protein kinase active on serine and threonine residues; participates in cellular sphingolipid homeostasis by negatively regulating sphingolipid biosynthesis; also involved in glycerophospholipid metabolism and response to mating pheromone

name: RADiation sensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to DNA damaging agents, DNA synthesis and topoisomerase inhibitors; null mutant is sensitive to X-rays, gamma rays and UV radiation; null displays increased chromosome instability, increased loss-of-heterozygosity in diploids, an increased mutation rate and elevated Ty element transposition; null mutant is temperature sensitive, and has both a decreased growth rate and competitive fitness on rich and synthetic media; null has decreased starvation resistance, increased thermotolerance, and decreased replicative lifespan that is increased relative to wt by caloric restriction; null contains large-budded cells with nuclear extensions at the nuclear envelope, adjacent to the nucleolus; homozygous null has a sporulation defect, and the heterozygous null is haploinsufficient
function: Recombinase enzyme with DNA-dependent ATPase activity; involved in DNA recombination, telomere maintenance, meiotic recombination and double strand break repair; localizes to nuclear chromosomes

name: Multicopy suppressor of SNF1 mutation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants are sensitive to citric acid, oxidative stress, heat, dessication, cannot utilize proline as a nitrogen source; overexpression slows growth, increases sensitivity to TOR inhibitor rapamycin
function: Sequence-specific DNA-binding transcription factor involved in the regulation of transcription in response to a wide variety of stresses; shuttles between nucleus and cytoplasm

name: SECretory
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations cause decreased invertase secretion, abnormal ER and nuclear morphology and increased glycogen accumulation
function: Subunit of COPII vesicle coat, nuclear pore outer ring, and Seh-1 associated complex; involved in COPII-coated vesicle budding, nuclear pore distribution, and ubiquitin-dependent ERAD pathway; contributes to regulation of GTPase activity, TORC1 signaling, and DNA-templated transcription

name: Accumulation of DYads
phenotype: Non-essential gene; homozygous null mutation in diploid leads to aberrant spores and reduced sporulation efficiency; overexpression causes slow growth, abnormal budding and defects in actin cytoskeleton

name: Ubiquitin Fusion Degradation protein
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutant exhibits G1 cell cycle delay at restrictive temperature; ts and missense mutant show abnormal accumulation and distribution of substrate proteins, and sensitivity to hygromycin B and paromomycin; missense mutant is sensitive to Huntingtin protein while overexpression confers resistance; in large-scale studies, repression causes increased DNA damage and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; ts allele confers sensitivity to benomyl
function: Nuclear ubiquitin-binding subunit of the Hrd1p and Doa10p ubiquitin ligase complexes, both of which recognize and ubiquitinate proteins with misfolded domains during ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD); also a subunit of the RQC complex which forms a stable complex with 60S ribosomal subunits containing stalled polypeptides and triggers their degradation (ribosomal quality control), and the VCP-NPL4-UFD1 AAA ATPase complex which is required for the efficient dislocation of ER-lumenal degradation substrates and their subsequent proteolysis by the proteasome

name: required for biogenesis of the Large ribosomal subunit and initiation of Translation in Oxygen
ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to osmotic stress, desiccation, and to several chemicals including streptomycin, tunicamycin, MMS, edelfosine
function: Subunit of the stator stalk of the F0 coupling factor of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: METhionine requiring
function: Alpha subunit of sulfite reductase complex which participates in sulfate assimilation and converts sulfite into sulfide

name: Vacuolar Membrane Atpase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays several ionomic phenotypes, decreased resistance to metals, oxidative and hyperosmotic stress; null mutant also has vacuolar and mitochondrial morphology defects, and reduced numbers of lipid droplets; homozygous diploid null mutant is temperature sensitive, has a respiratory growth defect, reduced utilization of various carbons sources, decreased acid and alkaline pH resistance and auxotrophic for inositol; overexpression increased replicstive lifespan and delays the onset of aging-associated alterations in mitochondrial morphology
function: Hydrogen ion transporting ATPase involved in vacuolar acidification and cellular protein metabolism; localizes to the vacuole membrane; subunit of the V1 domain of the vacuolar proton-transporting V-type ATPase

name: Vacuolar pH
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased processing of vacuolar hydrolases, decreased metal resistance, and decreased resistance to acid pH; null mutant also has decreased competitive fitness during growth in various carbons sources; homozygous diploid null mutant has a sporulation defect, is auxotrophic for inositol, thermosensitive, and has decreased starvation resistance; homozygous diploid null mutant accumulates glycogen and displays an increase in chronological lifespan
function: Hydrogen ion transporting ATPase involved in polyphosphate metabolism, protein complex assembly and vacuolar acidification; localizes to vacuolar membranes

name: Chaperonin Containing TCP-1
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to sensitivity to translation-interfering drugs, such as azetidine-2-carboxylic acid, cycloheximide, hygromycin
function: Subunit of the chaperonin-containing T-complex (TriC) that mediates protein folding

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows abnormalities in mitochondrial genome maintenance and sensitivity to oxidative stress
function: Subunit of the stator stalk of the F0 coupling factor of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; also has a role in oligomerization of the complex; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Vacuolar Membrane Atpase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to metal ions such as Zn2+, Cd2+, and Ni2+, and accumulates reduced levels of inorganic polyphosphates; null mutant exhibits shortened chronological and replicative lifespan, is sensitive to oxidative stress, and shows earlier onset of mitochondrial dysfunction during aging; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness in several different media; homozygous null mutant diploid is sensitive to desiccation and freeze-thaw stress, requires myo-inositol, and fails to respire; null mutant is sensitive to a variety of chemicals
function: Hydrogen ion transporting ATPase involved in vacuolar acidification, calcium homeostasis, and the assembly of proteasome storage granules; localizes to vacuolar membranes and vacuole-mitochondrion membrane contact sites; subunit of the V1 domain of the vacuolar proton-transporting V-type ATPase

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; in systematic studies null mutants become resistant to edelfosine, MMS, idarubicin, benomyl, caffeine, but sensitive to UV, cordycepin
function: Subunit of the stator stalk of the F0 coupling factor of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Translocase of the Inner Mitochondrial membrane
ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations) and increased number of peroxisomes
function: Subunit of the F0 coupling factor of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in reduced respiratory growth on non-fermantable carbon sources and abnormal mitochondrial morphology
function: Subunit of the F0 coupling factor of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; also has a role in formation of dimers and oligomers of the complex; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon source and shows no sporulation, abnormal mitochondrial morphology and increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations); in systematic studies null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness; in Sigma1278b null mutant shows greatly decreased filamentous growth
function: Subunit of the F0 coupling factor of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to utilize nonfermentable carbon sources such as glycerol and ethanol, and is sensitive to oxidative stress

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to utilize nonfermentable carbon sources such as glycerol and ethanol, and is sensitive to oxidative stress
function: Subunit of mitochondrial respiratory chain complex IV; contributes to cytochrome-c oxidase activity; involved in aerobic respiration and cytochrome c-to-oxygen transport

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits petite phenotype (inability to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources and slow growth on fermentable carbon sources) indicating respiratory defficiency
function: Zinc-binding subunit of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex IV; involved in aerobic respiration and the transfer of electrons from cytochrome c to oxygen during oxidative phosphorylation

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased respiratory growth with non-fermentable carbon sources; overexpression leads to reduced growth under standard conditions with fermentable carbon source (glucose)
function: Subunit of the F0 coupling factor of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; also has a role in formation of dimers and oligomers of the complex; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Topoisomerase I Damage Affected
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm and mating projection tip in large scale studies

name: Chromosome Transmission Fidelity
phenotype: Non-essenctial gene; null mutant shows severe chromosome instability and high frequency of chromosome loss; in systematic studies mutants have lower competitive fitness and display slow growth, abnormal bud morphology and increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including MMS, hydroxyurea, camptothecin, rapamycin
function: Subunit of a heptameric complex related to replication factor C (Ctf18 RFC-like complex) that loads the DNA polymerase processivity factor proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) onto DNA to initiate DNA replication; required for mitotic sister chromatid cohesion; localized to the nucleus

name: Bypass UAS Requirement
phenotype: Essential gene; viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions; conditional alleles confer sensitivity to cold; reduced function increases competitive fitness
function: Promoter-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor that binds TATA-binding protein and participates in preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of the heterodimeric negative cofactor 2 complex

name: Negative Cofactor B
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to slow growth; overexpression causes cell cycle arrest or delay at G1 phase
function: Transcription corepressor subunit of negative cofactor 2 complex; involved in assembly of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly and the negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II

name: GTp binding protein Resemblance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutants show defects in vacuolar delivery of reporter proteins, and are sensitive to temperatures, cell wall-affecting drugs, sirolimus (rapamycin); also show decreased telomere length and reduced competitive fitness
function: GTPase that is subunit of the Gtr1-Gtr2 GTPase complex and the EGO complex; involved in TOR1 localization to the vacuolar membrane, positive regulation of TORC1 signaling, negative regulation of autophagy during nitrogen starvation, chromatin silencing at telomeres, and transcription from RNA polymerase I and III promoters; also involved in phosphate ion transport; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, vacuole membrane, and late endosome membrane

name: Processing Of Precursor RNAs
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression causes decreased vegetative growth rate; diploid heterozygous null mutant displays increased resistance to heat shock during stationary phase, but decreased resistance during exponential growth

name: Processing Of Precursor RNAs
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function lowers competitive fitness; heterozygous null mutation causes increased chromosome instability, sensitivity to azauracil and mycophenolic acid
function: RNA binding protein involved in ribosomal RNA (rRNA), transfer RNA (tRNA), intronic box C/D small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) processing; role in endonucleolytic cleavage-dependent decay of nuclear-transcribed messenger RNA (mRNA); localizes to ribonuclease MRP and nucleolar ribonuclease P complexes

name: NucleOlar Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to increased chromosome instability
function: RNA binding subunit of H/ACA snoRNP complex that contributes ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and small nuclear RNA (snRNA) pseudouridine synthesis; role in cleavage during rRNA processing

name: Chromatin Assembly Complex
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive and displays decreased competitive fitness in both fermentative and respiratory growth media; null mutant is UV sensitive, displays decreased telomeric silencing and an altered free amino acid profile; null mutants are resistant to treatment with benomyl and myriocin, and sensitive to MMS, hygromycin B, camptothecin and rapamycin; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: BREfeldin A sensitivity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is a myo-inositol auxotroph with a decreased growth rate and reduced competitive fitness on both fermentative and respiratory growth media, as well as in alkaline conditions; null mutant has a decreased ability to utilize the nitrogen source allantoin; null mutant displays a reduction in the methylation of histone H3K4; null mutant displays an elevated rate of plasmid loss; null mutant has short telomeres and an altered distribution of Rap1p within the nucleus; null mutant has increased flocculation and decreased resistance to dessication; heterozygous diploid null mutant is haploproficient
function: Component of the histone methyltransferase Set1C/COMPASS complex that is involved in histone H3-K4 methylation

name: DNA Polymerase B (II) subunit
function: Subunit of epsilon DNA polymerase complex that contributes to DNA polymerase activity; involved in leading strand elongation during DNA replication, nucleosome mobilization, and heterochromatin organization that contributes to chromatin silencing

name: POLymerase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations lead to cell cycle arrest, chromosome missegregation, increased mitotic recombination and mutation frequency, increased sensitivity to DNA stressors (hydroxyurea, MMS, UV)
function: DNA-directed DNA polymerase involved in DNA repair including base-excision, nucleotide-extension, postreplication and mismatch repair; role in removal of primer during DNA replication, leading and lagging strand elongation; localizes to nucleus, cytosol, delta DNA polymerase complex

name: ELongator Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays heat sensitivity and low rate of exponential growth, becomes sensitive to cell wall-affecting drugs, hydroxyurea, sodium; also shows resistance to K. lactis toxin zymocin
function: Histone acetyltransferase subunit of Elongator holoenzyme complex; involved in transfer RNA (tRNA) wobble uridine modification and regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II; localized to nucleus and cytoplasm

name: UBiquitin Activating
function: Subunit of a SUMO activating enzyme (E1); contributes to the formation of a high energy thioester bond with ubiquitin-like protein SUMO, the first step in protein sumoylation; localizes to the nucleus

name: Activation Of Smt3p
phenotype: Essential gene; repression leads to opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)
function: Subunit of a SUMO activating enzyme (E1); contributes to the formation of a high energy thioester bond with ubiquitin-like protein SUMO, the first step in protein sumoylation; localizes to the nucleus and relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia

name: Replication Factor C
function: Component of the DNA replication factor C complex that contributes to DNA clamp loader activity; involved in sister chromatid cohesion and leading strand elongation

name: Replication Factor C
function: Subunit of the DNA replication factor C complex that is contributes to DNA clamp loading; involved in DNA mismatch repair and leading DNA strand elongation

name: Replication Factor C
phenotype: Essential gene; heterozygous null mutation in diploid causes starvation sensitivity; reduction of function results in decreased competitive fitness
function: ATPase that contributes to DNA clamp loading; involved in leading strand elongation, mismatch repair, sister chromatid cohesion; localizes to nucleus, cytosol, is subunit of Rad17 RFC-like, Ctf18 RFC-like, Elg1 RFC-like and DNA replication factor C complexes

name: Replication Factor A
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant displays abnormal cellular morphology and increased mutation frequency

name: Replication Factor A
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant has decreased resistance to heat, UV, and DNA-damaging agents; abnormal cellular morphology, cell cycle progression, and shortened telomeres

name: Replication Factor A
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant has decreased resistance to heat, UV, and DNA-damaging agents; abnormal spindle morphology/positioning, cell cycle progression, chromosome segregation and budding
function: A DNA-binding protein involved in DNA replication, repair and recombination as well as maintenance of telomeres; localizes to condensed nuclear chromosome as well as telomeric regions of chromsomes

name: ELongator Protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to paraquat and MMS, but resistant to tunicamycin; also shows decreased thermotolerance, increased heat sensitivity, defects in endocytosis and biofilm formation; in competitive growth studies null mutant shows decreased fitness
function: Subunit of Elongator holoenzyme complex; contributes to transfer RNA (tRNA) binding and ATPase activity; involved in transfer RNA (tRNA) wobble uridine modification and regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II; localized to nucleus and cytoplasm

name: NUclear Pore
function: Component of the inner ring of the Nuclear Pore Complex (NPC), which is involved in nucleocytoplasmic transport and assembly of the NPC; also has roles in chromosome segregation, nucleosome positioning and chromatin silencing, tethering of telomeres to nuclear periphery, and the mitotic spindle assemble checkpoint; binds the RSC chromatin remodeling complex

name: Isocitrate DeHydrogenase
function: Subunit of the mitochondrial NAD(+)-dependent isocitrate dehydrogenase complex, which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to form 2-oxoglutarate; involved in glutamate biosynthesis and the tricarboxylic acid cycle; localizes to the mitochondrial matrix and nucleoid

name: Yeast homolog of the human leukemogenic protein AF9
N-terminal AcetylTransferase
