phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in protein N-terminal acetylation and shows increased heat sensitivity, decreased mating efficiency, reduced mitophagy and respiratory growth rate, lower survival in stationary phase, and decreased competitive fitness; overexpression causes increased chromosome instability
function: Protein alpha-N-acetyltransferase subunit of NatA complex involved in N-terminal protein amino acid acetylation; localizes to cytosolic ribosomes

name: ARrest Defective
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased pheromone sensitivity, reduced mating efficiency and sporulation, decreased respiratory growth; increased heat sensitivity and decreased innate thermotolerance; null mutation also decreases survival rate in stationary phase
function: Subunit of protein N-terminal acetyltransferase (NatA) complex; contributes to the transfer of acetyl groups to N-terminal Ser, Ala, Gly, or Thr residues of proteins; NatA complex colocolizes with cytosolic ribosomes

name: N-terminal AcetylTransferase
function: Subunit of acetyltransferase NatA complex involved in N-terminal protein acetylation; localizes in cytoplasm

name: Restores TBP Function
function: Non-DNA binding transcription factor; subunit of the CDc73/Paf1 transcription elongation complex; involved in regulation of transcription from RNA Pol I and II promoters, snoRNA 3'-end processing, regulation of histone H2B ubiquitination and H3 methylation and other cellular processes

name: Succinate DeHydrogenase
function: Subunit of the succinate dehydrogenase mitochondrial respiratory chain complex, and also of the TIM22 mitochondrial inner membrane protein insertion complex; required for cellular respiration

name: Transcription Factor B subunit 3
phenotype: Essential gene; tfb3-ts mutant displays sensitivity to caffeine at the permissive temperature and sensitivity to UV light at the semi-permissive temperature; in large-scale studies, repression confers increased chromosomal rearrangement and loss; diploid heterozygous null mutant has lowered innate thermotolerance and is haploinsufficient
function: Subunit of holo TFIIH and TFIIK complexes involved in core RNA polymerase binding transcription factor activity; contributes to phosphorylation of RNA polymerase II C-terminal domain, nucleotide-excision repair, and transcription by RNA polymerase II

name: Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function causes senstitvity to MMS and decreased competitive fitness
function: Protein-protein adaptor subunit of proteasome regulatory particle, base subcomplex; involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation and proteasome assembly; localizes to nucleus and proteasome storage granules

name: ANP and osmotic sensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive, has a decreased growth rate, decreased competitive fitness on various growth media and decreased ability to utilize various carbon sources; null mutant has abnormally round buds, large cell size, and abnormal lipid particle morphology; null mutant displays decreased resistance to desiccation and freeze thaw, a decreased ability to form biofilms, and reduced chronological lifespan; null mutant has increased chitin deposition, and increased accumulation of sterol esters, triglycerides and glycogen in early stationary phase cells; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

name: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to localize actin patches to growing buds, accumulates high amounts of chitin in cell walls, and shows defects in mitochondrial movement; in systematic studies null mutants produce abnormally shaped buds, show decreased endocytosis, increased sensitivity to heat and multiple chemicals, including caffeine, caspofungin, cycloheximide, DMSO, azole drugs, fenpropimorph, MMS

name: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant forms aberrant actin structures, grows very slowly, and produces spores with reduced viability; repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology, elevated excretion of inositol and confers resistance to myriocin

name: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant forms abnormal actin cytoskeleton structures, grows very slowly and produces spores with low viability

name: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant forms aberrant actin structures, grows very slowly, and produces spores with reduced viability

name: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant forms aberrant actin structures, grows very slowly, and produces spores with reduced viability; conditional (ts) mutant shows decreased endocytosis and increased sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress; repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology and confers resistance to myriocin

name: AStra Associated protein
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutation causes cell cycle arrest at G1 phase upon shift to non-permissive temperature and decreased levels of telomere length regulator Tel1p and TORC1 component Tor1p; reduction-of-function mutations confer rapamycin sensitivity and reduced telomere length
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the ASTRA complex in a large-scale study

name: CNo-Like
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to canavanine and thialysine; in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness and increased sensitivity to rapamycin

Essential gene; conditional mutants accumulate decreased amounts of 18S rRNA at elevated temperatures; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness; repression causes sensitivity to the TDP-43 human RNA-binding protein that forms inclusions and aggregates in ALS disease models; overexpression slows growth, induces chromosome instability; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Predicted dephospho-CoA kinase involved in coenzyme A biosynthetic process; component of the CoA-synthesizing complex

name: Coenzyme A Biosynthesis
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat sensitive
function: Pantetheine-phosphate adenylyltransferase subunit of the CoA-synthesizing complex that is involved in coenzyme A biosynthetic process

name: Set1c, WD40 repeat protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays defects in chromosome maintenance and dynamics, increased accumulation of glycogen and increased flocculation

name: Set1c, homolog of Dpy30 from C.elegans
Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause increased sensitivity to bleomycin and hydroxyurea, increased chromosome instability; heterozygous null mutant diploid shows increased sensitivity to toxins
function: Peripheral lid subunit of proteasome regulatory particle involved in protein deneddylation

name: Chaperonin Containing TCP-1
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutation causes hypersensitivity to benomyl; repression leads to abnormal mitochondrial morphology; haploinsufficient, has chromosome instability in heterozygous diploid; overexpression results in slow growth; overexpression in Sigma1278b causes increased invasive growth
function: Subunit of the chaperonin-containing T-complex (TriC) that mediates protein folding

name: Chaperonin Containing TCP-1
phenotype: Essential gene in systematic studies; haploinsufficient, showing slow growth and chromosome instability in heterozygous diploids; overexpression leads to slow growth rate
function: Subunit of the chaperonin-containing T-complex (TriC) that mediates protein folding

name: Chaperonin Containing TCP-1
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show increased sensitivity to benomyl and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; haploinsufficient, resulting in chromosome instability in heterozygous diploids
function: Subunit of the chaperonin-containing T-complex (TriC) that mediates protein folding

name: Chaperonin Containing TCP-1
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function causes decreased competitive fitness

name: Chaperonin Containing TCP-1
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to decreased competitive fitness and hypersensitivity to benomyl; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Subunit of the chaperonin-containing T-complex (TriC) that mediates protein folding

name: Chaperonin Containing TCP-1
phenotype: Essential gene in systematic studies; haploinsufficient, showing chromosome instability and lowered innate thermotolerance in heterozygous diploids; overexpression leads to slow growth rate; overexpression in Sigma1278b results in greatly decreased filamentous and invasive growth
function: Subunit of the chaperonin-containing T-complex (TriC) that mediates protein folding

name: mRNA DeCaPping
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes slow growth and heat sensitivity; scored as essential in strain S288C in a systematic study, likely due to slow growth

name: Synthetic Lethal with Mss4
function: A subunit of the EGO complex involved in signal transduction and microautophagy; localizes to the vacuole membrane and late endosome membrane

name: Exit from rapamycin-induced GrOwth arrest
function: Subunit of the EGO complex involved in TORC1 signaling and Slm4p localization to the vacuole; localizes to vacuolar membrane

name: Multicopy suppressor of Ers1 Hygromycin B sensitivity
function: Subunit of the EGO complex involved in microautophagy and vacuolar acidification; localizes to late endosome membrane

name: Has Symptoms of class E mutants; resembles Hbp, Stam and East
CLUstered mitochondria
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology but has no effect on respiratory competence
function: mRNA-binding translation initiation factor; subunit of eIF3 eukaryotic translation initiation factor 3 complex

name: SECretory
function: Subunit of the exocyst complex which mediates the targeting and tethering of post-Golgi secretory vesicles containing exocytic cargo to sites of exocytosis at the plasma membrane; interacts directly with the active, GTP-bound form of Cdc42 (Rho GTPase), and with PtdIns[4,5]P2; involved in exocyst assembly and ER inheritance; localizes to sites of polarized growth

name: Guided Entry of Tail-anchored proteins
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows defects in protein retention in ER and is sensitive to elevated temperatures, shows abnormal mitochondrial morphology, defective respiratory growth, sensitivity to antifungal drugs, cell wall-affecting drugs, oxidative stress; homozygous diploid is unable to sporulate

name: Guided Entry of Tail-anchored proteins
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows defects in protein retention in ER and is sensitive to elevated temperatures, shows abnormal mitochondrial morphology and defective respiratory growth, also shows sensitivity to antifungal drugs, cell wall-affecting drugs and oxidative stress
function: Anchoring protein involved in retrograde vesicle-mediated Golgi to endoplasmic reticulum (ER) transport and protein insertion to ER membrane; localizes with Golgi to ER Traffic (GET) complex and putatively integral to membrane

name: GPI Anchor Attachment
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants show decreased response to pheromone and increased heat sensitivity; depletion results in cytokinesis defects; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Subunit of GPI-anchor transamidase that has a role in the attachment of GPI anchor to protein; in high-throughput studies localizes to endoplasmic reticulum and is putatively integral to membrane

name: G Protein Alpha subunit
function: Heterotrimeric G-protein complex GTPase involved in pheromone signaling and desensitization during mating; plays a role in mating-related nuclear migration and karyogamy; also involved in inositol lipid-mediated signaling, regulation of MAPK export from the nucleus, and the heterotrimeric G-protein complex cycle; localizes to the plasma membrane and endosome

name: Heme Activator Protein
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor that activates gene expression in response to carbon catabolites; subunit of the CCAAT-binding transcription factor complex

name: Heme Activator Protein
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor that activates gene expression in response to carbon catabolites; subunit of the CCAAT-binding transcription factor complex

name: Histone AcetylTransferase
function: A H4 histone acetyltransferase; involved in chromatin assembly or disassembly as well as chromatin silencing at telomeres; subunit of histone acetyltransferase complex

name: POl1 Binding
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants display Spt(-) phenotype (Suppressor of Ty), delayed G1/S phase transition in the cell cycle and increased chromosome instability; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Subunit of the FACT, the primosome and the replication fork protection complexes; binds to histones and nucleosomes; involved in regulation of transcription, DNA replication and DNA replication independent nucleosome organization

name: SuPpressor of Ty
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations result in cell cycle arrest at G1 phase; depletion causes chromosome rearrangements and loss; haploinsufficient
function: Subunit of the FACT, the primosome and the replication fork protection complexes; binds to histones and nucleosomes; involved in regulation of transcription, DNA replication and DNA replication independent nucleosome organization

name: Presequence translocase-Associated Motor
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants grow slowly and accumulate unprocessed precursors of mitochondrial proteins
function: Protein binding protein involved in protein import into mitochondrial matrix; localizes to presequence translocase-associated import motor and mitochondrial inner membrane presequence translocase complex

name: Amino acid Sensor-Independent
phenotype: Non-essential gene; overexpression causes an increase in chromosome instability; in systematic studies null mutation confers resistance to selenomethionine and tirapazamine, increased competitive fitness, and shortened chronological lifespan

name: Amino acid Sensor-Independent
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants display cell wall defects, sensitivity to oxidative stress, decreased competitive fitness, shortened chronological lifespan, and inability to utilize glycerol as carbon source

name: Amino acid Sensor-Independent
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays abnormal distribution of a reporter protein within ER; in systematic studies null mutation confers decreased competitive fitness and shortened chronological lifespan; overexpression leads to slow growth

name: Lethal with Sec Thirteen
function: Subunit of a GTPase activating protein (GAP) complex for Rag family GTPase Gtr2p; contributes to the activation of Gtr2p in response to amino acid stimulation, resulting in the activation of the TORC1 complex; localizes to the cytoplasm and is recruited to the vacuolar membrane during amino acid starvation

name: Lethal with Sec Thirteen
function: Subunit of a GTPase activating protein (GAP) complex for Rag family GTPase Gtr2p; contributes to the activation of Gtr2p in response to amino acid stimulation, resulting in the activation of the TORC1 complex; localizes to the cytoplasm and is recruited to the vacuolar membrane during amino acid starvation

name: Vacuolar Protein Sorting
function: Endosomal retromer complex subunit involved in retrograde transport of membrane-bounded vesicles from endosomes back to the trans-Golgi network where they are recycled for further rounds of transport

name: Vacuolar Protein Sorting
function: Endosomal phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate binding retromer complex subunit involved in retrograde transport of membrane-bounded vesicles from endosomes back to the trans-Golgi network where they are recycled for further rounds of transport

name: Yeast Mitochondrial Ribosomal protein
function: Subunit of the mitochondrial alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, involved in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle

name: alpha-KetoGlutarate Dehydrogenase
function: Subunit of mitochondrial alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, involved in tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle

name: ATP synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations)
function: Subunit of the F0 coupling factor of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; also has a role in assembly of the complex and in formation of dimers and oligomers of the complex; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

name: Stability of MiniChromosomes
phenotype: Essential gene; mutation of acetylation site(s) results in defective cohesion establishment, increased sister chromatid separation and/or inviability; conditional mutant has increased colony sectoring due to chromosomal instability; conditional homozygous diploid mutant has decreased reciprocal recombination and is unable to sporulate; repressible mutant accumulates cells with a 1C DNA content indicative of a G1 arrest or delay
function: Subunit of the nuclear mitotic cohesin complex that has ATPase activity; involved in sister chromatid cohesion, synaptonemal complex assembly, ascospore formation and double-strand break repair

name: Yeast iNG1 homolog
phenotype: Non-essential gene; overexpression causes slow growth and abnormal silencing; null mutant has decreased fitness, abnormal vacuolar morphology, and is sensitive to 6-azauracil, protein synthesis inbibitor cycloheximide, and herbicide amitrole
function: Methylated histone-binding subunit of the NuA3 histone acetyltransferase complex involved in chromatin modification and positive regulation of RNA polymerase II transcription

name: OligoSaccharylTransferase
function: Subunit of oligosaccharyltransferase complex that has protein disulfide oxidoreductase activity; involved in protein N-linked glycosylation via asparagine

name: Regulation by OXygen
function: RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in open complex formation and preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of the core mediator complex

name: GALactose metabolism
function: Subunit of the core mediator complex; functions as a RNA pol II coactivator involved in preinitiation complex assembly; binds TFIIE and TFIIH-class transcription factors; recruits Gcn4p to the transcriptional machinery; involved in regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoters, positive regulation of invasive growth in response to glucose limitation, and regulation of core mediator complex localization to chromosomes in response to heat shock

name: Chromosome SEgregation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes slow growth, elevated rate of chromosome loss, increased cold and heat sensitivity; in systematic studies mutations confer decreased chronological lifespan, decreased endocytosis, increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including caffeine, rapamycin, MMS, hygromycin B, azoles
function: Subunit of the core mediator complex that acts as RNA polymerase II coactivator involved in preinitiation complex assembly; required for regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II; localized to the nucleus; also found in the cytoplasm under hypoxia

name: Suppressor of RNA polymerase B
function: Component of the mediator complex involved in the initiation of basal RNA polymerase II transcription

name: Suppressor of RNA polymerase B
function: Core RNA polymerase II binding transcription factor component of the mediator complex involved in the initiation of basal RNA polymerase II transcription; binds TATA-binding protein and is involved in assembly of the RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex; also involved in transcription termination

name: Suppressor of RNA polymerase B
function: RNA polymerase II transcription cofactor component of the mediator complex involved in the initiation of basal RNA polymerase II transcription

name: Suppressor of RNA polymerase B
function: RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in assembly of the preinitiation complex (PIC); involved in regulation of ribosomal protein gene transcription in response to nutrient levels and chemical stimuli; subunit of the mediator core complex

name: Suppressor of RNA polymerase B
function: Core RNA polymerase II recruiting transcription factor component of the mediator complex involved in the initiation of basal RNA polymerase II transcription

name: SuPpressor of Ty's
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, are delayed in G1 progression, have abnormal morphology of vacuoles and buds, shortened lifespan, decreased alcohol tolerance, large cell size, increased resistance to X-rays and nickel, decreased resistance to other metals and to heat, osmotic stress; overexpression enhances filamentous growth
function: Subunit of the SAGA and SLIK histone acetyltransferase complexes that regulate transcription through modification of chromatin

name: Sec Sixty-one Suppressor
phenotype: Essential gene; double mutation in the TMS domain causes slow growth and abnormal ER morphology; conditional mutant accumulates prepro-carboxypeptidase Y; in large-scale studies, mutant displays increased resistance to cycloheximide and rapamycin; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to ascomycin and resistant to heat shock
function: Structural molecule and protein transporter; subunit of Sec61 and Ssh1 translocon complexes; contributes to intracellular protein transmembrane transport; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies

name: Sucrose NonFermenting
function: SWI/SNF complex subunit involved in chromatin remodeling, nucleotide-excision repair, and positive regulation of transcription by RNA polymerases I and II; binds rDNA, involved in 27S pre-rRNA processing

name: Mitochondrial Genome Required
function: Subunit of the mitochondrial inner membrane presequence translocase complex, required for import of proteins into the mitochondrial matrix and inner membrane

name: Splicing ENdonuclease
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant displays defect in tRNA and rRNA processing, and delayed progression through the G1/S cell cycle phase transition

name: Upstream Activation Factor subunit
function: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase I transcription factor involved in chromatin organization and transcription of the nuclear large rRNA transcript; subunit of the RNA polymerase I upstream activating factor complex

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits petite phenotype (inability to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources and slow growth on fermentable carbon sources) indicating respiratory defficiency; null mutant also shows elevated copy number of mitochondrial genome

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows no respiratory defficiency under aerobic growth conditions; in systematic studies mutants exhibit increased biofilm formation and increased competitive fitness

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes partial respiratory growth defect on nonfermentable carbon sources and slow  growth on fermentable carbon sources (petite phenotype); in a systematic study null mutant shows decreased utilization of proline or glutamate as nitrogen source

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is deficient in respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and grows slowly on fermentable carbon sources (petite phenotype); in systematic studies mutants show decreased competitive fitness, shortened chronological lifespan and decreased rate of alternative nitrogen source utilization

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits petite phenotype (inability to grow on nonfermentable carbon sources and slow growth on fermentable carbon sources) indicating respiratory defficiency; overexpression also causes repiratory growth defect; in systematic studies mutations confer decreased competitive fitness and shorter chronological lifespan

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows lower respiratory growth rate and decreased competitive fitness

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and grows slowly on fermentable carbon sources (petite phenotype); null mutant shows decreased survival in stationary phase and decreased competitive fitness; in systematic studies mutant cells are among the smallest

name: Cytochrome c OXidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources and grows slowly on fermentable carbon sources (petite phenotype); null mutant also has abnormal lipid composition in mitochondria (lower amounts of phospatidylethanolamine and cardiolipin) and shows increased sensitivity to osmotic stress; in systematic studies mutants exhibit decreased competitive fitness and increased resistance to edelfosine and miconazole

name: PolYol Phosphatase
function: Glycerol-1-phosphatase; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in a large-scale study

name: UBiquitin-Conjugating
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant arrests at the G2/M phase transition at non-permissive temperature with large-budded cells containing a single nucleus, short spindle, and replicated DNA; conditional mutant has increased resistance to hyperosmotic stress, decreased resistance to amino acid starvation, and elevated levels of protein sumoylation at permissive temperature; conditional and repressible mutants display elevated levels of chromosome loss and gross chromosomal rearrangements
function: SUMO transferase involved in conjugation of the SUMO protein modifier to target proteins; required for spindle elongation during mitosis; localizes to condensed nuclear chromosomes

name: Weak Suppressor of Smt3
function: SUMO-ligase and SUMO-targeted metalloprotease activated by genotoxic stress; localizes as single spot per nucleus, with shift to vacuole upon DNA damage

name: SWi2/snf2-Related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is temperature sensitive, has reduced competitive fitness in various growth media and decreased resistance to zinc-limited growth; null mutant has an increase in chronological lifespan and increased innate thermotolerance while in stationary phase; null has decreased UV resistance; null mutant displays increased sensitivity to transcriptional elongation and microtubule inhibitors
function: Structural component of the Swr1 complex which is involved in chromatin remodeling.

name: T-snare affecting a Late Golgi compartment
VAcuolar Morphogenesis
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have shortened lifespan, are defective in vacuolar fragmentation, sensitive to UV, heat, desiccation, caffeine, ethanol, metals, oxidative stress, DNA damaging agents, antifungal fluconazole, and various antibiotics including TOR inhibitor rapamycin; homozygous diploid null mutants bud abnormally and cannot sporulate; overexpression enhances pseudohyphal growth in Sigma1278b, is lethal in S288C

name: Trehalose-6-Phosphate Synthase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased innate thermotolerance and higher sensitivity to desiccation; null mutation results in reduced accumulation of glycogen and trehalose, and lower ethanol tolerance; in systematic studies null mutant has small cell size, abnormally elongated buds, reduced respiratory growth rate; decreased biofilm formation and decreased competitive fitness
function: Alpha,alpha-trehalose phosphate synthase subunit of the alpha,alpha-trehalose-phosphate synthase complex; involved in biosynthesis of trehalose and cellular responses to oxidative stress, heat and dessication
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the plasma membrane in a large-scale study
Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the bud membrane and the mating projection membrane

name: PEroXisome related
function: Peroxisomal membrane protein anchor involved in the recycling of peroxisome targeting sequence receptors from cargo proteins back to the cytosol

name: carboxyPEPtidase Y-deficient
phenotype: Non-essential gene in strain S288C, essential in strain Sigma1278b; null mutant accumulates cytoplasmic vesicles and stacked endosomal intermediate structures, and fails to undergo autophagy; null and point mutants secrete carboxypeptidase Y instead of properly targeting it to the vacuole; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness under a variety of conditions, defective respiration and sporulation, and altered resistance to many chemicals

name: SuPpressor of Ty insertions
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants grow slowly, are sensitive to heat and DNA-damaging agent MMS; some mutations increase ethanol tolerance; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression interferes with silencing
function: DNA- and chromatin-binding general transcription factor that recruits other transcription factors in preinitiation complex assembly for RNA polymerases II and III, and rDNA transcription by RNA polymerase I; subunit of TFIID and TFIIIB; also involved in the chromosomal incorporation of transposable elements

name: Heat Shock Protein
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutations cause increased frequency of rho- mutations and decreased growth rate; overexpression in diploid Sigma1278b increases pseudohyphal invasive growth
function: ATPase that binds unfolded proteins; involved in protein folding and refolding, and in protein mitochondrial targeting; localizes to cytosol and mitochondria

name: Glycerate PhosphoMutase
function: Phosphoglycerate mutase; catalyses the conversion of 3-phosphoglycerate to 2-phosphoglycerate during glycolysis and the reverse reaction during gluconeogenesis; localizes to the mitochondrial intermembrane space and the cytosol
Subunit of transcription factor TFIIA complex involved in RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly

name: Transcription Factor G
function: Protein phosphatase activator subunit of transcription factor TFIIF involved in recruitment of RNA polymerase II and dephosphorylation of RNA polymerase II C-terminal domain; participates in assembly of RNA polymerase II transcription preinitiation complex, transcription start site selection, promoter clearance, and transcription elongation

name: THIamine metabolism
phenotype: Essential gene; thi80-L90P mutant is sensitive to acadesine; in a large-scale study, the diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
function: Thiamine pyrophosphokinase involved in the biosynthesis of thiamine diphosphate, a derivative of thiamine (vitamin B1) which acts as a coenzyme in a range of processes including the Krebs cycle; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: ER Oxidation or Endoplasmic Reticulum Oxidoreductin
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutation causes increased chromosome instability; overexpression leads to slow growth; in diploid Sigma1278b strain overexpression increases invasive pseudohyphal growth

name: Alkyl HydroPeroxide reductase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has increased competitive fitness in defined media; null mutant displays decreased resistance to oxidative stress; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient

name: Thiol-Specific Antioxidant
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is hypersensitive to oxidative stress and shows decreased anaerobic growth rate, increased mutation frequency, sensitivity to DNA-damaging factors, such as UV, 4-NQO and hydroxyurea
function: Thioredoxin peroxidase; involved in control of cellular redox homeostasis and response to oxidative stress; localized on polysomes and in cytoplasm

name: DNA Polymerase B (II) subunit
function: Subunit of epsilon DNA polymerase complex that contributes to DNA polymerase activity; involved in leading strand elongation during DNA replication and heterochromatin organization that contributes to chromatin silencing

name: POLymerase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays chromosome instability and sensitivity to cold, HU, and selenite; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness in a variety of media, is sensitive to heat and desiccation, has elongated telomeres, and shows altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Subunit of DNA polymerase delta; contributes to DNA polymerase activity and single-stranded DNA 3'-5' exodeoxyribonuclease activity; involved in RNA-dependent DNA biosynthesis, leading and lagging strand elongation, Okazaki initiator RNA removal, DNA amplification, and DNA repair

name: THreonyl tRNA Synthetase
phenotype: Essential gene; ths1-G145D mutation in editing domain causes slower growth; in large-scale studies, repression confers lower competitive fitness; overexpression causes slow growth and increased invasive growth; diploid heterozygous null mutant shows lower starvation resistance, sensitivity to human cationic antimicrobial peptides, and sensitivity to various chemicals
function: Threonyl-tRNA synthetase that performs threonyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling threonine to threonyl-tRNA; localizes to cytoplasm

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene in strain S288C, non-essential in strain W303; reduction of function decreases competitive fitness, confers sensitivity to nucleobase analog 5-fluorouracil; base-substitution mutants are resistant to cycloheximide, conditionally arrest in meiosis after spindle pole body duplication but before spindle formation for the first meiotic division; heat-sensitive mutants are petite and have an S phase delay at permissive temperature; repression also causes S phase delay; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient and subject to chromosome instability
function: Thymidylate synthase involved in biosynthesis of pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotides; localized to nuclear periphery

name: TOPoisomerase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has an increased respiratory but decreased fermentative growth rate; null mutant is resistant to topo I inhibitors but sensitive to topo II inhibitors and DNA damaging agents; null mutant displays decreased resistance to hyperosmotic stress, alkaline pH and metals, but increased resistance to oxidative stress and increased chronological lifespan; homozygous diploid null mutant has increased mitotic chromosome loss, increased loss of heterozygosity and a sporulation defect; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate and enhanced invasive growth
function: DNA topoisomerase type I that unwinds DNA; involved in chromatin organization, chromosome condensation, DNA replication, recombination and transcription; subunit of the replication fork protection complex which stabilizes stalled replication forks and is thought to be involved in coordinating leading- and lagging-strand synthesis and in replication checkpoint signaling

name: TOPoisomerase
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutant displays decreased viability at permissive temperature, and has decreased innate and acquired thermotolerance; reduction of function mutant has a G2/M phase delay and abnormally large buds with G2 spindles; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate
function: ATP-hydrolyzing DNA topoisomerase type II that unwinds DNA; involved in chromatin organization, DNA replication, and recombination; localizes to synaptonemal complexes and DNA replication termination sites

name: CyclophiliN Seven suppressor
phenotype: Essential gene; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness; at permissive temperatures, conditional mutants are sensitive to hygromycin and to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl; heterozygous diploid nulls show increased growth rate, increased chromosome instability
function: Co-chaperone that binds Hsp90 and Hsp70 proteins; involved in protein folding; localizes to cytoplasm

name: Independent of Mitochondrial Particle
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits slow growth, impaired endocytosis, large cell size, abnormally round buds, decreased life span, and is sensitive to osmotic stress, metals, heat, radiation, dessication, antimalarial chloroquine, various mutagens, and various antibiotics

name: LYSine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; reduction-of-function mutant displays increased innate thermotolerance; in large-scale studies null mutant has decreased competitive fitness and increased resistance to selenomethionine; overexpression in a diploid confers increased pseudohyphal growth
function: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor that regulates expression of genes involved in lysine biosynthesis

name: GlyColysis Regulation
phenotype: Non-essential gene, though systematic screen reported knockout as inviable; null mutants grow slowly, have large cells and increased respiration in the presence of repressing sugars; null also has decreased ethanol and acid tolerance, is sensitive to antifungals and DNA-damaging agent MMS
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved nucleosome organization, cellular response to glucose and the regulation of glycolysis, and the regulation of ribosomal protein gene expression; localizes to the nuclear envelope

name: GlyColysis Regulation
function: RNA polymerase II transcription factor that activates transcription of genes involved in glycolysis and ribosomal protein genes; also involved in regulation of antisense transcription at diverse loci
Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in positive regulation of transcription by nitrogen catabolites

name: ARsenicals Resistance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased fitness and accumulates arsenite, making it sensitive to various forms of arsenic; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding transcriptional activator of genes involved in response to arsenic; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Multiprotein Bridging Factor
function: RNA polymerase II transcription coactivator

name: WD repeat containing Transcriptional Modulator
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, show increased competitive fitness in minimal medium; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficent and sensitive to starvation
function: Transcription factor that regulates meiosis, chromatin silencing; inhibits ribonucleotide reductase by sequestering it in the nucleus

name: SUppressor of TFIIB mutations
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays heat sensitivity, increased mutation frequency, sensitivity to oxidative stress, abnormal phosphorylation of RNA polymerase II, and reduced tRNA levels; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and slow utilization of galactose; diploid homozygous null mutant shows increased chronological lifespan and sporulation efficiency, and decreased resistance to oxidative stress, UV, desiccation, and heat shock; null mutant shows altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Chromatin binding transcription coactivator; involved in positive regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II and III; contributes to assembly of RNA polymerase III transcriptional preinitiation complex, double-strand break repair via NHEJ, and hyperosmotic response; localizes to nucleus

name: GALactose metabolism
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased growth in the absence of galactose
function: Transcription factor-binding protein involved in galactose metabolism; negatively regulates Gal4p transcription factor activity; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: OverProducer of Inositol
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline) and petite-negative phenotype (loss of the mitochondrial genome is lethal); null mutant has reduced growth rate on nonfermentable carbon sources and decreased survival rate in stationary phase; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in a variety of media and altered resistance to various chemicals
function: Transcription corepressor and phosphatidic acid-binding protein; regulates transcription from RNA polymerase II promoters and negatively regulates phospholipid biosynthesis; involved in the endoplasmic reticulum unfolded protein response; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum and to various components of the nucleus

name: Muc1 expressed Independent of TEC1
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in a large scale study

name: Negative Regulator of Glucose-repressed genes
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, are auxotrophic for myo-inositol, sensitive to acids and cations, and are resistant to antifungal miconazole; overexpression slows growth, decreases resistance to TOR inhibitor rapamycin
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor that regulates transcription by RNA polymerase II; involved in regulation of pseudohyphal growth, biofilm formation, hyperosmotic response, and glucose sensing

name: Antisense of Depressing Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows quickly, is impaired in mating
function: DNA-binding transcription repressor involved in mating and pheromone-dependent signaling

name: Intrastrand cross (X)-link Recognition
function: Sequence-specific DNA-binding protein involved in negative regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoters and the cellular response to hypoxia; binds damaged DNA and is implicated in DNA repair; colocalizes with nuclear chromatin

name: ELongation Factor
function: Transcription elongation factor that binds RNA polymerase II

name: INOsitol requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows inositol auxotrophy and reduced synthesis of phosphatidylcholine; overexpression causes abnormal cellular morphology and cell cycle progression
function: Component of sequence specific DNA-binding heteromeric transcription factor Ino2/Ino4p that activates transcription of genes involved in phospholipid metabolism

name: Species-specific tRNA Processing
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding RNA polymerase II transcription activator; localizes to nucleus, cytoplasm, and plasma membrane

name: MiniChromosome Maintenance
phenotype: Essential gene; identified as an ARS-specific minichromosome maintenance mutant; reduction of function mutant is an alpha-specific sterile with decreased pheromone-induced cell cycle arrest, defective alpha factor production, decreased growth rate, reduced viability, elongated and misshapen buds, and abnormal spindle morphology; temperature sensitive mutant arrests in mitosis with large, elongated buds, a single, undivided nucleus in or near the neck, and has abnormal nuclear morphology and chromosomal instability; overexpression results in G1 arrest with some elongated and pear-shaped cells; heterozygous null is haploinsufficient
function: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription activator and repressor; involved in the regulation of mating type switching, mating-type specific transcription, arginine metabolism, and G2/M transition of mitotic cell cycle; binds DNA replication origins and is involved in DNA replication initiation; localizes to the cytosol, nucleus, and nuclear chromatin

name: Multicopy Inhibitor of GAL gene expression
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null muants exhibit accelerated growth, decreased replicative lifespan, increased chronological lifespan, decreased ethanol tolerance, have abnormal vacuolar morphology, are tolerant of zinc deficiency and of heat shock; overexpression shortens replicative lifespan, slows vegetative growth, enhances filamentous growth, interferes with cell cycle progression and budding
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor involved in the regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II in response to glucose and starvation

name: INOsitol requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows inositol auxotrophy and reduced synthesis of phosphatidylcholine
function: Component of sequence specific DNA-binding heteromeric transcription factor Ino2/Ino4p that activates transcription of genes involved in phospholipid metabolism

name: ARGinine requiring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal vauolar morphology, decreased fitness, cannot utilize ornithine as sole nitrogen source; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression slows growth
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in regulation of arginine and ornithine biosynthetic processes

name: KARyogamy
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows abnormal vacuolar morphology, decreased sporulation, karyogamy, and competitive fitness; reduced function results in abnormal microtubule morphology
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding transcription factor involved in response to mating pheromone

name: Transposon Enhancement Control
function: DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in the regulation of pseudohyphal growth, cell aging, and transposition; subunit of a complex with Ste12p and Dig1p that regulates transcription of mating genes

name: Cousin of Msn2
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation increases competitive fitness; in systematic studies null mutants exhibit decreased endocytosis and increased sensitivity to sphingolipid-depleting drug myriocin; homozygous diploid is auxotrophic for inositol

name: SWItching deficient
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutations prevent mating type switching; diploids show rough colony morphology; in systematic studies null mutation causes cell cycle delay at G1 phase, reduced competitive fitness and increased replicative lifespan
function: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in regulation of the mitotic cell cycle and of mating-type switching; localizes to both the nucleus and the cytoplasm

name: Regulatory Particle Non-ATPase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has lower abundance of proteasome subunits and shows decreased proteolytic processing of reporters; null mutant has slow growth, increased sensitivity to metals; in systematic studies null mutants display increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including camptothecin, hydroxyurea, MMS, bleomycin, caffeine, cycloheximide, azoles
function: Sequence specific DNA-binding, RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in positive regulation of proteasome-mediated ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism and transcription from RNA pol II promoters in response to stress; implicated in the regulation of DNA repair; localizes to the nucleus

name: Deficiency of Ribosomal Subunits
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to cell wall-damaging agents and metals, shows defects in protein transport through the Golgi
function: Subunit of the Cdc50p-Drs2p phospolipid flippase complex; maintains membrane lipid asymmetry in post-Golgi secretory vesicles; contributes to clathrin-coated vesicle formation, endocytosis, protein trafficking between the Golgi and endosomal system and the cellular response to mating pheromone; localizes to the trans-Golgi network

name: GIg Suppressor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased cell size and increased resistance to some antifungal drugs; overexpression results in slow growth and increased invasive growth in homozygoud diploid
function: Translation regulator involved in positive regulation of translation; binds mRNA and single-stranded DNA; localizes to the polysomes, cytoplasmic mRNA processing bodies, and cytoplasmic stress granules

name: Translation Elongation Factor
phenotype: Overexpression increases cell size, slows growth, and disturbs the actin cytoskeleton
function: GTP- and GDP-binding translation elongation factor; subunit of translation elongation factor 1 complex that binds GTP and aminoacyl-tRNAs, and catalyzes their codon-dependent placement at the A-site of the ribosome; involved in the transport of tRNAs from nucleus to cytoplasm; moonlighting role as an actin filament bundling; associates with the Rho1p GTPase in the vacuole membrane; also localizes to mitochondria and vacuolar membranes

name: Translation Elongation Factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants are sensitive to TOR inhibitor rapamycin; heterozygous diploid null mutants are heat-tolerant, have unstable chromosomes, and are sensitive to various antibiotics; overexpression increases cell size, interferes with the cell cycle, slows growth, and disturbs the actin cytoskeleton
function: GTP- and GDP-binding translation elongation factor; subunit of translation elongation factor 1 complex that binds GTP and aminoacyl-tRNAs, and catalyzes their codon-dependent placement at the A-site of the ribosome; involved in the transport of tRNAs from nucleus to cytoplasm; moonlighting role as an actin filament bundling; associates with the Rho1p GTPase in the vacuole membrane; also localizes to mitochondria and vacuolar membranes

name: Suppressor of SIT4 Deletion
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to heat and shows reduced acquired thermotolerance; null mutation causes sensitivity to Calcofluor White and SDS, indicative of cell wall defects; in systematic studies null mutation decreases anaerobic growth and competitive fitness and elevates sensitivity to multiple drugs, including azoles, camptothecin, fenpropimorph, rapamycin
function: mRNA binding protein that interacts with both the 5' and 3' untranslated regions and represses translation; regulates intracellular mRNA localization, translation, and organization of the cell wall; localizes to P-bodies, cytoplasmic stress granules, the cellular bud and bud neck

name: Elongation Factor Beta
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C and W303 but non-essential in Sigma1278b; heterozygous null mutant displays both decreased growth and decreased resistance to starvation; disruption of complex formation with EF1A results in the loss of actin cables and patches and an increase in cell size
function: Guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor subunit of the translation elongation factor 1 (EF-1) complex; functions in translation elongation and regulation of translational termination; moonlighting role as a regulator of the actin bundling activity of the EF-1 subunit eEF1A, encoded by TEF1 and TEF2

name: Yeast Elongation Factor
function: Translation elongation factor and ATPase involved in translational elongation and termination

name: HYPusine-containing protein
phenotype: Essential gene in S288C; conditional (ts) mutations lead to accumulation of polysomes, abnormal actin cytoskeleton and defects in shmoo formation; null mutant is reported as viable but slow growing in some strain backgrounds
function: Cytosolic ribosome-binding translation initiation factor; involved in positive regulation of cytoplasmic translational elongation through polyproline stretches

name: Translation Initiation Factor
function: Translation initiation factor involved in translational initiation, stress granule assembly, and ribosomal large subunit biogenesis; subunit of the eukaryotic translation initiation factor 4F complex; localizes to the cytoplasm, cytoplasmic stress granule, and cytoplasmic mRNA processing body

name: Translation Initiation Factor
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes accumulation of halfmer polysomes; ts mutations in the C-terminal domain confer sensitivity to amitrole at the restrictive temperature; mutation that blocks GDP-dissociation inhibitor (GDI) activity also confers amitrole sensitivity; in large-scale studies, the diploid heterozygous null mutant exhibits chromosome instability; repression confers reduced competitive fitness; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Translation initiation factor, GDP-dissociation inhibitor, and GTPase activator; involved in negative regulation of translational initiation, mature ribosome assembly, formation of cytoplasmic translation initiation complex; subunit of multi-eIF complex; localizes to cytosolic small ribosomal subunit and 48S preinitiation complex

name: Function Unknown Now
phenotype: Gene variously reported to be essential or to cause a severe slow growth phenotype when deleted; null mutant accumulates 20S pre-rRNA; heterozygous null mutant displays decreased fitness
function: Protein and ribosome binding GTPase involved in the formation of the cytoplasmic translation initiation complex and maturation of SSU-rRNA; involved in regulation of translational initiation; localizes to the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit and eukaryotic 48S pre initiation complex

name: SUPpressor
phenotype: Essential gene; heterozygous diploid null mutants are haploinsufficient; heat-sensitive alleles increase budding index; reduced function mutants have unstable chromosomes
function: Translation release factor involved in translational termination and mRNA decay; subunit of the translation release factor complex, also localizes to cytoplasmic stress granules

name: POre Membrane, 33 kDa
function: Integral nuclear envelope protein that associates with the nuclear pore; contributes to NPC distribution

name: Synthetic, High Osmolarity-sensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays reduced invasive and pseudohyphal growth, resistance to Calcofluor White, and sensitivity to zymolyase treatment; gain-of-function mutation confers increased filamentous growth; in large-scale studies, the null mutant requires inositol, exhibits increased competitive fitness, and is sensitive to various chemicals

name: Suppressor of lethality of Kex2 Gas1 double null mutant
Mitochondrial Magnesium Exporter
function: Magnesium ion exporter of the mitochondrial inner membrane; involved in magnesium ion homeostasis

name: KAryoPherin
function: Nuclear localization sequence-binding protein that imports various proteins to the nucleus; involved in mitotic exit; localizes to cellular bud neck, cellular bud tip, and cytosol

name: Hda One Similar
function: A histone deacetylase protein; plays a role in regulating transcription involved in G1/S transition of the mitotic cell cycle; localized to nucleus, cellular bud neck and prospore membrane

name: Heat Shock transcription Factor
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression arrests growth in haploid, increases invasive growth in diploid; reduced function decreases resistance to TOR innibitor rapamycin, increases competitive fitness; conditional alleles confer sensitivity to heat and to microtubule-destabilising agent benomyl; R206S substitution makes protein constitutively active
function: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor that induces expression of the Hsp90-family protein chaperones Hsc82p and Hsp82p during the cellular response to heat; also negatively regulates TOR signaling

name: Triose-Phosphate Isomerase
phenotype: Essential gene under standard conditions; null mutant is viable with inositol supplementation; null mutant displays sensitivity to lithium chloride and sodium valproate; in large-scale studies mutant displays a chromosome instability (CIN) phenotype, decreased endocytosis, and increased competitive fitness
function: Triose phosphoisomerase involved in the glycolytic breakdown of carbohydrates into pyruvate; localizes to mitochondria and plasma membranes

name: tRNase Z
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression confers increased accumulation of TBSV replicon RNA; in large-scale studies, overexpression causes slower growth; repression confers increased competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to niclosamide and to several human cationic antimicrobial peptides and is haploinsufficient
function: 3'-tRNA endoribonuclease involved in mitochondrial tRNA processing and endonucleolytic cleavage of the 3'-end of pre-tRNAs to produce mature tRNAs

name: tRNAHis Guanylyltransferase
phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes accumulation in the nucleus of aberrant tRNA-His that lacks the extra G residue at the 5' end and contains elevated 5-methylcytidine levels
function: tRNA guanylyltransferase that catalyzes the posttranscriptional addition of guanyl residues to the 5' ends of histidine tRNA molecules

name: tRNA Methyltransferase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; ts mutant displays chromosome instability at restrictive temperature; mutation of mitochondrial targeting sequence and human disease-analogous mutations confer reduced respiratory growth; in large-scale studies, null mutant scored as inviable likely due to slow growth; repression confers decreased competitive fitness, sensitivity to HU, resistance to myriocin, and Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); ts mutant is sensitive to K28 killer toxin at restrictive temperature; overexpression causes arrest or delay in G1 phase
function: tRNA methyltransferase that methylates guanine residues in both cytoplasmic and mitochondrial tRNAs; localized to both the cytoplasm and to mitochondria

name: DEpressed Growth rate
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has no pseudouridilation of some RNAs; in systematic studies mutants show abnormally elongated buds, abnormal levels of various free amino acids; increased sensitivity to some chemicals, including MMS, caffeine, Congo Red, rapamycin, and increased resistance to several other chemicals, including cycloheximide, camptothecin, fenpropimorph, fluconazole, tunicamycin, bleomycin

name: tRNA ThreonylCarbamoyladenosine Dehydratase
function: A tRNA threonylcarbamoyladenoside dehydratase involved in cyclic threonylcarbamoyladenosine biosynthesis; localized to the mitochondrial outer membrane

name: tRNA ThreonylCarbamoyladenosine Dehydratase
function: tRNA threonylcarbamoyladenosine dehydratase required for the formation of the modified nucleoside cyclic N(6)-threonylcarbamoyladenosine in tRNAs; localized to the mitochondrial outer membrane

name: TRyPtophan
function: Tryptophan synthase; catalyzes the final step in the biosynthesis of tryptophan; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

name: Cytochrome Oxidase Assembly factor
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced respiratory growth on nonfermentable carbon sources; in systematic studies null mutant is sensitive to MMS, tunicamycin and hydroxyurea, also shows reduced competitive fitness and decreased ability to utilize amino acids as nitrogen source

name: GLyCogen
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants show defects in actin cytoskeleton and endocytosis; reduction of function leads to increased cold and heat sensitivity
function: Type I protein phosphatase catalytic subunit; involved in regulation of cell shape during vegetative growth, glycogen and carbohydrate metabolic processes, regulation of cell cycle passage, and checkpoints during DNA replication, mitotic spindle assembly, and cell cycle; involed in rRNA processing, protein dephosphorylation targeting both and C-terminal domain of RNA polymerase II; found in nucleus, nucleolus, sites of cell division, and spindle pole body

name: Phosphatase type Two C
function: Protein serine/threonine phosphatase involved in the inactivation of MAPK activity involved in osmolarity sensing and associated with cell wall integrity; also implicated in pheromone-dependent signal transduction, mitochondrion inheritance, and tRNA splicing via endonucleolytic cleavage and ligation; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Yeast dnaJ
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits slow growth, decreased fitness and lifespan, abnormal colony shape and vacuolar morphology, increased sensitivity to heat, oxidative stress, metals, caffeine, cardivascular drug amiodarone, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase inhibitor wortmannin, Hsp90 inhibitor tanespimycin, TOR inhibitor rapamycin, antioxidant spermine, reducing agent L-1,4-dithiothreitol, microtubule-destabilising agent benomyl, protein synthesis inbibitor cycloheximide, herbicide amitrole, allergen glyoxal, and various alcohols, antibiotics, antifungals, and mutagens; homozygous diploid null mutant displays increased resistance to carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene, and is sensitive to zinc, sorbate, mycotoxin Trichothecin; overexpression confers resistance to TOR inhibitor rapamycin and causes increased invasive growth and prion loss
function: ATPase-activating protein chaperone involved in 'de novo' protein folding, refolding and catabolism; subunit of the TMD recognition ER membrane insertion complex; localizes to the cytoplasm near the nucleus

name: Ras and a-factor Converting Enzyme
function: Metalloendopeptidase involved in the CAAX-box dependent processing and maturation of the mating pheromone a-factor and Ras proteins; integral membrane protein localized to the endoplasmic reticulum

name: SIt4 Suppressor
phenotype: Essential gene; null mutant is viable but slow growing under anaerobic conditions; repressible mutant displays elevated [SWI+] and [PSI1+] prion curing, and overexpression increases [SWI+] curing but decreases prion loss during heat stress; repressible mutant has an Opi- phenotype, overproducing and excreting inositol in the absence of inositol and choline
function: Protein that binds to misfolded proteins; involved in protein folding, misfolded protein transport, and ubiquitin-dependent catabolism of misfolded proteins by nucleus-associated proteasomes; also involved in translational initiation and tRNA import into the nucleus during starvation response; localizes to the nucleus and the cytosolic small ribosomal subunit

name: Blocked Early in Transport
phenotype: Essential gene; overexpression causes abnormalities in cell cycle progression and cell morphology; repression leads to increased chromosome loss and rearrangements

name: AuTophaGy related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in autophagy, pexophagy and the CVT pathway; null mutant displays decreases resistance to zinc treatment, and desiccation; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness on various media
function: Phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate binding protein involved in autophagic vacuole assembly, peroxisome degradation, protein  localization to pre-autophagosomal structure and cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway; localizes to the mitochondrion, pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS), trans-golgi network

name: MYOsin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased mating efficiency and decreased competitive fitness; mutation in globular tails causes defects in localization of ASH1 mRNA

name: MYOsin
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations result in cell cycle arrest and blocked cytokinesis; depletion leads to opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); overexpression causes cell cycle arrest
function: Microfilament motor protein that binds actin and calmodulin; involved in vesicle transport along actin filaments, vesicle docking involved in exocytosis, and membrane addition at the site of cytokinesis; also involved in organelle inheritance, apical bud growth, polarized cell growth, and establishment of mitotic spindle orientation; subunit of the Myo2p-Vac17p-Vac8p transport complex; localizes to sites of polarized growth, incipient bud sites, vesicles, filamentous actin, and actin filament bundles

name: Net1 Associated Nuclear protein
function: U3 snoRNA-binding protein involved in RNA polymerase I transcription regulation and small rRNA processing; nucleolar localization to heterochromatic rDNA, the small-subunit processome, and the t-UTP subcomplex of the 90S pre ribosome; required for the subsequent assembly of the rest of the preribosome

name: Ubiquitin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to various stressors including: elevated temperature, zinc deficiency, nitrogen starvation, oxidative stress, desiccation, canavanine addition and hydrostatic pressure; null mutant displays decreased spore germination, decreased survival in stationary phase, decreased competitive fitness in various growth media, and is an inositol auxotroph; homozygous diploid null mutant has a sporulation defect
function: Ubiquitin, a protein tag covalently attached to proteins to target them to selective degradation by ubiquitin-dependent proteasome-mediated protein catabolic system; localized to the cytoplasm

name: UBiquitin Activating
function: Ubiquitin activating enzyme (E1); catalyzes the formation of a high energy thioester bond with ubiquitin, the first step in protein ubiquitination; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Coupling of Ubiquitin conjugation to ER degradation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes elevated accumulation of reporter proteins and confers increased sensitivity to nickel ions; in systematic studies mutants show increased sensitivity to camptothecin MMS, amitrole and Congo Red
function: Ubiquitin-protein transferase activator involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic processes associated with the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and localization of proteins to the ER membrane; an integral component of the ER membrane and associated with both Doa10p and Hrd1p ubiquitin ligase complexes

name: Coupling of Ubiquitin conjugation to ER degradation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates ubiquitin conjugates and shows increased resistance to sirolimus (rapamycin), decreased resistance to bleomycin, camptothecin and tunicamycin
function: Ubiquitin binding protein involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic processes; acts as an Atg8p-ubiquitin adaptor during nitrogen starvation response

name: UBiquitin-Conjugating
phenotype: Essential gene in the S288C genetic background, non-essential in the Sigma1278b background; phosphomimetic mutations at putative MAPK sites confer lower innate thermotolerance or sensitivity to DTT, while phosphoresistant mutation causes higher thermotolerance; in a large-scale study, repression confers resistance to myriocin
function: Ubiquitin conjugating enzyme that catalyzes the transfer of ubiquitin from one protein to another; involved in endoplasmic reticulum-associated protein catabolism and vesicle organization; subunit of the proteasome complex which catalyzes protein degradation

name: Cell Division Cycle
phenotype: Essential gene; conditional mutants display a cell cycle arrest in the G1 phase with both elongated and and multi-budded cells; mutation results in increased accumulation and decreased ubiquitination of specific proteins, decreased resistance to metals and DNA damaging agents, decreased telomere length, decreased innate thermotolerance and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; overexpression results in decreased growth rate, increased resistance to metals, increased ubiquitination of specific proteins, and abnormal vacuolar morphology
function: Ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme (E2); subunit of Skp1/Cul1/F-box (SCF) complexes involved in proteasomal-dependent protein catabolism; capable of autoubiquitination; required for both the G1/S and G2/M phase transitions of the mitotic cell cycle

name: RADiation sensitive
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits chromosome instability and genome rearrangements; mutants display sensitivity to UV, gamma rays, and X-rays; lifespan extension of the null mutant under caloric restriction is reduced relative to that of wild type; in large-scale studies the null mutant requires myo-inositol, displays increased cell size and reduced chronological lifespan, and displays altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Ubiquitin-protein transferase; subunit of the Rad6-Rad18 and Mub1-Rad6-Ubr2 ubiquitin ligase complexes; involved in ubiquitination of histones and substrates of the N-end rule pathway, and in ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism; involved in the mitotic G1 DNA damage checkpoint, meiotic DNA double-strand break formation, and telomere maintenance via recombination; involved in double-strand break repair via homologous recombination and in both error-free and error-prone translesion synthesis; role in the stress-induced homeostatically regulated protein degradation (SHRED) pathway; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm, and colocalizes with the proteasome complex and with nuclear chromatin

name: UBiquitin-Conjugating
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have increased lifespan, are defective in vacuolar fragmentation and peroxisomal transport, sensitive to UV and various antibiotics, resistant to DNA-damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate, microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl, DNA topoisomerase inhibitor camptothecin, and chelator bleomycin
function: Proteasome complex subunit that binds and transfers ubiquitin; involved in protein polyubiquitination and cellular response to heat as well as ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism via mutlivesicular body sorting pathway

name: Methyl MethaneSulfonate sensitivity
function: A subunit of the ubiquitin conjugating enzyme complex with ubiquitin-protein transferase activity; involved in protein polyubquitination, postreplication repair, and free ubiquitin chain polymerization; localized to both nucleus and cytoplasm

name: Yeast Ubiquitin Hydrolase
function: A ubiquitin-specific protease that is thiol-dependent; involved in ubiquitin homeostatis and localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Alcohol Sensitive Ring/PHD finger
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced ubiquitination of RNA polymerase II largest subunit and is highly sensitive to SDS or butanol in some strain backgrounds, but not in S222C or W303; overexpression causes elongated buds and delays in cell cycle progression through G2/M phase transition

name: AuTophaGy related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased mitophagy and no autophagy or pexophagy; null mutant is sensitive to nitrogen starvation and unable to sporulate
function: Subunit of the Atg12-Atg5-Atg16 complex; serves as a protein tag; involved in conjugating Atg8p to phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), autophagic vacuole assembly and cytoplasmic-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway

name: Ubiquitin Related Modifier
function: Ubiquitin-like protein tag; covalently attached to substrates in the process of protein urmylation; involved in thiolation of uridine in the wobble position of tRNAs; role in invasive growth due to glucose limitation and in budding; localizes to the cytosol and to the nucleus in high-throughput studies

name: Homologous to UBiquitin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has slow growth, abnormal budding pattern, defective shmoo formation and decreased mating
function: Protein tag that contributes to messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing, cell morphogenesis involved in conjugation with cellular fusion, and protein modification; localizes to mating projection

name: Suppressor of Mif Two
phenotype: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutations cause increased telomere length, sensitivity to MMS, and decreased competitive fitness; overexpression results in slow growth, increased glucose consumption and ethanol accumulation
function: Ubiquitin-like (SUMO) protein modifier; conjugated to target proteins via isopeptide bond formation between the carboxyl terminus and the epsilon-amino group of a lysine residue of the target protein during the process of sumoylation; localizes to the nucleus, the septin ring, and condensed chromosomes during meiosis I

name: BREfeldin A sensitivity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive, displays decreased competitive fitness on numerous growth media, has a decreased ability to utilize glucose as carbon source, and allantoin or glutamine as nitrogen sources; null mutant has abnormal nuclear morphology, filamentous and invasive growth defects, decreased stress resistance and a decreased ability to undergo ribophagy in response to nitrogen starvation; null mutant displays decreased resistance to cell wall stressors, antifungal agents and DNA synthesis inhibitors; null mutant has numerous alterations in the amino acid metabolome; null mutant has an increased replicative lifespan; null mutant has a defect in retrograde transport from the Golgi to the ER; homozygous diploid null displays a defect in meiosis with reduced gene conversion, and abnormal sporulation with an altered DL:LL dityrosine ratio; heterozygous diploid null mutant is haploproficient
function: Protein involved in deubiquitination, ribophagy, regulation of ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport and retrograde vesicle-mediated transport (golgi to ER); localizes to the cytoplasmic mRNA processing body and has been shown to bind to mRNA in large scale studies

name: Defective in Mitotic Arrest
function: Ubiquitin protein ligase involved in septin ring assembly and organization, and the mitotic spindle orientation checkpoint

name: Defective in Mitotic Arrest
function: Ubiquitin protein ligase involved in septin ring assembly and organization, and the mitotic spindle orientation checkpoint

name: HMG-coA Reductase Degradation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant retains misfolded proteins in the ER, accumulates sterol esters and triglycerides, shows sensitivity to cadmium, lovastatin, cycloheximide; overexpression causes slow vegetative growth and increased invasive growth

name: Modulator Of Transcription
function: Ubiquitin-protein ligase subunit of the CCR4-NOT complex, involved in protein ubiquitination and catabolism, mRNA decapping, and regulation of transcription elongation

name: Ribosomal Protein of the Large subunit
function: Fusion protein that is cleaved to yield ubiquitin and a subunit of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in assembly and nuclear export of the ribosomal large subunit, and translation

name: Ribosomal Protein of the Large subunit
function: Fusion protein that is cleaved to yield ubiquitin and a subunit of the cytosolic large ribosomal subunit; involved in assembly and nuclear export of the ribosomal large subunit, and translation

name: UBiquitin-specific Protease
function: A ubiquitin-specific protease that is dependent on thiol; localizes to both the cytoplasm and endoplasmic reticulum

name: UBiquitin-specific Protease
function: A thiol-dependent ubiquitin-specific protease; involved in ubiquitin homeostasis and protein catabolism; localizes to the cytoplasm and nucleus

name: UBiquitin-specific Protease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits shorter replicative lifespan, increased intracellular glutathione, increased [Psi+] prion formation, sensitivity to canavanine, and excretion of hydrogen sulfide; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows altered competitive fitness in several different media, altered sensitivity to a variety of chemicals, increased resistance to hyperosmotic stress and K28 killer toxin, and increased sensitivity to acid pH, heat, and oxidative stress; diploid homozygous null mutant requires myo-inositol, accumulates less glycogen and excretes glutathione, and is sensitive to cadmium and lithium ions, tricothecin, and desiccation
function: Thiol-dependent deubiquitinase involved in negative regulation of proteasome-mediated protein catabolism; subunit of the regulatory particle that recognizes and unfolds ubiquitinated proteins, and translocates them to the proteasome core complex

name: UBiquitin-specific processing Protease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have increased lifespans, are resistant to various antibiotics, and sensitive to DNA topoisomerase inhibitor camptothecin, heat, gamma rays, and desiccation; homozygous diploid null mutants are defective in sporulation

name: Regulator Of Quality control
function: Regulator of the Ubr1p E3 ubiquitin ligase involved in the stress-induced homeostatically regulated protein degradation (SHRED) pathway; involved in the cellular dessication response; localizes to the cytoplasm

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays heat sensitivity and under-glycosylation of secreted proteins; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and desiccation resistance, rounded cell shape, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
function: Dolichyl-phosphate beta-glucosyltransferase involved in synthesis of oligosaccharide chains for N-linked protein glycosylation; integral to endoplasmic reticulum membrane

name: UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutant exhibits chromosome instability at high temperature; ugp1-S11A mutant is sensitivt to killer toxin, Calcofluor White, Congo Red, and caffeine; repression confers lower glycogen accumulation and sensitivity to NaCl and SDS; in large-scale studies, repression causes lower competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to heat shock and concanamycin A
function: Uridylyltransferase activity involved in biosynthesis of beta-glucans, glycogen, and trehalose; localizes to cytoplasm and plasma membrane

name: AuTophaGy related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is not defective in autophagy, pexophagy or the CVT pathway; null mutant has fragmented vacuoles; null mutant displays decreased resistance to zinc treatment; overexpression results in an increased proportion of large budded cells arrested or delayed in G2 or M phase with a divided nucleus; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient
function: Sterol 3-beta-glucosyltransferase involved in ascospore-type prospore membrane assembly; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large scale study

name: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
phenotype: Essential gene; activation blocks sporulation, increases resistance to GlcNAc phosphotransferase (GPT) inhibitor tunicamycin; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, decreased resistance to tunicamycin; repression causes loss of the mitochondrial genome, and decreased accumulation of dolichol-linked oligosaccharides; heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to tunicamycin
function: Dolichyl-P-dependent N-acetylglucosamine-1-P transferase (GPT) that catalyzes transfer of N-acetylglucosamine from UDP-N-acetylglucosamine to dolichyl phosphate; involved in synthesis of oligosaccharide precursor for N-linked protein glycosylation; localized in endoplasmic reticulum
Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the vacuole in a large-scale study

name: Uracil DNA N-Glycosylase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to gamma rays in the presence of aminopterin and sulfanilamide; point mutant displays elevated mutation frequency; null mutant is resistant to 5-fluorouracil; null and point mutants are sensitive to 4-aminofolic acid and sulfanilamide, sodium nitrite, and sodium hydrogensulfite; null mutant shows greater replicative lifespan extension in response to caloric restriction than does wild type; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows increased competitive fitness in some media and decreased fitness in others; null mutant has elevated sensitivity to heat and osmotic stress
