function: Uracil-DNA glycosylase involved in restoring DNA after damage; localizes to nucleus and mitochondria

name: 5-FluoroURidine resistant
function: Uracil phosphoribosyltransferase involved in salvaging pyrimidine-containing compounds

name: Degradation of Allantoin
phenotype: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased competitive fitness in minimal media; mutants are also sensitive to paromomycin and neomycin but resistant to selenomethionine and tirapazamine
function: A ureidoglycolate lyase that is involved in the breakdown of allantoin; localized to membranes

name: URAcil requiring
phenotype: Essential gene; ts mutant is resistant to 5-fluorouracil at the permissive temperature and rapidly becomes depleted of UTP and CTP upon incubation at restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, conditional mutant displays gross chromosomal rearrangements and heterozygous null mutant diploid displays chromosome instability
function: Bifunctional adenylate and uridylate kinase involved in 'de novo' pyrimidine biosynthesis; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm

name: AminoPEptidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased resistance to heat and decreased competitive fitness in both minimal medium and rich medium with 6% ethanol; null mutant displays decreased telomere length and decreased chronological lifespan; null mutant has decreased resistance to several different toxins; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient in turbidostat grown cells in FPM medium but is haploproficient in conditions that mimic phase I of batch fermentation; overexpression results in decreased vegetative growth

name: AminoPeptidase
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased accumulation of cadmium, but decreased accumulation of zinc and calcium ions; null mutant has both a decreased mutation frequency and decreased protein carbonylation in the presence of cadmium; null mutant displays decreased resistance to zinc sulfate; null mutant has an inability to concentrate Atg11p to the pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS); null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus; haploinsufficiency results in chromosome instability (CIN) in the heterozygous diploid null
function: A metalloaminopeptidase involved in vaculolar protein catabolysis; localized to the vacuole

name: Amino acid Vacuolar Transport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased vacuolar accumulation of aspartate and glutamate under nitrogen starvation
function: L-aspartate, L-glutamate (amino acid) transmembrane transporter involved in vacuolar transport; localizes to the vacuole membrane

name: carboxyPEPtidase Y-deficient
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits increased apoptosis and necrosis during chronological aging, while overexpression reduces cell death; null mutant is defective in autophagy and mitophagy, and sensitive to a variety of chemicals; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays reductions in competitive fitness, chronological lifespan, desiccation resistance, and innate thermotolerance
function: Vacuolar peptidase with a role in autophagy

name: Plasma Membrane Calcium
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation leads to increased sensitivity to calcium and aluminum; overexpression increases resistance to calcium and aluminum; overexpression in Sigma1278b enhances invasive pseudohyphal growth
function: Calcium-transporting ATPase involved in calcium ion and transmembrane transport; role in cellular calcium ion homeostasis; localizes to vacuolar membrane

name: CarboxyPeptidase yscS
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has lower growth rate, shows leucine auxotrophy and elevated sensitivity to nicotinamide; in systematic studies mutants exhibit increased heat sensitivity, reduced filamentous growth and decreased competitive fitness; overexpression causes slow growth
function: Carboxypeptidase, proteolytic enzyme that hydrolyzes terminal or penultimate peptide bonds at carboxy termini of peptides; localized to the vacuolar lumen

name: PRoteinase C
function: Serine-type carboxypeptidase involved in vacuolar protein catabolism, vacuolar zymogen activation, phytochelatin biosynthesis and macroautophagy; localizes to the vacuole lumen

name: Yeast Vacuolar Conductance
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants have moderate defect in vacuolar fragmentation, increased competitive fitness in glycerol; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Voltage-gated ion channel of the vacuolar membrane; active for calcium, potassium, and sodium; involved in cellular cation homeostasis

name: Cross-Complements Ca(2+) phenotype of csg1
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants are enhanced in respiratory growth, show decreased competitive fitness, are impaired in the use of arginine as a nitrogen source, sensitive to the carcinogen toxaphene and to metals, resistant to antifungal miconazole and to copper; overexpression is lethal in strain S288C, induces G1 phase arrest or delay in strain W303

name: Vacuolar Transporter Chaperone
function: Calmodulin- and inositol hexakisphosphate-binding polyphosphate kinase involved in vacuolar transport, vacuole fusion, microautophagy and polyphosphate biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum and vacuolar membranes

name: Niemann-pick type C Related
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates phytosphingosine and phytosphingosine 1-phosphate, and shows abnormal mitochondria, respiratory defficiency and sensitivity to oxidative stress; a gain-of-function mutation causes resistance to aureobasidin A and edelfosine, and increased sensitivity to sphingosine
function: Sphingolipid transporter involved in sphingolipid metabolism; localizes to vacuole membrane, to endoplasmic reticulum and likely integral to membrane in high-throughput studies
Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the vauole membrane in a large-scale study
Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the vacuolar membrane

name: Zinc Resistance Conferring
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants are sensitive to zinc, sodium selenide, and cobalt, show decreased competitive fitness; null mutants are resistant to TOR inhibitor rapamycin; overexpression confers sensitivity to TOR inhibitor rapamycin; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploproficient
function: Vacuolar zinc ion transmembrane transporter involved in cellular zinc homeostasis

name: Zinc-Regulated Transporter
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutants are sensitive to antimicrobial ciclopirox olamine, resistant to cadmium, oxidative stress, GlcNAc phosphotransferase (GPT) inhibitor tunicamycin and reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol, and show increased competitive fitness as haploids in minimal medium but decreased competive fitness as diploids under batch fermentation conditions; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
function: Zinc ion transmembrane transporter of the vacuolar membrane involved in zinc ion transport and cellular zinc ion homeostasis

name: PRoteinase B
phenotype: Non-essential gene; mutations affect the cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (Cvt) pathway; in large-scale studies, competetive fitness of the null mutant varies in different media; null mutant has an endocytosis defect and decreased sporulation efficiency; overexpression in strain Sigma1278b confers increased invasive growth
function: Serine-type endopeptidase involved in vacuolar protein catabolism, response to starvation, and spore formation; localizes to the vacuole lumen

name: carboxyPEPtidase Y-deficient
function: Endosomal retromer complex subunit involved in retrograde transport of membrane-bounded vesicles from endosomes back to the trans-Golgi network where they are recycled for further rounds of transport

name: Yeast PARK9
function: Vacuolar membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; also localizes to contact sites between mitochondria and vacuolar membranes

name: AuTophaGy
function: Serine-type carboxypeptidase involved in vacuolar zymogen activation, phytochelatin biosynthesis and macroautophagy; localizes to the vacuole lumen

name: Amino acid Vacuolar Transport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows elevated accumulation of proline in vacuole; overexpression causes slow growth and increased invasive growth in Sigma1278b
function: L-glutamine, L-isoleucine, L-tyrosine (amino acid) transmembrane transporter involved in vacuolar transport; localizes to the vacuole membrane

name: Amino acid Vacuolar Transport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to rapamycin; in systematic studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to oxidative stress
function: L-glutamine, L-isoleucine, L-tyrosine (amino acid) transmembrane transporter involved in vacuolar transport; localizes to the vacuole membrane

name: Amino acid Vacuolar Transport
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced accumulation of proline in vacuole; in systematic studies null mutants have shorter replicative lifespan, decreased anaerobic growth and biofilm formation; overexpression leads to abnormal vacuolar and mitochondrial morphology
function: L-glutamine, L-isoleucine, L-tyrosine (amino acid) transmembrane transporter involved in vacuolar transport; localizes to the vacuole membrane

name: CObalt Toxicity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to cobalt and exhibits reduced competitive fitness; overexpression causes slow growth

name: VeRProlin
function: Actin-binding protein that activates actin nucleation mediated by the Arp2/Arp3 complex; required for bipolar bud site selection, endocytosis and cytokinesis; localizes to the incipient bud site, the bud neck and to actin cortical patches

phenotype: Essential gene; repression causes accumulation of ER membranes and cytoplasmic vesicles, and secretion of unprocessed proteins; in large-scale studies, heterozygous null mutant diploid displays haploinsufficiency and sensitivity to human antimicrobial peptides
function: SNAP receptor that acts as a membrane marker and interacts selectively with one or more SNAREs on another membrane to mediate membrane fusion; has palmitoyltransferase activity; involved in non-autophagic vacuole fusion, and ER-to-Golgi and intra-Golgi vesicle mediated transport

name: Suppressor of the Null allele of CAP
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in endocytosis; overexpression causes defects in actin cytoskeleton and abnormalities in cell cycle progression through G2
function: SNAP receptor involved in Golgi to plasma membrane transport, vesicle fusion, endocytosis, and exocytosis; localizes to the endosome, trans-Golgi network, transport vesicle membrane, plasma membrane, and bud neck

name: Suppressor of the Null allele of CAP
BaTteN disease
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows defects in protein sorting, reduced uptake of arginine, elevated formation of [URE3] prion, decreased sensitivity to Calcofluor White, and increased sensitivity to ethanol; overexpression causes abnormal budding and sensitivity to acidic conditions
function: SNARE and chaperone binding protein; involved in amino acid, retrograde (endosome to Golgi), and intracellular protein transport, and also nuclear protein localization, regulation of pH, and protein folding; localized to the cytosol, nucleus,  perinuclear region of the cytoplasm, the nuclear periphery, and late endosome

name: Bet One Suppressor
phenotype: Essential gene; repressible mutant accumulates 40-60 nm secretory vesicles, and an extensive network of endoplasmic reticulum; repressible mutant accumulates a precursor form of carboxypeptidase Y and pro-alpha factor, indicative of a failure in transport of proteins to the Golgi apparatus; reduction of function mutant has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium and displays increased sensitivity to MMS and hydroxyurea; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate

name: AQuaporin from Yeast
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and sensitivity to oxidative stress and copper ions; overexpression causes slow growth

name: Degradation Of Alpha
function: Ubiquitin-binding protein; involved in ubiquitin homeostasis, proteasome-mediated ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism, mitochondria-associated ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism, ribophagy, and NHEJ during stationary phase; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

name: WW domain containing protein interacting with Metacaspase
function: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus in a classical study and to the cytoplasm, nucleus and mitochrondrion in large-scale studies

name: BREfeldin A sensitivity
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness on minimal medium and a decreased ability to utilize urea as a nitrogen source; null mutant accumulates the cell wall proteins Ccw14p and Cwp1p in the culture supernatant and excretes elevated levels of (1 -> 6)-beta-D-glucan; null mutant exhibits an endocytosis defect; null mutant exhibits fragmented vacuoles; homozygous diploid null mutant has abnormal sporulation with an altered DL:LL dityrosine ratio
function: Protein involved in endocytosis; predicted to be an integral membrane protein

name: Arginine methyltransferase-Interacting RING finger protein
phenotype: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes sensitivity to 5-fluorouracil, elongated bud morphology, decreased resistance to caffeine and camptothecin, and increased resistance to fluconazole, fenpropimorph and tunicamycin
